HEADLINE: A Historic Transition in Mexico

 BODY:
The inauguration of Vicente Fox Quesada as Mexico's president today is a hopeful watershed in that nation's history, one that may someday be deemed as significant as Mexico's early-19th-century independence from Spain or its early-20th-century revolution. It marks the first peaceful transfer of power from one political faction to another in modern Mexican history, as the Institutional Revolutionary Party ends its 71-year rule. Mexico's 100 million people have reclaimed their government, and now look to Mr. Fox to consolidate their democracy.
Strengthening the rule of law is the most daunting challenge and greatest opportunity facing the Fox administration. Mexican society mobilized to end the PRI's capricious rule partly out of a sense of disgust with widespread corruption. Mr. Fox has appointed a tough law-and-order team and has pledged to respect the judiciary's independence. The new government will audit public accounts and may appoint a transparency commission to investigate possible crimes committed by past administrations. Such moves will send a proper message of zero tolerance for corruption. 
 But Mr. Fox's ability to inquire into past wrongdoing will be complicated by his need to work with opposition parties to advance his agenda. The PRI still commands a plurality of votes in both chambers of Congress, and governs two-thirds of the states. Mr. Fox will have to woo centrist PRI legislators to support his free-market economic initiatives and leftist Revolutionary Democratic Party legislators to support democratic reforms the PRI may oppose. He will have to resist the social conservatism of his own National Action Party's base, lest he help bring about an alliance between the PRI and the P.R.D.
The imperial presidency was the omnipotent epicenter of PRI rule for decades. Mr. Fox will have to accept the downsizing of his own office to strengthen Mexico's democracy. He must bolster the independence of the long-subservient legislative and judicial branches of government.
The departing president, Ernesto Zedillo, deserves credit for enabling the democratic transition and for handing his successor a strong economy. He wisely granted the central bank autonomy and secured robust but disciplined growth in the last few years. The economy is expected to grow 7 percent in 2000, the rate Mr. Fox believes necessary over the long term to raise the living standards of most Mexicans. But he will be hard pressed to match that rate next year. Inefficient state-owned electricity and oil monopolies are in dire need of billions of dollars of investment to expand capacity, but privatizing them is not politically feasible.
The Fox administration will present special challenges for Washington, long accustomed to dealing with an authoritarian government in Mexico. Mexican public opinion is likely to loom larger in the bilateral relationship. Mr. Fox will press his vision of a more ambitious North American Free Trade Agreement along the lines of the European Union. He is also likely to be a forceful advocate for democracy and human rights in the hemisphere. If President Fox's six-year term lives up to its promise, Mexicans can start taking pride in their nation's present reality, instead of having to seek comfort in its future potential. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Looking at Higher Education, Report Finds Vast Differences Among States

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
High school students in Nebraska are twice as likely as those in Alabama to take mathematics courses designed to prepare them for college. Young people in North Dakota are twice as likely as those in Nevada to enroll in college. And because of differences in state tuition, Vermont families must spend nearly 40 percent of their annual income to send a child to a state university, compared with families in Utah, where the figure is 17 percent.
A new survey packed with statistics like these has found wide disparities in how states prepare students for a college education, help them pay for tuition and ensure that they graduate. 
 "Your chances of getting to college are enormously dependent on where you live," said Patrick M. Callan, president of the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, the nonpartisan organization that released its findings yesterday.
The report pointed to factors that have long been known to cause discrepancies in access and achievement, including students' race, family income and a state's relative wealth.
In Illinois, for example, which sends a higher percentage of its students to college than most other states, 41 percent of white residents 18 to 24 are enrolled in college, as compared with 24 percent of young people of all other races, the survey said.
The report also suggested that the federal government has done little to ensure that a student in one part of the country receives the same educational opportunities as a student in another.
Indeed, the report made clear, the states that bear the primary responsibility for higher education, with 78 percent of American college students enrolled in state colleges and universities. And those states differ greatly in how much they help their residents pay for higher education.
"While higher education is so good for so many people, an awful lot of people aren't getting to it," said James B. Hunt Jr., the departing governor of North Carolina and the chairman of the organization that released the survey yesterday.
"My own state," said Mr. Hunt, who is completing his fourth term, "gets a very poor grade on college participation."
The survey found that only 34 percent of North Carolina high school freshmen went on to apply to college after four years, one of the lowest rankings in the country. That compares with New York and Connecticut, where the figure is 44 percent, and New Jersey, where it is 54 percent, the best in the nation.
"I'm not really certain why," Mr. Hunt said of the disparity. "I think it has a lot to do with the fact that we have been historically poor, we have a high number of minority citizens who have not been given good opportunities, and I don't think a lot of our people have valued higher education."
Still, those students who do attend colleges in North Carolina, both public and private, are more likely than those in many other states to graduate, with 56 percent completing a bachelor's degree in five years, the survey said.
Drawing on figures from throughout the 1990's, the survey found that the highest percentage of students in any state who take at least one college-preparatory mathematics course was in Nebraska (61 percent), while the lowest was in Alabama (27 percent).
A spokesman for the Alabama Department of Education, Tom Salter, disputed Alabama's ranking, saying, "it may have been true 10 years ago, but it's not true now."
Mr. Salter said that beginning with the class that graduated from high school last spring, all Alabama students must take geometry to graduate, a subject that is considered upper level, or college preparatory, by the authors of the survey. Mr. Salter acknowledged, however, that Alabama spent less per student in kindergarten through 12th grade than almost any other state.
The survey found that the state with the highest percentage of residents who graduate from high school was North Dakota, with 95 percent.
Gaylynn Becker, the assistant director of approval and accreditation for the North Dakota Department of Public Instruction, attributed the state's success to many factors, most notably "the expectation of parents here that you will graduate from high school and you will go on to college."
Moreover, Mr. Becker said, the percentage of students in the state who have at least one parent who graduated from college is among the highest in the country. He also cited the sparseness of the state's population -- at about 600,000, among the smallest in the nation -- and the relatively high number of public and private colleges that serves it, at least 10.
Evaluating how well states make it possible for students to afford college, the survey gave its highest grade to Utah, where 17 percent of a family's annual income is required, on average, to pay for tuition at a public university. That compares with Vermont, where the average portion of family income required to pay the average tuition at a state university or college was 39 percent. The figures do not include financial aid.
In explaining those differences, Joni Finney, the vice president of the organization that produced the survey, cited the relatively low average tuition at four-year state universities in Utah -- $2,100 -- and the relatively high average cost in Vermont, $6,479.
Ms. Finney also said that far more students in Utah than in Vermont attend public colleges, as opposed to private colleges, allowing the Utah to achieve economies of scale that drive down the cost of tuition.

HEADLINE: Is It the 2000 Bug? Year of the Dragon? It's a Baby Boomlet

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Having a baby at NYU Downtown Hospital? Take a good pillow; you may be stuck laboring in the hallway. Delivering at Lenox Hill Hospital this month and hoping for a private room? Keep dreaming.
Birthrates have soared at many hospitals in the New York region in the last year, especially in recent months. From New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, where deliveries are up 15 percent over last year, to Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, where births climbed 9 percent, to New York University Medical Center, where deliveries are calculated to jump 17.5 percent by year's end. 
 And many hospitals, even those where birthrates were relatively flat for most of the year, report that October and November were especially busy. Why did so many people get pregnant last January and February? A collective celebration of David Letterman's successful open heart surgery? Inability to get to work because of a broken pipeline at Pennsylvania Station? Perhaps it was a millennium thing.
"I guess everyone was just happy that the world didn't blow up," said Michael Hinck, a spokesman for Flushing Hospital Medical Center in Queens. Delivery volume there rose only modestly this year until October -- which was off the map. The 191 babies born that month totaled 15 percent higher than in October 1999.
Other hospitals report similar October gains. Lenox Hill Hospital, on the Upper East Side, saw a 25 percent rise in births over last October, when the rate was flat over 1998.
Perhaps Mr. Hinck's explanation is striking in its lack of scientific basis. But many directors of obstetrics departments are also puzzled. While most of them like to think 2000 has been a good year because women have suddenly discovered their hospitals are wonderful, a few other explanations seem more plausible.
The Year of the Dragon, which began in February, is considered a great one in which to have a baby among many Chinese and Korean immigrants. Centers that serve a large Chinese population have gained from such lunar luck.
And while the October boomlet certainly suggests millennial madness, Dr. Michael Divon, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at Lenox Hill, posits that more people with money who would have left the city in other eras are now sticking around and having children. "It's the economy, stupid," Dr. Divon said.
A week ago, the waiting list for a private room was 20 people long, he said, while normally there are 6 people on the list. Women are not yet laboring in the hallways at that hospital, which can happen when too many women show up at once. "We are O.K. for now," Dr. Divon said. "But an increase from now will require more resources."
In 1999, there were 123,739 live births in New York City, a tiny decrease over 1998; no 2000 data is available yet from the city's Department of Health to verify if a true yearlong boom took over the city.
It is not quite clear whether the apparent mini-boom has extended to the suburbs; some hospitals in New Jersey, Connecticut and Long Island say yes, others no. Nationally, the picture is equally murky, since the National Center for Health Statistics does not have any 2000 data yet.
At Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles, for instance, the number of births rose 7 percent this year so far over the same period in 1999. At Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, the biggest birthing center in the Midwest, the rate rose only 4 percent, and executives there say they believe that is high for Chicago.
Dr. Iffath Hoskins, chairwoman of obstetrics and gynecology at NYU Downtown Hospital, could not care less about what is going on -- or not going on -- in the Midwest. All she can say is that there have been plenty of nights in the last year during which she ran to check on a woman in one room who was in labor, zipped off to deliver a baby in the next room, then checked on patient No. 1 again on her way to a Caesarean section.
Dr. Hoskins traces her hospital's boom directly to the Year of the Dragon, celebrated by many of her Chinese patients, who make up about 65 percent of obstetric clients. "Our Chinese patients tell us they planned it this way," she said.
(There is some evidence of a dragon effect in Hong Kong, where 38,134 babies were born between this January and September, up from 37,270 in the same period in 1999. But then again, in 1998, the Year of the Tiger, there were 39,043 births in that period. So who knows?)
NYU Downtown Hospital has had to add 10 postpartum beds in the last year to keep up with the frenzy. "We are happy with these kind of logistical problems," Dr. Hoskins said. Her staff at times disagrees. August was their busiest month -- they had 272 deliveries in a space intended for about 150 -- and they had to call in extra nurses, parking attendants, lactation consultants, housekeeping and neonatal security guards.
One night they had 14 deliveries. "It was horrible," she said. "I was the only one working with a smile. Moms are supposed to get a candlelight supper the day after they deliver. They ran out of china, and I suspect they ran out of the good shrimp and wine. I really have to believe that some of the patients got a sandwich and were told to be happy."
So what does it all mean? Who knows. But hospital executives love the volume. While delivering babies is not a terribly profitable business, the maternity ward is considered an excellent place to recruit patients.
"We are grateful for the increase in volume and hope that it continues," said Dr. Gary Eglinton, the chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens in Flushing, where births have increased 12 percent so far this year.

HEADLINE: Preferences Law Voided

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The California Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a lower court decision that overturned a San Jose ordinance requiring government contractors to solicit bids from companies owned by women and members of minorities.
The court said the ordinance was unconstitutional because it violated the state's Proposition 209. 
 That initiative, approved by voters in 1996, amended California's Constitution to prohibit preferences for women and minorities in state and local contracting, employment and education.
San Jose's ordinance requires city construction contractors, on contracts exceeding $50,000, to contact at least four companies owned by women or members of minorities, negotiate with them and accept their bids or state legitimate reasons for rejection.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stock Sell-Off Accelerates And Broadens

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Selling on Wall Street moved into high gear yesterday as investors received another dose of technology earnings disappointments and were left wondering how much more the American economy and corporate earnings will slow.
Hardest hit was the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index, which fell as much as 6.8 percent before cutting its losses to 4 percent. The index, which plunged 22.9 percent in November, finished its worst month since the crash in October 1987. The index is down 48.5 percent from its record reached in March, its second-worst decline from a high ever. And it is at its lowest level since Aug. 12, 1999, wiping out all of the 97 percent rally to its March high. 
 But the sell-off, which had been contained recently to the Nasdaq and the technology sector, also spread to other sectors that will suffer with slower economic growth.
"The collateral damage from the tech implosion has taken down many nontech areas as well," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
But the damage was not as great as it might have been. By late afternoon, investors apparently saw a lot of bargains, both in technology and other hard-hit stocks, and the three main gauges managed to pare their losses.
The Nasdaq tumbled as low as 2,523, reaching a milestone of sorts, down 50 percent from its March record. The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 3.2 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped as much as 3.5 percent before bargain hunters trimmed the losses for both gauges back to 2 percent.
But the declines in the Dow and S.& P. 500 showed how the selling has extended to economically sensitive stocks like International Paper, Dow Chemical, Union Carbide, Sears, Roebuck and Gap. Gap and Limited, two big specialty retailers, announced disappointing November sales on Wednesday. Gap's sales were down 1 percent, while the Limited's sales were up just 3 percent. Gap fell 88 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $24.94, while Limited fell 94 cents, or 4.6 percent, to $19.44.
Even with the late afternoon rally, the stock market's main gauges, as they begin the last month of the year, are heading toward their worst annual returns in more than 20 years. In other words, the stock market could give millions of investors the worst news they have ever heard.
"The concerns about the economy have reached such a level that we are reducing equity exposure," said Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "We have shifted out of a rotational market in which we were running out of tech and into other areas.
"What remains to be seen," he added, "is how weak does earnings growth get? Does it go to zero? How weak does the economy get?"
Like many of the recent Nasdaq sell-offs, this one was touched off by more bad news as companies disclosed the effect a slowing American economy is having on their sales and earnings. Gateway, the nation's second-largest direct seller of computers behind Dell Computer, reported after the close of the market on Wednesday that its Thanksgiving weekend sales came in 30 percent below those in the same period a year earlier. The company said it would probably miss current earnings and revenue forecasts by a wide margin, and its shares fell $10.50, or 35.6 percent, to $19.
The Altera Corporation, a manufacturer of programmable computer chips used in cellular phones, said late Wednesday that its first-quarter sales next year would rise less than 5 percent. Its stock dropped $2, or 7.7 percent, to $23.94.
The continued decline in stocks is going to heighten the focus on Federal Reserve policy makers, who will meet on Dec. 19 to consider the direction of interest rates. At their November meeting, they indicated that no rate cut was in the offing soon. A repeat of such a hard line at the December meeting would probably heighten fears of a recession and send stocks lower.
One recent signal of investor concern comes in the flows of money in and out of domestic stock mutual funds. According to AMG Data Services, which tracks these flows, investors took $7.3 billion out of stock mutual funds investing in domestic and foreign stocks in the four weeks ended Wednesday. But in just the last week, there was a net inflow of $1.5 billion, showing that some investors were seeking to take advantage of bargains.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman, Sachs who has become identified with the bull market of the 1990's, released an optimistic comment before the stock market opened.
"Indications that cash is building in portfolios, and that valuations are the most appealing they have been all year, support the forecast of rising stock prices," she said in a note to clients.
And while agreeing that the announcements from technology companies have been especially negative recently, she said that Goldman analysts were not as worried. "They do not see evidence of particularly weak conditions," she wrote. "Indeed, demand appears to be solid in several categories, including enterprise hardware and software, and across several markets, including those in Europe and Asia."
At the end of the day, the Nasdaq was down 109.00 points, to 2,597.93. The S.& P. 500 fell 26.96 points, to 1,314.95. The Dow dropped 214.62 points, to 10,414.49. Trading volume was near a record level on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1.498 billion shares trading hands. The record of 1.512 billion was set on April 4.
For the year, the Dow is down 9.4 percent, which, if the year were over, would be its worst year since 1977, when it fell 17.3 percent. (It dropped 9.2 percent in 1981.) The S.& P. 500 is off 10.5 percent for the year, also possibly its worst performance since 1977, when it dropped 11.5 percent. The Nasdaq, which is down 32.6 percent for this year, is heading for its worst year ever. It plunged 35.1 percent in 1974.
The sell-off in stocks sent many investors to the bond market for safety, pushing interest rates to their lowest levels since the spring of 1999.
In the Treasury market, the yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.47 percent, from 5.52 percent on Wednesday, as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 12/32, to 102 3/32. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 5.61 percent, from 5.64 percent.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
LENDING PROGRAM EXPANDS

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
Four community development credit unions have joined three commercial banks as lenders in the New York City Capital Access Program, which provides loans and credit lines of $1,500 to $1 million to small businesses that may not meet the criteria for conventional bank loans. The seven-year-old program has granted more than 350 loans totaling more than $18 million to companies with about 4,000 employees, according to the city's Economic Development Corporation, the program's sponsor. The credit unions -- Bethex in the Bronx and Homesteaders, Lower East Side People's and Union Settlement in Manhattan -- join the three banks in the program: Chase Manhattan, EAB and Sterling National. HEADLINE: Council Readies Unique Sex Bias Measure

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
New York City would become the first jurisdiction in the country to grant victims of rape, domestic violence and other crimes "motivated by gender" a broad civil right to sue their attackers under a bill unanimously passed by a City Council committee yesterday.
The measure, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign into law, seizes the opportunity left open six months ago when the United States Supreme Court struck down a similar provision in a 1994 federal law known as the Violence Against Women Act, ruling 5 to 4 that the general power to regulate crime resides with states and localities, not with Congress. The bill was co-sponsored by at least 33 Council members, giving it more than enough votes to pass when the full Council considers the measure on Tuesday. 
 The local measure goes further than current state laws by allowing victims of such violence up to seven years to bring suit, rather than one to two years, and permitting them to seek lawyers' fees and punitive damages as well as compensation.
"Examples of the way gender bias infuses crimes such as domestic violence, sexual assault and stalking abound," Julie Goldscheid, acting legal director of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, told members of the Council's General Welfare Committee, which passed the bill onto the full Council. "Who can forget the horrific images of women being assaulted by gangs of cheering men displayed continuously on the news after the Puerto Rican Day parade in this city?"
Privately, some Republican Council members were critical of the proposed law, because they see it as treating some victims of crime better than others, or as benefiting lawyers more than victims. "But nobody wants to be caught voting against this one," a Republican Council member said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "It'll come back to haunt you that you opposed a law protecting women from crime."
The text of the proposed law states that Congress and the United States Department of Justice concluded after many hearings and studies that "victims of gender-motivated violence frequently face a climate of condescension, indifference and hostility in the court system." By establishing a private, civil right of action, the law tries to provide "an officially sanctioned and legitimate cause of action for seeking redress for injuries resulting from gender-motivated violence," regardless of sex or sexual orientation, the text says.
Unlike overall crime in the city, domestic-violence incidents have not dropped. According to the Mayor's Management Report, the Police Department made 23,935 family-related arrests in the fiscal year that ended in June and 4,012 arrests for violations of orders of protection. Domestic-incident reports totaled 252,902. In 1999, the police reported 87 homicides related to domestic violence.
Advocates of the proposed law said that while state law already allowed battered women, like any other injured party, to sue for damages, the courts had often not been sympathetic in domestic-violence cases, and that a long history of bias against women in case law and a one-year statute of limitations on civil suits involving assault made it exceedingly difficult to pursue relief that way.
Dorchen A. Leidholt, director of the Sanctuary for Families Center for Battered Women, said that domestic-violence felonies were typically reduced to misdemeanors, and misdemeanors to violations, and that though restitution was always a sentencing option, it was rarely used. In divorces, judges are often hostile to women who seek economic redress for injuries from abusive husbands, she said.
Ms. Leidholt cited the case of "the unfortunate Elmhurst woman who in 1998 was fined $5,000 by an irate Supreme Court justice for filing a personal injury suit against her husband for beating her with a broom" when she was unable to prove conclusively that the beating was the cause of her herniated disk.
Under the proposed law, plaintiffs must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the acts involved were not random acts of violence but were motivated by gender. In about 60 cases handled by federal courts around the country before the Supreme Court ruling, that burden was typically met through what one federal judge listed as "gender-specific epithets; acts that perpetuated stereotypes of women's submissive role; attacks during pregnancy and at times when plaintiff asserted her independence." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Lower-Rate Mortgage Is Returning to the Market

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
A mortgage type that offers borrowers lower rates in return for sharing any profits with the lender on the eventual sale of the home is reappearing around the country.
The loan type has been all but unavailable for 20 years except in scattered areas, but now it is being offered nationwide at interest rates one to two percentage points below prevailing market rates. 
 The saving on a $260,000 fixed-rate 30-year mortgage at 7 percent, for example, compared with a 30-year traditional $260,000 fixed-rate 30-year loan at 8.5 percent, would amount to $269.39 a month.
In return for the lower rates, borrowers are required to pay the lender 30 to 60 percent of the home's future appreciation. If the property does not appreciate during the 15- or 30-year term of the loan, borrowers need repay only the balance of the loan, plus interest.
Known by the acronym SAM, for "shared appreciation mortgage," the loan can also be used to refinance borrowers' current homes or to move up to a more expensive home. It can be used by purchasers of houses or condominiums, but not co-ops.
The last time such loans were available, they were offered mostly by local lenders and so there was a patchwork of terms and interest rates, but this time around they are available at uniform rates nationwide through about 1,500 banks, mortgage companies and other financial institutions.
Moreover, the loans are backed by the combined strength of several big financial institutions. These include Bear, Stearns & Company and National Commerce Bank Services, the retail consulting affiliate of the National Commerce Bancorporation of Memphis.
Applicants with good credit ratings can borrow as much as $650,000, with the interest rate on the loan depending on the percentage of the future appreciation that the borrower agrees to pay the lender. The higher that percentage, the lower the interest rate is likely to be.
As for how the $650,000 loan limit was determined, the president of the correspondent lending group at National Commerce Bank Services, Scott Stafford, said: "We wanted to be in the jumbo market, and we thought that was the limit before we would get to super jumbo. If the limit were $250,000, imagine how hard it would be to find a home at that price in New York or San Francisco."
Neil Bader, chief executive of ISI Skyscraper, a mortgage company based in New York, said, "To the extent you have less than 15 percent appreciation over five years, which many neighborhoods do once you're out of Manhattan, it's a great deal."
Of course, the trouble with such loans is that the borrower could end up surrendering a substantial part of any profit if the home appreciates markedly, as has been the case with many New York properties in recent years.
ISI Skyscraper expects to begin offering the shared appreciation loan next week in the New York area, Mr. Bader said, while the president of Madison Home Equities in Carle Place, N.Y., Nadine Maloney, said her firm was offering them now. Allied Mortgage Capital Corporation, based in Houston, expects to begin offering the loan next week at its 570 branches. (It has no branches in New York but does in every other state, including New Jersey and Connecticut. Allied's president and founder, Jim Hodge, said its application for a license to do business in New York was pending.)
National Commerce will buy the loans from the individual lenders and sell them to Bear Stearns. In turn, Bear Stearns will create bonds to sell to such institutional investors as insurance companies and pension funds.
The weakness of the earlier shared appreciation mortgages, according to Mr. Stafford, was that "there was no investment bank behind the mortgage program."
But with an investment bank behind them in Britain, shared appreciation loans succeeded handsomely in England, Scotland and Wales, according to Sam Masucci, who managed global residential property markets for Warburg Dillon Read, an investment banking division of UBS, the large Swiss investment bank. Warburg Dillon bought the SAM loans from the Bank of Scotland and created the bonds for investors.
"The SAM's were so successful," said Mr. Masucci, now the managing director of Bear Stearns's mortgage group, "that they accounted for one of every three of the Bank of Scotland's first mortgage loans."
As do other types of loans, SAM's come with conditions.
For example, borrowers must occupy their home as their primary residence within 60 days after receiving the loan, and must continue to do so throughout the term of the loan. They can move out for up to 12 months, but if they sell or rent their property they will have to pay the outstanding loan balance immediately, as well as the interest from the shared appreciation, if any.
Borrowers need not share the increased value of their home for any improvements that cost over $10,000 (or 6 percent of the value of the home before the improvement, whichever is greater) as determined by appraisals made before and after the improvements are made. But fences, pools and sheds, whatever their cost, are not considered qualified home improvements. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 5, 2000, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Residential Real Estate column on Friday about a type of mortgage that offers a lower rate in return for a share of profits in the eventual sale of the property misstated the name of a lender that will soon be offering such loans in New York. The company is IPI Skyscraper, not ISI Skyscraper.

HEADLINE: William B. Furlong, Sports Columnist And Author, 73

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY 

 BODY:
William Barry Furlong, a widely read sports columnist, magazine writer and author, died last Saturday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 73.
The cause was complications from leukemia, his family said. 
 Mr. Furlong wrote for The Chicago Daily News and The New York Times Magazine, and from 1974 to 1979 he was a sports columnist for The Washington Post. He also contributed to Sports Illustrated, Newsweek and The Saturday Evening Post. After leaving newspaper work, he was a management consultant in Washington, often writing on economic affairs.
He wrote three books: "Go for Broke," with the golfer Arnold Palmer; "Season With Solti," a year with the Chicago Symphony and its conductor, Sir Georg Solti; and "More Than Two Aspirin," about the causes and treatments for migraine headaches.
As a high school senior, he started writing professionally, first for The Southtown Economist in Chicago. He received a bachelor's degree in aeronautical engineering from the Illinois Institute of Technology.
Mr. Furlong, who lived in Washington, is survived by his wife of 37 years, Isabel; a son, William B. Furlong Jr. of Seattle; and a sister, Elizabeth J. Furlong of Chicago.
He was known for intriguing first paragraphs of articles.
*On the young Jack Nicklaus: "Of all the rich, old malevolent illusions assaulted by Jack Nicklaus in his first 20 months as a professional golfer, the one that old-timers on the circuit were most disturbed to see shattered -- or at least cracked -- was the notion that golf is an impossibly difficult game to master."
*On Gordie Howe: "Nowhere are the dark forces that impel a man toward athletic self-destruction more clearly definable than in a hockey player -- indeed, the hockey player -- named Gordon Howe."
*On Smoky Burgess, one of baseball's best pinch-hitters: "Forrest Harrill (Smoky) Burgess is a short, round, mildly ulcerous man whose job in baseball is to demonstrate that they also serve who mostly sit and wait."
 *On Al Lopez: "The mystique of the positive-thinking Al Lopez, who manages the Chicago White Sox, an occasional baseball team that has astonished the sports world, is a rich enigma based largely, he claims, on a policy of doing nothing and doing it well."

HEADLINE: Think Tank;
Taking Stock: More Lawyers and Engineers, Fewer Inventors

 BODY:
In 1869, before James A. Garfield took over the presidency, he observed that "the developments of statistics are causing history to be rewritten." Garfield's prescient statement is quoted in a new book, "The First Measured Century: An Illustrated Guide to Trends in America, 1900-2000," by Theodore Caplow, Louis Hicks, and Ben J. Wattenberg (A.E.I. Press). As the authors note, Americans "pioneered the measurement of facets of American life that had never been systematically counted before such as crime, love, food, fun, religion and work. . . . The numbers that fill the news -- the Gross National Product, the Consumer Price Index, the unemployment rate, the teenage pregnancy rate, the poverty rate and so forth were inventions of the American 20th century."
The collection of charts and thumbnail essays, which is the companion volume to a PBS documentary to be broadcast on Dec. 20, are based on census data, government statistics and surveys by the National Opinion Research Center, among other sources. Together, they offer snapshots of social change in the United States. 
 Below are some excerpts.
Patents allow their owners to prohibit others from making, using or selling the invention for a period of 20 years from the date of application for the patent. About 95 percent of all patents are issued for inventions, as distinct from the small number of patents issued for designs and botanical plants. Prior to 1986, the charts show only patents for inventions; starting in 1986 patents of all types are included.
The lone inventor whose Yankee ingenuity enables him to build and patent a better mousetrap is a stock American hero. In 1901 four out of five United States patents were issued to individuals. In 1999 more than four out of five were issued to corporations. Some of this change occurred as individuals incorporated their business, but the trend toward larger-scale organization of technological innovation is clear. As the patent archives grew, the process of searching and validating a patent claim became the domain of experts whose services could be formidably expensive.
Furthermore, nearly all corporate organizations, including universities and research centers, reserve the right to patent any invention made by an employee, often, but not always, with some financial reward for the inventor.
In the first half of the century, large year-to-year fluctuations in the real G.D.P. the chart at top of the next column indicated severe swings in the business cycle between expansion and contraction of the economy.
In the second half of the century, as the chart shows, these fluctuations became much more moderate, while the economy continued to expand.
The moderation of the business cycle after midcentury has often been attributed to improved monetary policy and the effects of government programs. Better monetary policy prevented rapid, "unsustainable" expansion of the economy and also arrested contrations of the economy.
Some government spending programs, such as unemployment insurance and farm subsidies, were deliberately designed to counterbalance economic swings.
Federal insurance of bank deposits prevented economic contrations from causing liquidity rises. Government spending, which tends to be independent of the business cycle, represented a larger part of the economy in the second half of the century.
Government transfer programs such as Social Security were also insulated from the business cycle.
 The supply of engineers per thousand population the chart at top of the next column increased in every decade, driven by technological progress and increasingly complex production processes. Most engineers were middle-level employees of large enterprises. At the end of the century, a bachelor's degree was still sufficient for licensing in many engineering specialties.
The relative supply of lawyers was more responsive to trends in social policy than to technological progress. Because requirements for entry were raised during the first half of the century and the size of law schools was effectively restricted, the ratio of lawyers to population was slightly lower in 1970 than 1900. The number of lawyers per thousand population nearly tripled between 1970 and 1998, largely in response to the widening role of governments and a boom in litigation.
The relative supply of physicians declined early in the century, primarily as a consequence of the 1910 Flexner Report, which brought reform to the standards and curricula of United States medical schools and closed marginal schools. The restriction of supply in the face of increasing demand gave physicians the highest average incomes of any occupational group.
Such restrictive policies were largely abandoned after 1970 in response to public pressure, as well as massive new funding from Medicare and Medicaid.

HEADLINE: Automakers Are Facing a Sales Slowdown

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Through most of the 1990's, automakers avoided building new assembly plants, convinced that the good times would not last. They have finally committed themselves in the last two years to a string of new factories, only to find their timing is as poor as ever: sales have begun to slow, particularly for Detroit's manufacturers.
The combined sales of Detroit-based automakers fell 3.5 percent last month, compared with November of last year. While sales are still at a level that would have been considered very strong until the last two years, they have now lagged last year's pace in six of the last seven months -- and much more production capacity is becoming available. 
 General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler have already responded by eliminating overtime and briefly closing a few factories; Ford and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler both announced further temporary closings today. Ford also said its per-share earnings in the fourth quarter would fall 10 cents short of analysts' consensus forecast of 85 cents.
Asian and European automakers are also starting to encounter trouble, with their sales barely rising this autumn, including last month; earlier in the year, their monthly sales were leaping by 20 and 25 percent compared with the corresponding months a year earlier. Foreign automakers have benefited from their recent entry into the markets for large minivans and pickup trucks, with vehicles like the Honda Odyssey and Toyota Tundra.
Honda's 3.5 percent increase in sales last month "was more an indication of strong demand for some hot products that we're fortunate to have than the overall strength of the market," said Dick Colliver, the executive vice president of Honda's North American operations. "The overall market has slipped into neutral and there is not a lot of forward motion right now."
The slowdown, however, has done nothing so far to stop the binge of auto factory construction. Toyota opened a factory in Princeton, Ind., last year and DaimlerChrysler is about to open one in Toledo, Ohio. Honda and Mercedes recently announced the construction of new factories in Alabama while Nissan said last month that it would erect an assembly plant in Mississippi. All of these factories will build sport utility vehicles, pickups or minivans, which will probably result in surplus production in market segments that had been the industry's most profitable.
Diane C. Swonk, the chief economist and senior vice president at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago, predicted that the slowing would result in the closing of older factories. The blow to the Midwest will be cushioned because tens of thousands of unionized auto workers are now retiring each year, making layoffs unlikely.
Sales next year, though weaker than in the last two years, are still likely to be strong by historical standards, she added. "We're slowing down to sales nobody thought were attainable a few years ago," Ms. Swonk said.
Auto executives and dealers attribute the slowdown to the fairly high interest rates and the steep descent of the Nasdaq composite index. "The stock market has got people worried," said Alan Helfman, a Chrysler and Jeep dealer in Houston.
Sales weakened last month for cars, minivans and pickups, while growth in sport utility sales slowed despite an abundance of new, car-based models. G.M.'s sales fell 8.4 percent last month compared with the period a year earlier. Ford's sales dropped 7.9 percent excluding Land Rover, the luxury sport utility vehicle maker that it acquired last summer, while Chrysler's sales dipped 5.5 percent.
Honda's sales climbed 3.5 percent last month, and Nissan's rose 4.3 percent. Toyota's gained 4.6 percent.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 16.6 million vehicles last month, much slower than the average pace of 17.6 million so far this year. But until sales reached the 17 million range last year and this year, most auto executives thought that annual sales of 15 million represented a good year.
Economists are watching the faltering pace of auto production because the industry still plays an enormous role in the American economy, and any slowdown could cause ripples across the nation if auto workers cut back on spending.
The auto sector makes up 4 percent of the nation's economic output, and the Federal Reserve estimated a few years ago that the industry accounted for a quarter of the total economic output of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana. G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler each have at least eight times the annual sales of the Microsoft Corporation.
Chrysler today said that among its 12 assembly plants in the United States and Canada, 2 would not operate next week, one would not operate the following week and 5 would not operate during the week before Christmas.
Sales last month weakened the most for cars and minivans, and lagged somewhat for pickup trucks as well. Sales were stronger for sport utility vehicles, especially for the new breed of so-called crossover utility vehicles like the Ford Escape and Chrysler PT Cruiser. These are built like cars but have features that led regulators to classify them as sport utility vehicles, so they qualify for more lenient fuel-economy and safety regulations than cars do.
Luxury cars and luxury sport utility vehicles, like Jaguars and Land Rovers, also did well, as well-heeled buyers continued to throng showrooms even as middle-income buyers became more scarce. "When sales moderate, the premium brand sales hold up somewhat better," said George Pipas, a Ford market analyst.
Automakers tried earlier this autumn to maintain high levels of sales by offering extremely deep discounts. These discounts have proved inadequate to offset the effects of a falling stock market and less-vibrant growth in the overall economy. Automakers are now reducing production, possibly enough to avoid even deeper incentives later this winter.
A big problem with incentives is that they often cause loyal consumers to buy sooner than they otherwise might, so that sales in future months are penalized. Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director of industry and market analysis, acknowledged this today in saying that G.M.'s sales lagged in November partly because the company had offered so many large rebates and zero-interest loans a month earlier.
"We did have some payback from the strength of some of our marketing initiatives in the month of October," Mr. Ballew said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Failed Rally Ends a Week Of Stock Pain

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
A failed rally yesterday ended another grim week for investors, as worries about slowing economic growth and the unresolved presidential election continued to plague Wall Street.
After rising more than 1 percent in morning trading, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 10,373.54, a drop of 40.95 points, or 0.4 percent. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index, which has recently been pummeled, also could not hold its gains. After rising almost 6 percent by early afternoon, the Nasdaq closed at 2,645.29, a gain of 47.36 points, or 1.8 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was flat, rising 0.28 point, to 1,315.23. 
 Despite its gains yesterday, the Nasdaq closed the week down 9 percent. The Nasdaq has now fallen in 10 of the last 12 weeks, giving up 38 percent of its value since Sept. 1. For the year, the Nasdaq is off 35 percent, putting it on track for its worst performance since the bear market of 1974.
The Nasdaq's collapse has left investors and strategists sharply divided. Bulls note that the last major pullback in technology stocks, which came in the fall of 1998 on worries of a slowdown in worldwide economic growth and a credit crisis, proved to be a great opportunity for aggressive investors. Wall Street's fears turned out to be misplaced, and the Nasdaq more than tripled between October 1998 and March of this year. Even at its current levels, the Nasdaq has almost doubled from those 1998 lows.
Now, Wall Street is once again panicking needlessly, said Stephen Slifer, chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers. Mr. Slifer said he expected the economy to grow about 3.5 percent next year and inflation to remain low at 2.5 percent. Given that outlook, corporate profits should continue to grow solidly next year, he said.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury bond, meanwhile, has fallen to 5.51 percent, its lowest level since April. Lower interest rates are another positive for stocks, because they make bonds less attractive as an alternative investment.
"I think this is a pretty good time to be buying stocks, quite frankly," Mr. Slifer said.
But Mr. Slifer is in the minority these days. Many strategists and investors are concerned that the United States economy is headed for much slower growth, or even a recession. General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler reported sharply lower sales for November yesterday, and the National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index fell to its lowest level since December 1998.
"There will probably be a recession next year," said Ralph Wanger, chief investment officer for the $8 billion Acorn mutual fund. "The economic indicators are rolling over, it looks like."
The slowdown has already affected some economically sensitive industries, from machine tool manufacturers, which are hurt if companies cut capital spending, to casinos, which suffer as consumers cut their disposable spending, Mr. Wanger said.
Richard Bernstein, director of quantitative research for Merrill Lynch, said the slowdown in corporate profit growth was unlikely to reverse quickly. "Since 1970, the shortest period of profit deceleration was six quarters; so far we've had two," he said.
Mr. Bernstein also warned investors against expecting the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates quickly to help stocks. Although profit growth is slowing, the economy continues to grow, and oil prices remain above $30 a barrel, so the Fed will be reluctant to lower rates, he said. In addition, many stocks remain expensive by historical standards despite their declines this year. "Our feeling is the Fed is going to be very, very reluctant to play the role of the cavalry," Mr. Bernstein said.
Technology stocks will be especially vulnerable if the economy slows, Mr. Bernstein said, because venture capitalists and public investors have created too many companies over the last several years, and the sector is ripe for a shake-out.
"Everybody who had an idea got funded, and a lot of these companies should not be companies," he said. "Our fear for 2001 is that there is tremendous overcapacity in the technology sector."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 522 words

HEADLINE: An Economy in Transition

 BODY:
The party may be over. It is not yet clear whether the present economic slowdown will ultimately lead to a recession or is simply the "soft landing" Alan Greenspan has been plotting so carefully. But either way, it spells the end of the economic nirvana of recent years -- that potent concoction of extremely robust growth, accelerating productivity gains, low inflation and low unemployment. The universal sense of awe at the magical "new economy" is giving way to a sense of unease.
One of Mr. Greenspan's predecessors famously said that the role of the Federal Reserve chairman is to remove the punch bowl when the party gets going. That is precisely what the Fed has done by raising interest rates six times in the past 18 months. Now Mr. Greenspan, the fabled helmsman of the economy viewed by many Americans as the one indispensable public servant in Washington, is being pressed to reverse course and stop fretting about inflation. 
 Evidence of a slowdown keeps mounting, and Mr. Greenspan will have to weigh it all against the persistence of low unemployment and high energy costs, traditional inflationary signals. The economy grew at a 2.4 percent annual rate in the third quarter, compared with 5.6 percent in the second quarter. Corporations are finding it harder to increase their profits or borrow money and are consequently spending less. Consumer confidence, that mushy measure of the nation's psyche, is falling. Retailers, expecting a modest Christmas, are offering unusually hefty discounts at the outset of the holiday shopping season.
Santa's sense of disquiet may become a political liability for the next president. Bill Clinton owed much of his second-term political buoyancy to the same economic euphoria that turned Americans, at least in Mr. Greenspan's view, into a nation of irrationally exuberant investors. Millions piled into the stock market to profit from the tech-driven revolution, and at times seemed to turn the hope that the new economy had transcended the restraints of the business cycle into a self-fulfilling prophesy. But that euphoria has chilled greatly.
Alan Greenspan may yet pull off a "soft landing" for the economy, as he did in the mid-1990's, ensuring continued though less robust growth. But things have been hard for stock market investors, particularly those who had grown accustomed to the idea that it pays to speculate. After surging 40 percent in 1998 and 86 percent in 1999, the seemingly unstoppable Nasdaq composite index, dominated by tech issues, is down 35 percent for the year and almost 50 percent from its March highs. Day traders have been forced to get day jobs.
Economists have long debated the extent to which wild swings in the stock market affect the real economy. When markets soared, Mr. Greenspan worried that consumers feeling inordinately wealthy because of their paper gains in the market would overheat the economy. Now the opposite question becomes an issue. Even long-term investors are likely to react to plummeting stock prices. Seeing your 401(k) fund shrink has a way of dampening your appetite for luxury items and lavish gifts. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Lesser-Known Successor Is Making His Voice Heard

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THREE months ago, South Africa's Anglican bishops decided that they should take the blood test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and that they should be public about it. Among the first to go was the church's head, Archbishop Njongonkulu Ndungane of Cape Town, who had his blood drawn before a crowd of journalists.
The publicity, of course, was the church's way of encouraging others to be tested in a nation where more people may be infected with the human immunodeficiency virus than anywhere else in the world. "The whole purpose was to break the silence," the archbishop said in an interview, "and take away the stigma by having bishops and archbishops going to tests on AIDS." 
 Archbishop Ndungane, 59, came to Washington to speak at a White House conference this week on what religious groups, especially in developing nations, can do to fight AIDS. A well-traveled prelate educated in South Africa and England, he is a man of many distinctions. Head of the Anglican Church Province of South Africa (one of the Episcopal Church's sister communions), he has been prominent among religious leaders in calling for cancellation of the foreign debts of impoverished nations.
As a young man, he served time on Robben Island, the notorious prison run by South Africa's former white minority government, which enforced a system of apartheid, strict racial separation. (For years, its most famous inmate was Nelson Mandela, later released and elected South Africa's first black president, after apartheid's end.)
Yet it is fair to say that Archbishop Ndungane is not as well known, certainly outside his country, as his predecessor, Desmond Tutu, a fierce critic of apartheid who won the Nobel Peace Prize.
Such outspoken stands as Archbishop Tutu and some other religious leaders took during the apartheid era left the Anglican Church and other churches with much moral capital on which to draw. "There's a high regard for the church, because of the role it has taken in justice issues," said Archbishop Ndungane (pronounced en-dun-GON-ay). "We are still looked on as the voice of moral conscience."
What religious leaders say about AIDS is important in South Africa today, because the government has sent mixed signals to citizens about the disease's cause. Earlier this year, Mr. Mandela's successor, President Thabo Mbeki, drew widespread criticism when he expressed interest in a theory that poverty and malnutrition caused AIDS, rather than H.I.V. Health care workers expressed fear that his comments had harmed efforts to discourage people from risky sexual behavior.
ARCHBISHOP NDUNGANE said he believed that Mr. Mbeki had moved away from the position. The archbishop said his own concern was that the government and the churches join forces in fighting the disease.
As he spoke, he pointed to a newspaper article, faxed to him at his hotel, about the crushing impact AIDS was likely to have on South Africa's population and economy. From his advocacy on the foreign debt issue, the archbishop is well-versed in issues of economic development and international lending.
In a speech last year, he warned that the foreign debts of African nations were forcing them to pay more in interest than they received in aid. "Contrary to general assumptions, therefore, the rich are not paying the poor," he said then. "The poor end up paying the rich."
When he was young, Archbishop Ndungane contemplated a lucrative career in commercial law. But as with many other South Africans, the anti-apartheid struggle changed his life.
In 1960, he took part in protests organized by the Pan Africanist Congress against the pass laws, the rule that black citizens carry passports inside the country. After the Congress was outlawed, he was arrested for belonging to a "banned" organization.
Sent to Robben Island a few years before Mr. Mandela, he spent 18 months quarrying stone and mixing cement with other inmates to build the prison. "My claim to fame is I built the jail for Mandela," he said.
"Robben Island in those days was hell on earth," he said. "We were made to suffer there. We were forced to feel a need to abandon ideology and hope. The fact that I am here is testimony to the resiliency of the human spirit."
He also underwent a conversion experience, brought on by wrestling with an old question: How could a good God permit such suffering? Amid the turmoil, he experienced an inner peace. "It was at that moment that I felt touched by the hand of God," Archbishop Ndungane said. He committed himself to a ministry of reconciliation.
He has served as a parish priest, head of a seminary, the church's chief executive officer and as a bishop. A widower, he remarried, to a businesswoman who was herself a widow.
In 1996, he was elected Cape Town's archbishop, in a process that required a two-thirds vote by clergy and lay representatives, then confirmation by the church's bishops. He regards Archbishop Tutu as a friend and father figure. "I used to say, 'I pity the person who succeeds Desmond Tutu,' " Archbishop Ndungane said. "Little did I know that the good Lord would point at me."
The archbishop said he did not worry about people drawing comparisons. "It never concerns me," he said. "My philosophy is, it's God who calls and God who equips. It is God who gives us gifts which he wants us to use at a particular time."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Two Large Insurers Shift Costs to Bigger Vehicles
With evidence growing that sport utility vehicles, pickups and large vans cause disproportionate harm to cars and their occupants, two insurers that cover nearly 25 million vehicles have begun making drivers of the bigger vehicles pay more for liability insurance.
Officials of Allstate Insurance and Progressive Insurance, the nation's No. 2 and No. 4 insurers, have begun raising the cost of liability insurance for many bigger, high-riding vehicles while lowering premiums for the smaller cars owned by most Americans. Page A1. 

Shares of Xerox Drop on Downgrade
Moody's Investors Service has downgraded the rating on about $11 billion in Xerox debt to below investment grade, or junk-bond status. Separately, the company, which lost $167 million in the third quarter and does not expect to see black ink until 2001, laid off 200 workers in New York, with plans to dismiss 75 more. Shares of Xerox fell 69 cents, to $6.25. C2.
 
Oil Prices Fall as Iraq Cuts Supply
Picking a crucial moment, Iraq abruptly stopped pumping and exporting oil. It is not the first time this year that Iraq has disrupted its oil supply, which provides 4 percent of world consumption, to protest United Nations sanctions. Oil markets reacted calmly, with the price of crude falling $1.80 a barrel in New York, to $32.02. A3.
 
Europe Challenges U.S. Steel Tariffs
The European Union filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization, challenging United States import restrictions on imports of steel wire rod and welded pipe. Europe contended the tariffs violated free trade rules and had damaged European companies. C2.
 
Financier to Be Extradited to U.S.
The financier Martin R. Frankel will be extradited to Mississippi to face charges he bilked three insurance companies of about $200 million. German authorities agreed to release Mr. Frankel, who was arrested in 1999 after an international manhunt. Federal and state regulators have been seeking Mr. Frankel's extradition. Germany has also agreed to release Mr. Frankel to authorities in Connecticut and Tennessee where he faces charges, including money laundering and securities fraud. C4.
 
Buyout Firms to Take Over Datek
A group of private investors agreed to pay $700 million to acquire a controlling stake in Datek Online, one of the nation's fastest-growing online brokers. The new majority owners -- Bain Capital, TA Associates and Silver Lake Partners -- agreed to buy out Jeffrey Citron, above, the company's founder and former chief executive, and Sheldon Maschler, who was once the head trader at Datek. C2.
 
Industrial Activity Contracts Again
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity slid to 47.7 in November from 48.3 in October, as industry activity contracted for the fourth consecutive month. C2.
 
Delphi to Lay Off More Than 1,700
Delphi Automotive Systems, the auto parts maker, said it would furlough 1,700 workers in plants in Michigan, Ohio and New York because production of cars and light trucks in North America was slowing. The workers will be laid off indefinitely starting in the next three weeks; all will be rehired. C3.
 
Phone Unit Seized in Belgium
Global TeleSystems of London said a Brussels court seized control of its Belgian unit after an employee said he thought it was going bankrupt. The European telephone company said that the employee was wrong and that the seizure would be contested. C2.
 
Some Fund Prices Not Available
Because of transmission errors, some mutual fund prices were not available at press time.

LENGTH: 332 words

HEADLINE: Verizon New Jersey Withdraws Request for Basic Rate Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Citing overwhelming public opposition and pending state hearings, Verizon New Jersey withdrew a proposal to double its basic telephone rates yesterday. But in Connecticut, Southern New England Telecommunications told state regulators that it needed an unspecified increase on local phone rates.
The president of Verizon New Jersey, Dennis Bone, said the company had withdrawn its rate request for business reasons, not legal ones. 
 The proposal "has been controversial to say the least," Mr. Bone said. He said the company planned to submit a simpler proposal to the Board of Public Utilities after Jan. 1.
Anthony Wright, program director of New Jersey Citizen Action, which organized opposition to the proposal, said he was appalled at Mr. Bone's characterization of the decision.
"It had nothing to do with soul searching, and everything to do with avoiding the B.P.U. outright rejecting their plan," he said. "It was shocking that he thought the problem with the proposal was about public relations, rather than about substance."
Verizon, which provides about 98 percent of the local telephone service in New Jersey, had also asked the B.P.U. to declare the state a competitive market so it could charge deregulated rates. The company recommended raising the state's basic telephone rate of $8.19 a month to a choice of plans priced at $15, $16 or $17.50 a month. Each package automatically included premium services for customers, like caller ID and call waiting, but did not give customers the option of refusing the services.
Meanwhile, Southern New England Telephone, a subsidiary of SBC Communications Inc., said higher prices were essential to spur competition in the market for residential telephone services. S.N.E.T. serves more than 90 percent of the estimated 1.4 million residential phone lines in Connecticut.
S.N.E.T. has not said what kind of price increases it would seek, but is asking permission for annual increases at or below inflation rates.

Mexico's New President Promises to Share Power
Vicente Fox Quesada, 58, the former business executive who led a national movement for democracy, became the first opposition politician in 71 years to be inaugurated president. He promised that he would share the power that the Institutional Revolutionary Party long monopolized. A1
 
House Arrest for Pinochet
A Chilean judge charged Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the kidnappings of political opponents after he overthrew the Socialist government of Dr. Salvador Allende in 1973. The 85-year-old ailing general was ordered placed under house arrest. A1 

Testing U.N., Iraq Cuts Oil
Iraq abruptly stopped exporting oil, testing the resolve of the United States and the Security Council just before an important series of debates on Iraq is to begin next week, diplomats said. It is not the first time this year that Iraq has disrupted its oil supplies, which provide about 4 percent of world consumption, to protest sanctions. A3
 
More Clashes in Mideast
Deadly street clashes continued in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, where Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians. But the first Friday of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan passed without serious violence in East Jerusalem, where both Palestinians and Israeli security forces showed restraint. A6
 
AIDS Drugs for South Africans

Training for Peacekeeping
The Army has ordered that all fighting units based in the United States undergo special training intended to avoid human rights abuses by soldiers sent overseas on peacekeeping missions, Pentagon officials said. A6
 
Chinese Justice Minister Out
China's Minister of Justice, Gao Changli, 63, was removed from office this week, officials acknowledged. According to some accounts he is under investigation for corruption. Justices Press Both Sides In Hearing on Vote Case
The United States Supreme Court quizzed the lawyers for both sides in an intense session that ended in uncertainty over how -- or whether -- the justices would decide Gov. George W. Bush's appeal of the Florida Supreme Court's extension of the state's vote-counting deadline. The justices met privately afterward to discuss the case, but no timetable for a decision was announced. A1
 
The Florida Supreme Court rejected an appeal by Vice President Al Gore that it begin the immediate manual recount of 14,000 disputed ballots from South Florida, forcing Mr. Gore's contest of the presidential election into a lower-court trial that begins this morning. The Florida justices also refused to order a new election in Palm Beach County sought by voters who had complained that its "butterfly" ballot caused confusion. The Bush team scaled back some demands that Gore lawyers had asserted would excessively delay proceedings. A1
 
Leaders of Florida's Republican-controlled Legislature said they could select electors with a resolution that would not require action by Gov. Jeb Bush, Mr. Bush's brother. A10
 
Victorious in Washington

Plans for Bomb Disposal
Colorado officials agreed to let the Army detonate small bombs filled with the toxic liquid sarin that were recently found on the grounds of a defunct weapons plant, the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, north of Denver. Experts will build a structure over the site where the bombs were found, detonate them and then search for more bombs below the surface. A7

HEADLINE: Recount Seals Senate Race In Washington For Democrat

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: OLYMPIA, Wash., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Maria Cantwell, who made a fortune with a high-tech company and financed her own United States Senate campaign, narrowly defeated Senator Slade Gorton, the state's Republican incumbent, results of a recount confirmed today.
Her victory creates the possibility of a 50-50 tie in the new Senate. 
 Ms. Cantwell, a former one-term member of United States House in her first statewide campaign, defeated Mr. Gorton by 2,229 votes out of nearly 2.5 million cast. The last of Washington's 39 counties reported recount results today. The unofficial count, reported last week, had given her a margin of 1,953 votes.
"I am honored to have won such a close election," Ms. Cantwell said in a victory speech tonight, minutes after Mr. Gorton sent her a handwritten concession letter. The senator's campaign said he would not seek further recounts.
"It's over," said Cynthia Bergman, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gorton.
The recount resolved the election's last unsettled Senate race.
Mr. Gorton, who has been mentioned for a cabinet position if Gov. George W. Bush wins the presidency, has no immediate plans other than attending a lame-duck session of Congress next week, Ms. Bergman said.
King County, which is heavily Democratic and includes Seattle, won the race for Ms. Cantwell. She had a margin of more than 150,000 votes there. The county was the last to report results of the automatic recount, which state law required because of the close race.
Ms. Cantwell carried only five counties, but Mr. Gorton's big lead in the less populous areas could not overcome her advantage in Seattle.
The victory of Ms. Cantwell, 42, could divide the Senate's 100 seats evenly between Democrats and Republicans if Mr. Bush wins the White House. But Republicans would maintain nominal control of the Senate because Dick Cheney, as a Republican vice president, would cast any vote needed to break a tie.
If Vice President Al Gore were to become president, Connecticut's Republican governor, John G. Rowland, would probably appoint a Republican to the seat vacated by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Mr. Gore's running mate, putting the Republicans back into a 51-49 advantage.
Washington, for the first time, joins California and Maine in having two women in the Senate. Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, is in her second term.
Mr. Gorton had won six statewide races, three terms as attorney general and three as senator. His only previous loss was his first Senate re-election bid, to Brock Adams, a Democrat, in 1986. He came back with a victory two years later and was re-elected easily in 1994.
But Mr. Gorton failed to persuade voters that his clout was too important to give up. The same state dumped a sitting speaker of the House, Tom Foley, in 1994.
During the campaign, Ms. Cantwell called Mr. Gorton a man who offered "19th-century solutions to 21st-century problems." She ran as someone who understood the high-tech industry and the new economy from the inside out.
She also benefited from Mr. Gorton's long list of enemies, including American Indian tribes, environmentalists, trial lawyers and abortion-rights activists, all of whom campaigned against him.

HEADLINE: Columbia Revels in Success Of Fund-Raising Campaign

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Nearing the end of a decadelong fund-raising campaign, Columbia University announced yesterday that it had raised $2.74 billion -- more than double the initial goal in 1990.
The sum is one of the largest ever raised by a university. Last year, Harvard announced that it had raised a record $2.6 billion in a five-and-a-half-year campaign. 
 "We are closing off a very important chapter in Columbia's history," said Columbia's president, George Rupp, yesterday, calling the campaign not only an important tool in competing for top students and teachers, but a symbol of the university's "forward momentum" as well.
Columbia's campaign is also one of the longest by a higher education institution. Started in 1990, when Michael I. Sovern was president, it spanned the tenures of two presidents, two development officers and two alumni chairmen.
The original intention was to raise $1.15 billion over five years, but the campaign, aided by a strong economy and booming financial markets, went so well that the university decided to extend it for five years and to double the goal.
Of the money raised so far, about $800 million has gone into Columbia's endowment, with $250 million dedicated to financial aid, $275 million to new endowed professorships, and $275 million to research and other programs.
Columbia has also used $370 million for new buildings including a student center, a dormitory and a business and law building -- and for the refurbishment of others, including the library.
The campaign has helped Columbia ratchet up its annual fund-raising to more than $300 million a year, which the university says has moved it to about 5th place from 11th among universities.
Columbia has received about 300,000 donations, some from repeat contributors. But the bulk of the money came from fewer than 400 gifts of $1 million or more, which accounted for $1.6 billion, or about two-thirds of the total.
There were two gifts of more than $50 million: $85 million in two parts from the businessman and philanthropist John W. Kluge ($60 million for minority scholarships and $25 million to subsidize junior faculty salaries) and $50 million from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation for the School of Public Health.
Six of the gifts were between $25 million and $50 million, and 29 gifts between $10 million and $25 million.
"It's a fairly typical pyramid for a large, private research university," said Richard K. Naum, Columbia's vice president for development and alumni relations.
The numbers announced yesterday represent totals collected through Sept. 30, although the "Campaign for Columbia," as it is called, does not officially end until Dec. 31.
"We're not out of the ballgame yet," Mr. Naum said.
Since Sept. 30, the university has received a pledge of $10 million for graduate fellowships and a $12 million pledge for the law school, which did not appear in the tabulated figures.
The university has already collected most of the $2.7 billion, but about $350 million of the total includes pledges for gifts that will come in over the next five years.
Stephen Friedman, the chairman of Columbia's board and a graduate of its law school, said that the campaign had been helped by the strong economy and financial markets and also by New York City's new vitality.
Dr. Rupp said he had no plans to extend the campaign, but added: "I actually find asking for gifts enjoyable. People with substantial assets are, for the most part, very interesting people. It is not painful to spend time with them."
Mr. Friedman, Columbia's chairman, noted that Columbia could use more fund-raising, because its endowment per student is still below that of Harvard, Princeton, Yale and Stanford.
"We would like to narrow the gap," he said. "We were under no illusion that you can eliminate it overnight. But as long as you have substantial opportunities, there are people out there who will get caught up in a fund-raising campaign and enthused about it and excited. The money-raising clock never stops."
And, he added, "The needs never end."

HEADLINE: A Sampling Of Works In Progress;
Silver and World Trade

BYLINE: By JOYCE JENSEN 

 BODY:
From the most raked-over history to the latest technology, scholars continually manage to ask new questions, rethink old verities and produce fresh insights. Arts & Ideas takes an occasional look at what some of today's thinkers -- the established as well as those who yearn to be -- are working on. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs and others may turn out to be dead ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here are three works in progress.
 Silver has been a source of wealth and power ever since the Sumerians in the Tigris and Euphrates valley mined it for themselves 5,000 years ago. But for Dennis O. Flynn and Arturo Giraldez, silver can yield riches of a different sort. 
 "A history of silver reveals a great deal about global trade networks and patterns," said Mr. Giraldez, a historian who is on the faculty of the Pacific World History Institute in Stockton, Calif. He and Mr. Flynn, an economics professor and the director of the institute, are collaborating on a history of silver.
Since the 16th century, silver has fascinated scholars and philosophers. Yet Mr. Flynn and Mr. Giraldez say that more recently, this precious metal has been forcing historians to adopt a less conventional and more global perspective on the history of trade.
Indeed, following silver's global production and trade patterns is precisely what the two professors say led them to reassess their own approach. "Studying monetary history from a global view takes on a life of its own," Mr. Giraldez said. "It spun our thinking in directions which we did not intend." They turned their attention away from Europe, and in the process became converts to the increasingly popular field of world history.
Mr. Flynn said that conflicts between the historical evidence and conventional ideas about silver and trade ultimatley forced them "to formulate a better theory." Now, he said, they believe "a highly integrated global economy has existed since the 16th century."
At the moment, the professors are researching two cycles in the evolution of the global silver market. The first phase, known as the Potosi-Japan cycle, lasted from 1540's to the 1640's. They name 1571 -- the year the city of Manila was founded -- as the moment when global trade was born. For anyone trading around the world, Manila was a link between Asia and the American continents; the stopping point for the first substantial and continuous trade across the Pacific Ocean. Silver, primarily produced in Japan, Mexico and Potosi (what is now Bolivia) and then sold in China, was no exception. After China's paper money system collapsed in the middle of the 15th century, the country gradually began to use silver instead. By the 1600's, silver had become more valuable than ever, worth twice as much in China as anywhere else in the world.
A second phase, known as the Mexican cycle, covered the first half of the 18th century. A large population surge in China engendered a huge increase in demand for silver there at the same time that silver production boomed in Mexico, spurred by tax breaks, government support for mining and some technological changes that reduced production costs.
Despite the current vogue for globalization, Mr. Flynn and Mr. Giraldez argue, these two silver cycles show that powerful economic, demographic and ecological forces linked the world long before the 20th century.
