SECTION: Section 5; Page 31; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: This Train Beats Walking (Sometimes)

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD; WAYNE ARNOLD contributes to The Times from Singapore.

 BODY:
EXPERIENCED rail travelers recognize it is an almost certain sign of delay when fellow passengers abandon the train and strike off into the surrounding mountains on foot. This may not be very practical wisdom for the average Amtrak passenger, but it could be good to know if, like me, you find yourself riding to meetings in Hanoi through Yunnan Province in China during the summer rainy season.
Maybe I had been too gullible when I read in my guidebook that there was a regular train from Kunming, the capital of the province, to Hanoi. I had been planning to vacation in Yunnan Province and needed to do some reporting in Vietnam. What better way to study the relative benefits of globalization, I thought, than to ride a train across the border from China, newly converted capitalist libertine and aspiring World Trade Organization member, to Vietnam, petulant socialist wallflower? 
 China had certainly let its hair down in the nine years since my last visit. Kunming, once a proudly dour Communist city, had swapped its olive drab for planters of zinnias. Chengdu, the leafy metropolis with the fiery cuisine in Sichuan Province, to the north of Yunnan, had transformed itself into an explosion of department stores, cellular phones and dot-com ads.
The trains also had undergone a makeover of sorts during that time. The bituminous stench of water boiling for tea endures, but loudspeakers blare the theme of "Titanic" instead of old patriotic marches. Gone are the sullen women, pushing dirty mops, who were the conductors. They have been replaced by perky women with pageboy haircuts and dirty mops.
The narrow-gauge railway up the Red River was built by France in 1910 after the country persuaded China to give it mining concessions in Yunnan. China and Vietnam have managed to preserve the same 473-mile railway despite war with the Japanese, Chinese Nationalists, the French, the Americans, and then, deprived of common foes, each other. Now the line accommodates a twice-weekly train with first-class berths for the equivalent of $37.
My ticket read like a Warsaw Pact VCR instruction manual, printed in every language but English -- Chinese, Vietnamese, Russian and German. It came as little surprise that almost no one on the train spoke English, not even the tour group of language teachers from Vietnam sharing the ride. But I was fortunate to be sharing a cabin with a British couple for whom this 18-hour journey was a footnote. They had just survived a week aboard the Trans-Siberian railway, a moving bazaar in which bunks make way for car parts and other assorted goods traversing the global economy.
Our jaunt through the mountains held its own in the misery category. Narrow gauge is railway jargon for tightrope, and the train careered drunkenly through the night. The engineer indulged his fear of head-on collisions with frequent blasts of an earsplitting horn. With the cabin window closed, the sound was just painful, but the heat was unbearable.
Deciding that hearing loss was preferable to suffocation, we voted to open the window, only to be vetoed by our fourth inmate, an antique Vietnamese man. We deferred to the man's age; the window stayed shut.
We turned our efforts instead to persuading a conductor to turn on the air-conditioning. But the railway's frugality dictated that it not be turned on during cool weather, regardless of the temperature inside. After fuming at his console for 10 minutes, the conductor relented by setting the temperature to "arctic."
Morning found us semifrozen, our train stalled along a swollen Red River about 25 miles from the border at a muddy village called Lao Fan Zhai. Jungle-covered mountains rose steeply around us. The rains had sent a landslide down over the tracks up ahead. For four hours, we waited, watching the rain clouds play among the lush peaks as tribesmen in colorful attire drifted through the station to gawk at the massive diesel engine.
It was around this time that the local passengers decided to take their chances on foot. To say I wondered if I shouldn't follow them, the cognoscenti, is putting it too mildly. Hoofing it through the frontier appealed to my sense of adventure. But a modern instinct overcame me: I was a paying passenger and the railway had contracted to deliver me, I reasoned. Though the arrival time on my ticket was a joke, I clung to my faith in the agreement's spirit and sated my taste for adventure with a bowl of spicy noodles from the station canteen.
My inertia was rewarded when, through a series of interpreters, we were told that workers were trying to clear the route. Indeed, it wasn't long before men with picks and shovels appeared, having liberated the tracks ahead. We pulled into Hekou, across the border from Lao Cai in Vietnam, at about noon -- nearly two hours after the schedule in Kunming said we were to arrive in Hanoi.
The guidebooks say the Kunming-Hanoi train has been in service for the past seven years, enough time certainly for the Vietnamese and Chinese railway employees to have made clockwork out of the crossing. Those employees apparently were not on duty this particular day.
After our arrival, employees from both countries gathered on the platform to solve the twice-a-week riddle of how to carry passengers from China to Vietnam without letting a Chinese train pass into Vietnam. To accomplish this, our train was stripped to a single car to accommodate those of us continuing to Hanoi. A dilapidated Vietnamese car appeared on the rear to create what appeared to be bilateral travel, but then the Chinese engine rolled away and a Vietnamese engine, toylike by comparison, attached itself to the front.

JUST as the quiz-team leaders were nearing a solution, the extra-credit problem arrived in the form of four Bangladeshi students from Hanoi. Having made a day trip across the border, they now wanted to return. Problem: their visas to re-enter Vietnam weren't in order, but their Chinese visas didn't allow them to stay. China said they had to go back; Vietnam wouldn't take them.
Compounding the confusion, someone realized that there was now a Chinese car sandwiched in the middle of a Vietnamese train. A conductor boarded to shoo us all into the Vietnamese car while a clutch of railway workers on the platform yelled at one another in their respective languages.
By 4 p.m., the two sides had worn themselves into agreement. The Vietnamese engine lugged the Chinese car onto the next track and then returned. A grubby Vietnamese kitchen car was tacked onto the rear and, Bangladeshis on board, we eased across the border.
Immigration officials board the train in Lao Cai to check passports and glance into luggage, so after a brief encounter we were hurtling through the night along the Red River. We adjourned to the kitchen car to celebrate our arrival in Vietnam over tepid beers.
A drenched Hanoi station materialized outside our window at 1 a.m. -- 15 hours behind schedule. It was dark and quiet, and the gates were padlocked. So convincingly had the station shut for the night that we had to persuade the few remaining station employees that we had the right to be released.
Though it lacked the towering department stores of Kunming and Chengdu, Hanoi was in full capitalist embrace just the same. Vietnam had signed a trade pact with the United States while I was in Yunnan. Already, Hanoi's shelves were stocked with Gillette shaving cream, Head & Shoulders shampoo and Colgate toothpaste.
While both China and Vietnam appear open to trade from the rest of the world, the border they share is only semi-permeable, it seems. For no matter how comradely these Communist neighbors may say they are, they still won't accept each other's currency. Neither the hotel, nor the foreign-bank branches -- not even the government-run banks -- would trade Vietnamese dong for my Chinese renminbi. Vietnam and China may be fellow travelers on the road to globalization, but if the crossing at Lao Cai is any indication, they won't be bunking together.

HEADLINE: HOTEL CHECK-IN: T-1 LINES AND BATH BALMS;
Woodinville, Wash.: A rustic lodge with bath oils, granola and digital toys

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK; SAM HOWE VERHOVEK is a correspondent for The Times based in Seattle.

 BODY:
Given the fluctuating trajectories of Microsoft stock and the local dot-com economy, the new Willows Lodge may ultimately prove to be an idea whose time comes and goes and comes again.
A luxurious lodge-style resort, the Willows is in Woodinville, Wash., a town at the eastern edge of the Seattle suburbs near the software giant in Redmond and the hundreds of other high-tech companies that have congregated on the other side of Lake Washington. In fact, Microsoft was playing host to something called a "Leading Your Business" meeting at the 88-room lodge when my wife, Lisa, and I spent the night recently. The next morning, a casually dressed crowd of apparent conferees could be found huddled around a laptop in the lodge library. 
 Woodinville has a rustic charm, including wineries and lots of antiques shops. We were suitably impressed by the Willows, which opened in September, from the moment we stepped into the magnificent lobby, meticulously crafted from stone and several kinds of wood, including Douglas fir that was reclaimed from a 100-year-old building at the Port of Portland, in Oregon, then pleasingly sanded and waxed.
Given our getaway mood, the state-of-the-art digital technology at the Willows Lodge -- high-speed Internet connections, dual-line cordless phones and the like -- was hardly a principal source of appeal, though such features would obviously be important for a business traveler. And, come to think of it, the digital temperature control on the shower was fun to fool around with, as were the 27-inch stereo television and the CD player.
Still, all that high-tech stuff seems to mesh seamlessly into the more dominant lodge-style atmosphere of the place. When we checked in, the friendly clerk at the desk offered us a glass of sparkling water, then took us right up to our room.
It was a good thing he came with us, for we needed a bit of help figuring out all the futuristic dimmers and other controls, not to mention the button that controlled the gas jet in the large stone fireplace. There was a lot of reclaimed wood -- in the headboard, side tables, fireplace mantle and high rafter beams -- and stone as well, including a wonderful marble Mexican bowl that served as the basin for the sink. The walls were painted in hushed, earthy tones of olive, yellow and brown, perhaps a bit like the colors Starbucks might choose if it ever decides to go into the hotel business. The linens were Italian, the lamb's-wool pads under the sheets Australian, the coffee French-press.
After freshening up and having a drink from the honor bar in the room, which also offered herbal candles and bath balms, we explored the Northwest coast native paintings and sculptures that were placed throughout the lodge; the lighting, screens and pale-blond wood also reflect an Oriental aesthetic.
Just across the driveway from the lobby is the Barking Frog, a bistro-style restaurant that has an extensive selection of Northwest wines, including some made at the Chateau Ste. Michelle and Columbia wineries right there in Woodinville. Scheduled to join it sometime early next year is the Herbfarm, a wildly popular restaurant renowned for its four-star multicourse tasting meals featuring the freshest of Northwest ingredients. The Herbfarm, whose original home in Fall City burned down in 1997, and which has been in nearby Issaquah since then, may well, in time, become the Willows' prime drawing card.
The Barking Frog has a striking communal table set around a large fire, perfect for a rainy winter evening, though we opted for an even cozier table for two. The menu included an autumn salad of mixed greens with crispy blue cheese, Belgian endive and sauteed apples, as well as Chilean sea bass, pepper-seared ahi tuna, lacquered Alaskan halibut and lamb chops drizzled with pesto essence -- all very good though not outstanding. We passed on desserts, but they looked good, especially the chestnut tiramisu and the gratin of pineapple with tropical fruit. The tab came to $140 with wine and tip.
The Northwest wine list (in categories such as "loud and woolly," "lush and jammy," "round and woody," and "tart and lucid") is extensive.
Early the next morning, after a Continental breakfast of coffee, juice, fruit and granola (included in the room rate), we had a bit of time to explore the gardens, with a lot of Asian-themed art, rock displays and bonsai, as well as four fountains placed in such a way that one seems to hear water anywhere one strolls.
The lodge is also near the 29-mile Sammamish River Trail, which winds through the surrounding countryside and connects with other trails that lead all the way back to Seattle; a waiter at the Barking Frog said bicyclists sometimes made it out there from the city for weekend brunch.
Sadly, we had to head back to work, so, at least on this stay, we had time neither for a bike ride nor for an excursion to the impressive spa, which includes a workout room and outdoor hot tub. But we hope to return, perhaps even for work; if Microsoft ever invites your company to a "Leading Your Business" conference at the Willows, tell the boss it sounds like a demanding assignment, but you're willing to go.
The Willows Lodge, 14580 Northeast 145th Street, Woodinville, Wash. 98072, (425) 424-3900, (877) 424-3930; www.willowslodge .com. Rooms from $220 to $290; suites, $350 to $750.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
In a Leftist's Lens, The 'Common Man' Of a Dark Decade

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
THERE is a photograph of a despairing man, his face buried in his hands, sitting beside a poster for Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times." There is another of a woman standing glumly beside the empty window of a kosher poultry shop. Others: a man talks to a woman who has nervously raised the gloves in her hand to her mouth. Artists march with placards. Men sit around on benches, next to one another but effectively alone. A heavy woman and a thin one seriously, worriedly, study the signs in a travel bureau. This is how the streets of New York looked to Ben Shahn in the 1930's.
Around 1932, Shahn (1898-1969), a painter, acquired a Leica. Walker Evans taught him how to print and, as Shahn recalled it, gave him laconic instructions on exposure: "F/9 on the sunny side of the street, F/4.5 on the shady side of the street. For one-twentieth of a second, hold your camera steady." 
 Shahn was never much more technically competent than that, and he didn't much care. He said photography was "a mind, an eye, but not an art." He said he took pictures solely for his own use, meaning as references for his paintings, yet during the 1930's he was eager to have his photographs published as widely as possible. Not a professional photographer, he nonetheless photographed for the Farm Security Administration from 1935, the year it began, until 1938. Not an expert technician, he had an expert eye and, unfettered by the standard rules, took some daring license with the camera.
"Ben Shahn's New York: The Photography of Modern Times," more than 150 photographs, drawings, paintings and mural studies, is at New York University's Grey Art Gallery through Jan. 27. The exhibition was organized by Deborah Martin Kao, Laura Katzman and Jenna Webster, who are also responsible for an impressive scholarly catalog with the same title (Yale University Press). Ms. Kao and Ms. Webster are on the staff of the Fogg Art Museum, which owns Shahn's photography collection.
The D. C. Moore Gallery on Fifth Avenue has a show of Shahn's drawings through Dec. 29, and the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo is to exhibit a selection of his photographs, different in many respects from the Grey Art Gallery's, from Friday to Jan. 20.
Shahn's artistic reputation was established by 1932 by a group of paintings titled "The Passion of Sacco and Vanzetti." Both style and subject announced his commitment to social realism and leftist causes. When he started these paintings, he was not working with a camera but was already heavily involved with photography, for he depended heavily on newspaper photographs for "Sacco and Vanzetti." Throughout his career, Shahn extensively collected and diligently filed newspaper and magazine photographs.
His frequent dependence on photographs for his art has been pointed out before, but one of the strong points of this strong show is how extensive the comparative material is.l Newspaper photographs that Shahn collected and used as models for other works are on view: see the painting "Girl Skipping Rope" and the newspaper photo on which Shahn based the girl's figure. More often, Shahn's paintings and prints are teamed with photographs he took himself; "Seurat's Lunch," for instance, a painting of a man sitting outside a store with a facade lovingly painted all over with spots, is placed next to a photograph of just such a man and just such a store.
His photographs are intimate views of street life, close-ups of subjects unaware their pictures are being taken. He used a right-angle viewfinder and depicted himself using it; the device itself can be seen on two of his cameras in "Ben Shahn's New York." With his eye to the viewfinder, he would face north, say, while his lens pointed west, and the view west was what he saw. Subjects looking at him saw him staring in another direction and apparently had no idea that the perfectly visible lens was staring directly at them. Odd as that seems, it must indicate that street photography was not yet so common and that "the common man" did not yet assume he was an object worth studying.
The subterfuge was not new. Paul Strand employed it in the 1910's, Walker Evans in the 1930's. Photographers were already uneasy about the ability of small cameras to commit image theft in various ways.Shahn was blithely free of guilt.
His far-left politics meant that he identified with the people he was photographing rather than with isolated bohemians intent on creating art for the intelligentsia and art for art's sake. This was an approved leftist position. Stuart Davis in 1935 declared that the artist "participates in a world crisis" and "recognizes his alignment . . . with the workers."
Shahn was engaged in reform but against sentiment, against idealizing the poor; he said it was "alright to have a soft heart, so long as you have a hard eye." He sought a public art -- he painted several public murals -- that would serve revolutionary and reform causes and move people to action. Photography was the exemplary medium in this program, a new combination of art and document that could be seen, understood and even made by the proletariat. Shahn saw it as a step on the road to creating a revolutionary public art.
An era gets the technology that suits its needs or finds a way to wrap its aspirations around what it gets. The later 1920's and 1930's got the 35-millimeter camera, a recording instrument of, by and for the people, a means of registering the life of the masses in mass-produced publications. Coinciding historical, political, economic and technological events had turned a spotlight on those masses.
The Russian Revolution, the abrupt collapse of boom times that had been built on American technological prowess, the New Deal programs that made the federal government the guarantor of sustenance for large segments of the populace: all focused attention on the omnipresent "common man" (and woman). In 1937, Robert and Helen Lynd wrote "Middletown," a widely read sociological report on an "average" American city, and Life published a photo essay on the town that reached far greater numbers than the book did.
At the moment this "common man" became crucially important, the engines of production and developments in the media -- cinema, radio, tabloids, photo magazines -- had raised mass consumption and the mass audience to extraordinary levels. The camera, already implicated in the creation of the audience, became that audience's ideal reporter, revered as the most representative and truthful documentary form in a time with the utmost respect for documentary. The 35-millimeter camera -- unobtrusive, fast, able to take pictures without flash -- took to the streets, where the mass of people (especially if they were unemployed) milled about and could be caught in the very act of living their lives.
Europeans had had a vital street life since shortly after the middle of the 19th century, when Paris boulevards were built with sidewalks, but sidewalk life in American cities, except for tenement areas, did not become so important until the 1930's. In New York in that decade, a lot of photographers trained their eyes on street life, some of them associated with the Photo League, some with the Works Progress Administration, some with the Farm Security Administration and some on their own.
The idea that quick takes on ordinary life would reveal something factually or even politically important was implicit in the earliest hand-camera photographs of the late 19th century. But outside of news photography, pictures like these did not have a major place in photography until the 1920's in Europe and the 1930's in America. Newsreels, which Shahn watched avidly and which he said influenced him, had something to do with the upgraded importance of fast snaps of minor occasions. So did photographically illustrated magazines and newspapers that needed human-interest stories to fill space.
Feature films made a difference, too. Silent film and the close-up had enlarged the belief that emotions and information could be read instantly in the slightest lift of an eyebrow, and popular psychology hammered home the notion that gesture and facial expression revealed more than was intended. The quickening tempo of life and the sense that information had to be abbreviated because time was shrinking fast had been underscored in the 1920's by the founding of Time magazine and Reader's Digest.
The stolen, candid photograph, an instant slice of life, stepped onto this track as if by personal invitation. Shahn came fresh to the form, and to the camera itself, and never intended to make his living from photography. Yet he made some images that were radical in style as well as intent, taking advantage of the medium's special properties. A few of his close-up pictures, with people ranged horizontally across the picture plane, suddenly open up to deep or sharply angled perspectives. A few cut off foreground figures so abruptly that they are indecipherable. He invited disjunctions, not of a surrealist kind but of every other. Three men of different classes and ethnic backgrounds, all looking in different directions, are contained within one frame but separated from one another by architectural elements and shadows. Single figures appear at odd points in a composition or are entirely left out of groups they appear to belong to, and every person in a group may seem oddly or unhappily isolated.
Shahn welcomed chance into his photographs more willingly than most of his peers. He photographed modern times: hard pressed, anxious, half lived on the streets. He also employed the photography of the modern time he lived in: rapid, spontaneous, open to accident, even courting the kind of accident that only happens in photographs. His instrument and images fit the era they were trying to convert. In Shahn's hands and many others, the camera was politically motivated, with images that began in public and reached as large a public as possible: an art that would eventually change public perception even as it aimed to change public life.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2482 words

HEADLINE: Q. Gift for the Teacher?

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
FOR teachers at Brayton Elementary in Summit, the holidays had become too much of a good thing.
Gone were the days of handmade cards and "I Love You" coffee mugs. Students at the neighborhood school -- and in this case a very comfortable neighborhood -- were bringing teachers expensive perfumes, generous gift certificates and tote bags full of costly goodies.
"New Jersey has some very wealthy communities," said Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association. "For some parents, giving a $200 gift certificate is like others giving a sundae coupon to Dairy Queen." 
 Indeed, in school districts all around the state, tickets to Broadway shows, designer handbags, monogrammed stationery and little blue boxes from Tiffany were making their way onto teachers' desks.
Finally Summit, one of the wealthier towns in New Jersey, put its foot down. "Appreciative parents were giving wonderful gifts, but the teachers were feeling uncomfortable," said Cheryl Moretz, the principal at Brayton. "We wanted to get back to what the season was all about."
Three years ago, after a meeting with the teachers, Dr. Moretz began sending letters home encouraging parents and students to show their appreciation with small handmade gifts or letters and to give to the community during the holiday season. She also talked to Parent Teacher Association representatives and asked them to spread the word that less was better.
The children were asked to bring in a wrapped gift for a needy child and place it in the holiday house outside the school office and to donate canned goods for a community food drive. "It's been very well received," said Dr. Moretz. "It has taken some of the pressure off the holiday season."
Today, Summit is only one of a number school districts in the state with policies intended to discourage the giving of expensive gifts, instead suggesting homemade tokens or notes of appreciation. In other districts, policies go so far as to state that the cost of a gift must not exceed a certain amount.
The New Jersey School Boards Association, an 80-year-old organization that represents more than 600 boards, does not have an established gift policy, but according to Mr. Yaple, the association has recommended that boards address the issue of gifts with teachers and staff.
Many boards have policies, in part because districts do not want to give the appearance of favoritism, he said, nor do they want children of less-affluent families to feel bad.
"It can give the appearance of currying favor," Mr. Yaple said. "It might be more difficult to suspend Johnny if his parents just gave a $200 gift certificate to the nicest restaurant in town. It's not really a case of parents trying to buy a favor. They truly care about the teacher and they want to give a nice gift."
Rosemary Yates, who has taught kindergarten in Cherry Hill for 31 years, said: "I appreciate that families want to say thank you. "I don't look at it as a bribe. But if the district discontinued it, that would be O.K. too."
Most of the gifts Ms. Yates has received have been small tokens -- homemade baked goods and knickknacks. Occasionally, she said, she received a gift certificate, the largest one for $25, which she said she felt was more than one family would usually spend on a gift.
In some instances, however, teachers had few qualms about accepting lavish presents.
In 1977, a case even went to the state commissioner of education over a $350 cash gift that a group of high school students in Hillside had given to a teacher. When the school board issued a letter of reprimand to the teacher, the case ended up before Commissioner Fred G. Burke. Ultimately, the commissioner ordered that the letter be removed from the teacher's file because the board did not have a clear gift policy. As for the $350, it had to be used for "general pupil activities."
But the commissioner made clear the state's disapproval of excessive gifts. While teachers could certainly accept flowers or tokens, the ruling stated that larger gifts should not be permitted.
"Any policy in the public schools which would sanction such gifts is one which would invite abuse and promote undesirable competition," the ruling stated.
In the last 20 years, several boards -- including Ramapo Indian Hills Regional, Matawan-Aberdeen Regional, River Vale, Bloomingdale, Freehold Borough, Marlboro Township, Pennsgrove-Carneys Point, Princeton Regional, Glen Ridge and West Windsor-Plainsboro, have enacted policies discouraging gifts that are more than tokens.
The Hopewell Valley Board of Education is also considering a policy that would allow only modest gifts.
In addition, a number of private schools have gift policies. While Moorestown Friends School does not have a formal policy, expensive gifts are strongly discouraged.
But these are not easy policies to enforce, and not all districts publicize their policies on a regular basis.
The public schools in Montclair have a policy that discourage the giving of gifts to school employees, suggesting instead that the "more appropriate" way to show appreciation would be writing a letter.
"I find that parents don't adhere to it," said Kathy Lindsay, assistant principal of Nishuane Elementary School in Montclair, which has 620 pupils in kindergarten through second grade. Ms. Lindsaysaid she also understands that children and parents wanted to give gifts during the holidays and at the end of the year.
"There are two sides to this," she said. "I still have ornaments children gave me 20 years ago. I think of them every year when I take them out. The other side is that not every child can bring something in. There's some poor little soul saying, 'I didn't bring anything for you.' "
Instead, Ms. Lindsay has encouraged parents to make donations to the Montclair Fund for Excellence, which provides grants and scholarships, or to buy a book for the school library in a teacher's name.
She is not the only teacher who is sensitive to the economic differences among the pupils in her class, and to those situations in which holiday giving can make a child feel left out. For instance, in the early 1980's, administrators at the Princeton Regional School District adopted a gift policy prohibiting its staff from accepting anything other than small tokens from students and their parents.
"One kid comes in with a cut-crystal vase and the kid next to her comes in with nothing," said William Cirullo, the principal of Riverside Elementary School in Princeton. "Think how uncomfortable it is for the teacher. It has to be a level playing field. That's critical in the culture of our school. You don't want to put any child in an embarrassing, competitive position. You have to take money out of the picture."
Likewise, the West Windsor-Plainsboro District has also adopted a policy that discourages gift giving and encourages exchanging handmade items or notes.
And in Mercer and Middlesex Counties, according to Gerri Hutner, the spokeswoman for the district, parents sponsor breakfasts and write notes and cards to the teachers during Teacher Appreciation Week.
"The motive behind it is wonderful," Ms. Hutner said. "The lesson is to try to take away from material goods, but it's hard in our society."
The National Parent Teacher Association does not have a policy regarding gift giving, though several local organizations have taken on the issue because members felt that some guidelines were needed. Sometimes teachers initiated the discussion; in other instances, it was the parents.
Last year, when Robin Schlager became co-president of the Nishuane School PTA in Montclair, she and other board members decided to end a program in which $3,000 in PTA funds were spent on gifts for teachers -- each of the 120 employees, teachers and support staff, received a $25 cash bonus before the holiday break.
"I was a little disturbed by this," Ms. Schlager said. "It was nice and generous, but was it appropriate?"
Instead, the organization voted to have a catered holiday luncheon -- which costs from $800 to $1,000 -- in the library. In addition, parents donate homemade desserts, and each staff member receives a roll of gift wrap from the school's fund-raising sale.
Nonetheless, Mrs. Schlager said that gift giving could still get out of hand, even when parents had the best of intentions. In some cases, she said, teachers have received tickets to Broadway shows and gift certificates from department stores.
"The competition is a little over the top, especially in a town like Montclair, where some people have a lot and some don't."
To put a stop to situations like that, the PTA at the Elizabeth Haddon School in Haddonfield adopted a policy two years ago allowing class parents to collect no more than $5 a family once a year for a teacher's gift. In addition, the card must be signed by all the children -- whether or not their families contributed. And money was not to be collected at holiday time.
"Students and teachers alike celebrate different kinds of holidays in different ways," said Jennifer O'Neill, who was president of the group when the policy was voted on. Some classes were collecting at holidays, at the time of teachers' birthdays and at the end of the year, she said, and some collections were ranging from $10 to $14 from each child.
"There are people in our community who don't make whatever that magic number is," Ms. O'Neill said, "and it was a stretch for them."
At the Central Elementary School in the same district in Haddonfield, teachers told parents and the principal that the money being spent on gifts for them could be used to benefit the school.
"They felt the money would be used more productively for classroom enrichment," said Linda Tuno, a former president of the PTA at Central. "It was really teacher-driven."
Four years ago, the PTA at Central agreed to run the Holiday Gift Fund, which is billed as "an alternative way to show appreciation to Central School teachers." Parents send in a donation for any amount and the money is evenly divided among the teachers to be used for classroom enrichment and supplies.
"We had to make clear that it was voluntary, and that this idea did come from the teachers," Mrs. Tuno said. Teachers receive a gift card saying that the family made a contribution, but no amount is listed.
"It takes out 'What do I give, what do I give?' " said Mrs. Tuno.
In Cherry Hill, parents do not even collect money for winter holiday gifts, said Maggie Suender, PTA president at the Russell Knight Elementary School.
"Not everybody celebrates gift-giving holidays," Ms. Suender said. "Our community is becoming more and more diverse. We don't want to put anyone is an uncomfortable position."
And at the Liberty Corner School in the Bernards Township Public School District, Dr. Kathy Pecoraro, the principal, sends notes through the parent teacher organization discouraging gift giving.
"Teachers did feel uncomfortable very often," Dr. Pecoraro said. But it is not a policy that is easily enforced. "Can we stop parents?" she asked. "Probably not. When parents come to me expounding on the excellent quality of teaching, I say, 'Write a letter. Those notes are so precious. They are more powerful than gift giving.' "
Yet some educators feel that limiting or prohibiting the giving of gifts at holiday time can rob the child of the joy of giving -- particularly those who want to surprise the teacher with a holiday package.
In 14 years of teaching elementary school, said Claudia Raffa, a third-grade teacher at the Glenwood School in Short Hills, part of the Millburn Township School District, she has received many beautiful gifts that parents and children used to show their appreciation. She has received 500 pieces of monogrammed stationery, a Dooney & Bourke purse, which sells for about $200, and many gift certificates.
"They are very thoughtful," Ms. Raffa said. "The gifts come from the heart. Teaching where I teach, I know they are doing it because they want to."
She has also received several books for the classroom, and parents have also donated books and magazines to inner-city schools in her name, she said.
"The nicest part," Ms. Raffa said, "is that they are always accompanied by touching notes."
Lois Infanger, who has taught in the Millburn schools for 14 years said, "I've never wished Millburn had a policy." She does not recall receiving gifts that were excessive. "I'm very appreciative, and I don't keep track by any means."
In the past few years, most of the gifts have been store certificates given from the entire class -- usually for under $100, said Ms. Infanger, who currently teaches fifth grade at the South Mountain School.
And at the Friends School of Mullica Hill, "our kids are free to do whatever moves them," said Paula Cera, a parent who works in the school office. Middle school students usually collect money, and teachers receive a cash gift of $75 to $100, she said. "Our teachers are pretty well loved."
Indeed, Sandy Finio, who has taught kindergarten for 14 years at the Mark Newbie Elementary School in Collingswood, a working-class community in South Jersey, said she thought that taking away the practice of gift giving denied a small child the chance to enjoy being the giver.
On the day before the holiday break, she fills the table at the back of the room with craft material. If children come in without a gift, they can go to the table and make something.
"It's the worst feeling when you're 5 years old and you don't have a gift for your teacher," she said. "They are all thrilled to give you something. They will rush back and make a gift. I make a big deal about everything. That's essential. If you could see how much they love it. It has nothing to do with the cost."
An expensive gift would be "inappropriate," Ms. Finio said. But the gifts she has received over the years -- including many that fill the shelves in her classroom -- are mugs, candles, knickknacks and wooden apples. One mother painted the school building on slate and put Mrs. Finio's name on it.
"I've never gotten a Gucci bag," she said. "We're not that close to the Short Hills Mall."
She would rather have the small gift picked out by a child than money collected by a class parent and put into a gift certificate. "The kids have nothing to do with that gift," she said. "Would you give a 5-year-old money for their birthday?"
Because of that, Nancy Connell, whose two daughters go to school in Collingswood, said she had always let the children decide what would be the best way to show appreciation to the teacher. They usually pick a gift, sometimes something edible -- and under $10.
"You don't want to do too much," Ms. Connell said. "There is a fine line you don't want to cross. The kids really want to do it, and that's why we do it. They love their teachers."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Conflicting Rulings On Co-ops

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
A NEW YORK appeals court issued a ruling last month that complicated an already confusing legal situation regarding the rights of tenants who rent vacant co-op or condominium apartments from an original sponsor after the conversion.
In a case entitled Park West Village Associates v. Nishoika, a three-judge appellate court in Manhattan unanimously affirmed a trial court judge's determination that a tenant who rents a vacant co-op or condominium apartment from the building's original sponsor has no right to a renewal lease on the expiration of the existing lease. And while that decision conforms with the opinions of experts in co-op and condominium law, it is directly at odds with a decision rendered in October 1999 by a Brooklyn court of equal standing. 
 In that case, Paikoff v. Harris, a Brooklyn appeals panel ruled that tenants who rent vacant apartments from a sponsor -- even those who rent years after the conversion -- have the right to remain in their apartments indefinitely, provided they are willing to pay market rent. One practical effect of this would be that sponsors would be blocked from selling an apartment that had tenants, since they could not be evicted at the end of their lease.
Lawyers say that the conflicting decisions essentially afford different sets of rights and protections to tenants depending on where they happen to live. "Confusion now reigns," said Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who is also vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums.
Mr. Weinstein said that the widely held and generally accepted belief among real estate lawyers was that tenants who occupied co-op or condominium apartments in New York City before conversion are protected by Section 352eeee of the General Business law -- also known as the Martin Act -- the state law governing noneviction conversions. Generally speaking, he said, the Martin Act provides that nonpurchasing rent-regulated tenants are entitled to keep their regulated status for as long as they occupy their apartments. Non-rent-regulated tenants who took occupancy of their apartments before the conversion, Mr. Weinstein said, are protected by the Martin Act against increases to more than market rent and cannot be evicted except for cause -- such as nonpayment of rent or illegal use of the apartment.
At the same time, he said, the common understanding among co-op and condominium lawyers had always been that tenants who rented their apartments from the sponsor after the date of the conversion would have no such protection against eviction. As a result, Mr. Weinstein said, sponsors were legally permitted to decline to renew the lease of such a tenant -- and evict the tenant -- when the existing lease expired.
That, however, changed somewhat with the ruling in the Paikoff case in Brooklyn. That ruling, Mr. Weinstein said, essentially created a new class of protected tenants.
"The court in the Paikoff case completely misread the intent of the Legislature," he said. "The Legislature clearly did not intend to create a new class of protected tenants."
The position taken by Mr. Weinstein -- and the many lawyers who agree with him -- was upheld last month in the Manhattan appellate court's ruling. But while that ruling sets forth the law that must now be followed by trial judges in the First Department -- the judicial district that covers Manhattan -- it does not change the law resulting from the Paikoff decision in the Second Department, the judicial district that covers Brooklyn.
In fact, the geography of judicial districts is itself a potential cause of further confusion about which interpretation of the law applies in a given area.
Joel E. Miller, a Queens real estate lawyer, said that since the Paikoff case was decided in the Second Department, which has jurisdiction over Queens and Staten Island as well as Brooklyn, the trial courts in those boroughs will probably feel compelled to follow the Paikoff court's interpretation.
At the same time, he said, it is likely that trial courts in the First Department -- which covers the Bronx in addition to Manhattan -- will apply the interpretation of the ruling reached last month in the Park West case. "In a sense, you could say that the law will be applied in different ways in different places," Mr. Miller said.
Moreover, he said, as a practical matter, the conflicting appellate rulings may not be reconciled anytime soon. That, he said, is because it is unlikely that a sponsor will find it economically feasible to take a nonrenewal eviction case far enough through the trial and appeal process to get the Paikoff decision overturned.
"What's more likely to happen is the sponsor will say, 'If the guy is willing to pay a market-rate rent, why not just let him stay until he's ready to leave on his own?' " Mr. Miller said. He added, however, that a resolution could occur somewhat more quickly if sale prices of apartments in Brooklyn and Queens rise to the point at which it becomes more profitable to sell than to rent.
Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan co-op lawyer who is president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that any continuation of the current state of affairs would be problematic for co-ops and condominiums.
"From our perspective, the Paikoff ruling is not a good thing," Mr. Luxemburg said. "What we are most interested in is completing the conversion. And the only way to complete the conversion is to get the building 100 percent owner-occupied."
Colleen McGuire, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, sees the conflict as a good thing -- at least for tenants in the districts covered by the Second Department.
"At the very least we can keep tenants in their apartments for as long as they are willing to pay market rents," she said. "And at worst, we can use the Paikoff case as a bargaining lever to buy more time in cases where it looks like a sponsor might be willing to take the case all the way up to the Court of Appeals," the state's highest court.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
427 Rental Units for Active-Adult Retirement Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.

 BODY:
A DEVELOPER known for rental properties has broadened his offerings in the active-adult retirement market with a 427-apartment development that will differ from most such communities by allowing residents to lease, rather than purchase, their apartments. The development, Woodbridge Hills, will offer people 55 and over housing as well as social and recreational activities.
Woodbridge Hills is to be made up of 14 low-rise buildings with 23 to 32 apartments each spread over 21.7 acres just off the intersection of Green Street and Route 1. It will also have a 5,000-square-foot clubhouse with, among other things, an exercise room, a business center, an outdoor swimming pool and walking trails, according to Mark Fisch, president of Continental Properties of Woodbridge. It is developing the $45 million project using its own money and bank financing over the next three years. 
 New Jersey, especially Ocean County, has long been a hub for active-adult residences. But they have usually been built as condominium apartments and town houses or as single-family detached homes for residents to buy, not rent.
While new rental projects for those 62 and over are being built in the state, they generally do not offer such social and recreational amenities as clubhouses, which are common in active-adult developments, as well as in apartment complexes without age restrictions. Many rental apartment projects for older people are also restricted to those with low and moderate incomes.
Continental Properties has fused the rental and the active-adult ideas in Woodbridge Hills, which Howard S. Rappaport, a company vice president, described as a hybrid. "It will provide an alternative housing option and fill an underserved niche in the active-adult market," Mr. Rappaport said. "What we will be selling here is lifestyle."
Continental owns or manages more than 10,000 rental units in the state. It has also recently been involved with building active-adult, for-sale, single-family-home communities and has five such projects under way or planned in the state, totaling 973 units.
With the graying of New Jersey, and the nation, demographics continue to fuel the demand for all kinds of housing for older people, including active-adult residences. Of the state's estimated population of 8.1 million last year, 22.5 percent, or 1.83 million, were 55 or over, according to the latest census figures. That number, up from 1.7 million in 1990, is expected to grow to 2.23 million in 2010.
In Middlesex County, 21.5 percent of the 717,949 residents are 55 and over, and in Woodbridge, 20 percent of 97,000 residents are.
While the production of active-adult housing for sale continues at a brisk pace, there are several reasons why a rental alternative has been slow to catch on, industry professionals said. Among them is the difficulty of finding sites that local communities are likely to approve for rentals. Sites also must be able to accommodate a high enough density for such projects to make economic sense given their requisite recreational components, said James Robbins, who heads a housing consulting concern bearing his name in Fairfield.
William Becker, a consultant in Teaneck who specializes in active-adult housing, added that despite the hurdles there was a market for such rentals. There are, he said, "people who don't want to pay the average $150,000 it costs today to buy a home in a for-sale active-adult community," or "don't want to be tied to the house with a mortgage."
Mr. Becker said a rental alternative would be particularly appealing to single professionals, people who have lost a spouse and those who live in another part of the country for part of the year.
Agreeing with that assessment is Nathan Slovin, executive vice president of New Jersey Apartment Association, a trade group in East Brunswick. The idea of active-adult rentals, Mr. Slovin said, is sound because such projects will offer people the flexibility now enjoyed in developments with no age restrictions. "Not everyone in their retirement or preretirement years wants to buy or is ready to relocate to Arizona or Florida," he said.
That the state's overall rental market is strong is also on the side of such a trend. According to the apartment association, the rental vacancy rate dropped by one to two percentage points in the last year to less than 5 percent in north Jersey, excluding urban centers like Newark. The rate is slightly higher in central New Jersey and under 10 percent in South Jersey
IN turn, developers continue to build. Some 7,500 new rental apartments are on the market or will come onto the market in six months, Mr. Slovin said. With active-adult rentals, he said, Continental has found "a different approach to and niche within the industry."
Other developers may follow. Mr. Becker said that builders of the 6,000 active-adult residences under construction or planned in the state had indicated that as many as 1,000 units potentially could become rentals.
Continental Properties got involved two and a half years ago with Woodbridge Hills. Though the project is the company's first development in Woodbridge, it has built rental apartment properties in nearby Edison, Mr. Rappaport said, adding, "We know the area so we pursued the seller of the land."
The seller, Elizabethtown Gas, was winding down its maintenance, distribution and trucking operations on the site, which Continental agreed to buy in 1997. Mr. Rappaport said the property "lends itself more to a rental than a for-sale project" because at 21.7 acres it is too small to accommodate the number of single-family homes necessary for his company's more traditional active-adult projects to work. In addition, it is off Route 1 and not far from both the Woodbridge Center Mall and the Menlo Park Mall, he added.
The company took title to the property in September. It spent the intervening years getting the site rezoned from commercial to residential use and securing the needed state and local approvals.
Woodbridge Hills is supported by the community. It is, James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, said, "a thoughtful project, which largely responds to the need for increased market-rate senior housing in Woodbridge and Middlesex County." He pointed out that there was a two-year waiting list for the income-restricted rental housing run by the Woodbridge Housing Authority.
The project, he added, will offer "an attractive opportunity to help seniors remain in Woodbridge in a more manageable and affordable way" than living in large single-family detached homes and without making, "a complicated investment in real estate." At the same time, Mr. McGreevey said, the project "will not have a deleterious impact" on municipal services like schools or local roads.
The 427 apartments at Woodbridge Hills, designed by Roth Architects of Voorhees, will be in three-story, stone and wood-sided elevator buildings. All the one- and two-bedroom units, with 800 to 1,100 square feet, will be equipped with washers and dryers and wired for advanced telecommunications, including high-speed Internet access. Those on the ground floor will have patios, while upper-level units will have balconies.
The project is expected to attract residents mainly between 55 and 62 and from Woodbridge and Middlesex County, Mr. Rappaport said, adding, however, that it will also draw people from across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in Staten Island.
Monthly rents are expected to be $950 to $1,100, which will be competitive to rentals not restricted by age in the area, he said. He added that the rents would include the use of the project's recreational amenities, which will be built at the same time as the housing. Initial occupancy will begin by late next spring.
Mr. Robbins, the consultant, said that, while the project's amenities were not grand, the project still "will serve as a litmus test" of what people will be willing to pay in rent for an active-adult style of living.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Ground Is Broken for UConn Football Stadium

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
LESS than a year after the United Technologies Corporation announced that it would donate a 75-acre site here for a new football stadium for the University of Connecticut, bulldozers and backhoes are busy doing site preparation. The the first game is to be played at the stadium on Aug. 30, 2003, against Rutgers.
Construction of the $90 million, 600,000-square-foot, 40,000-seat stadium at 615 Silver Lane began in October on a crisp fall day as the earth-moving equipment waited in the background. 
 "It was a great football day, actually," said Thomas W. Andrea, a spokesman for United Technologies. "I think it made a lot of people realize this is really going to happen."
Matt J. Fleury, a spokesman for the Capital City Economic Development Authority, said, "This stadium is going to elevate the University of Connecticut football program to national prominence." The development authority was formed to oversee development of the stadium and the proposed $771 million Adriaen's Landing mixed-use development project less than two miles away on the Connecticut River in Hartford. "That stadium will be a linchpin to the future economic development in the vicinity," Mr. Fleury added.
Indeed, United Technologies is already considering uses for the rest of Rentschler Field, a 680-acre property that a subsidiary, Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, used as a private airport until six years ago.
Town officials say they have been told that the development will have a mix of housing, stores and possibly a research park, though Mr. Andrea said it is too soon to say.
"We're in the middle of a planning process so it's too early to talk about any definite proposals," Mr. Andrea said. "We don't want to create any expectations until we know exactly what's going in there." But the stadium will be integral to any development, he said.
Town officials said they were hopeful that the stadium, the rest of the Rentschler Field development and the Adriaen's Landing project will help to revitalize the entire capital area.
"We've got a huge parcel down there that's just crying for development and we hope that the stadium is going to be the catalyst that kicks it all off," said Anthony F. Kayser, chairman of the East Hartford Planning and Zoning Commission.
"If anybody had told me five years ago that football would have such a huge impact on my life, I wouldn't have believed it," said State Representative Melody A. Currey, a Democrat of East Hartford. "I never was a terribly big football fan, but I'm learning to like it.
"And when UConn puts a winning team in the stadium, it's going to put East Hartford on the map. Look at what's happened to UConn basketball -- who would have ever thought it would grow to what it is today?"
The only opposition has come from environmentalists who say that the former airfield represents one of the last large grassland habitats in the state. Nine birds on the state's endangered or threatened list were spotted during surveys last summer, and several dozen different species were making it their home.
Patty Pendergast, vice chairwoman of the Connecticut Ornithological Association and an active member of other environmental groups, said that while the birds might survive the stadium construction, further development of the site would push grasshopper sparrows, upland sandpipers and bobolinks off the property.
"East Hartford has some wonderful neighborhoods, almost like a Norman Rockwell painting, and they deserve a big, undeveloped field like that," Ms. Pendergast said. "It's always easier to build in a grassland, in a flat plain like this. Doing the right thing is hard, and the right thing in this case would be to redevelop the blighted areas in town first."
Rentschler Field is named for Fred Rentschler, who founded Pratt & Whitney in 1929. Amelia Earhart and Charles A. Lindbergh, the aviation pioneers,used the airstrip in its early years.
UCONN'S football team now plays in the 16,000-seat Memorial Stadium in Storrs on the school's main campus. It made the jump from Division I-AA ball to the top-level Division I-A this year, which requires a stadium of at least 35,000 seats. The school has obtained a waiver on the seating requirement since the stadium is under construction.
Mr. Andrea of United Technologies said that the company's president, George David, proposed the use of the property last November, after a deal to bring the New England Patriots to Connecticut fell apart. The state had proposed building a football stadium as part of Hartford's Adriaen's Landing project, which UConn would have used, but when the Patriots backed out, the stadium was dropped.
"We're Connecticut's largest private employer, and I think helping the state's largest public university kind of goes hand in hand with that," Mr. Andrea said. The stadium will be known as Rentschler Field for at least 15 years.
Madison Square Garden Inc., which manages the Hartford Civic Center, has been hired to manage the stadium as well, said Mr. Fleury of the Capital City Economic Development Authority.
"Certainly, their experience in the area is a plus, and we think that will create some synergies," Mr. Fleury said. "And their scale and experience as a manager of major venues was very attractive."
The stadium will cost the state almost $70 million, a consultant estimates. He adds that, with attendance averaging 18,000 per game in the first year and growing to 25,000 per game by the fifth year, revenue from ticket sales and concessions will cover the operating cost of the stadium and generate a small operating surplus over the life of the stadium.
Mr. Fleury said the stadium would generate a lot of money in taxes on the meals, lodging and other things people buy when they attend the games.
Mr. Fleury said the state would create an advisory board for the stadium that would include managers as well as town officials and area residents and businesses, to make sure any local issues are promptly addressed. In addition, the stadium will pay $1 million to $1.2 million a year to East Hartford in lieu of taxes, considerably more than the $40,000 the town now gets on the undeveloped land.
Mr. Andrea said United Technologies has retained Urban Strategies, a Toronto concern that has done several planning projects in the Hartford area, to prepare a development plan for the more than 600 acres left at the field. In addition, it has hired the Boston-based Spaulding & Slye for marketing and development work. United States Representative John B. Larson, Democrat of East Hartford, has been advocating a technology park for the site, town officials say, and United Technologies is said to be giving it serious consideration.
Michael P. Kirk, a spokesman for Mr. Larson, said the congressman had brought NASA officials on a tour of the property and was working with other government agencies to promote interest in the project. The proximity to a number of the nation's top universities as well as to the Pratt & Whitney engineering and research operation should be key draws, he said.
"His goal is to develop something that would bring a lot of education, a lot of science and a lot of research dollars into the state," Mr. Kirk said. In addition, the congressman is investigating what federal funds might be available to help in the construction of a research park.
Mr. Kayser, the zoning chairman, said that athough the state project did not need local approvals, that area was already zoned for mixed-use development, so that it was consistent with the town plan. The chief concern is traffic, he said, athough there are plans to eventually tie the site directly into Interstate 84 and Route 2, both major highways nearby, if the development of the property warrants it.
Noise from the site was also an issue, but the stadium will be gouged out of the former airfield, with the playing field 26 feet below grade, so the noise and the aesthetic impact should be minimized.
"They've been very accommodating to the town," Mr. Kayser said. "I think we were generally pleased with the plans."
Craig R. Stevenson, chairman of the town's Economic Development Commission, said the town was hopeful that the development would spark interest in an area that has been bypassed somewhat by Connecticut's economic boom.
"The Silver Lane area, in part, used to be a retail center, but with the opening of some of the suburban shopping malls it's fallen on hard times," Mr. Stevenson said.
The town has just completed a strategic plan that calls for a focus on entertainment-related businesses in the area around the stadium, which could include everything from restaurants to sports centers or an Imax theater, he said. There are about 100 undeveloped acres in the area in addition to the United Technologies land, he said, as well as a number of underused commercial buildings that have potential for reuse.
"The key is going to be to bring in uses that will make it a destination," Mr. Stevenson said. "They're only talking about having 6 football games and perhaps 20 major events a year there, but we want things that will bring people to town 365 days a year. We need people coming back week after week even if there's not a game."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVE;
At Cooper Square, a New Player Takes the Stage

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago -- or 30 or 40 for that matter -- the Cooper Square Committee would have scorned the redevelopment plan for three acres of urban renewal land off East Houston Street that a community task force worked out with the Giuliani administration a year ago. The committee is a nonprofit community development organization that formed four decades ago to resist the redevelopment plans of Robert Moses in the neighborhood.
But the other day Steve Herrick, the executive director of the Cooper Square Committee, said, "It's a good plan" -- not so much a ringing endorsement as a commentary on the impact of Manhattan's real estate market on the attitudes of a group that has been one of the city's leading community advocates for subsidized low-income, as opposed to market-rate, housing. In the years since the city-owned land has been ready for new construction, one problem or another has impeded it. 
 Now, without any additional public subsidies, a plan is moving forward that will produce 700,000 square feet of residential, commercial and community-facility space on this land. It has yet to enter the hearings stage of the land-use review process, but the wide support it has drawn augurs well for its prospects. This support has come despite the fact that in many respects it resembles a plan adopted almost 10 years ago that faltered over community wrangling.
There are to be about 600 new housing units, with 25 percent of them reserved for low-income tenants, plus a substantial 160,000 square feet of retail space and a community center of 30,000 square feet. And the developer is to pay the city $40.5 million for the land.
What might also surprise Mr. Herrick's predecessors as much as the plan itself is that the developer -- or more properly the managing member of the development partnership, formally known as Chrystie Venture Partners -- is new to the New York City scene. AvalonBay Communities, based in Alexandria, Va., is undertaking the Cooper Square project in partnership with Williams Jackson Ewing, a national retail developer based in Baltimore, and Blackacre Capital, a private investment firm in New York City. Phipps Houses, the New York-based nonprofit housing company, will participate as the developer and owner of a portion of the low-income apartments.
AvalonBay Communities is a real estate investment trust that owns 39,600 apartments in 136 developments nationwide. It has developed or redeveloped 23,000 of those apartments only within the last five years. The Cooper Square venture is its second foray into residential construction in the city. The first is the recently started Avalon Riverview, the second phase of development at Queens West on the East River in Long Island City.
Avalon Riverview will be a 32-story rental building with 372 market-rate apartments, a 130-car garage at the base, and 10,000 square feet of shops. Adjoining it will be an eight-story element with 80 apartments for the elderly, built with federal subsidies.
It is unusual for a national real estate company to undertake residential development in New York City, and even more unusual for it to take the path of bidding for a city-sponsored proposal. For most such companies, the major capital investment required at the beginning of a process of uncertain duration and outcome seems daunting. Companies experienced in the vagaries of New York City development are normally the only participants.
But the attraction is the chance to own new rental property in a market that is unlikely to become oversupplied with it. "Our strategy is to focus on the strongest markets," said Bryce Blair, president of AvalonBay. "The markets with the strongest constraints on supply over the long term will be the healthiest."
The phrase "constraints on supply" alludes to the difficulty of winning full site control and public approvals, and in multifamily development already completed or put into construction in the metropolitan area AvalonBay has had its share of these difficulties. It has completed projects within the last two years in Bronxville and Mamaroneck in Westchester County; in Nanuet in Rockland County; in Fort Lee, Jersey City and Florham Park, N.J.; in Melville on Long Island; and in Danbury and Stamford in Fairfield County, Conn. Currently in construction are a 412-unit 25-story building across the street from the Metro-North railroad station in downtown New Rochelle and a 408-apartment four-story complex on the Hudson River in Edgewater, N.J.
The approach it takes is to hire local figures to head its regional offices. The man chosen to head the New York office is Frederick S. Harris, 49. Mr. Harris is the former vice president of the Trottwood Corporation, which was the managing partner of M. O. Associates, the development entity that built Citylights, the co-op that was the first building in Queens West.
THROUGH the acquisition of the Dreyfus Corporation, the mutual fund company, and the outright purchase of other partnership interests, the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh came to be the principal partner in M. O. Associates. After Mellon decided in 1998 to withdraw from the Queens West project, the state's Empire State Development Corporation chose AvalonBay to build out the unbuilt site that Trottwood had already been awarded as well as two additional sites. And Mr. Harris went to work for AvalonBay.
"In the higher-income Connecticut towns Avalon even had to litigate to get the right to build its sites because there was so much local opposition," Mr. Harris said. "Here in the city the barriers to entry are different. It's all about capital and evaluating neighborhoods and the sheer stamina it takes to get big projects done."
At Cooper Square it seemed 10 years ago that a mixed-income project might go forward, with the support of the Cooper Square Committee. But local controversy over certain aspects blocked it, and eventually the city's financial support was withdrawn. But now the increased rents obtainable for market-rate apartments, and particularly the greatly strengthened rents obtainable for commercial space, have come to the rescue.
Following the guidelines in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development's public bidding process for the land, AvalonBay will preserve the two community gardens that have been long-term fixtures on the north side of East Houston Street east of Bowery. The city's requirements also included the 30,000-square-foot community center and the preservation of a former church on East First Street as a cultural facility.
Twenty-five percent of the apartments -- 155 out of the 618 total -- will be chosen by lottery from applicants earning no more than 60 percent of median income in New York City, which on the basis of current federal statistics of median income would mean that a family of four could have an annual income no higher than $34,000. Phipps Houses is likely to hold the lottery in early 2002, and occupancy is likely in the latter part of that year.
For its market-rate apartments, AvalonBay expects rents upward of $2,400 a month for a one-bedroom and $3,600 for a two-bedroom.
The design and architectural plan is the work of the New York office of Arquitectonica, an international firm that was founded in Florida in 1977 and became known in its early days for a flamboyant condominium in Miami called the Atlantis, in which a 37-square-foot cube was cut to create a 10-story interior skycourt. Bernardo Fort-Brescia, a founder of the firm, is the chief architect for Cooper Square.
"It's a true in-fill site," Mr. Fort-Brescia said. Its four irregular parcels stretch from the midblock between Bowery and Second Avenue south of East Second Street across East Houston Street to the midblock between Bowery and Chrystie Street. The plan calls for integrating the four new structures by extending a mapped but undeveloped street called Extra Place, now little more than an alley on the north side of East First Street. Extra Place will serve as north-south pedestrians-only spine for the four sites, providing shopping in a variety of retail stores.
The housing will be built to comply with the height and bulk standards called for in the citywide unified-bulk zoning plan that the Department of City Planning has drafted. Although the proposed changes are not final and neither Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani nor the City Council has embraced them, Cooper Square may serve as something of a showcase for the planners' intent.
South of Houston Street on 60,000 square feet of land there is to be a mixed-use building, no portion of which will be higher than 14 stories. It will have more than 100,000 square feet of retail space along Houston Street, plus the community center, with a full-sized basketball court and a swimming pool, at the lower levels.
On the 36,000 square feet behind the community gardens north of Houston Street there is to be a structure with six-story and nine-story elements on either side of Extra Place. And north of East First Street, two smaller buildings will provide the rest of the apartments.
"Everybody is basically pushing for this plan," said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, who served on the task force that worked it out with the housing agency. "It answered our concerns. Everybody gets something out of it if it goes forward essentially as the task force suggested."
