LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: As Cable Rates Rise, So Do Complaints

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
FOR almost 20 years, Allen Fritz of Dix Hills has watched in frustration as his Cablevision bill has increased. He has toyed with the idea of switching to a satellite television system before, but on Nov. 21, when Cablevision announced that it would raise its rates again in January, he decided to consider such a move more seriously.
"I'm paying $95.64 a month now, and I know I can save about $50 a month by going to a satellite dish," said Mr. Fritz, who sells watches. "With the rate increase, I'll be paying more than $100, so I'm going to switch or at least check it out. Satellite TV gives you receivers for two sets, and you pay extra for additional sets. But I'm paying extra now for additional cable boxes." 
 Besides, he said, of the 84 channels he gets from Cablevision, "I watch maybe 10 of them."
"Satellite gives you a wider selection," he added. In fact, the number can run into the hundreds of channels, depending on the plan and the provider.
Bill Powers, a spokesman for Cablevision, the Island's only cable provider, said that the January rate increases would average 6.6 percent. But about a third of Cablevision's 788,000 customers on Long Island -- those who subscribe to its most popular package -- will see their rates jump 12.6 percent, from $35.71 a month to $40.21. Those affected subscribe to what Cablevision calls its family or expanded basic service, which offers some 60 channels.
Subscribers to Cablevision's basic service, about 5 percent of its customers. will see rates go up even more -- 13 percent, Mr. Powers said. The new charges will be $9 to $11.92, depending on location.
On the other hand, the rate for the most expensive Cablevision package will decrease slightly, from $79.95 to $78.05 or $79.05, depending on location. The price of the Optimum Preferred package will remain the same, and so will the charge for Cablevision's broadband Internet connection.
In the last few years Cablevision, which is based in Bethpage, has raised its rates steadily. In 1998, the average increase was 7.5 percent; in 1999, 4.58 percent; and in 2000, 5.16 percent. In comparison, the Consumer Price Index for the New York City area increased by 4.2 percent in the same period.
Mr. Powers gave several reasons for the latest Cablevision increase. "The rate adjustment is primarily due to large increases in programming costs, about 15 percent this year," he said. "In addition, fuel costs for our large fleet of vehicles, as well as repairs, is up by about 50 percent. And manpower costs in a very tight labor market are also up."
He also cited "increases in operating costs, investments for customer service and network improvements to enhance system reliability," along with new channels added in 2000, including Animal Planet, Speedvision and Soap Net.
Mr. Powers said that Cablevision subscribers would be notified of rate increases for their individual plans within the next month.
Mark Cooper, the director of research at the Consumer Federation of America in Washington, took issue with the increases.
"This is what unregulated monopolists do," he said. "There is nothing out there to discipline their pricing, and so they figure that price increases that are two or two and a half times inflation are what they can get away with."
Others argue that cable television services are not monopolies because satellite systems provide an alternative.
Frank Petrone, the Huntington Town supervisor, said that his office had already received many calls protesting the Cablevision rate increase. He did not estimate how many complaints had been received. One resident complained that his Cablevision bill would be "higher than his town tax bill," Mr. Petrone said. "People are very unhappy, and we're going to forward their complaints to Cablevision," he added. "I have seen more of an outcry over this increase than I have in prior years."
A spokeswoman for the Town of Hempstead said that there had been two complaints so far but that more were expected as Cablevision subscribers received their notices.
A spokesman for the Town of Oyster Bay said that the town had received a "couple of complaints" and that callers had been asked to call the Public Service Commission, which can order adjustments.
In Huntington, Mr. Petrone said that he had asked the town attorney to look into the matter. "The early indication is that we don't have any regulatory authority over this," he added. "Cablevision has a 10-year franchise with the town that was renewed four or five years ago. We give them the right to come in and operate. We are concerned with the service they provide. We want to see that we have state-of-the-art equipment and service that is no less than any other town. We also deal with problems associated with cable to see if it is continually out."
These days, governments have limited oversight of the cable television industry. In 1984, Congress pre-empted local communities in the regulation of cable rates, and last year it deregulated the entire industry, said Mr. Cooper of the consumer federation, a nonprofit umbrella group for some 260 consumer organizations.
The spokeswoman for Hempstead said that the town was considering whether to ask the Public Service Commission to conduct a rate review.
Edward Collins, a spokesman for the commission, said that it had a say-so only on rates for basic cable service, not for premium packages. And he added that the agency would be reviewing Cablevision's new rate.
Edward Siegmann of Mattituck, the vice president of the Southold TaxPac, a private lobbying group, and a longtime Cablevision critic, said that when Cablevision announced rate increases in November 1999, he and others met with company executives to protest the $4 increase in basic service.
"They listened to our argument and took it off," said Mr. Siegmann, a retired brewer. "But a short time later, they added it to the cost of family service. If they don't get it one way, they get it another."
He said that he and others had also complained that Cablevision's local news channel, Channel 12, was not available on the basic plan. He said subscribers must sign up for the next tier of service to get it.
"They have us in a corner because there is no competition," he said. "We thought there might be competition from the telephone company, but it hasn't happened."
But there are two major satellite TV systems competing on Long Island, DirecTV and EchoStar Communications, whose service is known as the Dish Network. In both cases, subscribers have to buy or rent a small satellite dish, 18 or 20 inches in diameter. The companies handle the installation.
DirecTV, with headquarters in Hawthorne, Calif., charges $21.99 a month for basic service with some 45 channels. Gina Magee, a spokeswoman, said the most popular plan costs $31.99 a month and gives subscribers about 100 channels and access to 50 pay-per-view and audio channels.
With EchoStar, based in Littleton, Colo., monthly charges begin at $29.99 for 70 video channels and 30 audio channels. Subscribers who want to see local television stations pay another $4.99 a month.
Ms. Magee said she did not know how many subscribers DirecTV had on Long Island, and neither did an EchoStar spokeswoman. SkyTrends in Golden, Colo., a market research, data collection and reporting service for the home satellite industry, said that New York State had 737,951 direct-to-home satellite subscribers on Oct. 1, but it did not have separate figures for Long Island.
Maureen J. Hirsch of Bay Shore had both DirecTV and Cablevision for two years. When she moved recently to East Patchogue, she decided to subscribe to Cablevision exclusively.
Mrs. Hirsch said she initially wanted DirecTV because of the extensive sports coverage it offered. Her husband signed up for two sports packages, she said, and the premium package she bought gave her about 700 channels, including "every movie channel imaginable."
"I got a lot of channels, but unless you sit in front of the TV 24 hours a day, it's not cost-effective," she said. "My bills were $200 a month, but I was not watching any more TV. It was not worth it."
"Picture quality on DirecTV was better," she added, "but the weather kept interfering with it. On days when it was raining hard or if there was a lot of ice outside, it went out."
But Mr. Siegmann of Southold TaxPac said he would switch to satellite TV if he could. The reason he doesn't, he said, is that the tall oak trees that surround his house would interfere with the signal.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
If Walls Could Talk, Here's What They'd Say

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
ONE afternoon last week Randy O'Neill, the customer-service director for Lancer Insurance in Long Beach, was getting ready to drive out to Farmingdale to visit Paul Gatto's studio. Mr. Gatto was putting the finishing touches on an oil painting that Lancer had commissioned of an antique Mack bus. Mr. O'Neill wanted to take a look, because if the painting passed muster (and it did), Mr. Gatto would strike a limited series of 2,000 lithographs for Lancer.
"It's all got to be in our customers' hands by mid-December at the latest," Mr. O'Neill said a little nervously. 
 The customers Mr. O'Neill was talking about are some 1,500 owners and operators of small bus fleets across the country, and if the past five Lancer commissions are any indication, the lithographs will end up hanging on the walls of the customers' offices.
This year, Mr. Gatto painted a 1909 Mack bus against the backdrop of Jackson Square in New Orleans. Mr. Gatto works in a style that might be called "bus terminal semi-realism," evoking the slice-of-life paintings Norman Rockwell once produced for The Saturday Evening Post.
This year's painting will take its place on the wall of the insurance company's second-floor lobby and work area, joining a growing corporate art gallery. Most of the 13 canvasses already displayed are renderings of vintage buses, the predecessors of the 30,000 vehicles Lancer insures today. Some of the paintings, especially those done in the early 1990's by the late Mort Rosenfeld focus more on the passengers, mechanics and drivers, all depicted in a style reminiscent of Edward Hopper.
Last year Mr. Gallo painted a Greyhound Sceni-Cruiser pulling ahead of a Tucker sedan in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco. Clients receive not only the lithographs but a written description chock-full with vehicular details.
The Medici behind this artistic renaissance is Lancer's president, Dave Delaney.
As Mr. Delaney sees it, the substantial expense involved in the paintings and lithographs -- an estimated $250,000 so far, not counting staff time -- serves a distinctive marketing purpose. "It isn't cheap, you know, but it shows our commitment to the industry," he said. "We stand out more than if we just send calendars every year like everybody else. It's become a tradition."
The company strives to ensure every historical detail is accurate when commissioning the painting. A small team -- Mr. Delaney, Mr. O'Neill and several other executives -- debate each year's proposed subject, and once the subject is decided, then they collect old photographs to provide historical detail. Sometimes the team hires a freelance photographer to make additional photographs; sometimes they pay for the artist to go out and see the bus first-hand.
Two years ago, the collection came down from Lancer's walls and was shipped to Houston.
"We have a booth at the annual United Motor Coach Association trade show, and instead of giving out the usual brochures, we created an art gallery on the show floor," Mr. O'Neill said. "It was very popular. We got quite a few leads out of it."
A growing number of businesses are now aware of the impact that their decor has on both visitors and employees, and they are working with designers and architects to maximize that impact, said Michael Mannetta, the director of design at the Spector Group, an architectural firm in North Hills.
"The moment someone walks into your lobby, they get a message about your company based on a variety of factors," said Mr. Mannetta, a partner in the firm. "On a subconscious level, you're communicating what kind of experience someone can expect from your company, and that expectation is going to shape whatever business relationship you go on to have."
The designer's job is to work with the client in refining the message the client wants to communicate and then to translate that message into design, layout and furnishings. Lighting, color, materials and decorations are major components in the message, Mr. Mannetta said.
Bright lighting, light colors, a sense of space and natural plantings connote creativity, openness and a sense that the company's sensibility is progressive, Mr. Mannetta said. The use of wood, especially dark wood, and darker colors tend to convey the image of stability, reliability and trustworthiness, he added.
"Advertising firms are likely to emphasize the creative end of the spectrum, the desire to appear cutting-edge," Mr. Mannetta said. "A law firm tends to prefer the darker colors that convey solidity and suggest 'We've been around a long time, and you can expect us to be around for a long time.' "
Office decor also sends a message about the company's attitudes and expectations. "You walk into an office that's really cutting-edge in terms of design, where it's clear that much time and money have gone into the design and construction, and that tells you quite a bit about the company," Mr. Mannetta continued. "If you're a prospective client, you get the sense right away that you would be dealing with a business that spends what it takes to accomplish its goals. That sends a message about what kind of fee structure will be in place; they probably will charge on the high end of the market.
"Similarly, if you're a prospective employee, you get the sense -- without a word being said -- that this is a company that appreciates the finer things. You sense that you will be asked to contribute accordingly and to be paid accordingly."
At Harbor Industrial Park in Port Washington, Sam Kliger has come up with an innovative solution to the "how do I decorate my office" problem: he covered the walls with framed shopping bags from his clients. As the president of Kliger Weiss Infosystems, Mr. Kliger sells data-processing services that help retailers track sales and inventory. Every time he gets a new customer, Mr. Kliger asks for a shopping bag. They are framed against a matte black background and displayed at eye level.
Currently, about 100 bags festoon the walls, including those from Kenneth Cole, Montblanc, Panasonic and the World Wrestling Federation.
"When a prospect comes into my office, or a client, they look at the wall, and right away they know who I do business with," Mr. Kliger said. "It makes quite a statement."
The art gallery also serves a second purpose: to motivate employees and to promote customer service.
"I want to remind my employees that without those companies up there on the wall, you're nothing," Mr. Kliger said. "We're in a professional service business. Everything we do is for the clients. The bags keep the clients' names in front of them all day long."
But not all the bags show the client off to best advantage. The reason, Mr. Kliger said, is not aesthetics but economics. "Look," he explained. "It's price-sensitive. You go to Armani, you get a beautiful bag. You go to Wal-Mart, you get a junky bag."

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); LOUISIANA, USA (79%);

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1745 words

HEADLINE: Reading, Writing and . . . Work? Not Always

BYLINE: By ADAM BOWLES 

 BODY:
CAROLINE BENNETT of New London, an 18-year-old student at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, is unabashed about the reason why she does not have a job despite annual expenses of more than $10,000 in tuition, fees and room and board. "I'm lazy," she said.
But she offered a better excuse for many of her friends from her dormitory who are spending the semester without campus jobs: they don't need the money and would rather study to get better grades. 
 "A lot of people don't have jobs, and it's not because there are not jobs to be had, but because they don't need to," she said. "If people can afford to not work during the actual school year, then they are not going to. I think people are getting paid more during the summer. And their parents have good jobs."
The state's lowest unemployment rate since the mid-80's -- 2.4 percent -- has not only made it difficult for many businesses to fill openings. Colleges, which rely on student labor for many jobs, are also having a hard time. UConn has had to scale back its shuttle bus service because it can't find enough student drivers. The checkout lines at the Wesleyan University library in Middletown are longer because fewer students have applied to work there. And Albertus Magnus College in New Haven has turned to temporary employment agencies to fill clerical jobs traditionally held by students.
"We've offered cash and other incentives," said Janet Freniere, manager of transportation services at UConn. "We've been to every job fair. But the kids don't want to work. With the supposed wonderful economy that we have, I can imagine that a lot of the parents are saying: 'Go to college. Concentrate on your academics. Don't worry about it, we'll take care of you.' "
Education officials said that wealthier parents and lazier students were only part of the problem. The tight labor market has also forced many companies to increase benefits and wages, so students can find higher paying jobs off campus.
"I would assume many students are getting jobs off campus for more than minimum wage," said John Tirinzonie, director of job development for the Connecticut Department of Labor (minimum wage in Connecticut is $6.15 per hour). "Companies in private sectors have the opportunity to offer more money to students than what many of the colleges and universities can afford to pay."
One example is Stop and Shop in Middletown. Clinton Mattis, a customer service manager at the grocery store, says whenever he gets desperate for workers he takes a five-minute drive to Wesleyan and posts job notices inviting students to come work for him.
Many of them do, and lately word of mouth has been all the advertising he needs. Most student jobs at the university pay minimum wage, so with a starting salary of $6.45, some limited health benefits and flexible work schedules, Mr. Mattis does not have many problems attracting students.
Neither does Cynthia Galle, owner of Neon Deli just outside campus, who employs 25 Wesleyan students. She says they like working for her because she offers a flexible schedule, she takes them out to dinner for the holidays and gives them birthday money. Her starting wages are $6.25 an hour and she pays up to $8. "They get to eat free, and that's big for the guys," she added.
Sarah Kozinn, 21, a senior at Wesleyan, works the cash register and makes sandwiches at the deli. She said her parents and grandparents were paying her college expenses (tuition alone is more than $25,000 a year) and she needed extra cash only for things like movie tickets.
"It's not a matter of survival," she said. "It's more a matter of pleasure. I've worked on campus before, at a lab, but here you can create your own schedule, and that's kind of convenient."
Nowhere does the struggle to find student workers appear to be greater than at UConn.
Ms. Freniere, the manager of transportation services, says she desperately needs nearly 30 student bus drivers to add to her 55-person work force to keep up with additional routes created by recent campus expansion.
The labor squeeze has forced Ms. Freniere to shut down several routes and to reduce the number of campus shuttles to just one on some routes, a major inconvenience with many of the parking lots far from the campus center. So she did what a lot of colleges have had to do: she raised salaries.
Last year, Ms. Freniere bumped entry-level wages up to $7.15 an hour from $6.45, to give her a $1 cushion above minimum wage. Once a student receives a commercial driver's license, the salary increases to $8 an hour. Student assistant managers can earn as much as $12 an hour, but even that will increase next year to at least $13.
Gerald Weller, director of dining services at UConn, is also feeling the need for student workers. If all 13 dining halls on campus were fully staffed, he said, there would be 500 part-time student workers. This year there are about 350.
"We're competing against this robust economy," he said. "I think everybody assumes that. It puts a burden on the full-time staff."
Mr. Weller says problems from the labor shortage aren't significant, though he says that earlier in the year some dining halls closed an hour earlier for lack of staff and a small food store at one dormitory has not opened because it doesn't have the help it needs. While he typically struggles for the first six weeks of the fall semester to fill student positions because students are still living off their summer savings, this year the "six-week rule" grew by a few weeks.
Yale University in New Haven is also having a problem. Thomas Conroy, deputy director of public affairs at the university, said it had job shortages in library services, dining halls and the student employment office.
"Sometimes it's not an issue of fewer students who want to work, but students who are working fewer hours," Mr. Conroy said. "For some of them, they don't need the money."
At Trinity College in Hartford, Carolyn LeGeyt, the assistant director of financial aid, said that total student earnings through a federal work-study program on campus are 48 percent lower than what they were last year, something that hass been happening for three year The program links financial aid students to jobs on campus.
"Students are either working half the time they did last year or half the students are working," Ms. LeGeyt said. "In some cases they may have worked really hard over the summer and have enough to carry them over, or in some cases they are being supplemented by their parents."
Ms. LeGeyt said some departments on campus had voiced frustration over the lack of student response to their job postings.
Rachel Cheng, associate university librarian at Wesleyan, said competition among campus departments for student workers had intensified in the last couple of years.
"Everybody wants to get good students," Ms. Cheng said, adding that openings at the library means it takes students longer to check out books.
Michael Serpe, director of communications at Albertus Magnus, mentioned several offices that were resorting to temporary agencies for workers.
"If we try to find a student to do work part time in our administrative offices it's substantially more difficult than five years ago," Mr. Serpe said. "Students aren't sitting around anymore. They're working at Circuit City or somewhere."
To be sure, some colleges in Connecticut report the opposite problem: they have more student applicants than they do have jobs.
Dean Golembeski, communications director for the Connecticut State University System, which includes Eastern, Western, Central and Southern, said none of the system's campuses were having difficulty filling student jobs this year.
Patricia Nielson, director of career services at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, said the majority of jobs awarded on campus were part of the federal work-study program. Ms. Nielson said students found it convenient to stay on campus and work and that flexible work schedules gave them more time to study and socialize.
Mike Yagid, a 19-year-old Quinnipiac student, works in the career services department. Mr. Yagid said he could easily earn $10 an hour with a job off campus, which would be $2 more than what he earns now.
"Most of my friends work on campus," he said. "The ones who do work off campus complain about it because it's so hectic and because of the commute. For my needs, working on campus is perfect."
At Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Julie Savino, dean of financial aid, said there were 600 work-study jobs on campus and more than enough students to fill them. She has to turn students away. Ms. Savino added that other private sector services on campus, like dining services, also reported no hiring difficulties.
William Alpert, an economics professor at UConn, says it is all a matter of need. "Students from lower income parents are going to have lower wage expectations and probably have higher revenue needs," he said. "They are going to take jobs whether they are on campus or off campus."
At colleges where the labor crunch has hit the hardest, officials are developing strategies like higher salaries, cash bonuses and free meals to food-service employees to attract students to job openings.
At UConn, Dolan Evanovich, associate provost for enrollment management, said the university had lifted the wage cap for student workers, mostly managers, from $10 to $20 an hour in the last year. There are 5,000 students on the university payroll.
Mr. Evanovich says it is difficult to entice students because many want jobs that are directly related to their career goals and shun service jobs like washing dishes.
At St. Joseph College in Hartford, Phil Malinoski, director of financial aid, said starting wages for work-study jobs on campus had increased from minimum wage to $7 to be competitive with off-campus jobs. Five years ago, the college had a waiting list of students looking for jobs. This year some departments have had to do without the office help. "Certainly we benefit from student help," he said. "But we don't want to be in a position where we couldn't survive without students."
Mr. Alpert, the UConn economics professor, said students may soon be heading back to work.
"You have had higher incomes for most of the 90's and parents are now footing the bill," he said. "But have no fear -- the economy is turning down and student labor will be back. This is a transitory problem."

HEADLINE: CITIES;
Aquarium On Verge Of Change

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
Strictly speaking, the $59 million New Jersey State Aquarium, a state-financed tourist attraction on the waterfront that draws about 500,000 visitors a year, is not for sale.
That said, someone might soon acquire everything in the aquarium but its name, as well as six acres of waterfront real estate, public financing and a loan if an agreement to build an entertainment complex next door is reached. 
 This seems to be where the bargaining chips are falling as as very closely held meetings continue between Coopers Ferry Development Association, a nonprofit agency overseeing Camden's waterfront development, and Steiner & Associates of Ohio.
Tom Corcoran, the president of Cooper's Ferry, said in an interview that although negotiations began in April, shortly before the expiration of an exclusive development option granted by Cooper's Ferry to Kravco, a Pennsylvania shopping mall developer, there was still no signed agreement.
Mr. Corcoran said he anticipated a formal announcement of Steiner's plans for the Camden waterfront by February. Officials from Steiner declined to discuss its plans.
The deal is part of a 20-year plan by Cooper's Ferry that will pump about $500 million in new development in and around the Camden waterfront by 2010. The organization has been responsible for the construction of the aquarium, the One Port Center office building, which houses the Delaware River Port Authority, directly east of the aquarium, as well as the E-Center entertainment arena, Wiggins Park, the Camden Children's Garden and docking and visitor facilities for the battleship New Jersey.
In addition, Cooper's Ferry expects to announce within the next several months that it has reached an agreement with a Philadelphia developer for a $50 million residential conversion of the RCA Nipper Building by 2003.
In November, the Delaware River Port Authority released $320,000 to Cooper's Ferry to cover Steiner's costs in developing site plans.
Mr. Corcoran said that Steiner's plans for the waterfront featured a $50 million to $60 million addition to the northern side of aquarium with four or five exhibits, an IMAX theater and a mix of restaurant and retail shops. The addition would be paid for "mostly by Steiner, though some public funding may be used," he said.
The addition would occupy six acres of state-owned waterfront land extending north from the aquarium to Market Street, where a $26 million aerial tram would link the site to a retail and restaurant complex on the west bank of the Delaware River at Philadelphia's Penns Landing, scheduled to begin operation in 2003.
"This is not a privatization by any means," Mr. Corcoran insisted, though he said that Steiner would get a "management presence" at the aquarium "over all phases of the operation."
"If you're going to ask someone to spend that much money to improve a facility, you have to give them a voice," he said.
He declined to say if Steiner would retain the aquarium's current executive director, Brian Duvall, or any of the aquarium's 100 full-time employees in Camden as well as at the Ocean Life Center in Atlantic City.
The aquarium sits on land owned by the state, and is managed by the New Jersey Academy for Aquatic Sciences, a nonprofit organization that includes representatives from the governor's office and the city.
Under the current proposal, Steiner would also be able to raise the aquarium's admission fees.
"Given the size of this facility, and increase in time that visitors will spend in it," Mr. Corcoran said, "it's likely that there will be an increase in admission fees."
He said Cooper's Ferry decided to negotiate with Steiner because of its success with entertainment complexes in Florida, Ohio and Kentucky, where it had built a waterfront aquarium that was an anchor for additional commercial development.
"It's a good quality aquarium," said Brian Duvall, executive director of the aquarium. "They've done a good job out there."
Mr. Duvall, the aquarium's third executive director since its opening in 1992, added that he was not opposed to sharing control with a retail entertainment developer.
"We've worked very hard to act as an anchor for development," Mr. Duvall said. "There is no way we'd be looking at significant and positive development opportunities on the waterfront if this aquarium had not been as successful as it is. An outside developer would have funds to build exhibits using new technologies that were not available when the aquarium opened. The whole idea that you're going to bring someone in to takeover an operation for money-making possibilities is ridiculous."
Still, not everyone shares Mr. Duvall's optimism. Mike Devlin, executive director of the Camden Children's Garden, the four-acre, $8 million outdoor garden and amusement area that opened on the aquarium's southern side in July 1999, said he was "extremely concerned that we haven't been included in any of these negotiations."
"I've been hearing almost since we opened that the state wants to privatize the aquarium," Mr. Devlin said, "and it's got me worried because the future of the garden is eminently connected to the future of the aquarium."
Under a five-year agreement with the Camden City Garden Club, the Children's Garden's nonprofit sponsoring organization, a single ticket provides admission to both the aquarium and the children's garden. The institutions share receipts from tickets sales, though the aquarium determines how the receipts are divided.
Mr. Devlin said that visitors had been complaining about ticket prices since they were raised a dollar in July to $12.95 for adults and $9.95 for children under 12. In addition, when the aquarium raised its ticket prices, the proceeds to the garden were also reduced, to $499,000 from $624,000 for fiscal year 2000, ending June 2001.
"Right now we're drawing on some of our other dollars to keep going," Mr. Devlin said. "It is causing a financial hardship."
Moreover, he added that security provided by the aquarium had become lax. "There have been examples of vandalism and theft, more than we'd like to have seen."
As for the aquarium itself, though the price of admission was raised and a submarine simulator exhibition -- supposed to open at that time -- is still under construction, the facility is having a comparatively good year. In the fiscal year ending June 30, 2000, it attracted 527,777 visitors, up about 10 percent from the previous year. The aquarium drew the fewest visitors in 1995 (446,315), and the most in its first year, when 831,793 people toured the complex.
About a third of the aquarium's $11.9 million operating budget comes from admissions ($3.7 million in the last fiscal year). Another third comes from the state ($3.2 million). The rest is made up from sponsorships, food sales, facility rentals, private grants and educational programs.
Stephen Schilling, a developer who is building a $24.5 million minor league baseball stadium on the waterfront across from the site, said he shared Mr. Devlin's concern over being excluded from the negotiations.
"But I am absolutely in favor of anything that will bring more people and new business to Camden," Mr. Schilling said. "I hope Steiner goes go forward with what they've planned. The fact that a credible developer looked at Camden means that other credible developers will also look at Camden. Myself, I'm not done looking at Camden."

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
MORE MILLIONAIRES

BYLINE: By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
The number of millionaires in New Jersey nearly tripled between 1993 and 1998, rising from 3,000 to 8,310, according to the Statistics of Income report issued by the state Division of Taxation last week. Based on a review of 1998 income tax filings, the report found that incomes in the state's wealthiest counties, Morris, Hunterdon and Somerset, grew by about 60 percent over that period, while incomes in the poorest counties, Hudson, Cumberland and Atlantic, grew by 30 percent. The number of people or families making less than $10,000 a year decreased from 1,020,964 to 718,748. The millionaires make up 0.2 percent of the population and account for nearly 12 percent of the state's income, while the bottom 10 percent of earners make 1.7 percent of the income. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER; E-mail: daschn@nytimes.com

 BODY:

Illuminating Christmas
 
Q.: I understand that electric Christmas tree lights were introduced in New York City. When?
 
A.: Historians generally credit Edward H. Johnson, the vice president of Thomas A. Edison's electric company, with the introduction of the lights, in the rear parlor of his New York home, in 1882.
The 80 hand-wired, hand-blown glass bulbs were wrapped in red, white and blue crepe paper, and twinkled and blinked as the tree twirled around. A reporter from a Detroit newspaper described the tree as "most picturesque and uncanny . . . it was brilliantly lighted with many colored globes about the size of an English walnut and was turning some six times a minute in a little pine box." 
 It was only three years after Edison produced his incandescent bulb, and mere weeks after his Illuminating Company of New York City, the nation's first commercial power station, opened at 257 Pearl Street.
Victorian consumers were as mistrustful of electric lights as they had been of candles; for years they remained costly, hazardous and bothersome. General Electric acquired Edison's light bulb business in 1890 and began selling tree lights in the 1900's, $12 for a box of 28.
In 1903, the Ever-Ready Company of New York began mass-producing strings of lights. Prices for the electric lights soon dropped markedly, and by 1920 candles were fading from use. The first electric menorahs appeared after World War I.
 
5-Plus Avenue
 
Q.: An additional boulevard, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, was once mapped out for Manhattan. What became of the plan?
 
A.: Since it was first approved in 1811, Manhattan's grid plan has proven impervious to all but a few attempts to improve on it. One occurred in 1910, when Mayor William J. Gaynor, astounded by the automobile traffic he saw snarling Fifth Avenue, called for a broad new thoroughfare to be carved out of Midtown, just west of Fifth Avenue.
The new avenue, which was to stretch from Eighth Street to Central Park, would be 100 feet wide, and would cost, by the mayor's calculations, $40 million. Though the street would require the demolition of hundreds of buildings, Mayor Gaynor was convinced that property owners would willingly finance the scheme, since their back lots would be transformed overnight into high-priced real estate on a principal avenue.
Many motorists preferred Fifth Avenue because it was free of street railways and freight traffic from the waterfront. Traffic on the street increased eightfold between 1885 and 1913, while that on Broadway only doubled. A study found that rush-hour pedestrians on the avenue traveled at approximately the same speed as cars.
While the public considered the proposal, newspapers printed cartoons depicting the mayor scooping up buildings with a shovel. The plan was mostly ignored after he was wounded by an unemployed dock worker in summer 1910, and when the mayor died three years later it was completely forgotten. In 1911, the architect Henry Rutgers Marshall suggested a broad, gently curved boulevard linking the old Pennsylvania Station with Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. It, too, was quickly forgotten.
 
Lincoln in Brooklyn
 
Q.: There is a log-cabin-like structure at East 93rd Street and Flatlands Avenue in Canarsie. Is it real?
 
A.: Yes, according to Marty Cohen, a manager at Fillmore Real Estate, whose offices are in the little cabin. The log house is "at least 100 years old," he said, and was an ice cream parlor in the 1940's and 50's. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Raquel Cheatham, Darren Skinner

 BODY:
Raquel Mary Cheatham and Darren Christopher Skinner, both associates at law firms in Washington, were married there yesterday by Msgr. Russell Dillard at St. Augustine's Church.
The bride is with Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice; the bridegroom works at Arnold & Porter. 
 Mrs. Skinner, 29, graduated summa cum laude from Spelman College and received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. She is the daughter of Bernice and Leroy R. Cheatham Jr. of Brooklyn. Her father retired as a counselor at the Queensboro Correctional Facility in Long Island City, Queens. Her mother, also retired, taught science at David Ruggles Junior High School in Brooklyn.

He also holds Master of Laws degrees from the London School of Economics and Harvard. He is a son of Dr. Peggy King Skinner and Dr. Selwyn M. Skinner of Miami. His father, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, practiced with the Public Health Trust unit of the University of Miami Medical School.

HEADLINE: Millburn Should Develop Businesses Suited to It

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Regarding "Been Up so Long It Looks Like Down" (Nov. 19), about empty stores in downtown Millburn, it would be easy to assume that the presence of an upscale mall in Short Hills or the many discount stores along Route 22 have caused commercial property to go unoccupied in Millburn. But a more thorough analysis would lead one to conclude that it is a lack of vision on the part of downtown landlords and merchants and of the municipal government that are the real problems. 
 Millburn is now involved in an effort to reinvent itself. The cries most often heard are "Why can't we be like Maplewood Village or Madison?" or "Why can't we get a big box store in here to draw people to the downtown?"
The only chance for progress is for the various parties to acknowledge the downtown infrastructure with all its limitations. This certainly did not happen under the last Downtown Alliance study proposal that actually wanted the city government to condemn certain parcels to add more commercial space. What Millburn can do is build upon the assets it does have, like brokerage operations and financial institutions. Perhaps we cannot get college students from a nearby campus to stroll in without cars, as Madison and South Orange have done, or create the downtown ambience of Maplewood Village, but if various parties would look to make buildings "smart" buildings, then perhaps we can attract more of the type of businesses that would compliment what is already downtown. This may regenerate downtown, or at the least bring us a cybercafe. As for the abandoned Saks site, it would be terrific if the use could be redirected to a residential one, or perhaps a satellite campus for a higher learning institution, but that may be
hoping for too much.
 
ABBOTT GORIN
Millburn

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK PARKS;
On the West Side, Who Will Pay to Make Room for Green?

BYLINE: By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
Efforts to create a park out of a parking lot on the Hudson River have hit rough waters, and the problem, as usual, is money.
In one corner is Circle Line, the cruise company, which has 17 years left on a lease to park cars on Pier 84 at 44th Street and on land to the south. In the other corner are backers of the Hudson River Park, a five-mile swath of green from Battery Park City to West 59th Street. 
 Circle Line left the Pier 84 lot in June and has agreed to give up its lease on the other lot so long as parking is provided nearby. After much haggling, the company and Community Board 4 came up with an idea: build a deck for cars on top of the World Yacht offices at Pier 81. (Circle Line owns World Yacht.)
"It was definitely a trade-off," said Pam Frederick, co-chairwoman of the board's Waterfront and Parks Committee. "But if we hadn't compromised, that section would have been a big parking lot while the rest became a park."
It may still, though, because the board thinks Circle Line should pay for part of the $3.5 million deck, said John Doswell, the committee co-chairman. The deck would, after all, provide 136 spots at $15 a day, primarily to the one million tourists who ride the Circle Line each year.
But Tom Fox, a Circle Line consultant, said the company never agreed to pay, because the pier and parking lot are city-owned. he said the bill could go to the Hudson River Park Trust, the government agency building the park. Or use federal highway money or the Economic Development Corporation, he said.
"The park is already short-funded," said Mr. Fox, who once oversaw the trust. "Let's be creative here."
Connie Fishman, the trust's vice president, said she liked the deck idea but couldn't spend park money on a parking lot. "The most important thing," she said, "is that we're not going to wait 17 years to design this part of the park."
On Thursday, the trust selected Richard Dattner & Partners as architects and Miceli Kulik Williams & Associates as the landscaper. The two companies will design the park from 25th to 59th Streets. That choice renewed the community board's hopes, and at its Wednesday meeting members plan to again ask the trust to help negotiate a deal.
For now, their paradise remains a parking lot. KELLY CROW

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS;
An Actor Awash in Ambition and Merlot

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LEDUFF 

 BODY:
He stood in the portico awash in light cast by a flickering gas lamp. It was raining, and his jacket did not quite fit. He had come from an audition. He had already had a few glasses of wine and apologized for it.
"There's nothing more important than Europe," he said for the first time that evening. He would say it many more times before the night was over. He would say it for the last time when the club closed, and the doorman asked him to go out, into the rain. 
 The meaning of this opaque phrase would grow murkier over the course of many drinks, but one must make allowances. George Demas is an actor, a man whose motivations and appetites lie at the bottom of a dark well.
He has appeared in the short-lived "Escape Artist" by Michael Lawrence and "Master of Monstrosities" by Edgar Oliver, the East Village Poe. He is considered more than respectable at his craft, but acting has yet to pay his rent.
What his years in alternative theater have earned him is a candidacy at Players, a club in Gramercy Park that was founded in 1888 by Edwin Booth, the brother of Lincoln's assassin, for men of the stage, the letters and the arts. Its hallowed halls have been graced by the presence of notables like Mark Twain, Lauren Bacall and Paul Huber, a character actor and great-uncle of Mr. Demas.
He is hoping that along with admission to the club will come all its privileges, hobnobbing with directors and producers who might change his business address from Off Off Broadway to On.
But there is a predicament here. The greatest role played by Mr. Demas is that of a lover of wine and song. And in the stodgy environs of the Players Club, allowances are few and respectability is paramount, and Mr. Demas finds his candidacy under subtle scrutiny.
The good pledge does make an effort at decorum. The other evening, he spent his more sober moments in the downstairs parlor expounding on the greatness of ancient Greece, the philosophy of psychosis and this canned peach, "Theater is infinitely more powerful than film."
But soon the ghosts stole up on Mr. Demas and he found himself standing in the drizzle of the second-floor balcony, a glass of merlot in hand. His father, it seems, was a top midshipman at the Naval Academy who, as a young man, shook the hand of President John F. Kennedy. After a term in the Navy, the father went to Harvard, and then became a successful economist, businessman, inventor and husband.
The genius the son pursues is much less measurable.
"I would just for once like to make my father proud," Mr. Demas said into the long cold evening. "If I ever win the Oscar."
And then it was back to the parlor for a game of billiards, another glass of wine and a splintering rendition of "I've Got to Be Me," which is an honorable sentiment for an actor but possibly a questionable one for an aspirant to the Players Club. CHARLIE LEDUFF

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
I'll Tell You My Sins, but Not My Salary

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THERE was a time in the distant past when topics like cancer and pregnancy were taboo in polite company. Thankfully, those days are long gone. So isn't it time to break one of the last and most unwarranted conversational taboos of all?
I mean the one about money. Oh, people talk endlessly about investing and so forth, but they are truly tight-lipped about how much money they have and how much they earn. The durability of this taboo is remarkable, given the readiness of so many Americans to talk about their sex lives, substance abuse, tortured upbringings and so forth -- and not only to their friends and acquaintances, but also on television and radio. 
 Economists might say that people talk openly about these formerly private matters because they derive utility from doing so. It raises their status in the social marketplace, and sometimes even raises cash. Tell-all memoirs are a staple of best-seller lists.
Unfortunately, in this paradise of openness, people have yet to realize how much it is costing them not to talk about how much they earn. And their silence creates market inefficiencies that benefit only one set of people -- their employers.
The lopsided distribution of knowledge in favor of those who buy labor puts the sellers of that labor (read: working stiffs) in a poor position to obtain the highest prices for their services. A company, after all, knows what it pays all its workers, and probably has a better idea of what people elsewhere are making, too. (The human resources department, whatever else its failings, is a valuable source of market data in this regard.)
As workers, however, you and your colleagues are locked into the same code of silence, so you really have no idea.
Many people think that keeping quiet about their pay lets employers pay them more for good performance without fanning the resentment of jealous colleagues. In fact, it is just the opposite: keeping one's pay a secret makes it easier for the company not to adequately reward superior performance. Clever employers make sure that each worker thinks that he is making more than everyone else -- a notion that is difficult to disprove without a free discussion of pay.
A contrasting situation is seen in Major League Baseball, where compensation is highly correlated to a player's perceived value. Team owners bid feverishly for free agents, and there is surprising openness about the pay that players ultimately receive. When Paul O'Neill, the Yankees' talented but aging right fielder, recently signed a one-year deal for $6.5 million, the terms were published in the sports sections of newspapers.
Nobody is embarrassed by this kind of openness, and it doesn't cost the players money. On the contrary, it probably leads to higher overall salaries, even if to greater differences between the salaries of superstars and journeymen. But even the second group is probably better off.
In the average workplace, however, it should not be surprising that the employer is the main beneficiary of the code of silence, because it is the kind of social rule that makes sense only for the rich. It is a handy way to exclude not only those who aren't rich (you know the old saw -- if you have to ask, you can't afford it), but also those who have grown rich by dint of their own efforts.
But the persistence of this taboo is bizarre, given that financial information in general has become so widely known. Consumers routinely disclose their earnings in credit applications, and modern databases make it possible for various strangers to find out all about your finances. The only people from whom such information seems to be a secret are your friends, co-workers and, often, family members.
EVEN they may have it soon enough, however, because obtaining such information gets easier all the time. Web sites like www.domania.com, for example, will tell you what you or your neighbor paid for a house. You can estimate your date's earnings at www.salary.com, by entering an occupation and ZIP code. So what's the big secret?
For many people, the reason is embarrassment; they may feel guilty about making so much by doing so little. Others feel badly about making so little, compared with what they think their friends and former schoolmates are making. Some people even fear abduction, even though ransom kidnapping is extremely rare in this country and almost never successful.
But if you fear that you may become prey for bloodthirsty telemarketers, relax. Those people already know all about you.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
The Business Class of 2000 Decides It's a Lucky Number

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
There's Gallery 2000, a jewelry store on Fordham Road in the Bronx, which opened in 1990. Within just a few blocks are Mirage 2000, Gold City 2000 and Diamond District 2000, all jewelry stores that have opened in the last decade.
Elsewhere in the city there is Design 2000, Destination 2000, Digital 2000, Pediatrics 2000 and 2000 Auto Electric Company. There is even Class 2000, an escort service that urges Yellow Pages readers, "Let us take you to the next millennium!" 
 These New York businesses, and hundreds of others have hit on the once-clever gimmick of tacking millennial cachet to an otherwise ordinary name. But now that the millennial year has come and is going, will they change their names?
The question startled Jose Guzman, an owner of Salon 2000 on St. Nicholas Avenue in Manhattan, not to be confused with Salon 2000 on Nereid Avenue in the Bronx.
"I'm thinking of getting rid of the name," Mr. Guzman said. "The name I'm considering is . . . ." He paused, pointing to the worn orange facade that displays the current name in purple lettering, Salon 2000 de las Estrellas, meaning Salon 2000 of the Stars.
Edward Chen, a Taiwanese immigrant who owns Cafe 2000 on the Upper West Side, said he chose the name in 1994 because he "wanted to have my store go to the millennium." He plans to keep the name.
"The year 2000 is not the last year of the 20th century," he explained. "It's the first year of the 21st century."
But Joe Amrhein, founder of Pierogi 2000, an art gallery in Williamsburg, has already printed a 2000-less sign to reflect the new name for his business: Pierogi.
In 1983, David Zelman named his SoHo home furnishings business Prologue 2000. "We chose the name," he recalled, "because we were doing things that I hoped would be an introduction to the way people viewed the world in the year 2000."
For corporate purposes, the business kept its original name, but for the consumer the future is Prologue. Since last year, the store has used the one-word name for the public.
On Fordham Road, the jewelry business is so good that no one thinks a change is needed. An employee of Mirage 2000, who identified himself only as Mohammed, said he was saving to start his own jewelry business, which he planned to call Millennium 2000. Is he afraid its name will be outdated before it opens? "No," he said. "Everyone that has a 2000 name does good business." SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH SEBASTIAN JUNGER;
From 'The Perfect Storm,' A Passage to Financial Freedom

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

DATELINE: TRURO, Mass.

 BODY:
THE winters of 1992, '93 and '94 here on Cape Cod were some of the coldest on record. Temperatures hovered in the 20's and low 30's, winds cut to the bone and local residents bundled in.
But Sebastian Junger, who was hard at work writing "The Perfect Storm," often let the temperature in his parents' modest summer house here drop into the shiver zone. 
 "The deal I made with myself is that if you are at the desk working, you can turn the heat on," said Mr. Junger, sitting again in the spartan bedroom where he had written the book, the true story of six fishermen who lose their lives battling a ferocious storm. Published in 1997, "The Perfect Storm" was an overnight sensation.
His mother worried about those living conditions. And a girlfriend who came to visit turned on every baseboard heater in the house, an act that Mr. Junger said was "for revenge."
"The house was just steaming," he recalled.
But Mr. Junger pressed ahead with his arrangement, which both encouraged him to work and kept him from wasting energy. "It was some kind of New England Calvinist thing," he said in a recent interview. "It kept me working a lot. The rest of the house was freezing. If I wasn't working, the heat went off.
"Most of the time, I wore a big overcoat. I wore a hat in bed. It was very cold. If I tracked snow into the kitchen, it would be there for weeks."
Mr. Junger, quite well off today, was not broke then, either. "I wanted a really focused and solitary life for a couple of years," he said, dressed in jeans and a slightly ratty wool sweater. When he needed money, he added, he returned to a job he had held occasionally in the past -- the dangerous but lucrative work of cutting down trees that hang over people's homes. The job, which involved climbing trees perhaps 90 feet tall, tying down the limbs and then chopping them off, paid well: $200 to $1,000 a day.
These days, Mr. Junger chops trees only when he wants to. "The Perfect Storm," whose paperback version is still on the New York Times best-seller list after 129 weeks, brought him a bonanza.
Although Mr. Junger would not say specifically, sales of the book and the film rights have generated around $4 million before taxes, according to his agent, Stuart Kriechevsky. Mr. Junger's advance was $35,000 for the hardcover, but sales of the book reaped close to $2 million in royalties in the United States alone. He split a $1.2 million fee for the paperback rights with his hardcover publisher, W. W. Norton. He received $500,000 for the film rights -- though the movie, by Warner Brothers, also became a blockbuster; it has grossed $323 million worldwide.
Mr. Junger puts his net worth at about $1.5 million. That sum has prompted him to invest for the first time and to change just a few spending patterns -- his biggest indulgences being an investment in a Manhattan bar and a home here on Cape Cod.
These days, Mr. Junger makes his living as a journalist, earning as much as $20,000 for a magazine article. And there are occasional speaking engagements, although he donates most of the honorariums to a charitable foundation that provides educational opportunities to children of workers in the maritime trades.
MR. JUNGER'S financial windfall sounds magical, but it was a long time coming. "I have been working since I was 20, and I'm 38," he said. "I actually once averaged out what I had made over my professional life. I think I could have made that much as a waiter or an insurance salesman. You know, I spent so many years in my 20's making $10,000 a year. When I realized that, it put this whole thing in a sort of different perspective."
Although his handsome, angular face, his intense blue eyes and his mystique as an adventurer (an articulate one, at that) have won him various marriage proposals on his book tours, he has remained single, without many obligations.
Yet he has clung to some puritanism. If anything, he is less interested in his finances than he was before becoming a best-selling author. As a journalist, he accepts only the assignments he wants. That has led him to cover human rights issues in places like Bosnia, Sierra Leone and Afghanistan, where he recently worked on an article for National Geographic Adventure about Ahmad Shah Massoud, the military commander who opposes the Taliban, the Muslim group that controls Afghanistan.
"It's fun to have money, but the more money I get, the less interesting it becomes," he said. "If you don't have very much, you have to think about it. If you are starving, you become interested in food. If you are struggling to pay the bills, money becomes tragically important. I don't have to worry about money again. The idea of putting five minutes into it is not appealing."
Well, maybe just five minutes. "It is not under a rock somewhere," he said of his financial bounty. "I have a financial adviser."
Through his accountant, Mr. Junger met Richard Wald, a financial consultant at Merrill Lynch who now manages his portfolio.
Mr. Junger's mandate was simple. "I told my broker: 'Just don't lose it. Keep up with inflation,' " he said. "But even if I lost it, I could just write another book."
Staying within those constraints, Mr. Wald said he had invested 35 percent of Mr. Junger's portfolio in tax-free municipal bonds. The balance is in equities, weighted heavily toward brand-name stocks like Cisco Systems, Merck, Citigroup and America Online, he added.
Like many other people, Mr. Junger finds finance numbingly dull. He said he did not know how he had done as an investor. "There is a graph, and it has gone up," he said nonchalantly. But this year, Mr. Wald says his client is down 3.4 percent, after gaining 27 percent last year.
Mr. Junger does not read the financial pages and says he has no desire to educate himself about the market. Asked what stocks he owned, he thought for a moment. "I don't think I know a single one," he answered.
"The stock market goes up or down, whatever," he said. "It will all come back around. If there were some horrendous crash, it would make me notice, but I don't need the money, so I could ride out a 20-year cycle. It's not like I am about to send a kid to college and I need $10,000."
ALTHOUGH "The Perfect Storm" did not deal with large social causes, that is where his interests are now. He wants to write about themes related to the environment or human rights, because "they affect the human race," he said. "The others are just human drama," he added. "That's why I don't write about mountaineering. It just doesn't matter if anyone climbs another mountain."
His journalistic priorities, however, have not led him to set strictures on the kinds of investments that Merrill Lynch can make. "I don't mean to sound idealistic, because it is not," Mr. Junger said. "It is just deeply uninteresting to me."
But his penchant for risky assignments has had at least one impact on financial planning. He has a new will. "I forced him to update his will," Mr. Wald said. "He seems to love going to these faraway places. He's not a guy who goes to the Caribbean."
Still, Mr. Junger's newfound wealth has turned him into something of a foodie -- he often goes out to restaurants. While writing "The Perfect Storm," he said, he shopped for groceries and ate at home. But he said he had not been to a grocery store since he moved to New York in 1995, after completing the book.
And he has twice spent bundles of money for personal reasons -- moves that may ultimately prove smart financially. In October, he closed on the $470,000 purchase of a 1780's farmhouse on nine acres here in Truro, adjacent to a national preserve and near his parents' summer house. "It met my criteria," he said. "It had to be old and isolated."
Through Mr. Wald, Merrill Lynch helped him to arrange a mortgage that covered the entire purchase price and was collateralized against his assets. "That way, he didn't have to sell stocks and trigger capital gains taxes," Mr. Wald said.
Earlier this year, Mr. Junger and three friends from the New York media industry put up about $360,000 to start the Half King, a bar on West 23rd Street in Manhattan that is a gathering spot for journalists and other writers. Mr. Junger contributed one-third of the investment. Though the project was overseen by one partner who had already owned a bar, Mr. Junger and his friends helped, too, particularly in the weeks before the Half King opened in July; the work included menial tasks like carting debris to the dump. Because of Mr. Junger's involvement, the bar has garnered plenty of publicity.
For Mr. Junger, the Half King was "a place to hang out socially."
"The thing about the bar is that in some very crude sense, there is a community, and this is the place where it happens," he said. But he is also proud of its financial success. "It's doing very well," he said. "We are making a profit, and we will pay back the initial investment early next year," which is on target.
TODAY, Mr. Junger is a bit less puritanical in his home life in New York, too. Last year, he moved from a two-room rental on East 3rd Street to a three-room apartment further south, on Rivington Street, that rents for $2,500 a month. Still, the place has the simplicity of a college dormitory. There is a mattress on the floor, a makeshift desk, a kitchen in chaos, no television set and a William Butler Yeats poem pinned on the wall. That is about as luxurious as his life gets.
The best place to find testimony to Mr. Junger's fame may be in the barrage of e-mail and phone messages that clog his computer and flood his answering service daily. Many are from television and radio programs, asking him to be a guest, particularly to discuss human rights issues. Recently, he was on ABC's "Nightline" to talk about civil-war violence in Sierra Leone, the subject of one of his articles in Vanity Fair.
As Mr. Junger tells his life story, he has never shared middle-class goals. As a child, he was fascinated by Indians, and his room in Belmont, a Boston suburb where his parents still live, remains filled with bows and arrows he made. He would often slip down a rope from his second-floor bedroom to spend the night in the woods. "If it was a cold night, I wanted to see whether I could keep myself warm," he said. "I wanted to test myself."
As a teenager, Mr. Junger said, he never measured himself by the girlfriends and fast cars that were the hallmarks of his peers' efforts to show that they were adults. "The problem with that is it doesn't prove anything," he said.
At Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., where his major was cultural anthropology, Mr. Junger had two roommates who planned to go into finance. They would ask him what he expected to do when he graduated, but he said he could not remember his response. An early resume included construction work, waiting tables and even cleaning beauty parlors. "That paid pretty well," he said, "about $20 an hour."
At the time, he had a contempt for business -- and still takes a somewhat dismissive view of it. "There are these people who work in the corporate mill," he complained. "They hate it, but they say to themselves, 'I can work very hard so I can retire at 40 and play golf.' "
He acknowledged some exceptions to his description of business as a grind. "Rich really seems to like what he does," he said of his broker, sounding somewhat skeptical.
Still quizzical, he added: "Who wants a life of ease? And who wants a life in the office that you hate, and who wants to play golf?"
Of the tame challenges that Mr. Junger despises, golf is the epitome. To him, it represents the antithesis of the personal risks faced by the fishermen in Gloucester -- or even by tree cutters. "One of the reasons I picked golf was the clothing and those words -- 'birdie' and 'bogey,' " he said, examining the roots of his distaste. "How can a grown man play a game with those words?
"I met a man who had been a sword-boat captain and had had an incredible career," he recalled. "He was in his late 40's, had a house in the suburbs and a wife and two kids. He said, 'I'm really looking forward to my golf game.' I couldn't understand how the two things could co-exist in one person -- a guy who had loved the sea life for 10, 20, 30 years. Golf is so tame."
MR. JUNGER'S parents never pressed him to become more mainstream. His father, Miguel, received a doctorate in applied physics at Harvard but turned down an offer to teach there. Instead, he started a consulting firm in applied physics, doing extensive research for the Navy.
Sebastian's mother, Ellen Sinclair, is an artist. Her work, mostly landscapes, hangs both in Mr. Junger's New York apartment and in the house on Cape Cod.
As Sebastian, ever the grand romantic, looked for the ultimate challenge after college, he found that writing appealed to him. So he roamed around the country, writing about things that caught his fancy. He once went with a friend to Presidio, Tex., a small town on the Mexican border.
"The border area is dicey," he remembered. "It was full of illegal aliens and drugs. I had a station wagon and slept out in the desert with an ax, just in case." He turned the experience into a 1991 article he sold to The Gamut, a literary journal.
In his late 20's, unable to support himself writing, he met a man in a bar who offered him a job chopping down trees. "It fulfilled all the criteria for a rite of passage," he said, "in terms of doing something that frightened me, that I was then proud of."
At a tree cutter, he showed some financial skills. "I would bid for a job, say $3,000 for three days," he explained. Then he would hire a carting company to clear the debris he left behind; he paid it $600 and kept the difference. That way, he never had to pay for insurance, which was expensive. "I was covered because the other company was on the property," he said with glee.
The experience generated his idea to write about people who risked their lives to earn a living. Mr. Kriechevsky, his agent, said he took him on because "Sebastian was writing about working people in a way that I didn't see other writers doing."
"He wrote about them with a real respect for physical work," Mr. Kriechevsky added, "and an interest in it."
After a newspaper article about the disappearance of a fishing boat off Gloucester piqued his interest, Mr. Junger submitted an outline for a book in 1992 to his agent, then went to Bosnia to work as a freelance radio journalist. Soon, he received word of a $35,000 advance from Norton and returned to work on the book.
Its eventual success, while letting Mr. Junger choose his assignments, has not led him to risky choices in investments. "In part," Mr. Wald said, "the portfolio is conservatively allocated because Mr. Junger doesn't need to take enormous risk to increase his capital."
Mr. Kriechevsky said Mr. Junger would probably receive royalties from "The Perfect Storm" for the rest of his life. The book has been published in 22 languages and 24 countries.
AS Mr. Wald recalls his first meetings with Mr. Junger, "I tried to teach the basics of Investing 101, like, 'Don't put all your eggs in one basket.'
"We opened a pension plan, because he had nothing in terms of retirement money," he added. "And each year we put in the maximum."
Each quarter, he and Mr. Junger review projected income, part of it from a contract with Vanity Fair for two articles a year. "We have a gentlemen's agreement," Mr. Junger said. "It is nonexclusive, but I offer them the ideas first."
Because Mr. Junger's income from writing and royalties is more than he needs to live on, Mr. Wald has money to invest, including gains from his client's investment portfolio.
Of course, if Mr. Junger marries, his lifestyle and spending habits will change. "We never speak of it," Mrs. Junger said, sounding like most mothers. Then she paused and said, "But I have a friend who is a psychic who told me that he will fall in love when he is 40 and get married immediately."
Mr. Junger appeared quite startled by that news, which seemed to amuse him. "I hope I get married one day," he said.
Maybe Mr. Wald should start buying the zero-coupon bonds that parents often use to pay for their children's education.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Two Paths to Profit From the January Effect

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BELEAGUERED technology-stock investors are consoling themselves that the January Effect -- the celebrated tendency of all stocks, especially small-capitalization ones, to perform well as the year begins -- should be particularly good to them next year. After all, popular wisdom holds that the previous year's biggest losers should be among the biggest January gainers.
Until recently, market scholars questioned that popular wisdom, but new research suggests that the technology investors are on solid ground in expecting a January bounce. The reason is tax-loss selling. At year-end, as investors look for losses they can use to reduce their tax bills come April 15, they sell their losers. Because those sales must be completed by the end of December to have the intended effect, there is abnormal selling pressure on such stocks. 
 That selling, of course, comes to a halt by Jan. 1. The January bounce is largest for stocks with small market valuations, because they are most likely to be held by individuals rather than institutions, which have fewer tax-related incentives to take year-end losses.
Until this new research, many scholars had dismissed tax-loss selling as a cause of the January Effect, preferring various other explanations. They noted that the January Effect exists even in countries that have no capital gains tax, and therefore no tax incentive to sell losers before the end of the year. To be sure, that does not completely disprove the tax-loss selling theory, since the January Effect in such countries could come from year-end selling by foreigners who do pay capital gains taxes.
But the new study, which will appear in the February 2001 issue of The Journal of Finance, shows convincingly that even if tax-loss selling is not the sole reason for the January Effect, it must be counted as a prime cause. The authors -- James Poterba, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Scott Weisbenner, an assistant professor of finance at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign -- devised an ingenious way to make their point: They studied whether changes in American capital gains tax laws over the last four decades had any impact on the January Effect. The answer, they found, was yes -- offering clear evidence in favor of the tax-loss-selling theory.
Consider what happened in the late 1980's, after the holding period for long-term capital gains was increased from 6 to 12 months. Before that change, year-end selling pressure affected mostly stocks whose losses occurred after July 1; only for such stocks, of course, would selling to capture losses have the greatest tax benefits. In January, these stocks therefore rebounded the most.
After the lengthening of the holding period, investors could use year-end selling to capture losses that occurred at any point during the year. That explains how the January Effect became just about as pronounced for stocks whose losses occurred in the first half of the year. And all such stocks tended to rebound in January.
So it would appear that technology investors can reasonably expect their stocks to outperform the market next month. Unfortunately, if you are not already holding such stocks, it is difficult to devise a trading strategy to profit from the seasonal pattern. According to Richard Roll, a professor of finance at the Anderson School of the University of California at Los Angeles, the January Effect, on average, is smaller than the transaction costs of buying and selling the stocks. Mr. Roll reached that conclusion after measuring the January Effect for even the biggest losers over previous years; he found that that bid-asked spreads between buyers and sellers are just as large as the January Effect on such stocks.
NOT that knowledge of the January Effect is useless. If you are already planning to sell some stocks over the next month or two, incurring transaction costs anyway, you should consider selling only in late January --after the January Effect has given a boost to the market.
Similarly, if you are already planning to buy stocks over the next month or two, you should do so before the end of this month. And you might want to focus on stocks that have been among this year's biggest losers.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Unfortunate Timing, No Matter Who Wins

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IF a bad economy can break a president, then this is not the moment to become president of the United States. The economy is clearly faltering, on all fronts. What we are experiencing is no brief dip, to be followed soon by a fresh surge of activity. America faces a dry period -- long enough, perhaps, to taint the next chief of state, whether he is Al Gore or George W. Bush.
There is plenty of political baggage in a slowdown at this moment. Bill Clinton took office in 1993 just as the economy was finally growing stronger. If George Bush had been re-elected, the upturn probably would have happened anyway. Instead, he received the blame for the slow growth years that preceded the Clinton administration, and now his son vies for the presidency just as the economy slows again. 
 The Democrats, of course, had taken such pride in the booming expansion. They had counted on it to elect Mr. Gore. And now Mr. Clinton is leaving office just as the expansion may be unraveling. "There is no question that we are looking at moderate growth going forward," said Martin Baily, the chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
Nearly every statistic proclaims the slowdown. Autos, housing, computer sales, capital spending, corporate profits, consumer confidence, factory production, store sales, income, job creation, stock prices -- all have weakened in recent weeks. And merchandise has piled up, encouraging companies to cancel orders if sales do not revive soon.
Responding to the changing mood, forecasters are beginning to scale back their estimates of economic growth to less than 3 percent over the coming year. In doing so, they are bringing their estimates in line with the Commerce Department's latest, shrinking numbers. The gross domestic product, the standard measure of how much the nation is producing, expanded at an annual rate of only 2.4 percent in the third quarter, the department announced last Wednesday. That was the slowest quarterly growth in four years.
Suddenly, the debate has shifted from how rapidly the economy can expand without raising the inflation rate to whether a slowing economy will keel over into recession. Or whether the slow growth, like water torture, will persist for months, hurting the next president as unemployment gradually rises and wages stagnate. "The stock market is so bad," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, "that there is a tendency on Wall Street to assume there will be a hard landing, a recession."
That is not the sort of talk that the economists advising Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush care to engage in. Until the presidency is settled, they are not taking calls from reporters, thus avoiding the risk of saying something that might trip up their leaders. When the subject came up at a Dick Cheney news conference last week, he said, vaguely: "I am personally not an economist, but it is a subject, clearly, that's of interest to us."
The pitfalls that could tip the economy into recession are plain enough. During the good years, stock prices rose beyond reasonable measures of corporate value. Simultaneously, both companies and consumers piled up debt to pay for their spending. So far, neither the falling market nor the record debt levels seem to be turning off consumption or halting investment. Still, bad news, day after day, eventually takes its toll. Just as spending soared, a pullback could be equally excessive. History offers more than a few examples of irrational exuberance followed by irrational pessimism.
Prosperity is not the only thing at stake. Political reputations are also in play. Clinton administration officials insist that their policies turned a rising economy into a booming one. They argue that the 1993 tax increase, coupled with the president's decision to hold back on public spending, pleased bond traders -- holding out to them the prospect of a disappearing deficit and less inflationary pressure.
As the economy boomed, bond traders did not insist on pushing up interest rates in expectation of rising inflation. And Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gambled successfully that the economy could expand more rapidly than in the past without more inflation. So he let the boom proceed without raising rates.
There is truth in these explanations. But if Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan deserve some of the credit for the boom, they almost certainly will get some of the blame for allowing the excesses to develop that now threaten the economy.
Business cycles have a life of their own, of course, and a perverse sense of humor. A persistent slowdown, or a recession, during a Gore presidency would be hard for Mr. Gore to explain without tarnishing his old boss. And a similarly weak economy with Mr. Bush in office would visit on the son the same unhappy reputation that has saddled the father.
