HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Practicing What Free Traders Preach

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE was something oddly symmetrical about the way the people on both sides of the barricades commemorated the first anniversary of the Battle of Seattle last week. Protesters who helped make the global trade summit a disaster hailed their triumph with a pep rally, where one street leader proclaimed that Seattle meant "no more business as usual" for trade ministers. They showed a feature film that eulogized the anti-globalization uprising.
But trade ministers are having their own bacchanal. The United States announced the opening of free trade negotiations with Chile, just a week after beginning talks with Singapore, a month after wrapping up a free trade agreement with Jordan and two months after signing a trade accord with Vietnam. And many analysts think the Clinton administration is lagging its foreign rivals. 
 The European Union just sealed a free-trade agreement with Mexico. European nations are also talking about eliminating tariffs and most trade barriers with Brazil and its neighbors, and they are considering the same arrangement with Central American nations -- a step ahead of Uncle Sam.
In the Pacific, there is a free-trade frenzy underway. Japan began bilateral free-trade talks with South Korea, Singapore and Mexico, the first time since World War II that Japan has tried to loosen restrictions on trade outside a global agreement. China, on ther verge of entry to the World Trade Organization after a long fight, one-upped Japan with a proposal that the entire East Asian region become the world's most populous free trade zone.
One reason for the rush: trade itself is having a banner year. John F. Kennedy was president the last time the flow of goods and services across borders increased as fast as it is set to grow this year -- a 12.5 percent rate, according to new World Bank projections. Every nation wants a bigger piece of the trade pie.
But if the momentum toward freer trade is clearly stronger than the backlash against it, there's also a sense in which the Seattle crowd can claim success.
The flurry of two-way and regional trade talks belies the failure to start a global round of negotiations to replace the one that collapsed in Seattle. The agenda is still in dispute, and there are practical concerns, like finding a venue willing to accommodate the expected demonstrations.
There's more at stake in global summits than when nations hand pick negotiating partners. Only the broader talks force all nations to address the most politically sensitive questions: subsidies for farmers (Europe, Japan), protections for textile workers (United States), standards for labor and the environment (developing world). The regional agreements are like warm-ups for the championship round.
But it is also notable that the events that were supposed to make people slow down and think twice about economic integration have done nothing of the sort. The Asian financial crisis, if anything, unleashed more trade and prompted greater harmonization of economies there. And the Seattle spectacle has simply prompted trade ministers to push tariff reductions in private talks.
Not unlike crisscrossing military alliances in the pre-World War I era, the proliferation of trade agreements is part of world diplomacy -- the way nations talk to each other. Europe uses trade to retain influence in Latin America, which Brussels feared would focus exclusively on Washington after Nafta. China's trade push reflects its ambition of becoming Asia's leading nation. Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Vietnam are wary of that trend.
"These free trade agreements are a question of how nations look at their strategic positioning," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. "People don't want to be cut out, not just because of commercial disadvantage, but because these are spheres of influence."
That reality poses an acute challenge to Ms. Barshefsky's successor. The domestic politics of trade have become increasingly poisonous since Seattle, and the sharply divided Congress almost guarantees a fight over any trade accords. But the United States will also be under intense pressure to step up the pace of trade liberalization.
The Seattle coalition will be particularly chagrined if Gov. George W. Bush's current advantage in the Florida count secures him the White House. Unions, environmentalists and consumer groups overwhelmingly backed Vice President Al Gore, partly because he promised not to expand trade without establishing labor and environmental standards first. Mr. Bush is an old fashioned free trader. He wants to expand Nafta now.
"There's a question of how much political capital Bush will want to spend," said Robert D. Hormats, a Goldman Sachs executive who is thought of as possible economic official in a Bush administration. "But we can't just sit around while everyone does these deals."

HEADLINE: Brazil Miffed As Chile Shifts Trade Focus Toward U.S.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The future of the world's third-largest trade bloc, the Brazilian-led Mercosur group, has suddenly been thrown into doubt by Chile's surprise announcement this week that it will defer its request for membership and instead seek a free trade agreement with the United States.
By opting to revive its efforts to gain a bilateral accord with the United States, Chile, which already has the most open economy in Latin America, has given new momentum to a proposal made by President Clinton in 1994 to establish a Free Trade Area of the Americas by 2005. At the same time, South America's efforts to speak with a single voice in the slow-moving effort to negotiate such an accord with the United States may have been seriously, and perhaps fatally, undermined. 
 Valor, a business daily here, described Chile's decision, announced Wednesday by President Ricardo Lagos during a visit to the United States, as a "stab in the back" of the four Mercosur countries: Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. Jornal do Brasil, another daily here, preferred a chess analogy, saying that the Chilean move "puts Mercosur in check."
"This is definitely a blow to any effort to present a united front in our negotiations with the incoming administration in the United States," a former Brazilian official said Friday. "We are all going to have to rethink things and try to regroup."
Chile, along with Bolivia, is an associate member of Mercosur, and when Mr. Lagos took office in March, he announced that one of his first objectives would be full membership in the group.
But talks quickly ran into trouble over the tricky question of achieving a common tariff policy.
Tariffs within the Mercosur group average about 14 percent, compared with the 6 percent that is Chile's goal for 2003, and Brazil argued that the Lagos government should be more accommodating to its neighbors.
"It is Chile that is seeking to join Mercosur, not Mercosur that is seeking to join Chile," the Brazilian foreign minister, Luiz Felipe Lampreia, said earlier this year.
In a recent interview, Mr. Lampreia said that "all four of us strongly desire" that Chile become a full member of the group, but he added that Mercosur nations would not fundamentally change their trade policy to eliminate the tariff problem with Chile.
During a recent regional summit meeting in Brasilia, Mr. Lagos showed some discomfort with that position, and two weeks ago said his country favored slowing the pace of negotiations with Mercosur.
Chile was an early and enthusiastic supporter of hemispheric free trade, having asked for a bilateral agreement with the United States when Mexico was granted that status in 1994.
But after Congress failed to give Mr. Clinton so-called "fast track" authority to negotiate such an accord, Chile's focus shifted to the South American group, which has a population of more than 200 million people and a combined gross national product of more than $1 trillion.
Efforts to reach the broader American-sponsored hemisphere-wide accord are continuing, with the United States and Brazil acting as joint chairmen. But Brazil has consistently expressed doubts about both the timetable and reach of the negotiations, leading to American complaints of foot-dragging or outright sabotage.
"I think the prospect of seeing a free trade area by 2005 is pretty unrealistic right now," William Daley, then the secretary of commerce, said in June at a conference in Madrid. "If Brazil doesn't become aggressive at some point, I don't think it's going to happen."
But with the Chilean shift, Brazil now faces the prospect that its South American partners may be tempted to defect. Jose Luis Machinea, Argentina's minister of the economy, said Thursday that "Chile should be congratulated" for its action and that his country now "should accelerate its integration" into the free trade area with the United States.
The Chilean decision also puts direct pressure on Brazil, as American officials are well aware. If talks between the United States and Chile, which are expected to start this month, lead quickly to an agreement, American and European investment could be drawn away from Brazil and toward Chile.
"A free trade agreement between Chile and the United States will be an important building block in the creation of an equitable and balanced Free Trade Area of the Americas," Anthony S. Harrington, the American ambassador to Brazil, said Thursday.
He added that he hoped that by 2005, "if not earlier," such a trade agreement might also include Brazil.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
150 Years of Dining, Champagne to Chop Suey, in One Bite

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Terrapin soup? Calf's head with brain sauce? Foot-long oysters plucked from Manhattan Beach? City health inspectors may not approve, but adventurous eaters can still savor these restaurant classics.
At the New York Public Library, 150 years of the city's history can be traced through what diners ate. There, one can sample a testimonial dinner at the legendary Delmonico's in honor of Charles Dickens during a visit to New York in 1867. It is also possible to size up the crowd at Reisenweber's, a lobster-palace-turned-cabaret, or to scan the prices at the Essex House, three decades and two recessions before Alain Ducasse began charging $160 for a four-course fixed-price dinner. One menu, in the form of a teepee, lists the dishes at a 1902 dinner of the Society of Colonial Wars in the United States. 
 More than 25,000 menus dating back to 1843 are housed in an archive in the main library on Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Considered one of the world's largest such collections, the archive offers a singular entry into the city's dining and social habits, beginning with its early obsession with French cooking through the culinary malaise of the Prohibition era to the current fascination with rare ingredients. "It really does justice to the texture of New York life in all its diversity and ebullience," said Alison Ryley, a former curator of the collection.
The archive was started in 1899 by an eccentric volunteer named Miss Frank E. Buttolph. From 1901 until her death in 1924, she set out across the city gathering bills of fare, from the chandeliered halls of the Waldorf-Astoria to the 15-cent lunchrooms along the Bowery.
Early menus paint a city enjoying an embarrassment of riches. Establishments like Delmonico's churned out lavish 12-course meals at $200 a head in an age of $5-a-week wages. In one memorable evening, the New York Riding Club held a white-tie banquet at which guests dined on horseback and sipped champagne from their saddlebags. The event was held at Sherry's Restaurant, which had moved into opulent quarters designed by Stanford White at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, just across the avenue from Delmonico's. Over the next two decades, the two restaurants were locked in a truffle-coated food fight that is deliciously recorded in the collection.
While menus from the city's top restaurants were written almost entirely in French, other documents from this period give added meaning to the proverbial melting pot. Chinese restaurants on Mott Street began offering chop suey and other Westernized dishes as early as the 1870's. Spaghetti and chow mein were served alongside schmaltz herring at some kosher restaurants in the Lower East Side.
Since the menus are housed in some 400 boxes that must be individually ordered, the process of looking through them seems as antiquated as some of the menus. For every item that captures the eye with inlaid gold or a pink tassel, there are dozens that simply lists the day's specials on plain paper. The only index is a card file that Miss Buttolph created herself, although library volunteers have begun keying in search terms, like "lady cake" and "Barbetta," into a computer database.
Yet, for all the endless variety of restaurants in the city, both present and past, the impulse for dining out appears to be timeless.
"People in New York go out to be seen and not necessarily for the food," said Michael Krondl, author of "Around the American Table" (Adams Media), a book of recipes drawn from the library's archives. "That's still true." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Tech's Down But He's Up, So What's His Secret?

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
YOU probably can't invest with Lawrence A. Bowman. The minimum investments for the funds he runs at Bowman Capital start at $1 million. But he recently offered thoughts about the market for smaller, individual investors. Following are excerpts from interviews. DANNY HAKIM
 
Q. Many middle-class Americans participate in the market only through mutual funds. Which fund managers do you respect? 

A. Bob Stansky of Fidelity Magellan is the best. Chip Morris of T. Rowe Price Science & Technology , Gerry Malone of Alliance Technology , Paul Wick of Seligman Communications and Information ; they are all very good, but they don't have the tools and the toolbox to do what we do. These guys are in Model T's and we're in race cars.
They're all very intelligent, and I'm glad I'm competing with them with their hands tied behind their backs, through no fault of their own.
 
Q. Since mutual funds don't use your hedging techniques to protect against bear markets, what would you do if you were an individual investor, now that the Nasdaq has fallen from over 4,000 to 2,600 since April? Is it time to buy a tech fund?
 
A. I wouldn't yet. People say if you have a long-term approach it always kind of works out, and it will, because tech will be up tenfold in the next, whatever, 10 years. They say it doesn't matter if you get in and the market declines.
The truth of the matter is, when you really run the numbers, what matters the most is what happens in the first year. If you're down 20 percent in your first year, you've got to get to 25 percent just to break even. You need a good start and I don't see the bottom yet. I really believe there could be another 20 to 30 percent down in the Nasdaq if demand continues to soften. So I wouldn't come in right now.
The purpose of bear markets is to wipe out excesses from the previous bull markets. The excess of the 90's has been the mantra of the bull market babies, which is to buy every dip. Until we've wiped that out, we haven't finished this bear market correction.
Now, what could make everything turn around is if you wake up tomorrow and the economy magically appears. It's hard to see that, though. The wealth effect will compound itself this quarter. Everyone I know feels more poor now than they did a month ago, or a month before that, in the strongest season of the year, so do not expect a strong holiday season.
Now if demand turns positively, then, you know what, call me up and I go, "Look, I was wrong, demand turned and we're long again."
 
Q. Are there any bright spots?
 
A. There are some areas that are still very strong. Without telling you if we own these stocks, I'll tell you areas where we see strength. In data storage, you see demand strong, so EMC and Veritas are strong. Surprisingly, there's strength in the Unix area, but specifically just with Sun. They're gaining share and they really have their act together. In networking you still see strength at companies like Cisco, which is hard to believe considering how large they are and how economically sensitive they are. There's still a ton of very robust demand at Cisco because they're such a high-quality company with the right products at the right time.
And then the optical switch companies' demand is so very strong, even with all the telecom blowups. Sycamore, ONI, Juniper on the router side, Avici. The problem with these companies is that the valuations are still high relative to the market environment we're in. But demand is still strong there.
These are companies I would look to own significantly if the economy turns. If a company's demand is this strong in a soft economic environment, imagine how strong it'll be when the economy recovers.

HEADLINE: Master of Universe (Updated Model)

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: SAN MATEO, Calif.

 BODY:
LAWRENCE A. BOWMAN employs a full-time staff of 10. For his cars. His 37 cars -- that's 3.7 vehicles per mechanic. There is the Cobra Daytona Coupe, the 1971 Barracuda, the 10 Corvettes. And, yes, there is a somewhat legendary red Ferrari in which he has been known to conduct job interviews.
"I love horsepower," says Mr. Bowman, who races Formula Fords for fun but promises that he has never driven over 180 miles an hour. Mr. Bowman, 42 and a chiseled 6-foot-3, pauses for a moment, thinking that he should perhaps throttle down. 
 "I've never gone over 174 on a public road," he adds, his face settling into a grimace with the faintest hint of a smile.
Mr. Bowman exudes confidence: he is one of today's masters of the universe, a private investment manager at the top of his game. He and his chief partner, John K. Hurley, both former star technology investors at Fidelity Investments, run the $5.5 billion Bowman Capital, a private technology investment firm that has been an oasis of positive returns this year in a land of losses. The firm -- part hedge fund, part venture capital fund -- caters to the elite of Silicon Valley. Michael Dell invests with it. So does Gregory B. Maffei, the former chief financial officer of Microsoft. And Avram Miller, a former top executive of Intel who is a director of CMGI. And so do scores of technology executives, venture capitalists and institutional investors like the MacArthur Foundation and the University of California at Berkeley.
In the last few years, the brand names of private money management -- Soros, Robertson, Meriwether -- were gathered up like twigs for kindling. As their complex bets on global macroeconomic trends, or on the convergence of currency, stock or bond prices, started losing tens of billions of dollars in the late 90's, they gave way to Silicon Valley's venture capitalists as the rock stars of money management. But now rising to prominence is a third group of money managers, like Bowman Capital, that make bets on both the winners and the losers in the valley.
The glad-handing days of 1998 and 1999 that made the venture capitalists and individual technology investors rich have ended. What becomes now of those technology investors in a world that has suddenly decided to heap scorn on their stocks?
In times like these, it helps to play with all the cards in the deck -- as Bowman has.
One should not be fooled by Mr. Bowman's California casual dress -- the slacks, the sweater, the bright orange watch -- or by the drab Silicon Valley office building across the street from a T. J. Maxx that is his headquarters. While he is a bona fide techie -- he worked as an engineer at Apple Computer and Texas Instruments in the 80's -- he is also an East Coast financial veteran, not only of Fidelity but also of Tiger Management when it was one of the world's largest hedge funds, the private investment pools for wealthy and institutional investors. Now, Mr. Bowman's firm, not quite six years old, ranks as one of the world's 10 largest hedge funds and is an emerging force in the world of venture capital.
What appeals to many Silicon Valley executives and other investors is that Bowman Capital knows when to bite the hand that has fed them all, hedging its bets by short-selling, or betting that some of its neighbors in the valley will decline. And decline they have.
"This quarter, it's 'run for the hills, be short and protect everything you can because the sky is falling,' " Mr. Bowman said in an interview last week. Yet after it started in February 1995, Bowman averaged annual gains of 62 percent through the end of last year, according to people close to the firm. More important, its funds gained 19 percent, on average, this year through November, compared with a 36.2 percent loss in the Nasdaq composite index, home to many technology stocks. Those returns take into account the firm's charges: a 1 percent or 2 percent annual management fee, as well as 20 percent of the profits. (Those fees are the norm in the world of private investment.)
DO I know as much about these tech companies?" said Mr. Maffei, an investor and now chief executive of 360networks, a telecommunications company based in Vancouver, British Columbia. "Yes, but they know more about trading stocks."
Jeffery J. Mora, who runs part of Northwestern University's $4 billion endowment, which invests some of its money with Bowman, said: "What we look for with Bowman is what they've delivered this year. In choppy markets, they can deliver attractive returns. These are guys that can profit both on the long and the short side. Larry has the skill to add value when markets go up or go down."
Indeed, as the gilded age turns leaden, the best money managers might turn out to be the ones that can profit on both sides of the fence, that can pick the good stocks in the valley and short the no-earnings dot-coms.
"We have the tools to do anything," Mr. Bowman explained. "The mutual funds can only go long. These guys are stuck. They can go 5 or 10 percent cash, then they have to just bleed every day.
"Same thing with venture capital funds," he added. "They go long and when the stock comes out of an I.P.O., they've got a stock they can't even sell." He was referring to the six-month lockup period that restricts insiders from selling stock right after an initial public offering.
Mr. Hurley, 36, said that last year, he had difficulty explaining to clients why their funds were "only up 100 percent because we're taking less risk."
"Reading about some of the great investors in history, the most important thing they do is preserve capital in bad markets," he said, adding that "a market like this makes it clearer to folks what we've been talking about."
The "nastiness" will continue, Mr. Bowman said, at least into the first quarter of next year. Indeed, the man to whom some of the valley's top venture capitalists turn for advice on the public markets has turned deeply bearish. In early November, his fund not only had as many short positions as it did long bets, it was more than half in cash, a very cautious stance.
"This year started out like a bottle rocket and it turned into a bomb," he said. "In the strongest seasonal quarter of the year, we're having demand disappointments everywhere," he said. "It's very, very scary."
MR. BOWMAN, a steelworker's son, graduated from Lehigh University and worked in Silicon Valley as an engineer until a few lucky bets on the market convinced him that he was as interested in trading his personal portfolio as he was in technology.
"I was clueless, but I felt like a genius," he said. "That got the passion going."
He then received an M.B.A. at the Stanford Business School, and moved to Boston, starting his new career at Fidelity.
"At 30, I was getting coffee for old-world bond traders and making copies," he said. But when he became a technology analyst, he learned the art of stock-picking from some of the industry's legends, like Peter Lynch, the revered former manager of the Fidelity Magellan fund, and Robert Stansky, Magellan's current manager. "Stansky, I'd put up there as the best growth investor I've ever met in my life," he said.
He also met Mr. Hurley, who also had a Stanford M.B.A. but had a much different background. Mr. Hurley had put off his enrollment at Stanford to serve with his Army unit in the Persian Gulf war, where he supervised battlefield computer and communications systems. At various times, each would run the portfolio that is now the $19 billion Fidelity Aggressive Growth fund.
Mr. Bowman and Mr. Hurley both heap praise on Fidelity, although working there was not without frustration. Mr. Bowman wanted to be a technology specialist but was working at a firm whose design was to train managers of diversified funds.
"Fidelity wouldn't open up an office in Silicon Valley," he said. "I begged them. You get paid at Fidelity to run diversified funds. That's why they've never had good specialists."
A spokeswoman for Fidelity, Anne Crowley, responded, "Historically, we have an excellent record on technology, and our record speaks for itself."
Still, the firm that Mr. Bowman and Mr. Hurley now run somewhat mimics Fidelity in miniature. One of the innovations of Edward C. Johnson III, Fidelity's chief executive, is that Fidelity's research analysts actually manage money; its Select funds, which focus on specific market sectors, are something of a farm team for its bread and butter, the huge diversified mutual funds like Magellan. Fidelity rotates its analysts from one Select fund to another to give them a breadth of knowledge.
Bowman's 25 analysts also manage pools of money, but they are all specialists in particular technology subsectors -- and they stay there. "All we want are specialized experts," Mr. Bowman said. "We don't want generalists."
In 1993, he left Fidelity, spent a year at Tiger Management learning the hedge fund business under another legendary investor, Julian H. Robertson Jr., and then went into business for himself by starting Bowman Capital. The firm was still relatively small, under $500 million in assets, when he decided to move from Stamford, Conn., to Silicon Valley in early 1997. His timing was propitious. Over the next three years, the world of money management divided in two: there were those who bet on technology and telecommunications stocks, and there were those who bet on everything else. The first group of investors were regarded as geniuses, and the second suffered mightily by comparison.
Then came the demise of Long-Term Capital Management in 1998, which had two Nobel laureates among its partners in addition to John W. Meriwether, the storied bond trader from Salomon Brothers. In March of this year, Mr. Robertson closed his firm, Tiger Management, declaring, "We are in a market where reason does not prevail."
Weeks later, George Soros, who once unsettled nations with his currency trading, said he would scale back his operations and rename his main fund an "endowment." Many of his investors fled as he switched to a strategy more akin to Geritol than Viagra.
As the old titans faded, new ones like Mr. Bowman rose, but they do not much resemble Mr. Soros or Mr. Robertson. The new giants -- Bowman in Silicon Valley, Pequot Capital in Westport, Conn., Galleon in New York -- run private funds that specialize mainly in technology. Unlike the old group of titans, Bowman uses very little leverage, because technology stocks are volatile enough by themselves. And for the most part, the firm does not bet on global macroeconomic trends.
Instead, the firm is like a Silicon Valley research group -- a consulting firm that helps venture capitalists and private companies understand what the public market is thinking. There is a price for this, and it is not only in money. The valley, like other niches of the financial world, has an I'll-scratch-your-back-if-you'll-scratch-mine ethic. No one can just show up at the door, waving the $1 million to $5 million minimum investment, and get in. Mr. Bowman expects many of his investors to become "insight partners" who will feed ideas and information to the firm. To that end, in 1998, it started its Founders fund, which has captains of the valley as its investors.
"The fund was launched to improve relationships with technology executives and venture capitalists," Mr. Bowman said. "Money is easy, O.K.? The scarcest resource over the long run is performance; it's not money. We can raise all the money we want; I don't care about that. We need partners. We need relationships."
CONSIDER Accel Partners, a $3.2 billion venture capital firm that has an informal alliance with Bowman. While Bowman does late-stage venture capital investing, Accel invests in companies that are, in some cases, just ideas.
"Some of the best business plans we've ever backed are four or five bullet points on a napkin," said James W. Breyer, Accel's managing partner. As a member of Bowman's board of advisers, Mr. Breyer has has passed several deals along to Bowman. In return, Accel uses Bowman as a consulting firm for understanding the public markets.
"That's not an area where we spend a lot of time," Mr. Breyer said. "We don't pretend to understand what the Fidelitys of the world do. There's a very different set of skills needed that we don't have. What a Bowman brings is a very deep understanding of what the public market looks for."
And this year, understanding the public markets has become ever more important. Investors of all sizes who plowed more and more money into technology stocks and funds over the last few years are now awash in losses. For the retail investor looking for a gold strike, the money management industry spawned scores of mutual funds that invested only in Internet and technology stocks. This year, some of those funds have closed, some are down by more than 75 percent and some are even excising the word "Internet" from their titles.
"Shorting killed you last year," Mr. Bowman said. "God, I wish we were a long-only mutual fund last year. But this is the kind of year that a firm like ours is able to reach into the toolbox."
Not that optimism has fled Silicon Valley, or Bowman Capital. After all, it has a venture capital fund to run, and that means the funding tap for new companies is staying open.
Late one mid-November morning in San Jose, four Bowman analysts had their Research In Motion pagers laid out on the oval conference table at Jetstream Communications, one of their venture capital pet projects. The company makes equipment to aid the speed and quality of voice communications over Internet networks. John Niedermaier, the company's chief financial officer, started his status report.
There were slides. There were charts. There were exclamation points. "Market opportunity is HUGE!" read one bullet point. "VOICE IS THE KILLER APP!!!" read another. There were wacky acronym mix-ups. ("It's VoDSL, not VDSL," someone said.) There were no earnings, of course, but there were promising-looking revenue numbers.
"The innovative work is not being done by the big companies; their engineers are creating new versions of existing software," said Spencer Punter, a Bowman partner, giving his pitch for why venture capital remained a vital source of opportunity.
"That's what's created this continuing cycle in the valley," he added.
LIKE everyone else, Bowman has made its share of questionable bets, including a venture investment in Pets.com, an e-commerce site. Though the firm has had venture investments since its start, it opened a dedicated venture capital fund only last year; it now has about $1 billion in assets.
"Putting a billion dollars to work around here is not the easiest thing to do," said one rival Silicon Valley money manager, who insisted on anonymity. "You take a shotgun out and hit anything that moves, and that's what he did," he added, referring figuratively to Mr. Bowman.
But Mr. Bowman's venture team does boast its share of sizzle, including investments in companies like Sycamore Networks and ONI Systems that are still well regarded, even if beaten up this year. Between Bowman venture capital investments that have gone public or gone bust, the firm has returned 288 percent, before fees, over two years through the end of September. Since then, Pets.com has ceased operations.
"We've had some investments that have not been successful; that's part of being in the venture capital business," said Matthew T. Cowan, a general partner in Bowman's venture investment arm. "In the ideal, three are going to be great, three are going to break even and you might lose money on three."
Bowman also uses hedging techniques in its venture capital fund, an approach rare in the V.C. world.
Mr. Miller, the former Intel executive, likes the safety net. "They can protect good positions by hedging something else," he said. "Frankly, most venture capitalists don't understand financial technology."
On average, Bowman Capital is about 45 percent exposed to the market. That means that if it had, say, $1 million in assets, it might buy $725,000 worth of securities and sell short $275,000 of securities, leaving it with a net long exposure of $450,000, or 45 percent of its assets. But by early November, the firm had bought and sold short securities in roughly equal proportions.
What will it take to get Bowman to reverse course and start buying again?
"We need to see an uptick in demand, both in U.S. consumers and in Europe, and that is hard to see coming into the first quarter of the year, which is the seasonally softest quarter. March could be a disaster," Mr. Bowman said, predicting that the first three months of next year will be "an unmitigated disaster."
"On the bullish side, cash levels over all are higher than I can remember across mutual funds and hedge funds, and sentiment is quite negative," he continued. "It won't take much to fuel a rally. That said, it won't be a sustainable rally unless fundamentals improve. We are in an economic slowdown and we don't know where the bottom is."
Bowman's largest positions, according to the firm's regulatory filings at the end of September, are two data storage companies: one that makes software, Veritas, and one that makes hardware, EMC.
"We do like the storage sector and EMC and Veritas are two leaders," he said, adding that the firm had been invested in both companies for about two years. "Business and the technological outlook for both are quite strong."
If anything, size will be Bowman's biggest challenge now.
"A tech fund at $200 million is a much different animal when it reaches $2 billion," said Barry H. Colvin, chief operating officer of Tremont Advisors, a hedge fund industry consulting firm. "They might not be able to short as effectively. They may have once had 50 positions and now they'll have 70 to 100 and now they have to buy bigger companies.
"Any sector manager has some number at which they will be constrained under their current strategy," he added. "I would say that Bowman is at that point. Those types of changes make it harder to make money."
For his part, Mr. Bowman said he believes that his firm will distinguish itself in this year of treacherous markets.
"Most of the guys we're competing with are bull market babies," he said. "That's why we're washing them out and we'll continue to wash them out.
"I'm praying for a market crash," he added. "Find me someone else who's doing that. You make money betting against the crowd."
Mr. Bowman has been known to choreograph push-up contests among his traders -- for money, of course -- and has a wolverine hide draped across a partition between two desks on his trading floor. And he has hardly surrounded himself with yes men.
"The successful money managers on Wall Street are all megalomaniacs," he said. "What we have here are wolverines. Individuals that will not lose."
TERESA ROMANEK, 29, interviewed for a secretary's job at Tiger Management when she was in her early 20's. "Teresa walks in, a farm girl from Nebraska, and says she wants to pick stocks," Mr. Bowman recalled. "I have a secretary's job, but she wants to pick stocks."
She became one of Bowman's first partners. Ms. Romanek, for her part, has a unique view of Mr. Bowman's ascent. "I remember when he got his first Ferrari," she said. "He parks it in the fire zone, cruises into the office in Bermuda shorts -- no socks, no shoes."
"He's matured since then," she added. "Now he wears shoes."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Having A Banana?

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Back when Jimmy Carter was president, his anti-inflation czar, Alfred Kahn, was chastised for his excessive frankness when he spoke about a possible recession. So in subsequent speeches he referred to the threatened event as a "banana."
Well, some people are doing their best to turn us into a banana republic; are we also about to turn into a banana economy? The answer is a definite maybe. 
 The long boom of the 1990's made many people forget a fundamental truth: the course of economic expansion never did run smooth. Alan Greenspan and his colleagues try to keep the economy on a steady course. But the Fed can never be sure either how much effect a change in interest rates will have or how long it will take for that effect to occur. So managing the economy is like trying to drive a car whose brakes have an uncertain and delayed effect on its speed. You have to expect an occasional sudden slowdown.
For more than a year the Fed has been tapping on those brakes, trying to slow an economy that it thought was growing too fast. Until a few weeks ago the higher interest rates didn't seem to be having much effect. Now there are signs that consumers are feeling cautious, a state of mind that isn't helped by the plunge in tech stocks. Meanwhile, low stock prices and high interest rates on corporate bonds are cramping business investment. So now it seems that the Fed may have stayed on the brakes a little too long.
If the economy slows too much the Fed can, of course, push interest rates back down. But like the rate hikes, any rate cut will have an uncertain and delayed effect. So there's a pretty good chance that the months ahead will see a slowdown severe enough to cause a rise in the unemployment rate. Whether that slowdown will be sharp enough or sustained enough to meet the technical definition of a recession -- at least two quarters of actual economic decline -- is more doubtful, but it's certainly a possibility.
But even if we do have a recession, so what? A brief recession might come as a shock to those who thought the laws of economic gravity had been repealed, but it needn't do any lasting harm. In 1990-91 we had a recession that, like the possible recession in our future, was basically a fumble by the Fed -- in other words, it didn't reflect any fundamental problems in the economy. Recovery was unusually slow, in part because of the side-effects of the savings and loan crisis, but even so the recession left few lasting scars and barely registered on the long bull market.
Admittedly, the recession before that -- the double-dip slump from 1979-82 -- was a much more wrenching affair. But that recession took place in an environment of runaway inflation, where getting prices under control took priority over a quick recovery. It's hard to see any parallel in our current situation.
If you want a parallel to worry about, it comes not from our own experience but from that of Japan. The world's second-largest economy went into a recession at the beginning of the 1990's and has never really gotten out, despite a series of interest-rate reductions that eventually brought short-term rates down to zero. And Japan's crisis followed an era of irrational exuberance that in some ways resembles the late 1990's in the U.S.: a period of vigorous growth, overweening national self-confidence and extremely high stock prices.
While there are some disturbing parallels between America now and Japan a decade ago, there are also important differences. U.S. stock prices never got as high compared with earnings as those in Japan, and we haven't had anything like Japan's real estate bubble. Japan's problems in getting a recovery going have also been aggravated by special national issues, like extremely conservative consumers and a rapidly aging population.
But aren't plunging tech stocks in effect predicting a severe recession? Maybe so -- but why would you believe that prediction? If the wild tech optimism of last spring didn't herald an unprecedented economic boom, the market's new pessimism needn't herald a looming slump.
So will we have a recession? Maybe. If so, will it be severe and prolonged? Not likely. And the best news of all is that the Fed will be able and ready to react, whoever is or isn't president.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Altered States;
A Shift in the U.S.-Cuba Time Warp

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN an era when an American president beguiles crowds in Vietnam, and China is a key trading partner, U.S. policymakers still need to be reminded of their victory over communism when talk turns to Cuba.
Cuba's transition to a free-market democracy is inevitable, a bipartisan task force of the Council on Foreign Relations declared in a report issued Wednesday. The committee asserted that the United States should move faster to open and increase a variety of contacts. 
 Yet whenever Washington focuses on that island with 11 million people just 90 miles offshore, peculiar things happen. Reason slips, tempers flare. And the custodians of the current hard-line policy are out of sync with the general public, which increasingly favors a less hostile stance toward Havana.
In October, Republican leaders stymied votes in both houses to open Cuba to more trade and travel. The bill finally signed by the president legalized the sale of food but denied vital funding; rather than increase travel, it froze current restrictions by codifying them into law.
Representative Mark Sanford, a South Carolina Republican, got a taste of the Cuba warp last summer, when he had won broad support for a measure to let Americans visit the island freely. After the vote, he sought to clear the air with his long-time ally, Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, who remains an ardent foe of any softening toward Havana.
What he got was a nasty fight. The two men turned red in the face as they screamed at each other. The spectacle on the House floor left staffers awkwardly staring at their shoes. Later, in conference, Mr. DeLay helped kill the Sanford bill.
After four decades of seeking to topple, discredit and isolate the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, the defense of the current American policy increasingly relies on strong-arm tactics and back-room deals.
Meanwhile, surveys show most Americans want a new approach. They want more interaction and trade. A recent poll by Florida International University found 80 percent of Americans would support a dialogue with the Cuban government. They favor the sale of food (86 percent) and medicine (90 percent). A key recommendation by the council task force urged opening Cuba to travel by all Americans.
Some people aren't waiting on Washington. Though officially barred from spending money in Cuba, an estimated 22,000 Americans illegally flew in as tourists from third countries last year. An additional 135,000 took part in authorized visits for academic, cultural and family exchanges.
The custody battle over 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez forced Americans to focus on Cuba for the first time in years, and many came to question the tactics of Cuban exile leaders, who have long had great influence over U.S.-Cuban relations.
"The people are way ahead of the politicians on this issue," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, who hopes to end the sanctions in the next Congress.
Two powerful lobbies, the American Farm Bureau and the United States Chamber of Commerce, are seeking to open up trade with Cuba. Leaders in both groups say they will press for what they say could represent a billion-dollar market for American food products alone.
EVEN some longtime supporters of sanctions see the change. "The consensus has moved on U.S. policy toward Cuba," said Dan Fisk, a former Senate aide who was instrumental in drafting the 1996 Helms-Burton Act, which tightened the embargo, but is now a signatory on the council report. The next president will witness the dismantling of efforts to isolate Mr. Castro, Mr. Fisk predicted.
Both Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore oppose eliminating all sanctions against Cuba while Mr. Castro is in power, leaving many analysts to foresee a piecemeal approach.
But economists in federal agencies like the Department of Agriculture and the International Trade Commission are now working on studies that forecast the economic impact of lifting sanctions.
Even among Cuban Americans, attitudes are changing. A majority favors selling food and medicine to Cuba, polls show, though most exiles voice support for the embargo. Elena Freyre, executive director of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, a liberal group, complained that exile lawmakers are out of step, catering only to the most intransigent, and best-financed, elements of the community. "The people who purport to represent that community are no longer doing so," she said.
But the battle must still be decided in Congress. In 1996, pro-embargo lawmakers -- nervous about President Bill Clinton's intentions -- stripped him of discretionary powers over the sanctions.
Some seasoned political fighters stand in the way. Among them is Mr. DeLay. His antipathy stems in part, aides say, from a jarring incident when he was a boy: gun-toting Cuban troops boarded his airliner during a stopover in Havana on a flight from Venezuela to the United States. And there are the two Cuban-American lawmakers from Miami, Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, who seem unyielding when it comes to Mr. Castro. In a political system oiled by compromise, such fervor can bring the process to a halt.
"The leadership has made a mockery of the democratic process," said Wayne S. Smith, a former diplomat in Havana. "For so long we have allowed our policy to be dictated from Miami against the will of a majority of the American people and a majority in Congress."
Mr. Sanford said the Cuban exile lobby has kept lawmakers in line with generous campaign contributions. "The answer, in part, is money," he said. "I've had people tell me, 'Hey, just take a quick trip to Miami and you're home $10,000 richer, in time for lunch.' "
Pro-embargo Cuban exiles and their allies say they are taking a moral stand against a repressive regime. The Cuban American National Foundation, the leading exile lobby, asserts that Mr. Castro is working with American "apologists" and multinational firms to "place tainted profits before principle."
Yet with American business leaders vowing to revisit the policy, the deep-pocketed exile lobby may have met its match. Jack Laurie, vice president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said his group will ultimately prevail. "We probably didn't realize the intensity of feelings of Cuban Americans," he said. "I'm sensitive to some of what they're saying. But by the same token, 40 years is a long time to harbor the same position."

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY;
Are Trees Good Places To Avoid Tech Shock?

BYLINE: By Joanne Legomsky 

 BODY:
Timmmberrr. That is not just the sound of your carefully built high-technology portfolio crashing. Investments in timberland are gaining currency as a way of earning good returns and adding a little stability to overall holdings.
"It makes it easier for investors to take on more risk with their other assets," said Eva Gregor, a managing director at Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Company, an institutional money management firm in Boston. 
 But isn't an investment in tracts of land and trees awfully cyclical?
"It is, and it isn't," Ms. Gregor said. As she explains it, while the price of lumber is very sensitive to the health of the economy, tree prices are much less so. "You have the choice of taking the trees to a pulp mill, a lumber mill, or not selling at all."
As an asset class, timberland falls into the category of alternative investments. But unlike, say, private equity investments or hedge funds, it is not a high-risk, high-return proposition. An investor with a relatively long time horizon can reasonably expect annual returns of 10 percent to 12 percent, after fees and any inflation, Ms. Gregor estimated.
Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo recently started a timber fund for individual investors willing to commit at least $1 million for 10 years.
Investors in timberland may be able to count on another benefit: Returns are not highly correlated with those of traditional investments. After all, trees grow, regardless of the markets. Joanne Legomsky

HEADLINE: DATABANK: NOVEMBER 27-DECEMBER 1;
One Step Forward, After Four Steps Back

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive Friday, investors hunting for bargains among technology stocks drove up the Nasdaq composite index after it had sunk all week.
But this Friday's rally, in which the Nasdaq rose as much as 5.8 percent, sputtered after the United States Supreme Court heard arguments on Florida's presidential vote, and the index gave back more than two-thirds of its gain. That left the Nasdaq 8.9 percent lower for the week and 35 percent lower for the year, at 2,645.29. At its worst, on Thursday, Nasdaq's second-busiest trading day ever, the index was down 50 percent from its March 10 peak. 
 More companies, including Gateway, warned of sales and profit shortfalls at a time when the economy might be slowing more sharply than the Federal Reserve wanted. "The market goes straight down whenever they talk about extending this legal battle," said Nicholas C. Haffenreffer, president of Resolute Capital Management in Washington.
 Other major gauges lost less. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 96.69 points, or 0.92 percent, to end the week at 10,373.54. The Standard & Poor's 500 shed 26.54 points, or 1.98 percent, to 1,315.23. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
High and Low

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Everyone is counting on the Supreme Court to bring civility, integrity and sanity to our election collision.
Unfortunately, in the immortal words of the old Don, "Nah ga da it." (The court is not going to do it.) 
 For the Kennebunkport Corleones, the Supreme Court deliberation serves the same function as the dazzling cross-cut scene in "The Godfather," when Michael attends his godchild's christening while his capos fan out to ice his rivals.
The movie church and the real court offer pious recitations and reverent ceremony that distract from the less savory stuff being done to secure the Family's interests.
The Wasp Corleones think it would be nice if the highest court helped them rub out Al Gore. But should the justices fail them -- and the Bushes know where they live -- they are pursuing other angles, some in sunlight and some in shadow, to grind Gore into little bits of chad and sprinkle him in the Everglades.
The Supreme Court may know a lot. But the Family knows best.
Sonny dissolves on contact. But he will be president. Of course, the dream could quickly corrode. Bush II may suffer the same painful fate as Bush I, economic slump leading to one term. And what if in 2004 we have another Bush-Clinton race? Hilllary may want to avenge Bill, just as W. avenged his dad's loss to Bill.
The Family has already paid a high price. Jeb's future is jeopardized. Sonny's future is jeopardized. Dick Cheney's health is jeopardized.
But, with its back against the wall, the Family drops the New England niceties. Consider Willie Horton, Anita Hill and John McCain in South Carolina. It was only business.
The Bushes sense trouble in Seminole and Martin Counties with those G.O.P.-doctored absentee ballot applications and the chance that thousands of Sonny's votes might be thrown out. They despise Al Gore as a weasel, agitating for those votes to be thrown out (just like the military ballots) after all his talk about counting every vote.
Let the Supreme Court palaver with Bush lawyers about the statutory use of the words "shall," "may" and "must," in determining whether Katherine Harris had to consider hand counts before certification.
Crosscut: The Bushes "shall" demand help from Ms. Harris, they "may" have sent a mob of khaki-clad Hill aides to intimidate the Miami-Dade canvassing board, and they "must" hang on to the count favoring W., as opposed to risking a true count.
Let the Supreme Court dissect Article II, Section 1, Clause 2 about the State Legislature's authority to regulate electors.
Crosscut: Jeb's Legislature is primed to do the wet work in a special session, guaranteeing Sonny Florida's 25 electoral votes no matter what else happens. Hired legal experts backed up plans to ram Sonny through, putting the veneer of legitimacy on the power grab. And after all his tortured ambivalence, Jeb has come out and admitted he will do what it takes to put big brother in the White House.
"I can't recuse myself from my constitutional duties as governor of the state, and I can't recuse myself from being my brother's brother, either," Jeb says. "I know the Gore campaign would love for me to basically disown my family, but I'm going to do what's right." Right.
Let the Supreme Court examine page 37-A as it relates to Section 102.166, debating whether the manual recounts are "authorized" or "required."
Crosscut: The Bushes dumping a horse head in the bed of Alex Penelas, the Democratic mayor of Miami-Dade County. Mr. Penelas, after conferring with Republicans, mysteriously stopped supporting the vice president's effort to get a recount. The mayor's Cuban-American constituents never bought Mr. Gore's pandering on Elian. Democrats charge that Mr. Penelas pulled a Tessio and cut a deal with the other family. He is considering switching parties and running for Congress. In which case, the Bushes could return the great service he did them.
Let the Supreme Court hold a disquisition over whether Title 3, U.S. Code, Chapter 1, Section 5 is, as Laurence Tribe claims, "all carrot and no stick."
Crosscut: The Bushes prepare a last line of defense with Tom DeLay and Trent Lott, who are all stick and no carrot.

HEADLINE: Environment Groups' Ratings Rile Ski Industry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The mistrust between environmentalists and the ski resort industry, which is sometimes rancorous, grew substantially this week when a coalition of environmental groups issued a report that graded 51 resorts in 10 Western states for their environmental policies.
While the groups said the scorecard was designed to be an objective review of the policies of each resort, with a strong focus on the impact of expansion efforts, it was roundly criticized by resort officials as biased because at least one of the coalition groups, Colorado Wild, has been an aggressive antagonist of resort developments over environmental policy. 
 Resort officials also said that no development could occur without meeting rigorous state and federal environmental standards.
"Our hope is that the situation does not become more polarized than it already is," said Julie Mack, executive director of the North Fork Preservation Alliance, the environmental policy arm of the Sundance Ski Resort in Utah, which received an A. "We have a real opportunity here for environmental groups to work with the ski resorts, but it will take a willingness on both sides to sit down at the table again."
The scorecard, produced by a group called the Ski Area Citizen's Coalition, ranked resorts on 11 criteria that focus largely on issues like expansion and development through new housing, ski trails or ski operations. The results, which are available on the coalition's Web site (www.skiareacitizens.com), show that only 9 resorts received an A and 7 a B. The rest got a C (14), D (11) or F (10).
The scorecard recommends "that you choose a more environmentally friendly ski destination at this time" than a resort with less than a B.
Among the resorts that received a failing grade were four in Colorado -- Vail Mountain, Keystone, Breckenridge and Beaver Creek -- that are owned by the same company, Vail Mountain Resorts.
Vail recently opened a major expansion of 500 acres, which has been ardently opposed by Colorado Wild. The group's executive director, Jeff Berman, was one of seven people arrested 18 months ago protesting the expansion. In a separate incident, the authorities in Mineral County in southwest Colorado said other members of the group were being sought on suspicion of trespassing after a late-night confrontation in August 1999 when members of a family of six camping on private property said they were approached near a planned golf and ski resort in Pagosa Springs.
Shortly after the incident, Mr. Berman conceded that alcohol might have clouded the judgment of some members of the group.
Another Colorado resort, Telluride, received an F on the scorecard although Colorado Wild has signed off on a settlement of a lawsuit over Telluride's expansion plans.
Stacey L. Gardner, spokeswoman for the National Ski Areas Association, a trade group, said episodes like those demonstrate a bias, which led many resort operators to decline the coalition's request for information for the scorecard. Ms. Gardner called it an "ill-warranted publicity stunt." She said 160 ski areas in 31 states have endorsed a set of environmental principles, developed by industry officials with federal and state agencies as well as other environmental groups that did not endorse the coalition's scorecard.
She also predicted that the scorecard would have little economic impact on the resorts, an assessment shared by resorts at both ends of the grading system.
Ms. Mack said she doubted that Sundance would gain much business after receiving an A. Bill Jensen, chief operating officer of Vail Mountain, said any ranking had the potential to influence a traveler. "Will it cost us $1? I wouldn't argue with that," he said. "Will it cost us millions? I wouldn't anticipate it."
As a spokesman for the coalition, Mr. Berman dismissed the industry's standards as a case of the fox guarding the henhouse. He conceded that many of the coalition's concerns with resort environmental policies should also be directed at the state and federal agencies that set the standards. But he insisted that the criteria developed for the scorecard reflected an honest effort to show the public which resorts are demonstrating the most sensitivity to environmental issues.
"We feel this is an excellent tool to choose a ski vacation," he said. "It's not to punish anyone."

HEADLINE: Critics Calling U.S. Supplier In Nicaragua A 'Sweatshop'

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
An arm of the Pentagon has come under fire for procuring large quantities of apparel from a Nicaraguan factory that labor rights groups say is a sweatshop and that the United States trade representative has voiced serious concerns about.
Several members of Congress say it is wrong for the Pentagon agency, which runs 1,400 stores at military bases and made $7.3 billion in sales last year, to obtain apparel from the Chentex factory, which a Nicaraguan union has accused of firing more than 150 union supporters. 
 In an unusually stern letter, The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, warned the Nicaraguan government in October that the United States might rescind some trade benefits unless it moved to ensure that Chentex complied with labor laws.
Labor rights groups in the United States have mounted an intense campaign against Chentex, a factory with 1,800 workers that is owned by the Nien Hsing Textile Company, after Nicaraguan workers accused the company of illegal firings. Many workers also complain about low pay, monitored bathroom visits, large amounts of mandatory overtime and being screamed at and occasionally hit by managers.
Cynthia A. McKinney, Democrat of Georgia, who sits on the procurement subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee, said it was wrong for one federal agency, the Pentagon, to buy large amounts of apparel from Chentex while another, the trade representative's office, had singled out the factory for criticism.
Representative McKinney and several other House members are working closely with a labor rights group that has obtained shipping documents showing that the Army and Air Force Exchange Service, a nonprofit Pentagon arm that runs the post exchanges, is one of the Chentex's largest customers. Other major customers have included the retailers Wal-Mart and Kohl's.
"The United States government is the last place that should be supporting and coddling sweatshop labor and the violation of human rights," Ms. McKinney said.
Labor rights groups and several House members say the Chentex battle is important because it seeks to upgrade wages and working conditions in poor nations at a time when the American economy is importing more goods than ever and American companies are relocating operations to low-wage countries.
Fred Bluhm, a spokesman for the Army and Air Force Exchange Service, said that in light of the many criticisms of Chentex the exchange service sent officials to Nicaragua to examine the Chentex operation. "Our representative who went there found no problems," he said.
Carlos Yin, the general manager of Chentex, said in a telephone interview that his company treats its workers well. He accused the union of exagerating problems and he insisted that only 12 union supporters had been fired, all of them union leaders. He said they were dismissed legally, asserting that it was the union leaders who had broken the law by calling a one-hour work stoppage and two-day strike without the workers' approval.
"We didn't do anything wrong," Mr. Yin said. "Nicaraguan law protects the workers very strong, and we can't go against the law."
But Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee, a New York-based labor rights group, said the company dismissed far more than 100 union supporters after they went on strike demanding a 40 percent wage increase.
At a factory that sews 35,000 pair of jeans a day, employees earn about 20 cents for the work they put into a pair of jeans that often sell retail for $30 in the United States. The workers, in effect, demanded to be paid 8 cents more per pair.
Mr. Yin, the factory manager, said all of his workers earn at least the minimum wage, which union leaders say is set unrealistically low in developing countries in order to attract foreign investment.
Last summer, Representative Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, visited Nicaragua and met mother who worked at Chentex 60 hours a week, while her husband worked at another Nien Hsing factory for 70 hours a week, and yet they lived in a hut with a dirt floor. "The couple had a 3-year-old daughter with discolored tips of her hair, probably from a protein deficiency," he said. "These are people who work 60, 70 hours a week, and their standard of living is just abysmal."
Mr. Brown, who got 67 House members to sign a letter to President Clinton last July about conditions at Chentex and another Nicaraguan factory, Mil Colores, said he would hold a news conference this week criticizing the Army and Air Force Exchange Service.
"I'm outraged that American taxpayers are being made part of this sweatshop global economy in this way," he said.

HEADLINE: Washington Is Setting Its Sights on Downtown

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The city government here is embarking on a major effort to revitalize the downtown area, trying to draw people to the heart of the city with new housing, more shopping and a broader cultural life.
Officials hope to capitalize on an increase in the popularity of urban living, with people moving from the suburbs back to cities around the country, to inject some life into an area of the District of Columbia that for many years has seen little development other than office buildings. The area is east of the White House, west of Capitol Hill and north of the national Mall with its museums and monuments. 
 "Our vision for a vibrant downtown is one of a true neighborhood -- a place where thousands of residents live, work, shop, do business and bring vitality to our streets and our city," Mayor Anthony A. Williams said.
The mayor, a former chief financial officer for the city, said the plan would link downtown prosperity to other neighborhoods through housing initiatives and job development strategies.
Other cities, including Chicago, Denver and Baltimore, have made downtown housing a central factor in redevelopment strategies.
A report on the plan, known as the Downtown Action Agenda, was issued in mid-November.
"Downtown residential development is a big thrust of this plan," said Andrew Altman, the city planning director. Mr. Altman said that city planners wanted to act on momentum created by about $3.5 billion invested in new development in Washington in the last few years.
The agenda outlines 18 steps for the next 12 to 18 months.
The plan includes construction of houses on city-owned land downtown, streamlining zoning laws and proposing tax abatements and other financial incentives to attract private investors.
The agenda calls for reconnecting blocked streets, particularly Pennsylvania Avenue, which has been turned into a pedestrian thoroughfare in front of the White House for security reasons.
City planners also suggest the development of public space at the site of the Washington Convention Center, and the redesign of the Martin Luther King Jr. Library, which officials said could be a cultural anchor for the community.
The plan includes $3 million to $5 million for beautifying streets and paying for a trolley system that would transport people from the Mall to downtown sites.
The agenda, officials said, will not overburden city taxpayers. The private sector is investing more than $4 million in roughly 50 projects planned or under way. Tax abatements, financial incentives and small public works initiatives will help offset costs.
In addition, $6 million in federal highway money is to be used for improvements on or around city streets, Mr. Altman said.
The city has had some success recently that may bode well for the new strategy. The MCI Center, home to Washington's professional hockey and basketball teams, was completed in 1997. Since it opened, the annual number of visitors to downtown attractions has grown to eight million from three million, officials said, and 29 restaurants have opened. A new convention center is under construction and should be finished in 2003. And the Newseum, an interactive museum of news in suburban Virginia, plans to open a museum and educational center downtown.
John McKoy, president of DC Agenda, a civic organization in Washington, said the plan integrated old ideas and took advantage of the economic growth in the city.
But Mr. McKoy, who was the city planning director from 1979 to 1984, said traffic patterns would have to be watched carefully to avoid possible problems during development.
"Everything in the plan will not happen," Mr. McKoy said. "But there are cranes on every corner. This is very exciting."
