HEADLINE: Turkey Grapples With a Severe Financial Crisis

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Confronting a plunging stock market, stratospheric overnight interest rates and protests in the street by teachers and hospital workers, the Turkish government struggled today to find a way to deal with a burgeoning financial crisis with political overtones.
Treasury officials met in Ankara with a team from the International Monetary Fund to discuss conditions for an emergency loan to alleviate the immediate crisis, but long-term structural solutions like banking reform and increased privatization looked tougher to work out. 
 The signs of economic trouble have intensified in recent days as concerns deepened that the government has not done enough to fight inflation, revamp its troubled banks and sell state enterprises.
"This started as a short-term liquidity crisis," said Burak Akbulut, an analyst with Bayindir Securities, "and it has turned into a crisis of confidence in the government's ability to reform the economic structure of the country."
The financial crisis is straining Turkey's coalition government as officials deal with a potential problem in relations with the European Union that could further shake confidence in the country's economy.
When European Union leaders meet in Nice later this week, they are expected to debate demands by Greece that Turkey resolve disputes over the divided Mediterranean island of Cyprus and some Aegean islets as part of its bid for membership in the organization. There was word late today of a possible compromise among European foreign ministers in Brussels, but there was no certainty that Turkey's fractious leadership would accept anything short of removing the questions of Cyprus and the Aegean from the membership criteria.
On the economic front, the Turkish government and the I.M.F. sought to calm the turmoil. The Turkish treasury said there was no need to change the basic economic plan. I.M.F. officials in Washington said over the weekend that the agency would recommend quick approval of a loan, but cautioned that Turkey would have to take hard steps to strengthen its economy and its banking system.
The reassurances and the start of special talks with the I.M.F. did not stop the Istanbul Stock Exchange's main index from dropping 8.12 percent today, to 7,329.61. Shares have lost 43 percent of their value over the last two weeks and, year to date, more than 60 percent in dollar terms. There was little sign today of a halt in the market's plunge.
The depth and duration of the financial crisis remain unclear. There were no signs of panic among the people, who are accustomed to economic and political turbulence. But even savvy investors seemed to be pinning their hopes on the I.M.F.'s coming through with an emergency loan quickly, an uncertain prospect.
News reports and rumors in financial circles here predicted that the I.M.F. was on the verge of pumping $2 billion to $4 billion into the economy. But a spokeswoman for the I.M.F. in Washington, Constance Lotze, said in a telephone interview that no decision was expected until after the meetings with Turkish officials end in 10 days. She also said it was uncertain that the I.M.F. board would approve more money before its meeting on Dec. 21.
The new round of troubles started with anxiety about the solvency of Turkey's midsize banks. The government is investigating some of the 10 banks already in receivership on suspicion of corruption, and more banks may be taken over. Healthy banks cut credit lines to the suspect institutions last week, starving the economy for cash and pushing up overnight interest rates into four digits.
The overnight interest rates -- what banks charge their best customers, usually companies and other banks, for short-term borrowing -- while staggeringly high, do not pose a financial risk on the basis of one night. But dangers increase if the rates remain high for an extended period.
Last week, Turkey's central bank added about $6 billion to the financial system to meet the demand for cash and to bring down rates, violating an agreement it had with the I.M.F. to let the Turkish lira float against a basket of dollars and euros.
When the central bank halted the cash infusions today, the overnight rate shot up again, touching 1,950 percent before settling at an average of more than 1,000 percent.
The cash squeeze is just one of the challenges impeding the government's 11-month effort to bring inflation under control and get Turkey's economy in line with those of advanced industrial nations. The effort was part of an economic overhaul required by the I.M.F. in exchange for a $3.7 billion loan package.
Turkey's currency has hardly been stable. The lira rose slightly today, settling in New York trading at a rate of 681,675 to the dollar. In the last six months, its value has declined roughly 10 percent.
The government managed last month to reduce consumer inflation to 44 percent for the year thus far, the first time it has been below 50 percent in 15 years. But the program has taken a toll on some business sectors and encouraged political volatility in this country of 65 million people.
Reduced government spending formed a key element of the anti-inflation program, but it meant that the government borrowed less from banks, whose profits then declined. Weaker banks were driven deeper into trouble.
The reduced spending also angered civil servants, whose pay raises have been kept well below the inflation rate. The 2001 budget proposes only a 10 percent raise for civil servants, most of whom are already paid barely enough to stay above the poverty line.
Government workers staged a one-day strike on Friday to underscore their demand for more money and a voice in the economy. Labor leaders said that 500,000 people joined protests around the country and 500,000 civil servants stayed home from work. "We are insisting on a dialogue," Resul Akay, president of the civil servants' confederation, said today, "but if they point us out to the streets, then we'll go to the streets."
Others have resorted to desperate measures. As the market dropped to a new low last Wednesday, a distraught investor walked into a branch of the Turkish Industrial Development Bank and shot the securities manager after an argument. The manager, who was hospitalized, is expected to recover.
Analysts said that the origins of the current crisis are short term and that it might pass, but they said long-term difficulties remained, particularly in the slow pace at which the government has been selling state-owned businesses.
"The government needs to fulfill the economic and political reforms and the privatization it has promised," Oner Ayan, a fund manager with Raymond James in New York, said in an e-mail interview.
The I.M.F. has urged officials to move faster with privatization, particularly big operations like the phone monopoly, Turk Telekomunikasyon, and Turkish Airlines. But politics and national pride have kept the pace slow.
The government had offered 20 percent of the telecommunications company and refused to relinquish control. Faced with the new economic difficulties, officials in Ankara swallowed their pride on Thursday and agreed to sell 35.5 percent and control to a strategic investor.
But it may prove too late. The bidding is scheduled for Dec. 15, but the potential bidders from the telecommunications industry are no longer flush with cash and the offers may prove disappointingly low at a time when Turkey desperately needs the money.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Rightist Squads in Colombia Beating the Rebels

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 4

 BODY:
They began as a gang of thugs backed by the once-powerful Columbian drug cartels. But when the guerrilla war intensified, they evolved into quasi-independent right-wing paramilitary squads that killed peasants suspected of supporting Colombia's leftist rebels.
Now the paramilitary forces have demonstrated with alarming clarity that they have become something else again: an army of combat-ready fighters that is directly engaging guerrillas and winning wide swaths of territory. 
 The United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, as the paramilitary groups are known formally, or A.U.C. by the Spanish initials, are also gaining an important degree of popular support from Colombia's middle class, say experts on the conflict and government officials here and in the United States.
As the government tries to restart frozen peace talks this week, the right-wing militias may well have a role in the process.
With 11,000 fighters, nearly double what they boasted a few years ago, and the backing of landowners, businessmen and coca growers, the paramilitary forces have beaten guerrillas on their own turf.
Through intimidation, massacres and, increasingly, direct confrontations, the militias have tightened their hold on the northern provinces of Antioquia, Bolivar and Cordoba and expanded into other regions, especially the coca-growing strongholds in the south.
They have also thrust themselves into the roiling world of Colombian politics, upsetting peace negotiations between President Andres Pastrana's administration and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, the nation's largest rebel group.
Through savvy public relations efforts by its straight-talking leader, Carlos Castano, and intimidation aimed at Colombia's establishment -- notably the kidnapping of seven congressmen in October in a successful attempt to broker a meeting with a top government official -- the paramilitary fighters have shown a determination to be heard.
Military success is widely believed to be strengthening Mr. Castano's hand in his quest for political recognition. Achieving military victory would make it more difficult for the government to prosecute him and other paramilitary leaders for war crimes if the conflict comes to an end. For the first six months of this year, the government's ombudsman has reported that 512 unarmed civilians were killed by paramilitary gunmen, compared with 120 killed by guerrillas.
Despite criticism from human rights groups, the public relations drive appears to be working. A large group of congressmen and several influential Colombians are publicly suggesting that the paramilitary units should have a role in the peace talks, a possibility that others say could produce years of conflict because of rebel opposition.
The debate comes as Colombia prepares to spend $1.1 billion in mostly military aid from the United States and other Western allies to curtail coca production in prime coca-growing regions like Putumayo Province in the south, an area where guerrillas and the paramilitary units have been battling for control.
"They are an unquestioned reality," said Senator Miguel Pinedo, who was among those kidnapped in October. "There's going to have to be a moment when they will have to be a part of the negotiating table, either independently or together with the rebels, but they have to be a part of it."
Phillip Chicola, director of Andean affairs for the United States State Department, agreed recently in a radio interview here. The paramilitary forces "are at some moment going to have to be part of a process," he said, "and I think the government and Colombian society are going to have to decide how to manage this issue."
Their growth can be attributed in part to the failure by the Pastrana administration to advance the peace effort in the last two years. The government is trying to resume talks before Thursday, when Mr. Pastrana must decide whether to reclaim by force the Switzerland-sized swath of territory ceded to the FARC guerrillas two years ago to lure them to the peace table. The talks have sputtered, but the guerrillas control the land.
Max Alberto Morales, who has served as an intermediary between the government and Mr. Castano, the paramilitary leader, said that Mr. Castano had been prepared to allow the peace talks with the FARC to proceed but that Mr. Castano had become concerned when the talks stalled, the FARC took control of a major chunk of territory and guerrilla violence continued.
"We had hope for a year that the peace process would get rolling, but what happened in that year is kidnappings became more common, roadblocks increased, they began to hijack airplanes and people were taken from churches," Mr. Morales said. "I think that all this touched the hearts of Colombians, and they said, 'We won't take this anymore.' For that reason the people in this country love Castano so much."
Beloved or not, Mr. Castano has been quick to take advantage of the shifting moods in Colombian society.
In two highly emotional televised interviews last spring, he cast himself as a protector not of the large landowning class that has helped finance the paramilitary forces, but rather of middle-class workers fearful of kidnappings. "The ones who have no one to defend them are the middle classes," Mr. Castano said. "The Self-Defense Forces are looking out for the interests of the middle class."
After the interviews, a poll in El Tiempo, Colombia's most respected newspaper, showed that 38 percent of those questioned said their image of Mr. Castano had improved. Seventy-two percent said the paramilitary forces should take part in the peace talks.
"Castano is the only Colombian who has the nerve to attack the guerrillas, and that makes him the good guy," said Luis Jaime Cordoba, a Bogota teacher.
Mario Fernando Hurtado, a geographer, said he had come to agree with Mr. Castano's logic after watching him on television. "He knows the reality of the problems of the country, and though he justifies his actions with force, he's convincing in his arguments," he said. "I'm not in accordance with many of his methods, but in this country they're necessary, because having a peace dialogue with the guerrillas when they're not interested doesn't make sense."
Colombia is a poor country, but its cities have large middle-class communities that feel little kinship or connection to the peasant farmers in the countryside who are most often the victims of the paramilitary units' violence. With Colombia's unsteady political situation and a harsh economic downturn worsening, the vacuum was open for Mr. Castano to step in.
"Against this backdrop of deepening chaos and the absolute lack of the rule of law, then a charismatic and articulate individual has risen to the level of leadership," said Bruce Bagley, an expert on the conflict at the University of Miami who is worried about a deepening conflict if the paramilitary forces gain political support.
"Carlos Castano, the fixture, the man, has found the right time for his leadership to emerge as powerful and important in Colombia," he said. "He has resonance among important sectors in Colombian society."
Mr. Castano has also expanded his forces' reach into sparsely populated regions where they had only occasionally operated in the past, notably Putumayo Province along the Ecuadorian border.
"It's remarkable, from a military perspective, that he's been able to push into new areas without any concern about his rear flanks," said Robin Kirk, who has interviewed Mr. Castano for her work as the Colombia researcher for Human Rights Watch.
"He's able to project a force way beyond his base of strength, which is northern Colombia, and he has the E.L.N. on the ropes, and that is very new," she said, referring to the National Liberation Army, the second-largest leftist guerrilla group, by its Spanish initials.
In Putumayo, the paramilitary fighters have so unnerved the FARC in a series of brutal entanglements since September that the rebels responded by closing off the province's roads.
The FARC's tactics have created an embarrassing crisis for the Pastrana administration, because it is in Putumayo that much of Plan Colombia, a multibillion-dollar effort backed by the United States to root out drug trafficking, is focused.
Mr. Castano's efforts to push deep into Putumayo are aimed at controlling the region's lucrative coca production. It remains unclear if the paramilitary forces have been able to gain the upper hand in the conflict there, but a top State Department official said intelligence reports showed that "at a minimum they've held their own against men who've had a full run of the place."
Human Rights Watch and other human rights groups insist that the paramilitary forces should not be allowed into peace talks until the government fully investigates their connections to the military, which the rights groups accuse of having provided munitions and tactical support to the paramilitary units. A Human Rights Watch report in February showed that half of Colombia's 18 brigade-level army units had links to paramilitary units.
"They have to disappear as an armed force and submit themselves to justice," said Senator Jaime Dussan, an outspoken opponent of including the paramilitary units in the talks. "How can we give amnesty to those who have killed, those who have massacred?"
Still, even among those who have aggressively pushed for the government to rein in the paramilitary fighters, there is a sense that it may be too late, that the right-wing forces have grown so large and independent that they cannot easily be disbanded.
"Today, the paramilitaries have grown too much," said German Martinez, the legal officer in Puerto Asis who has investigated paramilitary killings in Putumayo. "It is a monster created by the state, but now it's at the point where it's free of the state. It's a lion that the state controlled, but it has freed itself, broken away."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Forecasts Show Slowdown In Spending on Advertising
Advertising spending in America in 2001 will not grow as fast as had been anticipated as recently as this summer, two leading industry forecasters predicted.
But both characterized the slowdown as a soft landing after record results bolstered by the Olympics and the elections rather than a harbinger of a more serious downturn. While the ebb and flow of ad spending is watched carefully, the forecasts were being scrutinized even more closely because of a consensus that the economy is slowing as consumers spend less. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. Page C12. 

3Com Issues a Profit Warning
3Com, the maker of telecommunications and data network equipment, said that its per-share loss for the second quarter would fall far short of analysts' expectations. C4.
 
Dow Rises, but Nasdaq Sputters
Blue-chip stocks sprinted to one of their best gains in five weeks, but the Nasdaq composite index declined. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 186.56 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,560.10. But the Nasdaq slumped 29.54 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,615.75. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index moved up 9.74 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,324.97. C14.
 
Kirch Bails Out Owner of Muppets
EM.TV and Merchandising, the company that recently acquired the "Sesame Street" characters, escaped financial collapse by announcing a bailout from the Kirch Group. Shares of EM.TV, until recently one of Europe's success stories, declined 40 percent after company executives acknowledged Friday that they would have to restate results and that earnings this year would be about one-tenth what they had predicted six weeks ago. World Business, Section W.
 
MP3.com to Resurrect Its Service
MP3.com plans to reactivate the online music service that became the subject of a losing battle with the record industry. This time, instead of testing the legal limits of digital music distribution, it will test the willingness of fans to pay for what they want to hear. C4.
 
U.S. Joins Lawsuit Against KPMG
The Justice Department joined a whistle-blower suit against KPMG, the auditing firm, which accuses KPMG of aiding in a client's scheme to defraud government health care programs by submitting bogus expense claims. C8.
 
October New-Home Sales Fell 2.6%
Sales of new homes fell 2.6 percent in October, the Commerce Department said, while a separate report showed that the index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent. C12.
 
Pepsi Announces Deal for Quaker
PepsiCo officially announced its largest acquisition ever, a $13.4 billion purchase of Quaker Oats and its prized brand, Gatorade. The scale of the acquisition -- roughly four times the size of its purchase of Tropicana in 1998 -- introduces a measure of uncertainty at a time when new leadership will take over. Shares of Pepsi rose $1.44, to $43.81. C8.
 
Carnivore Privacy Concerns Remain
Despite winning a favorable review by an outside group, the F.B.I.'s Carnivore Internet wiretap system continues to raise strong concerns about privacy and the legal limits of government surveillance, a prominent panel of computer security experts said. A16.
 
DoubleClick Lays Off 150 Workers
Cutbacks in the Internet advertising industry have reached DoubleClick, which laid off more than 150 employees, or about 7 percent of its work force. C4.

HEADLINE: 3M to Select G.E. Executive As Next Chief

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
For the first time in its history, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing has reached outside its ranks for a chief, hiring W. James McNerney Jr. from General Electric to be its chairman and chief executive.
The appointment, which 3M is expected to announce today, held little shock value on Wall Street. Livio D. DeSimone, 3M's chairman since 1991, will be 65 in July, and 3M's board has been prospecting for a replacement for several months. Although six 3M insiders were said to be on a short list of candidates, analysts had speculated that the company would go outside. 
 That speculation hit fever pitch last week, when G.E. ended its own much publicized succession race. The company named Jeffrey R. Immelt to succeed John F. Welch Jr. when Mr. Welch retires next year. Mr. Welch, in making that announcement, said that he expected the also-rans in that contest to be quickly spirited away to head other companies. Mr. McNerney, 51, head of GE Aircraft Engines, was one of them; the other, Robert L. Nardelli, 52, head of GE Power Systems, is expected to announce a new job this week.
Analysts say 3M could use an infusion of G.E. dynamism. "3M has good margins and a good product line that is getting better, but they need an injection of intensity," said Jack L. Kelly, who follows 3M for Goldman, Sachs. "G.E. has an 'in your face, perform or you're out' culture, and anyone who flourished in that culture will know how to raise the bar for performance at 3M."
Actually, 3M has reinvigorated itself of late. Until the middle of last year, the company was floundering badly. It had missed earnings estimates in three of six quarters, it was suffering from the economic downturn in Asia, and many of its products were selling in highly cyclical industries like construction.
Since mid-1999, though, the company, based in St. Paul, has cut costs and shifted its focus to high-growth markets. Products like fiber optics, abrasives used in the manufacturing of semiconductors and drugs that bolster immune systems already make up about 23 percent of its sales, and 3M has promised to raise that percentage to 35 percent by 2003. In September, Mr. DeSimone told analysts that 3M's earnings would grow at least 12 percent annually through 2003.
The company's stock has held its own through the market's gyrations. Although 3M has tried mightily to position itself as a high-technology stock, it has generally traded in line with makers of specialty chemicals.
That old-economy identification is helping it now. Since 3M's shares never rode the technology wave up, they did not ride it down. Moreover, G.E.'s $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell in October gave a boost to many old-economy stocks, as analysts predicted further consolidations of old-line manufacturers.
Shares of 3M, which entered 1999 trading around $70, closed up $5.38 yesterday, to $105.
Still, 3M has its critics. For example, it is only a small player in pharmaceuticals, and analysts say that it must either bolster that business with acquisitions, or shed it and concentrate on fiber optics.
Analysts say the need to make such moves might have spurred 3M's board to go outside for a new chief. The six inside contenders have each had three or more decades with the company, and analysts said they might well have been unwilling to rock a boat they had sailed in so long.
"The company needs to get out of a status quo rut and look at new strategic opportunities, and that means they need someone who is not wedded to the 3M world," said Peter J. Enderlin, who follows 3M for Ryan, Beck Southeast Research.
In his 18 years with G.E., Mr. McNerney certainly demonstrated ability to deal with change. He has run GE Aircraft Engines, GE Lighting and GE Asia-Pacific, which handled most of G.E.'s activities in Asia. He also did stints at GE Capital and GE Information Services.
"He's got the broadest repertory of any executive I can think of, and he'll be terrific for 3M," said Dayton Ogden, co-chairman of the executive search firm Spencer Stuart.
The company seems a good fit for him, too. Like G.E., 3M is a diversified manufacturer, with more than 50,000 products selling to a host of unrelated industries. Also like G.E., 3M executives are impatient with bureaucracy. Indeed, 3M will often split a business in two when it seems to be growing too big to react quickly to the market.
"3M has been gaining momentum in fast- growing markets," said Richard Friedman, an analyst with Standard & Poor's. "McNerney's challenge will be to keep that momentum going."

HEADLINE: Baseball's Unfair Economics

 BODY:
The signing of Mike Mussina, a star pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, by the Yankees to a six-year, $88.5 million contract greatly increases George Steinbrenner's prospects for another World Series victory next year. That is great news for Yankee fans. But it reinforces a trend that plagues baseball.
Teams in big cities generate lots of revenue, pay big salaries and attract the best players. Teams in small cities generate little revenue, pay low salaries and watch their players exit for New York and Atlanta. The Yankees spend about six times what Minneapolis spends on players. One pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers made about as much money last season as the entire Minneapolis team. 
 The disparity matters. Between 1995 and 2000, 189 playoff and World Series games were played. Only three of those games were won by teams ranked in the bottom half of the league by payroll. Competitive balance has become a joke. Yet without balance, baseball cannot thrive. The satisfaction of watching the Yankees play ball has everything to do with the quality of teams they face.
Two proposals have been issued to tackle the competitiveness problem. One came from the four independent citizens -- Richard Levin, president of Yale; George Mitchell, former senator from Maine; Paul Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve; and George Will, the syndicated columnist -- serving on a panel appointed by the commissioner of baseball. The other came from Paul Weiler, a law professor at Harvard. They differ in details, but agree in broad intent.
Both proposals include mechanisms to keep rich teams from spending too much. They also recognize the equally important need to keep weak teams from spending too little. The owner of the Florida Marlins may have made money by shedding his high-paid players after winning the 1997 World Series. But this decision was every bit as damaging to competitive balance as Mr. Steinbrenner's decisions to add to his already bloated payrolls. Both proposals would also redistribute locally generated revenue from rich teams to poor ones -- including revenue from gate receipts, local television and radio broadcasts and stadium advertising.
Some of these ideas are not new. For several years baseball imposed what amounted to a luxury tax on teams with the highest payrolls. But the tax was suspended in 2000, and besides it added only a couple of million dollars to payroll costs that already exceeded $90 million. By contrast, the independent panel would impose a 50 percent tax on payrolls that exceed $84 million. In addition, baseball has long had a system for distributing locally generated revenues. At present, it transfers about $160 million from high- to low-earning teams. The panel proposes to raise that by about 50 percent.
The proposed payroll guidelines and increased revenue sharing will trigger some opposition from owners and players. But neither proposal mirrors the one-sided assault on players' salaries backed by owners in the past, in that neither would do away with free agency or otherwise limit the ability of individual players to sell their talents to the highest bidder. But both seek to dampen the ability of the George Steinbrenners of this world to bid as freely as they presently do. And both focus on raising the payrolls of weak teams. The net result would be a better balanced, more profitable league. If the idea works, the league will attract more fans, and everyone -- players, fans and, yes, Mr. Steinbrenner -- will win. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: CONTESTING THE VOTE;
Excerpt From Bush's Remarks on the U.S. Supreme Court's Decision

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt from a news conference yesterday by Gov. George W. Bush at his ranch near Waco, Tex., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
MR. BUSH -- I'm grateful that the court made the decision that it made. 
 Remember, it wasn't all that long ago that a lot of people boldly predicted that the court wouldn't even hear our case. And now they're involved in making sure the outcome of the election is fair.
Q. Governor, yesterday Secretary Cheney suggested that it's time for the vice president to concede. Are you prepared to articulate that yourself?
A. No, I'm not, Carl. I think each of us is going to have to, you know -- that's a very difficult decision for anybody to make, and I understand that. I do believe I have won this election. I believe that I won it on the first count and on the second count and on the third count. But I'm -- but the vice president's going to have to make the decisions that he thinks are necessary. And I know that he'll put -- the interests of the country will be important in his decision making, just like it would be in mine.
 Q. Sir, are you saying you don't agree with Cheney? Do you think --
A. I think the vice president is entitled to his view. And -- but I do agree with this, that he's going to make a great vice president.
Q. Have we reached a point where the national interests are now in jeopardy because of this protracted process, Governor?
A. Oh, I'm not -- I wouldn't take it, necessarily, that far, Carl. I will tell you, though, it's important for us to -- at least as far as I'm concerned, it's important for our team to move forward.
Tomorrow, the vice president, at my request, is going to go up to Capitol Hill to further our discussions with the leadership and members of Congress because we've got a very strong agenda, and it's an agenda that I strongly believe has put me in the position I'm in. It's an agenda of strengthening the military to keep the peace, it's an education agenda. There are some warning signs about our economy that I think we ought to take seriously. And I talked to the leadership about that at the ranch over the weekend, and those -- which argues for a tax relief package. It's a tax-relief package that I campaigned on. And we need Social Security reform. And one of the benefits of Social Security reform is not only to make sure there's a Social Security system for the elderly today and for younger workers coming up, but under my vision of Social Security reform, it'll help with capital accumulation, which will help the economic growth. Yeah, Patsy.
Q. Governor, have you spoken to any more Democrats? And will Secretary Cheney be speaking to any tomorrow on the Hill?
A. I think the understanding with the secretary is that he'll be meeting with Republican leaders tomorrow and Republican members, and no I have not since I talked to you on Saturday.
Q. Governor, are you looking to have a Democrat as a treasury secretary?
A. Well, I'm not ruling anything out. And I know there's a lot of speculation going on, but I haven't made any decisions yet. And if I did, I probably wouldn't tell you.
Q. Do you think the Florida Legislature should go ahead and meet and vote on a slate of electors --
A. Well, Tom, I think it's -- I think we ought to take the -- I think we ought to take this process one day at a time. And today's the day, evidently, the judiciary is going to make some strong statements. And I felt like the Supreme Court of the United States made a very positive statement on our behalf. And I think that the important -- what I -- the sentiment I want to convey is this: that I am comforted by the fact that the highest court of our land heard our case and will make sure this election is fair.
I think that's -- I think that's very important for our citizenry to hear. And as far as what the Legislature does in Florida, that's going to be up to the leadership in the Legislature.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
European Union Moves To Fight Mad Cow Disease
European Union agricultural ministers voted to ban the use of animal feed laced with animal products for at least six months. And all cattle over the age of 30 months are to be removed from the food chain unless they can be tested to make sure they are free of disease. Perhaps two million will have to be slaughtered. A3
 
Action Urged in Serbia
A United Nations envoy urged the Serbian government and the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Kosovo to act quickly to prevent tensions from escalating along the border. A6 

The National Guard in Bosnia
The United States Army said it would effectively turn over the American peacekeeping mission in Bosnia to part-time National Guard soldiers, including troops from Kansas, Minnesota, Indiana and New York, over the next two years. A8
 
Soul-Searching in Britain
The stabbing by teenage gang members of a 10-year-old Nigerian boy, who was left by passers-by to die in a London housing project, has focused attention on urban slums, a surge in youth violence and antagonism among immigrant groups. A11
 
Violence and Politics in Israel
The Israeli Army confronted angry Jewish settlers in Gaza and fired rockets at a Palestinian refugee camp near Bethlehem. Former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu acknowledged that he might seek the office again. A11
 
Militant to Be Retried in Jordan
A Jordanian-American, Raed Hijazi, who was sentenced in absentia for planning terror attacks, has been extradited from Syria and will be tried again, officials in Amman said. A5

HEADLINE: Halls of Justice Going Up All Over;
New York City Nears a Peak In Its Courthouse Building Boom

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
In Hearing Room 387 at Queens Family Court, lawyers who jam into the closet-sized chamber have had to settle for a not-so-judicial-sounding seat assignment: the windowsill. At Brooklyn Family Court, defendants awaiting their turn overflow into equally grand accommodations: the stairwell. And at Manhattan's 111 Centre Street courthouse, where suspects and the families of victims sometimes have to assemble in the same room before trials because of cramped conditions, scuffles on occasion break out.
City and state officials need little nudging to acknowledge that the conditions are deplorable. But in the next breath, they are quick to boast about their very concrete response: the largest courthouse building boom in New York City since the 1930's. 
 Citywide, four new courthouses have recently opened, six new structures are under construction or in planning and eight courthouses or court-related buildings are scheduled for extensive renovations or expansions, although a few of these projects are several years off.
It is an estimated $2.4 billion, taxpayer-financed bricks-and-mortar campaign that will remake the daily courtroom experience for thousands of suspects, jurors and lawyers, among others.
Two of the projects -- the two-block-long Criminal Courthouse in the Concourse Village section of the Bronx and the 32-story Supreme and Family Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn -- will be the largest courthouses in the state and among the largest in the United States, state officials say. Both sprawling structures also happen to be coming in at a price tag tens of millions of dollars above their original budgets.
The 32-story project, at 330 Jay Street in Brooklyn, was originally expected to cost about $350 million. Now, officials say it will most likely be more than $700 million. In the Bronx, the new Criminal Courthouse, at 231 East 161st Street, which was originally budgeted at $231 million, is now looking more like a $353 million project, court officials said. And tag on an addition for Queens Criminal Court at 125-01 Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens has jumped from $76 million to as much as $150 million.
The work under way in each of the boroughs is inspired by a 13-year-old state law that requires the city to evaluate its courthouses and repair or expand them as necessary to ensure that they are "suitable and sufficient." The push to fulfill this mandate started before Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came into office. But it is only now, as the former federal prosecutor edges toward the final year of his tenure, that the construction campaign is reaching its full frenzy.
"This is a public works program on the scale the city of New York has not seen since the administration of Fiorello La Guardia and the Works Progress Administration," said Steven M. Fishner, the mayor's criminal justice coordinator, before adding with an obvious pride, "It will be Mayor Giuliani's legacy."
City and state officials say the new court space is desperately needed for a simple reason: rising caseloads. The Family Court system handled 240,480 cases last year, a 40 percent increase in the last decade. The Supreme Court's civil division has seen a 33 percent jump in its caseload in the last decade. The overall criminal caseload, meanwhile, is up 13 percent from 1989, although it is down somewhat from its peak during the crack epidemic.
The rising demands on the court system, particularly the Family Court, to serve as both arbiter of justice and social services supermarket has forced space requests to make room for everything from drug treatment facilities to offices for counselors who tend to the needs of abused or neglected children. Consider that the new Queens Family Court, set to open next October, will have more than 175,000 square feet, compared with the 71,000 square feet in the current court, a former public library at 89-14 Parsons Boulevard in Jamaica.
"We are bursting at the seams," said Jonathan Lippman, chief administrative judge of the state's Unified Court System, which operates the courts that are built at the city's expense. "And at a time when there are so many parts of our lives that are chaotic, you cannot afford to have a chaotic court system."
For people who use the court, the relief could not come sooner.
"It is prehistoric," said Peter Abbadessa, who was leaning against a phone booth door one recent afternoon at Queens Family Court. Every seat in the tiny waiting room was filled, with other people spilling over into hallways. "It feels like you are in prison, not court."
Upstairs, at Hearing Room 387, Amy B. Rood, a court referee who hears cases, must share her 10-by-12-foot room with three tables, two file cabinets and a desk, along with eight people on average who attend most hearings.
"It takes a lot of the dignity out of the process," she said. "It is not the type of setting anyone would want to have a custody case or an adoption or any significant event in your life to be decided."
The courthouse projects today honor few of the stereotypes set by the city's last major courthouse construction boom 70 years ago, when the structures rose like citadels. The grand marble entrance stairwells, towering neo-Classical style columns and robed sculptures holding staffs and scales to represent the figures of authority and justice are for the most part gone.
Instead, the new structures feature lots of exterior glass, open courtyards and natural light, as their architects say they are trying to create buildings that join the community, not serve as imposing temples on a hill.
"We want to make them feel accessible, part of the city that they occupy," said Ian Bader, a partner at Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, designer of the new Queens Family Court under construction at 152-02 Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica. "It is different from the temples of justice of the past, which are set apart and somewhat aloof."
The glass-and-brick Queens Family Court will be situated around a large glass-enclosed atrium, which will have a translucent sculpture by the German-American artist Ursula von Rydingsvard suspended from the ceiling. The structure will open out onto the grassy expanse of Rufus King Park.
The L-shaped Bronx Criminal Court -- which is so large that its footprint in just the first phase of the project is more than twice the size of a football field -- will also feature a extensive glass facade, as well as a large open-air courtyard with a mini-Guggenheim-looking building set within it that will serve as a jury assembly area.
The similarly giant Jay Street project in Brooklyn -- it will have 74 courtrooms and 10 hearing rooms -- departs so much from the courthouse norm that it could easily be mistaken for an office building, although the brick piers that will rise up its facade should, in at least a modest way, echo the notion of courthouse columns. Demolition of a city building at the site is supposed to happen soon, with construction set to start early next year.
Some city budget watchdogs have questioned the city's record infusion of money into court construction, although no one has publicly said the projects are not needed.
In a city with an more than $90 billion in estimated outstanding infrastructure needs -- schools, subway cars, fire stations and libraries -- only the court system has been allotted enough money to satisfy all its identified needs, according to a 1998 study of city capital demands and allocated financing by the city comptroller's office.
"It makes no sense to satisfy 100 percent of court capital needs when you are satisfying less than half of educational needs," said Glenn Pasanen, director of City Project, a nonprofit budget-monitoring organization, citing a 1998 study by Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi that put the schools' construction needs at only about 44 percent met. "It's yet another signal that the mayor is more interested in criminal justice rather than in investing in schools and kids where there is an societal and economic return."
City officials said the state helps out the effort by issuing the bonds needed to finance the construction. But city taxpayers must still cover the annual debt payments.
The officials said the costs of the projects have risen sharply because estimates in some cases were made years ago, when projects were conceived. Now, with the booming economy, contractors are submitting much higher bid prices given the intense competition for their labor.
"You can't expect that when a building is on the drawing board for years, and then comes into construction, that it is going to stay at the same price," Judge Lippman said. "That is not the way this economy, which is really booming, works."
Officials said heightened security in the wake of the World Trade Center and Oklahoma City bombings was also pushing up costs.
At the new Bronx Criminal Court, for example, a street that was planned to pass through the complex has been eliminated.
Bullet-resistant glass and blast-resistant walls have been added, resulting in about $25 million in extra costs, said Fred J. Wilmers, project manager at Rafael Vinoly Architects of Manhattan, the building's designer.
High-tech features in the buildings' designs are also adding to the bills. Lawyers, judges and every two jurors will have flat-screen monitors in some of the courtrooms at the new Bronx Criminal Court, in addition to other videoconference equipment that would allow some witnesses or defendants to testify from outside the courthouse.
But city and court officials, wary of previous criticism of high-priced courthouses, said they were trying to keep the luxuries to a minimum.
"It ain't no federal courthouse," said Mr. Fishner when asked about the 330 Jay Street project in Brooklyn, comparing it on his own with thefederal courthouse and office building at Foley Square, which features exotic wood paneling, private kitchens and showers.
The city's new courthouses are slated to have their own share of upscale touches, though, like the marble and granite lobby planned at the 330 Jay Street courthouse and the anigre -- an African hardwood -- on the lower part of the courtroom walls, according to plans.
The judge's chambers in the new buildings -- excluding staff space -- are typically about 350 square feet, which Robert E. Fisch, a court planning executive at Ricci Associates, a New York City company, said is "on the high end of reasonable."
Steps have clearly been taken to control costs, like the frequent use of artificial stone and a cement-based flooring, sprinkled with tan and white marble chips to give it a more upscale look. "It is a very utilitarian design," said Mr. Wilmers, project manager for Bronx Criminal Court. "The materials are chosen for long-term maintainability."
State and city officials say courthouse construction is an expensive undertaking, but well worthwhile.
"Our view is if you don't have a justice system that works, you don't have anything in these other areas, whether it be schools or social services," Judge Lippman said. "Without a justice system that is respected, society doesn't function."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Substitute for a Subway on Second Avenue: Free Enterprise

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THE Second Avenue subway is dead! Long live the Second Avenue Free Way!
Actually, "dead" is not exactly the right word for the subway, since it has never shown signs of life. Voters in 1951 approved bonds to pay for it, and workers during the 1970's briefly worked on a tunnel, but otherwise it has remained on everyone's permanent "To Do" list. 
 Last month another bond proposal intended for the subway was on the ballot, but voters didn't bite this time. As usual, therefore, there is no money to build the subway, and even if some cash miraculously appeared, construction could take decades.
But there is a cheap idea for easing congestion immediately on the East Side of Manhattan. It comes not from a transit planner but from a professor of philosophy, Harry Binswanger, who has lived near Second Avenue for 35 years. Much of that time was spent next to the construction site of the subway tunnel to Roosevelt Island, a noisy experience that soured Dr. Binswanger on any new subway for Second Avenue.
Instead, he proposes to speed passengers along what he calls the Second Avenue Free Way, which embodies the philosophy he teaches at the Ayn Rand Institute. Dr. Binswanger wants to liberate Second Avenue from the taxicab cartel and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"On Second Avenue," he suggests, "let anyone and any company hire out any vehicles they wish, at any price structure they wish, to provide any service they wish. Individual car owners with a free half-hour could run down Second Avenue, picking up passengers for whatever price is agreed upon. I project a flourishing, innovative, multitiered system of free, private, for-profit transport at rates far below the cost of subway fare or taxi fare."
Jitney vans in Brooklyn and Queens are already turning a profit while offering better service at lower fares than the M.T.A. buses, and they could presumably do it on Second Avenue, too. But the Free Way might work better with a little regulation of the sort envisioned by another libertarian, Daniel B. Klein, an economist at the University of California at Santa Clara.
Dr. Klein also opposes transit monopolies, but the alternative he prefers is a competitive system based on what he calls curb rights. A private company operating buses or vans on Second Avenue would have rights to pick up passengers only at certain stops. That way it could afford to invest in long-term regular service without worrying about part-time operators swooping in to snatch its customers. (Otherwise a crafty part-timer can turn a quick profit by showing up just ahead of the regular bus or van.)
THE city might, for instance, let private companies bid against the M.T.A. for its bus stops, and it could also let them lease spots on blocks where the M.T.A. buses don't stop. For return trips uptown they might get spots on First Avenue. They might also be allowed to use side streets or private lots to pick up passengers.
The newcomers would be free to innovate with different kinds of vehicles and routes: customized express runs into various spots in Midtown, say, or one-stop trips from the Upper East Side to Wall Street via the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. By offering quicker, more comfortable rides in vans and buses, the private operators could lure people out of taxis and private cars, thereby easing congestion on Second Avenue.
The city could use the fees it collected from these operators to innovate with ways to speed traffic. It could afford to hire officers to keep private cars out of the right lane (which is now supposed to be reserved for buses at rush hour, but which is frequently clogged with cars anyway). If there were enough demand from private buses and vans, there could even be a second car-free lane.
Some of these innovations might be impractical (not to mention politically impossible). But the beauty of the Second Avenue Free Way is that it wouldn't take much money or effort to experiment with them. And some of the ideas could have an immediate impact, said Elliot G. Sander, who ran the Manhattan bus system in the 1980's and is now the director of the Rudin Center for Transportation Policy and Management at New York University.
"We need to encourage more bus and van use in Manhattan," Mr. Sander said, "and Second Avenue would be an interesting place to start. The subway is at least 10 years away. In the meantime, we need innovative ways to move those folks along the line."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, the Big City column on Tuesday, about proposals to increase competition in Manhattan transit, misstated the name of the university where Daniel B. Klein, an economist who advocates a competitive system, is a professor. It is Santa Clara University. (The University of California at Santa Clara is nonexistent.)

HEADLINE: Last Word in China's Phone Industry

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 5

 BODY:
He is not a member of the Politburo, the highest council of the Chinese government. He could walk the streets of Beijing without being recognized. Outside of China, his name scarcely registers.
Yet Wu Jichuan, the top communications minister in China, shakes stock markets and industries with his pronouncements. 
 Today, Mr. Wu came to Hong Kong for a conference organized by the International Telecommunication Union. And in a packed session with reporters, he struggled to calm the latest tempest set off by his ministry.
Last week, official newspapers in China reported that the government had approved a proposal to replace a system under which both the cellular telephone caller and the receipent pay for the call to one that would require the caller to pay for it.
The shares of China's two publicly listed telephone companies, China Mobile and China Unicom, sank after those reports because they raised fears that the companies would lose billions of dollars in revenue. The stocks fell a combined $26 billion in market value, each plunging more than 20 percent.
Under pressure from shareholders, Mr. Wu held a conference call with fund managers on Friday, in which he said Beijing would not adopt the one-way payment plan for one to two years. China Mobile and China Unicom embarked on powerful rallies, making up almost all their lost ground.
"I think the media and the fund managers should have known that the opinions expressed on an individual basis did not represent the views of the government," Mr. Wu said today with visible irritation. "They should have gone to the spokesman of the relevant department."
The spokesman -- when it comes to China's communications policy -- tends to be Mr. Wu himself. In running the sprawling Information Industries Ministry, Mr. Wu has control over every nook and cranny of the country's telecommunications industry, from pagers and satellites to the Internet.
Mr. Wu seems to relish his influence, though he tries periodically, and without much success, to play down his role. After the conference call last week, some economists criticized him for intervening on behalf of state-controlled companies rather than for Chinese consumers.
"Since I'm a government official, I know nothing about the stock market," Mr. Wu said. "I did not mean to support or raise the stock price."
Whatever Mr. Wu's motives, analysts said his soothing words underscored a recognition by Chinese leaders that shareholders can no longer be ignored. China Mobile and China Unicom are listed in New York as well as in Hong Kong, and they are held in investment portfolios around the world.
"In China, the idea used to be that foreign investors were merely a source of capital," said Duncan Clark, a partner at BDA China Ltd., a telecommunications consulting firm in Beijing. "The leaders have realized in the last few weeks that shareholders have got to be treated as a constituency."
China has a more immediate reason not to alienate foreigners. Beijing hopes to sell shares in yet another state telephone company, China Telecom, sometime next year, according to investment bankers here.
That offering could be the biggest yet for a Chinese state-owned company, generating $6 billion to $7 billion. China Telecom is the remnant of the country's telephone monopoly, parts of which were carved up in 1999 to create China Mobile and the paging operation of China Unicom.
China Telecom still owns a huge, but unwieldy, fixed-line phone network, as well as a data-transmission business. Analysts said Beijing might award the company a cellular license to make it more attractive to investors.
China is rushing to prepare its telecommunications industry for an expected onslaught of foreign competition after it joins the World Trade Organization. AT&T today became the first foreign company to announce a joint venture in China since Beijing pledged to open its market.
AT&T said it would acquire 25 percent of Shanghai Symphony Telecom, a broadband services provider that will offer high-speed voice and data communications in the Pudong district of Shanghai next year.
Even as Mr. Wu tried to smooth feathers, he reasserted that China intended to keep a tight rein on the Internet. His warnings about the Internet have generated as many ripples as his comments about telecommunications.
Last fall, he alarmed outsiders by saying that Internet content companies were subject to the same prohibitions on investment as were Internet service providers.
Today, he expressed concern about uncensored exchanges. "Anyone who has used the Web knows already that people always use false names; no one uses their own name," he said. "If someone attacks someone else, there is no way to catch them, no way to sue them."

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: A Status Symbol Under Siege;
Big Plush Offices Make Way for More Humble Space

BYLINE: By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
Dick Poladian, a managing partner for Arthur Andersen in Los Angeles, received several angry e-mail and voice mail messages from distraught managers when he decided to get rid of their large windowed offices. And he acknowledged that his own children thought their dad "wasn't as important" when he, the boss, gave up his lavish corner office with credenza and conference table.
"They clearly thought I'd lost it," Mr. Poladian said about his family and the more than 200 managers that report to him. 
 But he stands by his decision nearly two years ago to reconfigure the offices, doing away with varying-sized rooms with windows and putting managers in cookie-cutter interior offices, in some cases two to a room.
To convince reluctant managers to go along quietly, some of the most senior people in the organization, including Mr. Poladian, moved into cubes, too. "The managers would have said 'he got his nice office' if I didn't do that," he said.
While lower-level managers throughout America have long been relegated to cubicle farms, senior executives have clung to big corner offices as a perk and status symbol. But lately, some companies are beginning to apply a more egalitarian approach to the management set's digs, too.
In part, cost is driving the trend. With real estate prices skyrocketing in much of the country, cramming more people into less space saves money. Verizon Communications, for example, squeezed Charles R. Lee and Ivan G. Seidenberg, its co-chief executives, into offices the same size as those inhabited by roughly 18 second-rung executives at the company's Avenue of the Americas headquarters in Manhattan. "We wanted to make sure we got as many offices as we could in there," said Peter Thonis, a spokesman for the telecommunications company.
Ending the turf mentality can also save in renovation expenses. Mr. Poladian of Arthur Andersen said he was sick of reconfiguring the offices every time someone was hired, promoted or left the firm. Until he adopted his one-size-fits-all policy, he says, the endless remodeling was his office's No. 2 expense behind payroll. "Now I can plug anyone in anywhere," he said.
The financial incentive for keeping things simple is also growing because knocking down walls and ripping up floors requires an immense amount of rewiring to handle high-speed computer data and voice traffic. "There's tons more cable than there was just five years ago," said John Lijewski, a principal at Perkins & Will, the corporate interior designers that remade Verizon's executive offices.
Doing away with all that construction work has less tangible benefits as well, like a more pleasant work environment. At the Tampa, Fla., law firm of Annis, Mitchell, Cockey, Edwards & Roehn, the constant sound of jackhammers was getting on the staff's nerves. When an associate was promoted to partner, or a new lawyer came aboard, rooms had to be enlarged or shrunk to fit the new occupant's rank.
"There was so much musical chairs," said Lawrence P. Ingram, a partner. "All this constant jockeying for the right offices. People were more preoccupied with the right office than billing clients."
Enough was enough. Annis Mitchell abolished the old-style law office architecture last year, spending $2 million to make every partner's and associate partner's office identical, down to the modular furniture. The new setup, Mr. Ingram says, helps in retaining and recruiting associates because it eliminates the hierarchical divide.
"I was very excited," said Ellen Koehler, a 30-year-old associate at the firm. "We got a 15-foot office with three windows."
Some partners were not as happy. "They felt we should have kept the old system: work hard, pay your dues and then get the reward of a big office," said Robert McLean, a partner who helped oversee the change. Mr. McLean held meetings with all the partners and ultimately everyone went along, though somewhat reluctantly, he says. The only concession the firm made, he says, was to let one longtime partner keep his old, bulky dark-wood desk.
For all the changes afoot in some places, workplace democracy remains a rarity in the old economy, said Jim Shaffer, owner of the Jim Shaffer Group, a management consulting firm in Annapolis, Md. Indeed, the size-is-power mentality holds even greater sway at some firms than it used to, he said.
Mr. Shaffer cited the example of a client who was hired recently for a middle-management position at a Midwestern insurance company. Shortly after she started work, a human resources representative came to her office and covered the windows with duct tape. When she asked why, she was told that the office had been occupied by a much higher-ranking company director and that "managers don't get windows," Mr. Shaffer said.
That incident might seem silly, but it demonstrates the enduring power of symbolism in the status-conscious world of corporate America. Even managers who have acquiesced to casual dress in the workplace can lash out when such a valued perk as a big office is threatened.
People still think the office is important, said Stephen Viscusi, the host of a nationally syndicated career-advice radio show called "On the Job."
"Look at 'Ally McBeal," ' Mr. Viscusi said of the television character. "She's not even a partner in that law firm but she's got a huge office."
In general, Mr. Viscusi says, executives he talks to still perceive the size of their office as a reflection of their position at a firm. Many even ask to see their office before they accept job offers. "Take away his car, club rights, a parking space," he said, "but don't take away his nice big private office."
Michael Gilson, director of facilities management for CBB Architects in St. Petersburg, Fla., agrees. No matter how many companies talk about discarding old habits, he says, most managers he works with are still obsessed with the size and positioning of their office. It matters to them, for example, whether the chief executive can see them from his own perch.
Mr. Gilson recalled standing with two utility company executives of the same rank who were checking out the results of a workplace renovation. "They walked up to the doorways of their offices, which were side by side, and both looked up," he said. "You could see their lips moving in unison as they counted the wall tiles, '2, 4, 6, 8.' "
One office was six inches wider than the other, but luckily for office morale, neither manager detected the difference, Mr. Gilson said.
Even when all the offices take up the same space, subtle accouterments can mark some off as first among equals. When the BF Goodrich Company moved its headquarters to Charlotte, N.C., this year, the entire executive team, excluding the chief executive, were given offices of roughly 15 feet by 15 feet with mostly identical furniture.
The move "speaks to our corporate philosophy; we are open and nonpolitical -- not a 'Dilbert' environment," said Gail Warner, a company spokeswoman.
There was one barely noticeable little touch in the offices of executives of vice-presidential rank and up, however: a quarter-inch wood inlay around the trim of their desks in the pattern of a Greek key. (Ms. Warner justified the distinction by saying it was "extremely subtle.")
If executives want to encourage democracy in the workplace, just bulldozing the posh executive suites will not do the trick, said Barry Miller, a workplace psychologist and management professor at Pace University in Manhattan. "It's like putting a honey label on a vinegar jar," he said. "It's not going to change the acidity of the contents."
And, he suggested, companies should think twice before cutting back office size and putting senior managers in cubicles because some positions require more space for storage and meetings, and confidentiality could be compromised in an open-office setting.
Beth Grossman, the executive vice president of Communications/Marketing Action, a New York-based marketing firm with a staff of 10, learned that lesson. Hoping to create an atmosphere of camaraderie, Ms. Grossman chose a smaller office than her previous one when her company moved last year. She soon regretted the decision. "My stuff started to pile up and I said to myself, "what am I trying to prove anyway?' " she said. Later, when an employee in a larger office resigned, she grabbed it.
And it wasn't just the need for more space, either, she confessed. "When my mother came up to visit, she was so upset because my office was so small," Ms. Grossman said. "She said: 'You're an executive of an agency. You should have the larger office.' "
To be sure, some executives really do not care a whit about how big their offices are or where they are situated. This insouciance, as everybody knows by now, is most pronounced in high-technology start-ups.
"We don't want people here who think like that," said Jim Nunan, the head of human resources for NonStop Solutions Inc., a software company in San Francisco, alluding to job candidates' intent on having their own offices. All eight members of NonStop's executive team sit in cubicles, just like the rank and file, he said. The main focus of their energy, he said, half-joking, is "let's go through the I.P.O. and get rich."
On the other hand, given the initial public offering market these days, maybe an office is not such a bad idea, after all.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
EUROPEAN UNION: COHEN'S WARNING
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen warned the European Union not to set up a military structure that could compete with NATO. The 15-nation union has vowed to establish a 60,000-member force by 2003, a move the United States supports on the conditions that NATO remain the primary guarantor of European security and do the planning for both groups. But France has insisted on a more autonomous role for the European Union. If the Europeans insist on setting up a rival planning structure, Mr. Cohen said, "NATO could become a relic of the past." Michael R. Gordon (NYT) 

AUSTRIA: VOTE ON EUROPE
More than 100,000 Austrians have signed a petition for a referendum on whether to quit the European Union, obliging Parliament to discuss the issue within six months. The petition says the union had stripped Austria of its sovereignty, undermined its agriculture and threatened its neutrality. The union imposed sanctions on Austria early last year for seven months for including the rightist party of Jorg Haider in government. Austria joined in 1995 after 75 percent of voters favored it in a referendum, but recent polls show support slipping drastically. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
IRELAND: WAGE ACCORD
Acknowledging union concerns about the impact of rising inflation on working-class wages, the government and labor leaders reached an accord to raise increases in pay rates by 3 percent over the next two years. The deal will help to defuse threats of strikes by public sector workers. A wide-ranging current pact limits increases to 5.5 percent a year until 2002. The new rates will add 2 percent in April 2001 and another 1 percent in April 2002. Brian Lavery (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
JAPAN: CABINET SHUFFLE
The embattled prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, shuffled his cabinet in an attempt to streamline the government and bolster its low public approval ratings. The new government contains 17 ministers, down from 22, but the biggest innovation, from a prime minister seeking credibility with voters in the coming election year, is the inclusion of two former prime ministers: Kiichi Miyazawa, the finance minister who was returned to his post, and Ryutaro Hashimoto, selected as minister for the new post of administrative reform. Howard W. French (NYT)
 
INDIA: POSTAL STRIKE
Postal workers across the country began an indefinite strike, demanding higher wages and better benefits. Three unions, claiming a total strength of 600,000 members, say the government has failed to live up to a May settlement. Post offices were deserted in most towns and cities. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
CHINA: DALAI LAMA TALKS
The exiled Dalai Lama said he has reopened indirect talks with China for the first time in two years. The Tibetan spiritual and political leader, who has lived in India since 1959, said his brother visited Beijing in late October at the invitation of the authorities. He said the Chinese had not allowed his brother to travel in Tibet or responded to a request to send a fact-finding mission to Tibet. Erik Eckholm (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
IVORY COAST: PROTEST DEATHS CLIMB
The number of deaths mounted as supporters of Alassane D. Ouattara, the opposition leader barred from running in legislative elections next Sunday, continued to clash with security forces. The government said 13 people had been killed since Monday, including a police officer and a gendarme. The party of Mr. Ouattara put the number killed at more than 30. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
 
SOUTH AFRICA: LOCAL ELECTIONS
Thousands of voters turned out to elect the members of 284 city and town councils across the country. The governing African National Congress was expected to win most seats, but races were expected to be close in Cape Town and Pretoria. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
ANGOLA: AMNESTY OFFER
Parliament approved a law that would grant amnesty to people accused of political crimes. President Eduardo dos Santos said the law was a gesture of reconciliation to members of the rebel group Unita. The state news agency reported that hundreds of Unita supporters surrendered after hearing about the amnesty, but Unita officials said the rebels had rejected the offer. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: EX-AIDE KIDNAPPED
A former development minister in President Andres Pastrana's cabinet, Fernando Araujo, was kidnapped from the Caribbean city of Cartagena, continuing a series of abductions in the business world in recent days, officials said. It was unclear who kidnapped Mr. Araujo, left, but leftist rebels, right-wing paramilitaries and common criminals are responsible for 3,000 kidnappings a year. Mr. Araujo's abduction came after the Nov. 28 kidnapping of the daughter of a top industrial leader and the Nov. 25 kidnapping of the Colombian manager of Hyundai Corp. Juan Forero (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: ISLAMIC BARBIE ABANDONED
Iran has abandoned a plan to protect Iranian youth from the "negative influence" of the popular Barbie and Ken dolls by replacing them with home-made Islamic substitutes called Sara and Dara, the official news agency reported. An official said "technical difficulties" were to blame for the abandonment of the project, adding that Iran was now forced to ask foreign companies to make the dolls. (Agence France-Presse)
 
IRAN: AFGHANS SENT BACK
Some 26,000 Afghans who illegally crossed the border into Iran's southeast Sistan-Baluchestan Province were arrested and sent back to Afghanistan, an Iranian police official told the state news agency. The United Nations issued a warning on Oct. 27 saying 500,000 to 1 million people were in danger of starving to death in Afghanistan because of the worst drought there in 30 years. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Speech by the Fed Chairman

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a conference of America's Community Bankers in Manhattan:
During the past couple of years, however, the widespread optimism that was apparent in financial markets has given way to some reassessment of risks and opportunities. This process has been under way ever since the global financial crisis in the fall of 1998. That episode forced many market participants to recognize the potential for international risks to feed back on U.S. markets. Events brought into sharper focus the possibility that liquidity in many markets can dry up simultaneously when fear spurs risk aversion, and an intense, near-term focus on protecting capital values markedly elevates the demand for liquidity. Markets largely recovered from that episode, but an imprint was left in the form of wider credit spreads and more cautious behavior on the part of banks and other lenders. . . . 
 In periods of transition from unsustainable to more modest rates of growth, an economy is obviously at increased risk of untoward events that would be readily absorbed in a period of boom. The sharp rise in energy prices, if sustained, is worrisome in this regard. As we learned from previous episodes, rising energy prices could engender risks to both inflation and economic activity. If accommodated by monetary policy, the jump in energy prices could spill over into general inflation and inflationary expectations, as was so evident in the 1970's. At the same time, the hike in the price of imported energy has acted, in effect, as a tax equivalent of roughly 1 percent of national income. Although there is as yet little evidence of the type of destabilizing inflationary pressures observed in the aftermath of previous oil price spikes or of exceptionally large restraint on consumer spending, Middle East tensions have heightened such risks.
The most significant effect to date from higher energy prices appears to be on profit margins, where corporate businesses, constrained by competitive market forces, have not been able to raise prices to fully offset energy cost increases. We estimate that owing to the rise in oil, natural gas and electric power prices, energy costs of nonfinancial, nonenergy, corporations have increased at a 40 percent annual rate since the spring of 1999. Apparently, most of the increase has eaten into the margins of domestic corporations outside the energy sector.
With equity prices weakening in response to reduced earnings from higher costs and a more moderate pace of sales, the "wealth effect" that spurred consumer spending is being significantly attenuated. Moreover, high and rising equity prices had facilitated a good deal of financing for newer companies, both in the equity and bond markets. Widened spreads in the high-yield markets reflect, in part, a reduced potential for new equity issuance to support debt servicing. Higher costs of capital for these companies likely is exerting some restraint on overall business capital spending.
Nonetheless, in the face of the energy price spike and the erosion of optimism in financial markets, consumer confidence, or sentiment, appears to be holding up reasonably well to date, though there have been some mixed signals of late. And although new orders for high-tech equipment have slowed from their torrid pace of earlier this year, order backlogs for such equipment continued to rise through October, and capital deepening and structural productivity growth continued apace.
Still, in an economy that already has lost some momentum, one must remain alert to the possibility that greater caution and weakening asset values in financial markets could signal or precipitate an excessive softening in household and business spending.
As might readily be expected, these changing economic dynamics, of necessity, are being reflected in our banking markets. Technological innovations played a key role in rendering decades-old banking laws and regulations obsolete. The relaxation of these regulations has, in turn, further reduced barriers to competition and accelerated the modernization of our financial system. That evolution, however, must continue to occur in a manner that preserves the fundamental soundness of the financial system and, in particular, the nation's banks. History teaches us that a sound banking system, willing and able to take deposits and extend credit, is a prerequisite for the long-term health of the national economy. Securities markets alone will never be able to substitute for the extensive and detailed knowledge that bankers -- especially community bankers -- bring to the intermediation process. . . .
At the same time, it is important that the response of management to these concerns not be overdone. The rise in the problems that we are observing can in some sense be attributed to the kinds of overreaching typically experienced during strong economic periods, when downside scenarios are more challenging to visualize fully, when the ambitions of borrowers are at their height, and when competition for market share is an especially driving force. Though lenders will be viewing new transactions with greater caution than they did a couple of years ago, both bankers and their supervisors should now guard against allowing the pendulum to swing too far the other way by adopting policy stances that cut off credit to borrowers with credible prospects.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fell 3.3% In October

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Factory business turned in its weakest performance in three months in October as a big drop in demand for transportation equipment and electronics helped depress orders to American manufacturers.
The Commerce Department reported today that factory orders fell 3.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $373.9 billion, the latest evidence that the slowing economy is suppressing the appetite of businesses and consumers for manufactured goods. 
 October's decline, which was larger than many analysts expected, wasthe first and biggest drop since factory orders plunged by a record 8.1 percent in July.
"The economy will finish the year 2000 not with a bang but with a whimper," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Manufacturers are feeling the pinch of both the Federal Reserve's six interest rate increases since June 1999, which have raised borrowing costs and dampened demand for big-ticket items, and of a strong dollar, which makes American goods more expensive overseas.
In another report, the Federal Reserve said industrial production grew more slowly in the third quarter than previously thought.
According to revised figures, output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 3.5 percent in the July-September quarter, down from the previous estimate of 3.7 percent.
Meanwhile, orders for transportation equipment in October plummeted 16.1 percent, mostly because of weaker demand for airplanes and aircraft parts.
Excluding the volatile transportation category, factory orders fell 1.2 percent in October, the second decline in the last four months. The transportation sector swings widely from month to month because it includes costly items like airplanes and ships.
Total factory orders rose 1.1 percent in September, according to revised figures, slightly weaker than the government previously reported.
