HEADLINE: RISKY DECISION/A special report.;
Study of Ford Explorer's Design Reveals a Series of Compromises

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER; Josh Barbanel contributed to this article by conducting a computer analysis of federal crash statistics.

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Dec. 6

 BODY:
Stephen Ross knew how dangerous it would be to wait.
His bosses at Ford would approve only one risky new project that year, 1986. If his new sport utility vehicle -- the one he thought the Ford Motor Company needed right away to stay competitive -- was to beat out a luxury sports car being promoted by more senior rival executives, he and his small team would have to come up with an inexpensive design. 
 So they improvised. Instead of a whole new design, which would be far too costly, they would simply bolt a roomy passenger cabin, stocked with leather seats and other family-friendly amenities, to the underbody of the existing Ranger pickup truck. The plan's crowning beauty was that the new vehicle could be built on the Ranger assembly line, using many of the same robots and auto parts.
"It's a lot riskier to do a complete new vehicle, particularly back then," Mr. Ross recalled. "In hindsight, we probably could have afforded it, but hindsight is always 20-20."
Ford called it the Explorer, and it succeeded beyond anyone's wildest dreams. Months after it went on sale, in April 1990, it was America's No. 1 sport utility vehicle; today, 3.2 million are on the road. And it was a gold mine: while Ford made less than $1,000 on the average sedan, the profit on an Explorer was nearly $8,000.
The Explorer was a marketing dream -- the perfect vehicle for a baby-boom generation that wanted it all. You could use it as your family car, and it had the rugged, adventurous image of a truck. The problem was, it also had the Achilles' heel of a big, tall truck: it rolled over more easily than a car would.
The roots of that problem lie in Ford's original design decision to build the new sport utility on the bones of a pickup truck instead of all in one piece, like a car.
Most other sport utility vehicles are also built on pickup truck underbodies. Indeed, many have rollover death rates considerably higher than the Explorer's. But the Explorer has become the most visible example of the problem because of recent deaths in sport utility vehicles after treads peeled off their Firestone tires.
A review of recently obtained Ford documents, as well as interviews with executives, engineers and marketers, shows how Ford designed itself into a box, then struggled to design itself back out. The biography of the Explorer reveals how executives at Ford, under great pressure to be in on the coming sport utility boom, decided to build their entry in a hurry and on a shoestring, but with only moderate attention to stability.
In succeeding years, amid rising concern about rollovers, Ford engineers strove to adapt that tippy, bouncy pickup design for a family vehicle that spent far more time racing down the highway than bumping along dirt roads. In the end, they had only limited success.
In most of the deaths linked to the Firestone tires, the vehicles were Explorers, and in almost every case they flipped over. Today, federal safety officials said the number of complaints of deaths linked to the tires had risen to 148. And while much attention has been focused on the tires, the accidents have also raised questions about the Explorer itself; in fact, tire problems have caused a tenth of the more than 1,200 Explorer rollover deaths since 1991.
An analysis of federal crash statistics by The New York Times shows the price that drivers of Explorers pay for a car with the lineage, and image, of a truck. The analysis shows that since 1991, occupants of Explorers have been 2.3 times as likely to die in rollovers -- tire-related or not -- as people in traditional cars. What is more, they are nearly twice as likely to die in rollovers as are occupants of Jeep Cherokees and Grand Cherokees, the only popular sport utilities long built like cars.
And the Explorer's fatal rollover rate has been rising considerably, according to the analysis. While the rates for cars and the Jeep sport utilities have stayed fairly steady (roughly 40 or 50 fatal rollovers per million vehicles), the rate for the Explorer rose from 53 per million in 1994 to 121 last year. Rates for other midsize pickup-based sport utilities have also risen, though not as much. Experts attribute the trend to a mix of factors, particularly growing numbers of younger drivers as middle-age parents have switched to even bigger sport utilities. Tire problems did not push up the Explorer rate significantly until last year, when they accounted for 18 of the 121 deaths per million vehicles.
The Explorer may be the sport utility leader, but it is hardly alone, and its story illuminates the kind of trade-offs other automakers made, as they tried to balance cost, safety and market appeal. Most of the 21 million sport utilities on the road -- including the Ford Expedition and Excursion; the Chevrolet Blazer, Tahoe and Suburban; the Dodge Durango; and the Toyota 4Runner -- were built on truck bases.
In the Firestone cases, Ford officials say a flaw in the tires, not the Explorer's design, was to blame. In designing the Explorer, they say, they consistently erred on the side of safety. Not only has the Explorer passed all the company's stability tests, they add, but it has the lowest rate of fatal rollovers of any similar-size pickup-based sport utility.
"Our analyses continue to find that the Explorer is a very safe vehicle and has performed very well in the hands of its customers since its introduction 10 years ago," said Ernest Grush, Ford's manager of safety-data analysis.
But many auto-safety experts have argued that there was a cocktail of blame behind the accidents -- that after the tires failed, the Explorer's pickup-truck base and high center of gravity made it harder to control, while drivers often made the fatal mistake of swerving at high speed.
Mr. Ross said the company had considered stability issues in early designs. But another Ford manager on the original project said rollovers had not become a priority until a controversy erupted in the late 1980's over the rollover record of the Bronco II, which was also based on a Ranger underbody.
"At the time we locked up the design of the Explorer, we had no knowledge of the rollover problems of the Bronco," said the manager, who insisted on anonymity to avoid being identified by company executives or lawyers suing the company. "It all hit later."
And by then it was too late, for Ford and the other automakers as well.
"There was a flurry of 'Let's have a sport utility,' and look around for the nearest platform," said Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which is financed by insurers seeking to reduce the cost of crash claims. "I don't think a lot of thought went into a lot of these designs. There was a bandwagon, a gravy train, that they couldn't afford not to jump on."
 
The Creation
Facing Trouble In Detroit
The mid-1980's were tough years for Detroit. Two oil shocks had nearly bankrupted Ford and Chrysler and humbled even General Motors. When the American economy began recovering in 1983, the soaring dollar allowed Americans to buy Japanese cars much more cheaply.
But as gas prices fell, the American auto industry began to sense salvation in a group of obscure, and relatively fuel-inefficient, vehicles known as light trucks: sport utility vehicles, pickups and minivans. Chrysler introduced the first modern minivan in November 1983, and the same autumn brought the Jeep Cherokee, the first four-door sport utility with the comforts of a car. Buyers snapped them up.
Observing popular culture, Ford recognized why Cherokees were selling so well. The rugged Western look was in style for clothing, partly because of Ronald Reagan's popularity. The researchers paid particular attention to Hollywood, where the top box-office draws were films like "Top Gun," "Rocky IV" and "Rambo First Blood, Part II." Americans, the researchers concluded, wanted automobiles that communicated ruggedness, individuality and an outdoor spirit.
The clear answer, Ford's light-truck team decided, was what, by the standards of the day, would be an unusually large sport utility vehicle.
"The Ford Explorer has the message, 'I'm big, I'm tall, I'm prepared to explore the world,' " said Dr. Clotaire Rapaille, chairman of Archetype Discoveries, a psychological research company that works for Ford and other automakers. Its name constantly brings that message home. "The letter "x" means outside, exterior, exploration," Dr. Rapaille pointed out.
Ford's research found that potential Explorer buyers cared a lot about their image and that the image they hoped to be envied for often had little to do with the way they actually used their Explorers. While they were unlikely to drive off-road even on vacation, for instance, they wanted four-wheel drive because it suggested they took adventurous trips.
From a marketing standpoint, that week or so of vacation became "the most important week of the year," said Mr. Ross, now the vehicle development director for Ford's Land Rover subsidiary in Britain.
So as it rolled out the Explorer in 1990, Ford began a marketing campaign to build the Explorer's image as a versatile vehicle that could take its owners anywhere their fantasies led them. Television ads consistently showed the Explorer going on adventurous trips, traveling over rock fields and mountain tracks, instead of running errands, a much more common use. Soon Ford added references to luxury. One ad showed a couple splitting their time between a Manhattan penthouse and a country cottage. In 1995 and again this year the Explorer became the nation's best-selling family vehicle.
Of course, the adventure ads overlooked the Explorer's shortcomings in everyday driving. The rollover problem was the most significant. But there were others.
Off-road, for instance, four-wheel drive helps motorists free themselves from deep snow and mud, but it provides little, if any, advantage on roads that are merely wet or covered with light snow. And off-road vehicles tend to be harder to stop. The four-wheel-drive Explorer needs 164 feet to stop from 60 miles an hour, 20 to 30 feet more than a typical family car.
The driving habits of many Explorer owners did not help. An extensive Ford survey in 1993 found that sport utility buyers said they drove faster than other motorists drove, followed other vehicles more closely than other drivers did and were especially likely to risk driving in bad weather.
Off-road driving also requires a high floor, so that the vehicle does not scrape its gas tank and other important components on rocks, and so that the wheels have plenty of room to bounce up and down. But a high floor limits cargo space and makes it harder for people to climb in and out, particularly the elderly.
The Explorer, in short, had a case of ambiguous identity. It said so right there in the "special notice" at the front of the owner's manual: "Your vehicle is not a passenger car."
 
The Problem
Unpleasant Surprise In Rollovers
In early 1989, with the Explorer just a year from mass production, Ford executives found themselves with a puzzle.
Consumer Reports, enormously influential in the auto industry, had just criticized the Explorer's two-door ancestor, the Bronco II, for a tendency to roll over during certain high-speed turns. Having already designed most of the Explorer and ordered its parts, company documents show, Ford grasped anxiously for a solution.
Ford executives, by their own account, were surprised by the extent of the Bronco's problems. Even so, rollover problems had plagued sport utilities since primitive truck-based ones were built for the military during World War II. Indeed, costly rollover lawsuits involving truck-based Jeeps had pushed American Motors to design the Cherokee from scratch as a sport utility vehicle in the early 1980's.
But once a sport utility is built on a pickup-truck base, particularly a base designed for another vehicle, it is extremely difficult to make it as stable as a well-designed car-based model, most auto engineers say.
Car-based vehicles have two main advantages, they say. Their seats -- and hence their centers of gravity -- are considerably lower. And since they are built as a single unit, they are more rigid than vehicles whose passenger compartments and underbodies are manufactured separately.
No matter how firmly bolted together, tall vehicles based on pickup trucks are more prone to sway during sharp turns, said Roy Lunn, a legendary designer of Ford sports cars who later designed the Cherokee. This is especially true of the Explorer and other vehicles with "leaf spring" suspensions -- a cheap, simple design dating back to buggy days.
To make a pickup-based sport utility as rigid as a car-based model, Mr. Lunn added, "you would have yourself such a heavy chassis that it wouldn't be practical, so you just live with it."
As the Ford engineers pondered their problem in 1989, they would have to live with that first design decision made three years before. To undo it would have set the Explorer back years more, and besides, this was the Explorer they wanted. So again, they improvised.
They came up with three options, company documents show. They could choose shorter suspension springs to lower the front end by half an inch and the back by an inch. They could recommend a fairly low tire pressure, which would give the Explorer a more stable ride (except when a tire failed) -- as well as the softer ride favored by people accustomed to cars. And they could redesign the entire vehicle to mount the wheels two inches farther apart.
They chose the first two. And when prototypes passed Ford's stability test, they decided against the widening, which would have been extremely time-consuming and expensive. "Utilize as many of the chassis revisions as possible without delaying Job 1," said a Ford memorandum, using industry jargon for beginning mass production of a new model.
The decision making shows how they weighed costs and benefits -- and, ultimately, were hemmed in by the original design as they tried to make that tippy truck into a safer family vehicle.
On the one hand, they did improve stability. On the other, the more radical option would have made it even safer. According to the government's new rollover ratings, which rank vehicles from one to five stars, the changes Ford made each added a quarter star. The widening would have added three-eighths more.
In the end, though, what they did not do was make the Explorer as stable as a traditional car or sport utility built on a car base, according to crash statistics and the rollover ratings, which compare the height of a vehicle's center of gravity with its width -- the lower and wider the better. The Cherokee scores near the top of the two-star group in the five-star ratings, while the Explorer is at the low end. (A Ford Taurus sedan, by comparison, rates four or five stars, depending on the model year.)
Mr. Ross, the Explorer planner, said a pickup-based sport utility could be as stable as a car-based model. In the case of the Explorer, he said, Ford's primary stability goal had been to make it better than the other sport utilities on the market at the time.
Ford took a similar tack several years later, with the 1995 Explorer. The front suspension was redesigned to be somewhat less prone to rollovers, but the new suspension was also lighter, providing less weight down low in the vehicle. Ford rejected a costly move to lower the engine, so the Explorer's center of gravity actually rose slightly.
 
The Trade-Offs
Along With Benefits, Design Liabilities
Automobile design is a matter of trade-offs. And often, dealing with one problem only adds to another.
For instance, using the Ranger's underbody for the Explorer gave Ford the image it wanted, with the budget it needed. But while the Explorer looked roomy, its design actually limited the weight it could safely carry.
By extending the passenger compartment and installing a second row of seats, Ford made the Explorer more than 600 pounds heavier than the Ranger but did not upgrade the suspension and tires to carry the bigger load. That meant a typically equipped Explorer could carry 1,025 pounds, even less than the 1,100 pounds for a Taurus. Many Explorers are built to carry as little as 900 pounds --a 150-pound person in each of five seats and 150 pounds of cargo.
Sport utility vehicles are more prone to roll over when heavily loaded because the seats and cargo area are above the vehicles' center of gravity. By contrast, the stability of cars and minivans is less affected when they are full because the passengers and cargo are situated at roughly the cars' and minivans' center of gravity.
Whether overloading played a role in the Firestone tire failures is not clear. Some of the Explorers that crashed were stuffed with people and luggage; some were not. In general, though, overloading "can really affect your stability and handling," said Donald F. Tandy, an engineer who oversaw much of the early work on the Explorer.
Another trade-off involved the tires. Ford chose the same size tires it had long chosen for the Ranger. Those tires had the lowest possible rating for withstanding high temperatures. And when the company lowered the recommended tire pressure in 1989 to increase stability and soften the ride, it also further reduced the tires' ability to carry weight without overheating.
Tire pressure became an issue in the Firestone controversy, with Firestone arguing that the lower recommended pressure -- 26 pounds per square inch, compared with 35 for the Ranger -- had contributed to the tires' failure, especially where Explorers were being driven at high speeds in high temperatures.
For its part, Ford pointed out that Goodyear tires inflated to the same pressure almost never failed on Explorers, and that Firestone had endorsed the recommendation for nearly 10 years, until it recalled 6.5 million tires last summer. Even so, Ford recently raised the recommended pressure to 30 pounds.
Sometimes, the trade-offs are not intended, and not understood until much later.
Ford believed the Explorer's size and design made it safe, Mr. Ross said, and Explorer occupants do have an unusually low death rate in multivehicle crashes. But he acknowledged that planners had scarcely considered whether the Explorer, while safer for its own occupants in a crash with a lower-riding car, was more deadly to other motorists.
Pickup-based designs are much deadlier to other motorists than are car-based models because these vehicles are heavier and taller and rely on two stiff, heavy steel beams that run the length of the underbody and curve up like runners of a sleigh. Instead of crumpling and absorbing shock, these beams tend to slide up and over cars' bumpers and door sills, punching into the other vehicle's passenger compartment.
Quantifying that danger is difficult.
Ford says it has no specific statistics for the Explorer. Its senior traffic-safety researcher, Priya Prasad, said the designs of all light trucks were responsible for an extra 1,000 deaths a year in other vehicles.
One statistician, Hans Joksch of the University of Michigan, has studied the deadliness of the Explorer's design. Explorers cause 115 to 140 deaths a year in vehicles they strike, while big cars of the same weight cause 30 to 40. So the Explorer's design appears to cost about 100 extra lives a year -- almost as many deaths each year as in tire-related crashes of Explorers over the entire decade.
 
The New Explorer
Making Safety A Higher Priority
Ford is trying to position itself as the industry's safety leader, so when it invited reporters last month to see the completely redesigned 2002 Explorer, engineers waxed particularly enthusiastic about new safety features.
The tires are larger, with a higher recommended pressure. The vehicle is two and a half inches wider -- the option discarded in 1989 as too expensive and time-consuming. The stiff steel rails of a pickup-truck underbody remain, but Ford lowered them considerably when it exchanged the Explorer's primitive suspension for a sophisticated car-like one, a change that also improved the braking to car quality. And the new underbody can no longer be built on the same assembly line as a Ranger.
Taken together, these changes should mean that the Explorer would be less likely to roll over and less deadly to other motorists as well. But the decisions to incorporate them were actually made several years ago, before the tire cases threw a spotlight on the Explorer's stability.
Impressed by the success of the Durango, with its third row of seats, Ford decided to add a third row to the Explorer as well. The width, tire sizes, suspension strength and maximum payload were increased mainly to accommodate the extra passengers and make the Explorer more competitive with other models, though stability was also considered, Ford executives said.
The rails were also redesigned to curve down just behind the grille. Mr. Prasad said this change seemed obvious only with hindsight.
More than half all midsize and large S.U.V.'s have been redesigned the last two years to be less deadly to other motorists.
Even so, Mr. Tandy cautioned that while engineers could do much to make certain models more stable, sport utilities would always be somewhat more rollover-prone than cars because of their greater height.
"Light trucks in general will have a higher rollover rate," he said, "because of all the things that make an S.U.V. an S.U.V."

(Photograph by Tim Parker for The New York Times); Ford built an image of a trucklike vehicle that could take its owners wherever their adventurous fantasies led them. Most people, however, use their sport utilities as traditional cars. (pg. C6)
 
Chart: "The Explorer: Product of an Imperfect Marriage"
Ford designed its Explorer on a shoestring budget in the late 1980's, bolting a roomy car-like passenger cabin on top of the underbody of a Ranger pickup truck. The high- riding design made the vehicle more prone to rolling over. Here are some of the design features of the Explorer -- many of them shared by other pickup-based sport utilities -- that have contributed to the vehicle's rollover problems and the steps Ford is taking to fix them on the 2002 model, which goes on sale in February.
 
PAYLOAD -- Ford did not tell buyers the maximum weight the vehicle could carry, even though overloaded vehicles are vulnerable to rollovers.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Will provide information on stickers in door jambs.
 
SIDES AND ROOF -- Sides are almost vertical, barely leaning in as they go up to the roof.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Roof will be a half-inch narrower, with the sides tapering in. This improves stability when luggage fills the interior to the ceiling.
 
TRACK WIDTH -- Wheels are only as far apart as on the Ranger, even though the Explorer is a bigger, more top-heavy vehicle.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Wheels will be mounted 2 1 /2 inches farther apart.
 
REAR SUSPENSION -- The Explorer uses a leaf-spring suspension dating back to buggies that slows braking and lets wheels slip sideways.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Will use costlier, carlike coil springs that improve braking and are more resistant to sideways wheel movements.
 
REAR SUSPENSION MOUNTS -- The frame rails are bolted on top of the suspension, so the vehicle's cargo floor is high.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Coil springs will be attached to rods that go through holes in the rails, lowering the cargo floor six inches.
 
GAS TANK -- It is mounted on the same side of the vehicle as the four-wheel- drive system, putting extra weight on the left rear tire, which has failed more frequently than other tires.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Will be moved to the opposite side of the underbody.
 
FRAME RAILS -- Shaped like the letter C, they are open on one side, making them less stiff and therefore less stable. They also curve up at the front, making them more likely to override car bumpers in crashes.
CHANGE ON 2002 MODEL: Will have enclosed rails, which make the vehicle stiffer, except at the front, where holes have been punched in the rails to help them absorb energy during a crash. The new frame rails also will curve down at the front.
(Source: Interviews with Ford engineers)(pg. C6)

Explorers and most other S.U.V.'s are based on pickup trucks, and have higher death rates in rollovers than cars or car-based Jeep Grand Cherokees.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-21
 
Russia Sends American To Prison in Spy Case
Edmond Pope, 54, was convicted of espionage, and a judge in Moscow gave him the maximum sentence of 20 years at hard labor, after a seven-week trial behind closed doors. Mr. Pope was accused last April of obtaining secret plans and technical reports for Russia's rocket-propelled Shkval -- or Squall in English -- torpedo, which travels at 230 miles an hour. His is the first espionage conviction of a Westerner in Russia since the end of the cold war. A1

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: WOMAN MINIMIZES ROLE IN DEATH -- A woman who was convicted with a friend in the 1997 slaying of a man in Central Park testified in a deposition this week that she had played only a minimal part in the crime. The woman, Daphne Abdela, and her friend Christopher Vasquez, both now 18, are being tried in a $150 million wrongful-death suit for the killing of Michael McMorrow, a 44-year-old real estate broker, in May 1997. Mr. McMorrow was repeatedly stabbed, then disemboweled, and his body left in a park lake. Ms. Abdela, who pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter, for which she is serving a 10-year maximum sentence, testified for the first time under oath Tuesday that it was Mr. Vasquez alone who stabbed Mr. McMorrow, according to her lawyer, Paul Callan. Arnold N. Kriss, the lawyer for Mr. Vasquez, would not comment. Lawyers for the McMorrow family said both defendants were responsible. Eun Lee Koh (NYT) 

BROOKLYN: SCHOOL GUARD DEPLOYMENT -- The way the city deploys 3,700 safety officers in 1,200 public schools is being reviewed, safety officials told the Board of Education yesterday. The officials hope to increase the number of agents at crowded schools and at schools with multiple buildings. The authorities are also considering expanding a program of parent patrols being used successfully in Community School District 6 in Upper Manhattan. Terri Thomson, above, the board member representing Queens, said some schools seemed understaffed, including Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, where two agents patrol a six-story elementary school with five temporary buildings and 2,100 students.
 Edward Wyatt (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: COLUMBIA STUDENT DIES -- The police are investigating the death of a 19-year-old Columbia University student who they say jumped or fell from the eighth floor of a campus apartment building to the ground-floor lobby around 3 a.m. yesterday. The student, who was identified as Andrea Melendez, was taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where she died of her injuries, the police said. Ms. Melendez was a sophomore at Columbia. She was apparently a resident of the building, at 562 West 113th Street. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)
 
BRONX: 2 CRITICALLY HURT IN FIRE -- A 71-year-old woman and her daughter, 52, were in critical condition yesterday after a fire erupted in their sixth-floor Bronx apartment, the authorities said. The woman, Idela Harris, and her daughter Louise Harris were admitted to Jacobi Medical Center's burn unit, a hospital spokeswoman said. Three firefighters were treated for smoke inhalation. It was not clear yesterday what caused the fire, which broke out at 1134 Burke Avenue at 6:47 a.m. and was under control by 7:29 a.m., a Fire Department spokesman said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)
 
MELVILLE: HOME LOAN FORECLOSURES -- Senator Charles E. Schumer called on the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development yesterday to impose an immediate moratorium on foreclosures of federal home loans in Long Island communities that have the highest rates of loan defaults. Hundreds of homeowners in Brookhaven, Patchogue, Wyandanch, Coram and Central Islip have said they are unable to make mortgage payments or pay for repairs on their homes. They had received appraisals and mortgages from what Mr. Schumer called predatory lenders who appraised properties at inflated rates. HUD said it would make a decision within seven days. Tina Kelley (NYT)
 
MINEOLA: CELL PHONE BILL INTRODUCED -- The Nassau County Legislature is considering a ban on the use of cell phones while driving. The proposed law, introduced by Presiding Officer Judith Jacobs yesterday, would ban people from using cell phones while driving in Nassau County unless they use a hands-free device like an earphone. Emergency calls are exempted. Violators would be fined $150. If adopted, the law will go into effect on March 1. Tina Kelley (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: AIRPORT ECONOMIC STUDY -- A new economic study reported yesterday that Bradley International Airport generated $2.5 billion annually for the region's economy, including $700 million in wages paid to 26,000 employees. The so-called direct impacts of the airport, in Windsor Locks, were estimated to be $334 million annually, led primarily by government operations, including the military. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)
 
NEW MILFORD: PRAYER CLUB ORDERED CLOSED -- A couple have sued the zoning commission after being ordered to stop holding weekly prayer meetings in their home for as many as 40 people. Kathy Castagnetta, the town's zoning enforcement officer, said meetings of that size, no matter what their purpose, were not a permitted use of a residential property under the town's zoning code. The couple, Robert and Mary Murphy, have filed a federal lawsuit charging that their First Amendment rights are being violated. (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: WORKER SHORTAGE -- A business group said yesterday that New Jersey businesses were facing the greatest worker shortage in 30 years. The group, the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, surveyed 16,500 member companies in September. Eighty percent of the companies said they had had trouble finding skilled workers last year. Forty-eight percent said the skilled-worker shortage had curtailed business expansion plans. (NYT)
 
TRENTON: GATES GIVES MILLIONS TO SCHOOLS -- The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced a $5.1 million grant to help teach New Jersey school principals and superintendents how to make the best use of computer technology. New Jersey is the 12th state whose school administrators have received such a grant, which is part of the foundation's total commitment of $350 million to education. The foundation derives much of its assets from shares of Microsoft Corporation, which Mr. Gates and a partner founded. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
CHERRY HILL: RACETRACK SOLD -- Garden State Race Track, in decline since casino gambling arrived in Atlantic City in the 1970's, has been sold and will be replaced by a 230-acre residential and commercial development, said Dennis Maloomian, president of Realen Properties in Berwyn, Pa., yesterday. The company and a partner bought the track last week from International Thoroughbred Breeders. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

HEADLINE: Hot Economy Cooling Down? Not New York's

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Every day brings new evidence that the once-booming national economy is slowing; even Alan Greenspan says so. But take a walk almost anywhere in Manhattan -- jostled by the leather-wearing, cell-phone-wielding, taxicab-grabbing, shopping-bag-swinging hordes -- and you have to wonder: what slowdown?
Economists here are wondering, too. They know from sad experience that New York City is not immune to national economic trends. They see some small clouds on the horizon, and a big black one called Wall Street. They are poring over data on jobs and housing and taxes, looking for signs of a slowdown. 
 "So far, we just don't see it," said Larian Angelo, chief economist for the City Council.
Private economists agree. "The New York City economy is not going to march to a different drummer forever," said Marc M. Goloven, senior regional economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "But so far, there is very little evidence of a slowdown."
New York City, for so many years the country's economic problem child, the place that was hit the hardest during the last recession, that lagged while the rest of the nation boomed, has now shot to the top of the heap.
At 5.5 percent, the unemployment rate is as low as it has been in a dozen years. Tax collections are up, and a local measure of business activity just hit an all-time high. Since March, the economy of the city has been growing far more robustly than that of the nation.
Most important, the city's private employers are creating jobs at the fastest pace in half a century and far faster than the national average. "We've never really seen anything quite like it in our historical records," said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner of the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Part of what makes New York City different is simply its mix of industries; there is no Detroit Stock Exchange, after all, and this is not exactly Motor City. The city was also late to the national economic party, and to some extent has just been making up for lost time.
The relative shortness of the recovery here may even bode well if there is another economic downturn. "It's not conclusive," said Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "But often, regions that get hit hard in one recession are not hit as hard in the next one."
Look hard enough and you can find some indications of softening. But even the experts cannot tell if these numbers mean that the economy is slowing down or just that people are coming to their senses after a multiyear spending spree.
For example, more hotel rooms were empty this October than in October of last year, the first drop in occupancy rates since last December, when the expected millennial windfall did not materialize, according to PKF Consulting, which tracks the hotel industry.
That does not mean, however, that it is easy to book a room at the Plaza (or the Carlyle or the Waldorf-Astoria). The new, lower occupancy rate is 87.5 percent, despite an increase in the number of hotel rooms in the city and a 9 percent increase in room rates over the last year, said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF. It is most unusual, he said, "for any major city to have occupancy rates in the high 80's or low 90's for any sustained period," as the city has for almost a year.
Retail sales may have cooled off a bit, too, after last year's holiday frenzy, but are still growing. During the 10-day shopathon that followed Thanksgiving, purchases in New York City rose by 2 percent compared with last year, according to one indicator from TeleCheck Services, which monitors payments made by check. That increase is well below the national average of 3.2 percent.
But it is unclear whether some shoppers here have been spooked by the stock market or are simply procrastinating because Hanukkah is late this year, said William Ford, a professor at Middle Tennessee State University and an adviser to TeleCheck.
Of course, the barrage of bad national economic news, the stock market's swoon and the continuing fight over who gets to live in the White House are having at least a psychological effect. A monthly survey of local businesspeople found that their expectations for the future had tumbled over the last two months, even as they said current business conditions were excellent.
And New Yorkers preparing to plunk down hundreds of thousands of dollars for apartments are also "a little bit more hesitant with everything that's going on," said Diane M. Ramirez, president of the Halstead Property Company.
But apartments are not going begging for buyers. Although prices are no longer soaring, they are holding, Ms. Ramirez said, adding that she becomes concerned when an apartment sells for less than what a similar apartment in the same building fetched six months ago. She has not seen that yet this year.
The city's economy has built up so much momentum in the last year that it may well take months to slow down, some economists say. "New York City is like a great big supertanker that goes steaming ahead," said John Tepper Marlin, chief economist for the city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi.
For example, he said, despite the carnage among the Internet companies known as dot-coms, October was one of the best job-creating months in the last five years for the business services sector, which includes many dot-coms as well as accounting firms, computer programming firms and temporary-help agencies.
The demise of dot-coms also freed up commercial real estate in the city, which was snapped up by financial firms that had been frantically seeking more space, said Bruce E. Mosler, president of United States operations at Cushman & Wakefield, the big commercial real estate brokerage. "Vacancy rates are declining, not rising, and rents continue to rise," he said, adding that he does not expect the market to quiet down until the middle of next year.
All this buoyant economic news does not extend to the entire downstate region. Job growth has slowed in the northern suburbs and on Long Island, and has stalled in parts of New Jersey and Connecticut, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The culprit, however, may not be a slowing economy, but a shortage of workers. In most of the places where job growth is slow, the unemployment rate is less than 3 percent -- and in Stamford, Conn., it is a minuscule 1.2 percent. Why create a new job if you can't find someone to take it?
Nationally, places where companies make stuff -- cars, combines, computers -- have been experiencing the biggest slowdowns, said Mark Zandi, who is the chief economist at Economy.com, which tracks regional trends. (These days, only a relative handful of jobs in New York City -- fewer than 7 percent -- are in manufacturing.)
High-tech centers like San Francisco, Boston and Austin, Tex., are also showing some weakness as individuals and corporations throttle back on their computer purchases, he said.
The fact that New York City is neither a high-tech mecca nor a manufacturing powerhouse does not mean the future here is necessarily bright, Mr. Zandi said. He worries about the outlook for the city's most important industry: Wall Street.
"If the equity market continues to struggle as it has been," he said, "I think the city's going to hit a wall."
Struggle is a mild word for the gyrations of the stock market this week. It soared on Tuesday, after Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve would act to head off any recession if the economy slowed too much. Yesterday, though, the market swooned again as some big companies warned that their earnings would be poor.
The Dow Jones industrial average is down more than 7 percent this year, and technology stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq index, have plunged about 31 percent.
This is bad news not only for investors, but also for Wall Street. When stocks decline, securities firms may make a little money from trading, but they lose the huge fees they make from initial public offerings and mergers.
Those high-profit businesses boomed in the first half of the year, sending Wall Street profits to record levels. But business fell during the third quarter of the year, and October and November have been even worse.
The stock market is not the only problem. The bond business has also been bad. And securities firms have been hit with a wave of mergers.
Industry estimates suggest that 10,000 workers will be laid off, most of them in New York. (About 5,000 will come from Chase Manhattan's purchase of J. P. Morgan, which sounds like a bank but is really an investment firm.) That sounds like a lot, but almost 180,000 people work in New York's securities industry; even they are a relative drop in the city's bucket of 3.7 million jobs.
There is some debate, as much political as economic, about how much the city's economy depends on Wall Street. Democrats tend to say the city leans on the securities business more and more; Republicans contend that the city's economy is becoming increasingly diverse.
The industry itself sides, for once, with the Democrats on this issue, and is now warning of a cataclysm for the city if its profits plunge.
"The disaster to the city's and state's budgets, economies and job markets from a declining securities industry could be biblical in proportion," according to a new report from the Securities Industry Association. (The industry, not coincidentally, is angling for more favorable tax treatment.)
Jobs are not the only, or even the biggest, issue. So many Wall Street jobs pay so well that the securities business has been the biggest driver of income gains in the city, and of tax collections, too.
Wall Street's lavish year-end bonuses, roughly $12 billion last year, accounted for about 7 percent of all the wages paid in the city, according to the industry association. Frank Fernandez, the group's chief economist, said that this year, bonuses will be the same as last year's, or "maybe down fractionally."
The New York State comptroller's office, however, just estimated that bonuses would reach a record $13.3 billion because of gains earlier in the year.
Tax collections, then, may not be much lower this year. But the association warns that 2000 bonuses "may be the last large infusion into the local economy from the industry in the near future."
Then there's the outlook for all the restaurants, cigar merchants, limousine services, jewelry purveyors and assorted sellers of life's little (and big) luxuries. Because of the uncertainty on Wall Street, this may not be a great time to be a Jaguar dealer, said Joan Zimmerman, executive vice president of G. Z. Stephens, an executive recruitment firm.
"I just think there will be fewer diamonds," she said, "and a little less champagne popped."

HEADLINE: Reversing Course, Accounting Board Eases Stance on Mergers

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The accounting rule-making body in the United States reversed course on a contentious issue yesterday and agreed to change accounting rules in a way that will substantially raise reported profits for companies that acquire other companies.
The rule makers, the Financial Accounting Standards Board, reversing a tentative decision it had made last year, ruled that good will -- the asset created when companies pay more to acquire each other than the book value of the underlying assets -- need not be written off over any particular period. 
 Instead, good will would be allowed to remain on the books indefinitely, until the company determines that the operations of the acquired company are performing so poorly that a write-off is needed.
In the corporate world, merger accounting has long been a highly contentious area, with companies seeking rules that would allow them to look good. The standards board is moving to end one of two ways that mergers are now accounted for, the so-called pooling method, that companies have long preferred.
The prospect of its elimination aroused fierce opposition from many businesses, which argued that changing the merger rules would make it harder for companies to merge, and legislation was introduced in Congress to stop the board from acting.
The new plan, which the board accepted in a unanimous vote, would eliminate pooling but would also make the alternative approach, known as purchase accounting, much more palatable to business.
"There is an element of compromise in this decision," said Robert Willens, an accounting analyst for Lehman Brothers. "It was clear that, as a political matter, for them to have any chance to eliminate pooling, they had to make purchase more attractive."
Edmund L. Jenkins, the chairman of the accounting standards board, said in an interview that political factors were not paramount in the decision. "Will this make some of our critics go away?" he said. "I expect that will be the case, but I also think the decision is well grounded."
Mr. Jenkins said that some intangible assets, as good will is formally known, clearly do not lose value over time. He said that if the board could design a rigorous test that companies must apply in deciding whether assets are impaired, and thus must be written down, it would provide more information for investors than an arbitrary standard requiring that assets be written off over a certain schedule. The current rule requires that assets be written down over 40 years or less, a timetable the board had decided to cut to 20 years before it reversed course yesterday.
With a 20-year write-down period, a company that bought another for $1 billion more than the book value of its assets would have $1 billion in good will, and writing it off would cut reported profits by $50 million a year. Under the new proposal, the reported profits would be that much higher, unless the company concluded that the asset needed to be written off because its value was impaired.
The current rule on when assets are deemed to be impaired, and thus must be written down, has been criticized because it allows so much discretion to executives that write-downs can seem arbitrary. They often come as part of a "big bath," in which a new management takes a large loss that can be attributed to the previous management.
Jane Adams, an accounting analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston and a former deputy chief accountant at the S.E.C., said: "I expect that the Securities and Exchange Commission will have some concerns relative to the adequacy of impairment models. Will the model be rigid enough to keep the good will impairment write-downs from being absolutely discretionary?"
Lynn Turner, the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, declined to comment on the Accounting Standards Board's decision. The board is a private-sector organization; the S.E.C. has the authority to overrule its decisions.
The decision was praised by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, who had opposed legislative action but pushed for the action the board took yesterday. "I think this is a sound approach, an economic approach," he said.
For companies, the new rule may come to seem the best of all worlds. Pooling accounting, which companies love because it does not require them to put good will on the balance sheet, has other problems. To use it, companies must use common stock to pay for the acquisition and are restricted from making future stock buybacks or selling assets of the acquired company for up to two years. That leads to companies' delaying the sale of assets they do not want, simply to ensure the accounting treatment they prefer.
Dennis Powell, the controller of Cisco Systems and an advocate of keeping pooling accounting, said the board's decision would "make the purchase method of accounting more effective and realistic."
The board has not decided whether companies merged under the old rules will no longer have to amortize good will. A final rule is not expected before spring, and its effective date has not been disclosed.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 9, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about a change in accounting rules for writing off "good will" defined the expression incorrectly. It is the difference between what one company pays for another and the fair market value of the acquired company's assets -- not the book value of those assets, which is the value on the company's balance sheet.

PUB-DATE: December 8, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 44; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4792 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If just a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

 * "A CENTURY OF DESIGN, PART 3: 1950-1975," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through April 1). Free form, a fixation on the curve, the bulge and the hollow, was the aesthetic of international design in the 1950's, to be augmented by the influence of Pop, Op and other art trends in the 60's and 70's. Designers welcomed new materials and worked the old in new ways, using plastics, rubber, steel, fiberglass, leather and synthetic fabrics. This show, the third in a four-part cycle meant to cover the whole of 20th-century design, is from the Met's own collections, so it can't be regarded as a survey of the field. Still, the show works hard and successfully to clue you in, presenting familiar icons of the period, like chairs by Harry Bertoia and Eero Saarinen, and more offbeat material like the brilliantly retro writing desk (circa 1953-54) by the Italian designers Gio Ponti and Piero Fornasetti. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck)
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an icebreaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
 
 * "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000" covers 1960 to the present and fills nearly the entire museum with almost a dozen different theme shows. "White" is one theme. Memorial art is another. Childhood and lost innocence is yet another. Like previous installments in this year-and-a-half-long navel-gazing reconsideration by the museum of how to present its permanent collection in anticipation of its future home, the show has the effect of being clever and a little too solipsistic: it's about smart curators making occasionally vivid and previously unseen connections among disparate works without making particularly fresh sense of the period as a whole. It's artistic game playing, highly pleasurable up to a point. The themes are always arguable, which is part of the game. This also becomes an occasion for the museum to parade acquisitions during the last decade, which include Gerhard Richter's series of paintings based on the Baader-Meinhof gang, occupying an entire room and probably the exhibition's high point. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * UTOPIA: THE SEARCH FOR THE IDEAL SOCIETY IN THE WESTERN WORLD," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089 (through Jan. 27). A pensive extravaganza, if one can imagine such a thing, with hundreds of books, manuscripts, maps, prints, photographs, bits of music, film, Nazi paraphernalia, Soviet propaganda, 1960's antiwar buttons, rock album covers and other curiosities spilling across galleries on two floors. It begins with a gigantic subject and enlarges on it, an ambitious strategy, serious, stylish and amusing. Like most library exhibitions, it is more of a reading event than a show about visual pleasure, but it has more than its share of redeeming virtues and benefits. Hours: Mondays, and Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Kimmelman).
 
 * "JOHN WESLEY: PAINTINGS 1961-2000," P. S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Jan. 14). For 40 years Mr. Wesley's paintings have maintained the same mild form of constructive lunacy. The art world has a handful of indispensable visionaries like Mr. Wesley, who help to keep everyone else honest. You may not enjoy his show, the first full-dress local retrospective, only because simple pleasure is not the intended effect. The images are borrowed from magazines and comics: Blondie and Dagwood Bumstead, Donald Duck and young naked women, painted flat, like coloring-book designs, with delicate black outlines, and off-key colors. The style alludes to Matisse, Hokusai, Greek vase painting, Art Nouveau, Toulouse-Lautrec. Emotion is there below the comic exterior, and it is pathos, mostly. Mr. Wesley offers up sex as unquenchable desire and woeful male inadequacy, a black comedy of men chasing after women they can only dream about. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Kimmelman).
 
 "THE YEAR ONE: ART OF THE ANCIENT WORLD EAST AND WEST," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Jan. 14). The Met puts the millennial-marking art exhibition in a new perspective with a show that only an institution of its stature and girth could pull off. Drawn from seven departments, it revisits the beginning of the "modern era" around the time of the birth of Jesus with 150 sometimes tiny artworks that sample the nearly two dozen cultures flourishing at the beginning of the first millennium. The array stretches from imperial Rome to Han dynasty China, with many stops in between. High points include bronzes from Thailand and Indonesia, a Chinese mortuary pillar and a stunning re-creation of the frescoed bedroom of a Roman villa. The display is supposed to reflect the beginning of a new world consciousness brought on by expanding empires and trade, a thesis more complex than the actual objects can sustain. But no matter, most of them are considered masterpieces, all are beautifully installed and the opportunities for cross-cultural visual comparisons are rich. Hours and admission: See above (Roberta Smith).
 
 * "YES YOKO ONO," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Jan. 14). The eye roll, a vestigial reflex, has the effect of not allowing you to see what is in front of you. It is understandably used these days to respond to celebrity spectacles passing themselves off as art events in local cultural establishments. Occasionally, however, you will miss something. You should bear this in mind here. We see Yoko Ono as she was before she became a celebrity: a mischievous, wry conceptual artist with a canny sensibility, cool but not dry, sometimes sweet, even corny -- and way ahead of her time in giving acute visual form to women's issues. As well as anyone, she encapsulated an evanescent and shifting moment in art. Fame distorts, and the show helps set the record straight. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
LYONEL FEININGER, "From the Gelmeroda Cycle," Achim Moeller, 167 East 73rd Street, (212) 988-4500 (through Dec. 22). The painter of misty yet precisely gridded Cubist cityscapes was always an excellent and versatile draftsman. In this fine exhibition of small drawings, mostly from the teens and all focused on a single church in the village of Gelmeroda near Weimar, Germany, we see the artist working with an exquisitely sensitive touch in styles ranging from sketchy naturalism to vigorously gestural Expressionism to crystalline abstraction (Johnson).
 
 * "FROM THE ARTIST'S STUDIO: UNKNOWN PRINTS AND DRAWINGS BY MARY CASSATT," Adelson Galleries, 25 East 77th Street, (212) 439-6800 (through Dec. 29). This extraordinary exhibition presents 120 prints and drawings from a heretofore privately held collection. Covering the entire course of Cassatt's printmaking career, it features multiple states of many of the great color etchings that she produced after seeing a show of Japanese woodcuts in Paris in 1890. These intimate images of women in private domestic moments or tending children are as striking for their abstract structure as for their incipiently erotic sensuality (Johnson).
 
 LASZLO MOHOLY-NAGY, Ubu, 16 East 78th Street, (212) 794-4444 (through Dec. 22). Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946), the once hugely influential Modernist and Bauhaus educator, is today only hazily remembered. This extensive and diverse sampling of small works on paper shows why. The show is like a hall of mirrors that palely reflect many more interesting artists: Rodchenko, Mondrian, Man Ray and others. Moholy-Nagy's dream of fusion among art, science and industry shows in a Constructivist formalism that while not unplayful has a bland, corporate impersonality (Johnson).
 
 JAUME PLENSA, "Twin Shadows," Richard Gray, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 472-8787, and Galerie Lelong, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 315-0470 (through Dec. 22) This 45-year-old Catalan who lives in Paris and Barcelona has an impressive flair for theater. At Gray, video-projected, God-like eyes survey a broad table covered in red velvet that bears engraved glass balls spelling out elemental dualities like "semen-blood," or "night-day." At Lelong recorded sounds of lovemaking issue from below a wooden deck; glass ball works mounted on opposite walls spell out the themes: "dream" and "desire" (Johnson).
 
 LAURIE SIMMONS, "Tourism, 1984," Skarstedt Fine Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through Dec. 23). Known for her photography of constructed mini-scale scenes, Ms. Simmons concocted "Tourism, 1984" after a harried visit to the Acropolis that year. She decided that such glamour destinations might be better experienced in reproduction, the way most of us know and remember them, anyway. So she photographed her doll-size "Teenettes" against sites blown up from bad slides: Las Vegas, the Great Wall of China, the Taj Mahal and other cliche attractions. The 60-by-40-inch Cibachromes play up the nostalgia-knowledge foisted on us by reproductions. To make it more fantastical, the stiff little mannequins who stand agape at the backdrops take on the coloration of the slides. It's enough to deter you from world travel for quite some time (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
CHARLES AVERY, "The Riddle of Pooch Avery," Dee/Glasoe, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 924-7545 (through Dec. 23). More a figure of intriguing sensibility than real accomplishment, this young London-based artist presents a series of illustrative, elegantly gestural drawings of decadent young people or wizened men in monastic robes. In each there appears a small dog, a kind of space-time traveler. It all hinges enigmatically on an enlarged family snapshot of the teen-age artist and his actual dog, Pooch (Johnson).
 
 MEL BOCHNER, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through Dec. 22). Mr. Bochner's new paintings give fresh immediacy to his enduring preoccupation with the tension between perceptual and conceptual experience. Contemplating a series of near-Minimalist red-and-white works with 12-inch dimensions graphically indicated, your mind oscillates between mathematical abstraction and the vibrant punch of color and shape. For some viewers, this may prove too dryly self-reflexive; for analytical philosophy buffs, it may be deeply absorbing (Johnson).
 
 SPENCER FINCH, "Up," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323 (through Dec. 23). This clever Conceptualist offers a variety of works inspired by the idea of looking or being "up," including pictures of a stain on his bedroom ceiling, a glowing watercolor representing the smell in an airplane at 35,000 feet, views of the Milky Way painted with Tang, and a dazzling installation of suspended lights configured according to the molecular structure of blue pigment that matches the sky over Los Alamos (Johnson).
 
 BERNARD FRIZE, Cohan Leslie and Browne, 138 10th Avenue, near 18th Street, (212) 206-8710 (through Dec. 23). In his first New York solo Mr. Frize, a French painter who has exhibited widely in Europe, presents resinous abstract paintings that suggest what Morris Louis might be doing today. Mr. Frize is oriented more to process than form, however; excepting one lovely striated veil painting, the interest is more in his inventively matter-of-fact ways with materials and procedures than his pictorial effects (Johnson).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). The Damien Hirst Universe is a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 * "THE IMPERIAL GAZE," Sepia International, 148 West 24th Street, (212) 645-9444 (through Dec. 30.) The British photographer Samuel Bourne was in India for only seven years (1863-70), but he took thousands of pictures, established a lucrative business and became well-known for his cityscapes and pictures of architectural monuments. Like many quest-driven travelers, though, he wanted, even needed, something from India: in his case, an experience of the Sublime in nature. In Kashmir, he encountered an earthly Eden, and on arduous treks to the Himalayas, he discovered the meaning of hugeness. The pictures that resulted are part of one of the richest bodies of photographic work to emerge from British India (Cotter).
 
 JILL LEVINE, Art Resources Transfer, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 691-5956 (through Dec. 31). All three of this gallery's project spaces are devoted to a survey of Ms. Levine's buoyantly quirky wall-sculpture. Since the late 1980's the artist has been assembling standardized styrofoam parts -- balls, rings, cones, cubes -- into funky configurations and painting them in various ways: Constructivist-style, intricate patterns or trompe l'oeil. Most recently, she has covered them with detailed Hindu imagery, setting up a Pop-brokered marriage of East and West (Johnson).
 
 "PROCESS/REPROCESS: JAPAN AND THE WEST," Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through Dec. 23). This disconnected but highly suggestive show mixes Western artists who have been influenced by Japanese traditions (like Richard Serra, James Lee Byars and Richard Tuttle) with Japanese artists who have been oriented to Western avant-gardisms (like Yayoi Kusama, Yoko Ono and Nikki S. Lee). What is most remarkable is how many different modes of artmaking are thus embraced, from Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism to Fluxus to the latest kinds of photographic and video performance (Johnson).
 
 * CINDY SHERMAN, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100, (through Jan. 6). With her latest untitled series Ms. Sherman is back in front of the camera lens again, disguised as women who, you might say, used to be somebody, maybe. They grin at the camera in clownish make-up, wobbly wigs and discount blouses, proud, valiantly oblivious to, or simply defiant of, our condescension, like the beauty pageant queen who drops her baton in the talent contest but keeps beaming. Formal devices by Ms. Sherman get overlooked because of the human element: the pattern of pigtails against plaid shirt in one portrait; the purplish freckled face of another woman with purple shirt and purple cap. This formal order becomes a rational structure that gives to the work its mix of frigidity and heat, a perfectly ambiguous cocktail for an ambiguous moment and an antidote to the weary sophistication of which there is too much in art now (Kimmelman).
 
 * SUE WILLIAMS, 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-1121 (through Dec. 16). A decade ago Sue Williams was making rage-filled, clotted, sometimes outrageously funny works about the tribulations of women. Now she's painting like late de Kooning: confetti splashes of red, yellow and blue, calligraphic pirouettes, sweeping curves and minor skirmishes, mostly spare on big, bare white canvases. It is as if she were seeing how far she could push this sort of elegant abstraction before alienating her old audience, which, in terms of approach, is not so different from her button-pushing early work (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
KIM DINGLE, "Never in School," Sperone Westwater, 121 Greene Street, (212) 431-3685 (through Dec. 22). In dainty little dresses and Mary Jane shoes, two small troublemakers, Fatty and Fudge, use classroom and playground for their subversive antics: fighting, taking off their clothes, writing dirty words on a blackboard and generally mess-making. What brings it all off is Ms. Dingle's chronicling of their cartoony doings in a satirical painting mode usually reserved for high-art subjects. Velazquez, meet Fatty and Fudge (Glueck).
 
 ADRIANNE GALLINARI, Drawing Room, 40 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through Dec. 20). Ms. Gallinari, a Brazilian artist who lives in Argentina, has used black crayon to cover the gallery walls with fields of illegible writing punctuated by primitivistic signs and figures. It suggests a kind of autistic or obsessive-compulsive industry, but lacks the intensity of real Outsider Art. (Johnson)
 
 JULIO GONZALEZ, Kent, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500 (through Dec. 16). This modest show of drawings and sculptures offers a glimpse of the artist who, in company with Picasso, revolutionized modern sculpture by inventing welded-steel assemblage. Drawings range from deft academic portraits to energetic sketches for the semi-abstract, semi-Surrealist sculpture "Cactus Man." The half-dozen small metal sculptures look at once like ancient artifacts and modernist fragments; among them is a graceful female torso hammered from a sheet of bronze (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
RALPH FASANELLA, Bread and Roses/1199 SEIU Gallery, 310 West 43rd Street, (212) 603-1186 (through Jan. 2). You could not pick a more appropriate place than this, the art gallery of New York State's largest health care worker's union, to present a small retrospective of paintings by Fasanella, the self-taught working-class hero, passionate leftist and visionary Social Realist, who died in 1997. His celebratory cityscapes and baseball stadiums and his darker allegories of American politics are marvels of expansive imagination and industrious detailing (Johnson).
 
 MIRIAM HERNANDEZ, Mixta Gallery, 1706 Lexington Avenue, near 106th Street, (212) 828-9173 (through Dec. 16). Ms. Hernandez's new work, which combines painting, drawing, collage and print techniques, has a loose, trying-things-out, diaristic feel. Each piece is about the size of a notebook page and centers around the figure of the artist as a golden-skinned Buddha wearing dark-rimmed glasses and floating in fields of soft reds, pinks and greens, which manage to look both tropical and Tibetan (Cotter).
 
 "PASTORAL POP!," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Dec. 15). Nature-inspired kitsch is the theme of this delirious seven-artist show. It includes Rob de Mar's comical landscape in the form of a spindly tree, Lisa Ruyter's psychedelic update of Seurat's "Grande Jatte," Alyson Shotz's grove of weird plant machines, Peter Gould's transformation of the guard station into a bucolic cartoon, Jason Middlebrook's Styrofoam stone wall planter, Katrin Asbury's miniature diorama in a planter and Rachel Feinstein's suspended Rococo-style pitcher exploding flowers like a pinata (Johnson).
 
 JILL VINEY, Trans Hudson, 416 West 13th Street, West Village, (212) 242-3232 (through Dec. 16). Ms. Viney produces pod-like sculptures with heavy, translucent outer shells and hazily visible entrails of found junk. Sleek, pudgy "Drifters" hover overhead like extraterrestrial putti; four-limbed works from the "Pulse" series attach to the walls like submarine bio-industrial creatures (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
* "THE CHINESE PAINTER AS POET," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through Sunday). In China, painting, poetry and calligraphy were the dream team of art: the "three perfections," they were called. Any truly evolved person was adept at each, and discussion of any of them was framed in the same terms: rhythm, touch, tone, spiritual energy. This eloquent exhibition examines the three-way partnership through some four dozen paintings, several of them of the first rank, ranging in date from the Song dynasty (960-1279) through the 20th century. In many cases the artist has inscribed his own poem on the surface of his painting in what amounts to a virtuoso multimedia solo performance. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Thursdays, until 8 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 R. CRUMB, "Restaurant Place Mat Drawings," Paul Morris Gallery, 465 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2752 (through tomorrow). All the drawings are from the last 10 years and were done, doodle-style, while Mr. Crumb waited for his meal. If the veteran Comix-meister makes no big advances here, that's O.K. His draftsmanly style and thematic obsessions are classics (Cotter).
 
 INGE MORATH, "Saul Steinberg Masquerade," Leica, 670 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 777-3051 (through tomorrow). When the Austrian photojournalist Inge Morath first met Saul Steinberg, the brilliant New Yorker magazine cartoonist, in 1956, he greeted her wearing a paper-bag mask with his self-portrait drawn on the front. An extensive project of photographing people masked by Steinbergian personae ensued. Almost 60 (more than enough) of these mildly amusing pictures are on view (Johnson).
 
 * PETER SAUL, Nolan Eckman Gallery, 560 Broadway at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 925-6190 (through tomorrow). If Mr. Saul isn't great, in his own gross way, he's close enough. The paintings and drawings in his 27th New York show, which is one of his best, dispense with his usual horrific epics. Each zeroes in on a series of large, misshapen marginally human heads that are, on their own, an epic of physical contortion and psychological pain. Yet everything about these images functions both as physical, largely repugnant fact and as gorgeous, seductive optical event -- while conveying a ferociously comic sense of the human psyche literally turned inside out. Few artists since Philip Guston have fused form and subject matter with quite such blistering, yet refined results (Smith).
 
 TOM WESSELMANN, "Blue Nudes," Joseph Helman Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 245-2888 (through tomorrow). Think saucy, sexy nudes when you think of Mr. Wesselmann, and you won't be wrong. But those were in his Pop mode of the 1960's. These, cued by Matisse's "Blue Nude" cutout of 1952, are something else again. Suave, elegant and painterly, the life-size figures are oil-painted aluminum cutouts that lie flat against the wall, which cleverly becomes part of them. The painting, built up in delicately nuanced layers, is virtuoso (Glueck).
