HEADLINE: MY MANHATTAN;
Even When Frost Dusts the Fields, a Cornucopia Spills Onto City Streets

BYLINE: By SUSAN JACOBY; Susan Jacoby's most recent book is "Half-Jew: A Daughter's Search for Her Family's Buried Past."

 BODY:
At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May's newfangled mirth;
But like of each thing that in season grows.
 
-- Shakespeare, "Love's Labour's Lost"
Every spring, when customers return to the Union Square Greenmarket to buy baby leeks or tender young asparagus, they tell the farmers, "We're so glad you're back." 
 In fact, New York's largest farmers' market never goes away. It is open year round, unless a fierce storm intervenes, on Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Although the number of stalls on Saturdays -- the biggest greenmarket day -- drops from a high of around 70 in September to about 30 in the depths of February, there is always something worth buying and someone worth talking to.
I used to be one of the greenmarket's "summer people," turning up at the first sighting of asparagus in early May and disappearing with the last field-ripened tomatoes in October. But the market has gradually insinuated its way into my weekly routine in all seasons.
Every Saturday morning -- except when the weather is so cold or snowy that most farmers are apt to stay home -- I head out from my apartment with a big shopping bag and take the Lexington Avenue line from 86th Street to the Union Square stop at 14th Street. Emerging from the subway with a cup of coffee to warm my hands, I walk uptown and begin my vegetable search with the northernmost farm stands in the paved area between 16th Street and Union Square Park.
 
Seasonal Pleasures
September, which combines the continuing bounty of summer tomatoes with the full fall harvest, remains my favorite greenmarket month. A close second, though, is December, with its unmistakable seasonal scent of freshly cut spruce, pine and balsam.
In a sense the greenmarket is a combination general store and church social. Here in front of the mushroom stand is a radical feminist writer I haven't seen since the ancient era of women's consciousness-raising groups (i.e., the 1970's). We rarely agreed on anything in the old days, but we agree now on the vast superiority of these mushrooms, cultivated in indoor darkrooms by the Bulich brothers -- the fourth generation of farmers in their family -- of Catskill, N.Y.
I also enjoy talking to people who used to be strangers and whom I would never have met were it not for our common attraction to fresh vegetables. One of my greenmarket familiars lives on East 123rd Street, and like me, she always tries to make it to the market by midmorning to snap up the best vegetables.
We greet each other by our first names because we buy tomatoes, mushrooms, sweet potatoes and squash from the same farmers. Odessa is well into her 80's, since she admits to having cast her first presidential vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1936, but you would never know it from the ease with which she hefts 10-pound sacks of fruits and vegetables.
I used Odessa's sweet-potato casserole recipe for this year's Thanksgiving dinner. Raised in a small town in Georgia, she sneers at cooks who top their sweet potatoes with marshmallows. "A touch of whiskey was my mama's secret," she revealed. "And never, ever goo up the potatoes with all that sugary stuff. If they come straight from the ground, they're sweet enough. If you have to put extra sugar on them, they're not fit to eat."
One of the things I love most about the greenmarket is its seasonal predictability. Each year, on the Saturday after Thanksgiving, the first Christmas trees, wreaths and garlands signal the real start of the holidays for me.
Anyone who can manage to haul a tree home from Union Square (I once saw a man wrestling a 10-foot Douglas fir down the subway stairs) will find it worth the effort. Most of the trees, like everything else in the market, are grown within a 120-mile radius of the city (though a few longtime tree farmers come from Vermont and the Finger Lakes region of New York). In my experience, the greenmarket trees are fresher, and last longer indoors, than anything sold at neighborhood sidewalk stands.
 
Defying the Frost
A dazzling assortment of seasonal plants is also on display. Hodgson Farms of Walden, N.Y., even sets up a portable greenhouse to provide a cozy environment for poinsettias that sell for about half of what florists charge.
Jack Faoro, the owner of Burnt Meadow Greenhouses in Gardiner, N.Y., specializes in handmade boxwood wreaths and garlands for the holidays.
Mr. Faoro is one of the hardy souls whose stand is open year-round on Saturdays (with the exception of a two-week vacation after New Year's). During the January-February nadir of the greenmarket year, he sells daffodil and tulip bulbs, which always cheer me up with their promise of better days to come.
The availability of a surprising array of fruits and vegetables attests dramatically to the mildness of recent winters. When I started shopping at Union Square in the mid-1980's, vegetables (except for winter squash and pumpkins) seemed to disappear by Thanksgiving.
Now fresh-from-the-ground carrots, celery, broccoli, cauliflower, radishes, turnips, scallions and even lettuce are for sale through December, unless there is an unexpected long freeze. The more predictable winter fare of apples, potatoes, onions and squash are there, too. Mushrooms cultivated in darkrooms are available all year, along with greenhouse-cultivated herbs and (usually) grape tomatoes.
 
'I'll Plant It'
Even in January and February farmers continue to sell celery and parsley root, along with potatoes, carrots and onions. "If the weather's mild enough, the root vegetables still come straight from the ground," says Alex Paffenroth, the owner of Paffenroth Gardens in Warwick, N.Y.
Mr. Paffenroth also responds to customer requests for new root crops. "If you want it and I don't grow it now," he says, "I'll plant it next season."
Even when the vegetables are at their lowest ebb, the market always offers fresh meat, fish, dairy products and baked goods. Customers must be prepared to stand in line for at least 15 minutes for the lobsters, scallops, flounder and other fish sold (when they abound in local waters) by P. E. and D. D. Seafood of Riverhead, on Long Island.
There is no need to worry about spoilage because all perishable greenmarket products are transported in refrigerated trucks and sold from impeccably clean coolers. One reason the crowd is so thick around P. E. and D. D. is that the seafood, surrounded by crushed ice, is displayed in glass cases that attract rubberneckers as well as paying customers.
For clam aficionados, the Doxsee Sea Clam Company of Point Lookout, on Long Island, offers not only the fresh variety but also its own Manhattan and New England clam chowder. New Yorkers may rememberthe old commercials claiming that Doxsee clam chowder was packed with so many clams that it should simply be called "Doxsee Clam." It's true.
Being an unregenerate carnivore (as I'm called by a friend who never eats anything but fish and vegetables), I avoid the fishy crowds and head for the Blew family farm stand. The Blews raise hogs in New Jersey, on their Oak Grove Plantation in Hunterdon County, with no hormones, growth steroids or antibiotics, and sell everything from fresh pork roast and spare ribs to bacon cured without nitrites.
The stand also features flour and meal products milled from the Blews's own grain, including not only plain flour but pancake mixes as well.
Although the greenmarket is open only four days a week (and there are extremely slim pickings on winter Mondays and Fridays), there is an extra reason to stop by Union Square in December.
Clustered around the south and southwest perimeter is the Union Square Holiday Market, with some 100 booths open daily from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. through Christmas Eve. The enterprise, now in its fifth year, was the brainchild of Eldon Scott, founder of Urban Space Management. It is unrelated to the greenmarket but Mr. Scott notes that "we like to think of ourselves as kissing cousins."
 
A European Tradition
The project was inspired by the northern European tradition of the Christkindlesmarkt -- seasonal booths found in Swedish, Danish, Austrian and German cities. The Union Square version features small businesses -- the kind of shops you almost never hear about unless they are in your neighborhood -- selling everything from antique jewelry to unusual children's clothes.
Many of the greenmarket farmers also offer a variety of homegrown or home-cooked products that make unusual and economical holiday presents. The endearingly named Wooly Hill Farm of Jordanville, N.Y., features yarns of every hue, sheepskin gloves and slippers and the kind of fluffy rugs that used to serve as backgrounds for snapshots of bare-bottomed babies.
Beth's Farm Kitchen, of Stuyvesant Falls, N.Y, produces succulent jams and chutneys made exclusively from fruits grown in nearby orchards. During the holidays the jars are boxed and beribboned for an extra dollar.
A year or two ago, Beth's also provided a classic example of one of the more comical greenmarket sights -- that of a first-time (and in many cases, last-time) customer trying to use city-slicker wiles to bargain.
 
A Country Store Mentality
Dressed in ungreenmarketish garb consisting of tight leather pants, Manolo Blahnik shoes and a mink jacket, a woman looked over a jar of "blazing tomato chutney" priced at $5.95. "How about $4 for that?" she asked. One of the many cheerful, polite young women who sell Beth's products replied, cheerfully and politely, "Sorry, the price is $5.95."
The customer from hell slammed down the chutney and said, "I can pay that at Dean & DeLuca." Hardly. One of the joys of the greenmarket is that prices are far below those for comparable foods in gourmet stores. Urban rubes, not city slickers, try to bargain down prices with farmers who are themselves sophisticated entrepreneurs.
Unlike the exchange at Beth's, most of the discourse between city and country gentlefolk is more in line with what the greenmarket founders intended in 1976.
"Obviously, the main purpose of greenmarkets was to make more fresh food available to city residents," says Joel Patraker, assistant director of the 27 markets scattered throughout New York City. "But beyond that, it's a way for people from the city and the countryside to exchange experiences. You see that with the thousands of schoolchildren who make field trips to the market every year. They learn that food doesn't originate in takeout cartons."
 
Conviviality Amid Carrots
The humanity and courtesy attached to most greenmarket transactions does indeed soothe the spirit. One reason I am such a faithful customer is that I relish the weekly contact with people who value my business instead of taking it for granted.
When someone suggests (as someone frequently does) that I am a little crazy to schlep bags of humble vegetables up and down the subway stairs every week, I tell them the story of the Day I Forgot My Money.
In mid-October I was inspecting some of the last heirloom tomatoes of the season when I discovered that I had forgotten to transfer money from my handbag to the waistband pouch I use for greenmarket shopping.
I asked a farmer if she would hold the tomatoes for me -- I knew they would be sold out in a few minutes -- while I looked for a cash machine.
"Oh, don't bother" she said. "I know you, honey. Just pay me next week." Lucky for me, since I discovered that I had also forgotten to bring along my A.T.M. card. When I showed up with the cash the following Saturday, my benefactress observed, "I knew you weren't the type to skip town."
 
To Market
The Union Square Greenmarket is open year round on Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. (Some farmers arrive later in the morning and many close well before 6 p.m., especially in winter.) Those hours are not firm during snowstorms or when the temperature is below 32 degrees.
All of the farmers mentioned in this article are in the market on Saturdays, weather permitting. Check with them for their schedule on other greenmarket days.
The hours and dates for greenmarkets around New York City are available from the central Greenmarket office, (212) 477-3220.
The Union Square Holiday Market is open daily from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. through Christmas Eve.

HEADLINE: Brazil Still Optimistic on Phone Auctions

BYLINE: By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Despite waning interest in cellular phone licenses around the globe, the Brazilian government hopes to raise at least $3.4 billion over the next three months by selling nine licenses to offer mobile phone services.
The government will sell three licenses for personal communications services, on the C, D, and E bands, for each of the country's three service areas: the urban state of Sao Paulo, the largely rural south and center west, and the populous north and northeastern coast. The minimum prices on the licenses range from $273 million to $510 million, depending on the area and the band. The licenses for the C band are more expensive, since operators will be allowed a six-month head start over D and E band winners. C band winners can start commercial operations on July 1. 
 Although many analysts consider the minimum bids high, the government is counting on carriers that do not yet have a presence in Brazil, like Vodafone of Britain, to bid up the prices. Industry experts also expect Brazil's fixed-line operators, especially local companies owned by Telefonica of Spain and Telecom Italia, to bid aggressively so they can expand their presence in the country's growing cellular market.
According to the National Telecommunications Agency, or Anatel, the number of mobile phone users in Brazil is expected to nearly double by the end of 2001, to 29.2 million, from 15 million in 1999. Anatel wants that number to reach 58 million by 2005 in a country of about 170 million.
"Investors showed a huge amount of interest during our road shows in Brazil, London and New York," said Renato Navarro Guerreiro, the president of Anatel. "The pent-up demand for telecommunications services in the Brazilian market is the largest in the world."
But uncertainty remains about how many companies will participate in the sale, which will begin with the C band auction on Jan. 30, followed by the D band on Feb. 20 and the E band on March 13, especially when heavyweights like AT&T, British Telecommunications and France Telecom have remained out of the bidding.
"The telecommunications industry worldwide has changed a lot in the last six months," said Paul Groom, an industry consultant here. "It has gone from being a strong-cash-flow, highly capitalized business to being one where a lot of these companies are highly in debt because of their third-generation bids in Europe." Third-generation technology, commonly called 3G, allows for services like high-speed Internet access and data transfers over a cellular telephone.
After Britain took in a record $34 billion for 3G licenses in April, only to be trumped by Germany's $46 billion sale in August, a recent auction in Italy brought in only $12.2 billion, less than half what the government had expected. Poland was the most recent disappointment, selling only three of its five licenses on Saturday.
Part of the problem, analysts say, is that 3G services are not catching on as quickly as expected in relatively mature cellular markets in Europe. That raises doubts about demand for 3G technology in markets where consumers have less buying power. A big question is how many Brazilians are going to be willing to pay for Internet access over their cellular phones.
Mr. Guerreiro from Anatel counters that the Brazilian government is not auctioning 3G licenses, but a middle ground called 2.5G, that will permit companies to offer regular cellular services using existing technology, as well as some mobile Internet applications.
In Brazil, the situation for regular cellular service is complicated because the country is coming out of an economic crisis and subsequent devaluation that brought economic growth, and consumer spending, to a virtual standstill in 1999 and most of 2000. That has cut deeply into expected revenues for existing providers.
"What you have are licenses for the third, fourth and fifth operators in these regions at a time when the second operators are having a very difficult time, and have had in most regions since they won their licenses in 1998," Mr. Groom said.
Analysts say, however, that companies that want to have a global presence will find it very difficult to skip this opportunity to enter the Brazilian market on a large scale.
"At the end of the day, one needs to be big in mobile service to be successful," said Luiz Carvalho, a telecommunications analyst for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "You want to achieve nationwide coverage."
As a result, companies will have to rework their business plans to fill the holes in Brazil's cellular coverage.
"In order for these companies to succeed, they are going to have to move down to the lower-income customers, which means that each operator is going to have to be much more efficient," said Luis Cuza, chairman of the telecommunications committee at the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo. "They are also going to have to focus much more on sales and marketing and gaining and retaining customers."

HEADLINE: Argentina's Woes: With Peso Overvalued, It Can't Compete

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
IT'S bailout time.
The International Monetary Fund, having just broken speed records for arranging a huge cash infusion for Turkey, will turn next week to Argentina, where it is expected to anchor a $25 billion rescue package. 
 The moves seem to have calmed markets in both countries, and it is to be hoped that they will work in the long run, too. But these countries' need to be bailed out reflects their failure to learn a clear lesson of the 1998 Asian crisis: Fixed foreign exchange rates have a way of blowing up when the going gets tough.
That lesson was ignored because fixed rates have such clear attractions when things are going well. Businesses can enter into contracts with foreign companies with confidence about exchange rates. The fixed rate is supposed to discipline governments, which learn they cannot simply print money to get around problems and therefore must make the tough decisions needed for economic stability.
All that is true enough. But what happens if those tough decisions are not made, or if external events overwhelm otherwise sound policies? When a crisis arrives, people start selling the currency to the government, which obligingly buys it and drains foreign exchange reserves. Mehmet Simsek, a Merrill Lynch economist, notes that the $7.5 billion the I.M.F. is putting into Turkey is about equal to the amount Turkey's central bank spent defending the lira to keep it from depreciating more than the planned 1 percent a month.
In Argentina, the government uses a currency board to assure that one peso equals one dollar. That policy helped end hyperinflation a decade ago and remains popular.
But it is also largely to blame for the country's inability to cope with a run of bad news. Neighboring Brazil devalued its currency, commodity prices fell, the dollar became the strongest currency in the world, and international investors became risk averse. "It was the biggest set of negative shocks Argentina has had since the 1930's," commented Francis Freisinger, a Merrill Lynch economist.
With a currency board, Argentina could not devalue its currency to stay competitive with Brazil. It cut wages of its workers, but not by enough. Unemployment soared, those with jobs had less money to spend, and the money supply contracted as investors took money out of the country. Argentina found itself in a classic Catch-22: Investors would not put money into an economy that was not growing, but there was no hope of growth without that investment.
The I.M.F. bailout buys time, and Alan Greenspan's hints that the Federal Reserve will reduce American interest rates provide hope. Since Argentina does not have its own monetary policy, it is stuck with Washington's. That hurt when the Fed raised rates while Argentina was in a recession. The best situation for Argentina next year would be a big decline in the dollar, which would devalue the peso and make Argentine exports more competitive.
Perhaps that will happen. If not, in a year or so the I.M.F. may have to decide whether to step in again. To keep that new aid from simply flowing out to foreign bondholders, Argentina might have to restructure its debts in a way that penalizes bondholders. If speculation ever rises that the dollar peg might be in jeopardy, the rush of local companies to buy dollars could force devaluation.
Two years after its devaluation, Brazil is booming. Argentina's currency board solved one problem, but it left the country unable to cope with a new round of adversity.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Rise on Expectations of an Eventual Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices recouped earlier losses yesterday as stocks declined, and as investors looked for added signs of slowing growth and an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
"The Treasury market has come a long way already," said Michael Cloherty, a fixed-income strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. But with volatility in the stock market and investor expectations for a Fed rate cut by the end of March, "the recent pattern is to do anything but stay steady," he said. 
 The 10-year Treasury note rose 1/32, to a price of 103 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.30 percent from 5.31 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond increased 4/32, to 110 26/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.50 percent from 5.51 percent on Wednesday.
Government debt tempered earlier losses as the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.6 percent, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.40 percent.
Investors have pushed bond and note yields down while anticipating a Fed rate cut by the end of March. In a speech Tuesday, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested that policy-makers were not as concerned with inflation, which prompted Treasuries to rally.
"The bond market seems convinced that Greenspan has turned around , but the stock market's not sure if he's in time," said Frank Waung, an economist at Societe Generale.
Mortgage bond investors who were caught by surprise as yields fell have been furiously buying Treasuries and derivatives known as interest-rate swaps over the last three days, traders said.
As rates fall, more homeowners can refinance their mortgage loans, which cuts short interest payments on mortgage bonds and hurts investors' returns. Mortgage investors hedge this by buying Treasuries or swaps to receive fixed-rate payments for a set period of time. In a swap, traders and investors agree to exchange fixed-rate and floating-rate interest payments for a set period of time based on a nominal dollar amount.
Signs that growth cooled in November may emerge today, when the government is expected to report that the unemployment rate rose to 4 percent after holding at a 30-year low of 3.9 percent for two months, according to a survey of economists. Average hourly earnings probably increased 0.3 percent in November after a 0.4 percent gain a month earlier.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Last Green Mile

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
With the odds increasing every day that George W. Bush will be declared the 43rd president, a couple of things are becoming clear: Bush voters are the likely winners. Gore voters are the likely losers. And all those people who voted for Ralph Nader and the Green Party are the likely really big losers.
Why? Just do the math. Assuming a very narrow victory for Mr. Bush, and a 50-50 split in the U.S. Senate, it's highly doubtful that on the big policy issues -- tax cuts, Social Security, education, foreign policy -- a Bush administration will be able to do much more, or much less, than a Gore administration. 
 Where Mr. Bush will have the biggest impact is not through the macro-politics, but through the micro-politics -- on all those issues that reside just below the radar, on all those issues where the hundreds of assistant secretaries, agency heads and department chiefs, whom the Bush team will appoint throughout the government, will have the discretion, guidance and desire to impose a conservative ethos.
And what are those issues? Well, let's see -- things like how environmental regulations are interpreted, where oil wells can be dug in Alaska, what sorts of lands the Interior Department sets aside for conservation, how worker health and safety rules are enforced or expanded, how labor laws are interpreted, how gun control is dealt with, how aggressively fuel efficiency standards are pursued, how assiduously global population control programs are supported and to what extent the U.S. works to curb the "greenhouse" gases that are causing global warming.
There is actually another name for all these environmental, social and labor issues: "The Nader Agenda." These are all the issues that Ralph Nader and his supporters professed to care most about. Well, guess what? All their issues are going to get the short end of the stick from a Bush-staffed bureaucracy, which will be heavily influenced by the oil and gas industry, the National Rifle Association and the anti-abortion lobby.
Just think about one area -- global warming. Instead of having as president Al Gore, someone who would have made it a priority to rescue the failed Kyoto climate change treaty, we will probably have a president and vice president both of whom came from the energy business and don't even believe global warming is for real. Mr. Bush's chief of staff will be Andrew Card, who spent the last seven years as chief lobbyist for the auto industry, fighting tighter fuel economy, air pollution and global warming regulations. So Mr. Nader helped deliver a president from the oil industry, a vice president from the drilling industry and a chief of staff from the auto industry. Have a nice day.
Indeed, when we wake up 20 years from now and find that the Atlantic Ocean is just outside Washington, D.C., because the polar icecaps are melting, we may look back at this pivotal election. We may wonder whether it wasn't the last moment when a U.S. policy to deal with global warming might have made a difference, and we may ask why the party most concerned about that, the Greens, helped to elect Mr. Bush by casting 97,000 Nader votes in Florida.
Nader's voters forgot what Nader's Raiders always remembered: Government is not just about the big bills and legislation. It's also about lots of little things, decided by lots of little bureaucrats whom each party brings to Washington when it takes over.
Throughout the campaign, the egomaniacal Mr. Nader -- who makes Ross Perot look selfless by comparison -- justified taking away votes from Mr. Gore by arguing that there really wasn't much difference between him and Mr. Bush. And, like a good Leninist, Mr. Nader also didn't seem to mind destroying the Democratic Party to save it. Well, maybe there didn't appear to be much difference between the two men -- but there was a huge difference between the hundreds of key people Al Gore and George Bush would appoint to staff their administrations. And those hundreds of people will make thousands of decisions that one day will add up to a very big difference.
If you need any proof of that, look at Florida. Look at how many key decisions were taken by "little people" who resided below the radar screens -- local judges, senior state officials and local election supervisors. They are the gears of government, and in a Bush administration they are the ones who will be interpreting and regulating everything the Naderites care about. As I said, have a nice day.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
A TriBeCa Building Is a Curtain Raiser for a Trio of Developers

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A group of developers is advancing plans for a mixed-income rental building on a site in the far eastern corner of TriBeCa that long has been dotted with vacant lots and mostly empty low-lying structures.
The $118.5 million project will contain 330 apartments. Of these, 204 units will be one-bedrooms, and the rest will be studios and two-bedroom apartments. They will range from 500 to 1,200 square feet and some will have terraces. 
 There will also be 18,000 square feet of ground-level retail space and a 225-car parking garage in the 19-story building, which will rise on the parcel at 111 Worth Street, just north of City Hall. Construction is to start in February and be completed by the summer of 2002, the developers said. The building is a project of three developers: Forest City Ratner Companies in Brooklyn, Joel Wiener of Manhattan and Schenkman/Kush ner Affiliates in Bridgewater, N.J.
The developers are applying for tax-exempt permanent bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency to develop the building as a so-called 80-20 project. Murray Kushner of Schenkman/ Kushner said he and his partners have secured a construction loan from Hypo Bank and are optimistic about receiving the bond financing. Still, he added, the partners could move ahead without it if necessary.
In exchange for the bond financing, the developers would reserve 20 percent of the units for residents making 50 percent of the median annual income in New York City, or $28,000, which is then adjusted according to family size. The remaining 80 percent of the apartments will be rented at market rates.
This is the initial foray into residential development in TriBeCa for each of the developers, who joined together over the last 18 months. Mr. Kushner said that while his company had never built a high-rise apartment building in New York City, it owns and manages 5,000 rental units and five million square feet of commercial space, mainly in New Jersey.
Forest City is known primarily for its office and retail projects, including the Metrotech office complex in downtown Brooklyn. While it has developed 40,000 residences nationally, none are in Manhattan.
To change that, the company began "to scout around for residential developments 18 months ago," said Sandeep Mathrani, executive vice president of Forest City. His company is also involved with different partners in a 300-unit rental project on which construction is to begin soon at 555 West 23rd Street in Chelsea.
Few rental properties have been constructed in the last decade in TriBeCa. This year, as in each of the last five years, roughly 400 units -- most of them loft condominiums carved from old industrial buildings -- will be produced in the neighborhood, according to Community Board 1.
The Worth Street building will join the Saranac, a 147-unit rental development at 95 Worth Street that the Zucker Organization of Manhattan completed last March. The developer said that project was leased in 10 weeks.
Both rental projects are in TriBeCa's easternmost fringe, hard against an area of government buildings. Judy Duffy, assistant district manager of Community Board 1, said these projects "are telling me people are desperate to live in TriBeCa no matter how far off the beaten track a location may seem to be."
Mr. Kushner said that when he contracted to buy the site 18 months ago, Mr. Wiener held a 70-year ground lease on it. The two became partners and were joined months later by Forest City Ratner, which had experience in securing approvals and developing in Manhattan.
The project is advancing at a time when Manhattan's rental market, while still strong, has cooled from its frenzied pace of the recent past, in part because of the volatile stock market and the failure of many dot-com firms, said Andrew S. Heiberger, president of CitiHabitats, a Manhattan brokerage firm.
Rents are dropping between 10 and 20 percent for luxury apartments, he said, adding that units not moving generally are studios priced above $2,200, one-bedrooms over $3,000, two-bedrooms above $4,000 and three-bedrooms over $6,000.
As for the planned Worth Street building, Mr. Heiberger said, "It's in a transitional area, so the less the neighborhood has to offer, the more price matters."
Average yearly rents for comparable units in TriBeCa are $52 a square foot, or $3,033 a month for a 700-square-foot one-bedroom, he said. At the Saranac the average was $55 a square foot, according to the Zucker Organization.
Mr. Mathrani said rents at 111 Worth Street are expected to be $52 a square foot. That means they will range from $2,166 a month for the smallest studio to $5,200 for the largest two-bedroom.
Despite the "negative press about the market," he said the project makes economic sense and its location will appeal to people who work in the surrounding office buildings.
The building, designed by Costas Kondylis of Manhattan, will be clad in beige brick and will feature decorative masonry detailing at its base. It also will be set back at the 14th floor, providing those units with terraces. Along with the parking garage, planned amenities will include a fitness center and children's playroom, and possibly a rooftop sun deck, Mr. Kushner said.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
The Fine Art Of Discerning A Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The date was Aug. 21, 1990. The nation's last recession was already one month old, but the Federal Reserve's policy makers, gathered for one of their periodic meetings to set interest rates, did not realize that. "Those who argue that we are already in a recession I think are reasonably certain to be wrong," Alan Greenspan, the chairman, told his colleagues.
Spotting the arrival of the next recession -- after more than a decade of often booming growth -- is once again a matter of growing concern. 
 Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues did not recognize the existence of the 1990-1991 economic downturn until it was five months old, which is one reason they waited to cut interest rates. Now, with the evidence still pointing away from an actual recession, they face a similar test of how to respond as the economy slows.
Slow growth is not much fun. The prosperity of the last five years that has lifted nearly every family will gradually disappear for millions of people, and both consumers and companies will grow cautious in their spending and investing. That is already happening.
But a recession is downright painful. Unemployment rises rapidly, bankruptcies multiply, layoffs become commonplace and homes lose value. "When growth slows, people lose jobs, but those who don't find their real incomes growing," said Kenneth J. Matheny, senior economist at Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. "In an outright recession, many more people feel the pain of unemployment and falling incomes."
A recession almost certainly has not arrived. By every measure, the gross domestic product, the broadest measure of the value of America's goods and services, is still growing, if not at the annual rate of more than 5 percent that prevailed last spring, then at 2 to 3 percent.
Still, recession is increasingly on people's minds. Federal Reserve officials, while expressing confidence that the economy is slowing to a soft landing rather than to a hard or recessionary one, nevertheless now say that the economy is decelerating more rapidly than they had anticipated. In sum, the risks of recession have risen.
The speed of the slowdown is worrisome. A sharp, rapid slowing in economic growth "can feel like a recession if it lasts long enough," Mr. Matheny said. In six weeks, his firm has cut its estimate of growth in the fourth quarter to an annual rate of 2.4 percent from 3 percent.
A decade ago, a 2.4 percent growth rate was considered by most economist to be relatively strong growth. But now 2.4 percent is thought to be insufficient to maintain full employment and to keep the nation's factories and offices humming at full capacity. Thanks to productivity gains, a healthy economy today is one that expands at a 3.5 to 4 percent annual rate, and perhaps even more.
Almost no one goes so far as to state that the economy is moving toward a recession or is in one, although Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, toyed with the thought this week. A Bush administration would like to date the start of a recession, if one actually develops, from the final months of the Clinton administration, thus blaming the Democrats. And manufacturers, hit harder than anyone else by the slowing growth, have come close to using the "R" word.
"We have to have a reduction in interest rates of up to half a percentage point to assure that this slowdown does not turn into a major downturn," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
The Fed is not likely to accommodate the manufacturers soon. While growth has slowed, Mr. Greenspan pointed in a speech on Tuesday to strengths in the economy. The Fed's policy makers, at their next meeting, on Dec. 19, are likely to give up their stated preference for higher rates. But they are not likely to switch gears and lower rates as quickly as some of the nation's industrial barons would like. "We must be equally vigilant against the risk of either an extended period of growth unacceptably below potential, or a resurgence of inflation," Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said in a speech Wednesday.
Still, the era of raising interest rates is now clearly over; starting in June 1999, the Fed raised rates six times, helping to produce today's slower growth. But there were other contributions, too.
Lenders have pulled back, raising interest rates and depriving some companies of credit. Capital spending is growing more slowly. Rising energy prices -- not only for oil, but for electricity and natural gas, too -- have hurt the economy more than expected and have also kept inflationary pressures alive. The sell-off of Nasdaq stocks and the flattening of other stock prices as corporate profits weakened has taken a toll. Inventory cutting, mostly in the auto industry, has shuttered factories. And the strong dollar has made exports more expensive, a blow in particular to basic manufacturers.
"The message from all the data is that there is a slowdown but not a recession," said Ian C. Shepherdson, chief domestic economist for High Frequency Economics.
But Mr. Shepherdson is a Wall Street forecaster. Mr. Jasinowski takes a more dour view. He defined a "major downturn" as one three-month quarter in which the economy actually contracts. The popular definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters in which the gross domestic product shrinks rather than grows. For a wide swath of manufacturing, that contraction is already occurring; the recession is here.
Manufacturing output is still rising, of course. From May through October, the latest month available, output grew at an annual rate of 3 percent. That was down from 7.8 percent in the first five months of this year, Mr. Matheny said. But take out the vibrant group of high-technology manufacturers who produce computers, communications equipment and semiconductors and a much different pattern emerges. The rest of manufacturing -- from automakers to textiles -- contracted from May through October, perhaps the first tiny step toward crossing the fine, hard-to-perceive line from slow growth to recession.

HEADLINE: On U.N. Dues, No U.S. Cover From Europe

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The European Union made its position final today: Europe will not pay higher United Nations dues to offset any reduced payments by the United States.
"What is our bottom line is that we will not pay more," said Ambassador Jean-David Levitte of France, which holds the rotating presidency of the European Union until the end of the year. The General Assembly finance committee, which Mr. Levitte addressed today, has until Dec. 22 to reach agreement on how, or if, the United States demand can be accommodated. 
 Europe's negative response throws the burden on the rest of the world to find a way to pay more if Washington is to be accommodated. Ideas are being discussed, but no firm plan has yet taken shape.
At issue are American demands to lower the percentage of the United Nations operating budget that Washington pays to 22 percent from 25 percent, and the peacekeeping assessment to 25 percent from 30 percent. Congress cut peacekeeping contributions in defiance of international agreements in 1995.
The United Nations has never recognized the move. Budgetary assessments are based roughly on a nation's share of the total world economy, with the American portion about 26 percent.
The Clinton administration did not fight Congress on these decisions, and accepted an agreement between Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat and ranking minority member of the committee, that essentially put conditions on American participation in the United Nations and tried to give Washington oversight of its budget and other affairs. Officials said that this was the only way to get any arrears paid.
For most of his 15 months as United States ambassador here, Richard C. Holbrooke has had to devote the bulk of his time to this issue in order to avoid what many feared would be a virtual break between the United States and the United Nations. A Republican-led Congress has set many conditions for paying a debt of $1.7 billion and for future contributions. Reducing the level of dues is the key demand.

HEADLINE: Rabbi Irving Koslowe, 80; Gave Rosenbergs Last Rites

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN 

 BODY:
Rabbi Irving Koslowe, the Jewish chaplain at Sing Sing for 49 years, who in 1953 counseled the convicted spies Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and led them in their final prayers, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a monthlong illness. He was 80 and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
The chaplaincy at the state prison at Ossining was a part-time job for the rabbi, but it remained a central focus of his life from the time he was appointed by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in 1950 until he retired last year. During all those years, Rabbi Koslowe visited the prison at least once a week, bringing with him a variety of visitors as well as Jewish newspapers, books, foods and items for holiday rituals. 
 "People ask me what I'm doing, bringing matzo ball soup to a bunch of killers," Rabbi Koslowe once told an interviewer. "But maybe we can make some change. Maybe we can bring some good in their life. Some of the guards would say I'm crazy, but I do what I can do."
In a ceremony when Rabbi Koslowe retired from the state prison system last year, the Jewish chapel at Sing Sing was renamed in his honor.
In addition to his prison duties, Rabbi Koslowe served as the rabbi of the Westchester Jewish Center, in Mamaroneck, from 1943 until 1987. In that time, it grew from a synagogue with 30 families to a center with more than 500 families.
Over the years, Rabbi Koslowe also taught psychology, criminal justice and pastoral counseling at Westchester Community College, Mercy College and Pace University.
From 1950 until the death penalty was abolished in 1963, Rabbi Koslowe witnessed 17 executions at Sing Sing. He spoke somberly about how he would spend the final hours with the inmate, leading him in the final confession, known in Hebrew as the vidduy, and the profession of faith, the sh'ma. In each case, he would tell the prisoner, "I'll be right by you." He would go into the execution chamber, stand opposite as the inmate was strapped into the electric chair, and stay until the end.
The Rosenbergs, who were charged with passing atomic secrets to the Soviets, were convicted of espionage and were executed on June 19, 1953. In a news program about the cold war shown last year on CNN, Rabbi Koslowe recalled that Attorney General Herbert Brownell called him from Washington with a last-minute plea that the Rosenbergs name co-conspirators. Mr. Brownell said that if the Rosenbergs gave him a name, a stay of execution would be considered, Rabbi Koslowe said.
The Rosenbergs refused. Julius was put to death. Rabbi Koslowe said he then returned for Ethel. "I came back and told her her husband was dead. Did she have anything to say to me, a name, to stay the execution? She said, 'No, I have no names to give, I'm innocent,' and she was far more stolid than he. She came right behind me, sat down and was executed."
Rabbi Koslowe never took a position on their guilt or innocence or on the appropriateness of the sentence. After the execution, he was involved in finding a foster home for the Rosenbergs' sons, Robert and Michael, who were eventually adopted by a family named Meeropol.
Michael Meeropol, now chairman of the economics department at Western New England College in Springfield, Mass., said in an interview that the Rosenbergs, who spent more than two years at Sing Sing before their execution, respected Rabbi Koslowe and enjoyed their time with him. He recalled interviewing Rabbi Koslowe for a book he and Robert wrote in 1975 called "We Are Your Sons: The Legacy of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg" (Houghton Mifflin, 1975).
"I asked Rabbi Koslowe if he thought my parents were religious, if they believed in God," Michael Meeropol wrote. (In news reports of the cold war era, the Rosenbergs were often portrayed as godless communists.)
Rabbi Koslowe responded: "I found them responsive at all times and respectful. I read some material about the fact that they had a disdain for religion. I read this in the newspapers. From my contact with them that was not apparent at all."
The rabbi recalled that the Rosenbergs regularly attended services in the prison synagogue, but he said he was not sure if it was for religious reasons or because it was a rare opportunity for them to be in the same room. But the motivation, he said, was not important.
The Meeropol book also contains letters the Rosenbergs wrote to each other in prison. In one, Julius wrote of Rabbi Koslowe: "Without doubt the Rabbi is a sincere, intelligent and learned man and the method he uses to integrate prayer with present circumstances and obtain uniform participation is very effective."
Rabbi Koslowe's Sing Sing congregation was never very large. The chapel's worn wooden pews and the carved ark that held the Torah scroll were donated by a synagogue that was being remodeled. Of the 50 seats, rarely were more than 10 occupied. Of the 2,400 prisoners at the prison in the early 1990's, Rabbi Koslowe estimated that 35 were Jewish. He was never unhappy about the size of the congregation, which he used to say was the only one in the world that did not mind losing members.
Rabbi Koslowe had a level of access at Sing Sing enjoyed by few others. "He had the run of the place," said his son Neil. "He never bothered to abide by the rules. He was there longer than any warden, any guard or any prisoners."
He became a consultant for the State Department of Correctional Services and was often called in to help during various prison disturbances, including the riot at Attica in 1971. He was a past president of the American Correctional Chaplains Association and editor of its journal.
Rabbi Koslowe graduated from Yeshiva University and its affiliated rabbinical school, the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. He had a master's degree in education from New York University and a doctorate in sociology from Yeshiva University.
In addition to his son Neil, who lives in Silver Spring, Md., Rabbi Koslowe is survived by his wife, Marly; two other sons, Kenneth, of Petach Tikvah, Israel, and Mark, of East Brunswick, N.J.; a daughter, Shari Schechter of Miami Beach; 19 grandchildren; and 6 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Pace of Borrowing By Consumers Slows

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by consumers increased at a slower annual pace in October, a sign that Americans were more cautious about spending as the holiday season neared.
Borrowing through credit cards, auto loans and other means rose $16.6 billion in October, the Federal Reserve reported. Excluding a one-time adjustment for previously unreported debt, new borrowing rose $8.7 billion in October after a gain of $8.9 billion the month before. 
 That means Americans took on new debt at a 7 percent annual rate in October, down from the 7.2 percent pace a month earlier and 9.3 percent in the first nine months of the year. Higher borrowing costs and energy prices along with declines in stock prices caused buyer optimism to sink in October and November.
"Consumers are just tapped out," said Christopher Low, chief United States economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. The revisions, a result of adjustments in asset reporting by two large, unnamed lenders, suggest that banks and others "were going through their loan portfolios with fine-tooth combs," Mr. Low said.
The average number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits rose last week to its highest in two and a half years, a separate Labor Department report showed. The four-week moving average rose 1,250, to 345,250. That is the most since mid-July 1998.

HEADLINE: The Problem Isn't the Kids

BYLINE: By Louis V. Gerstner Jr. and Tommy G. Thompson; Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of I.B.M., and Tommy G. Thompson, governor of Wisconsin, are co-chairmen of Achieve Inc.

 BODY:
Yet another international comparison of math and science achievement has found American children falling behind -- news that Americans tell pollsters they are tired of hearing. It would be convenient to dismiss the disparities -- after all, the United States wouldn't trade economies with any of the 14 countries -- from small ones like the Slovak Republic and Slovenia to larger and more populous ones, like Japan and Canada -- whose eighth graders topped ours. But what's at stake is tomorrow's economy, not today's.
These results force us to ask whether today's middle schoolers will have what they need to earn decent wages and secure a more comfortable future, or whether they face life in an ever-shrinking pool of economic opportunity. 
 The new results, from the Third International Mathematics and Science Study, in which 38 countries participated, show American eighth graders about where they were four years ago -- average, putting them on par with students from Bulgaria, Latvia and New Zealand. They came out ahead of those in 17 countries, including South Africa and Thailand.
It's especially troubling that four years ago, when today's American eighth graders were in fourth grade, as a group they ranked better -- well above the international math average on an earlier version of the same test, scoring behind their peers in only seven countries. The message here is extraordinary and irrefutable: Every day our public schools are open, the gulf between our children and the world's top performers grows wider.
The problem isn't the kids; it's what and how they are taught. What American schools consider eighth-grade math is barely sixth-grade math in countries like The Netherlands and Singapore. Most eighth-grade math exams in the United States emphasize arithmetic, computation, whole numbers and fractions -- topics that students in top-ranked nations are expected to master well before middle school. These countries' eighth graders are getting the fundamentals of algebra and geometry.
It is true that states across the country have raised academic standards and student achievement over the last four years, and we can find shining examples of success in virtually every school district. But far too few classrooms have been transformed. We need a national response.
The answer, however, is not to wait for a top-down federal solution or simply to spend more money without changes in teaching, learning and accountability. The states themselves must step up to the challenge, and they can do it best by working together to find and share the best classroom practices. Fifty blue-ribbon commissions and sets of proposals would waste more time and a lot more money. Besides, algebraic equations yield the same answers in New York as in Wisconsin.
Through a collaboration called the Math Achievement Partnership, 11 states, ranging geographically from Washington to North Carolina, are already pooling their resources and political capital to attack this problem. They are working with mathematicians and educators organized by Achieve Inc., the nonprofit organization, created by governors and corporate leaders, of which we are the co-chairmen.
The first step is using what we can learn from top-performing nations to agree on what our kids should know before high school. These expectations will be made public early next year. Next, the math partnership will develop more rigorous lessons in math, better training and support for teachers, and a common measure for comparing results annually, not every four years. The partnership is open to any state that wants to join.
We share a belief that states must govern their own educational enterprises. But with that authority comes a clear responsibility to act, and act promptly, when their systems fall short. Our children's well-being and our national competitiveness depend on it.

HEADLINE: New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce Names New Head

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Kathryn S. Wylde, a leader for two decades in the fields of housing and economic development, was named president and chief executive yesterday of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, the city's most prestigious business group.
The organization, which was founded in 1979 by David Rockefeller to formalize the public-private partnerships that had been forged during the city's fiscal crisis, is made up of about 200 top executives of major corporations and institutions. 
 Mr. Rockefeller, who is still active in the partnership, said that Ms. Wylde was the ideal choice to lead the organization. "Kathy has been one of the most effective members of the staff for over 20 years," Mr. Rockefeller said yesterday.
But although the partnership continues to play a significant role in education policy and housing, its critics say that in recent years it has lost its way and has failed to take an aggressive role in guiding city policy-making.
The announcement yesterday signaled that the directors of the partnership were eager to raise the profile of the organization, whose president for the last five years has been Robert R. Kiley, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Kiley is leaving to become commissioner of Transport for London, the agency that will oversee that city's troubled transportation system.
In addition to assuming the reins of the partnership, Ms. Wylde, 54, will retain her role as president of the New York City Investment Fund, a private fund that the financier Henry R. Kravis established in 1996 to stimulate job creation.
Since its inception, the $110 million fund has invested in more than 40 for-profit and nonprofit companies that are expected to generate more than 6,000 jobs in the city. Those companies include the Gun for Hire Production Center in downtown Manhattan, which provides temporary spaces and services to television and film producers, and Slice of Harlem, a company with three restaurants in the neighborhood.
The fund has also drawn on the volunteer services of dozens of prominent members of the financial community to identify industries with growth potential and to work with entrepreneurs to start and strengthen businesses.
It has also had some casualties -- most recently, when Urban Box Office, an Internet portal for fans of hip-hop culture, went out of business. Earlier this year, the fund dropped its goal of providing capital for local manufacturing, saying it was having trouble finding appropriate companies in which to invest.
Mr. Kravis said the further integration of the two organizations, which already operate from the same offices at 1 Battery Plaza and have many overlapping board members, would help restore "the vision that the partnership had when David Rockefeller set it up."
"It's time to take a fresh look at the partnership," Mr. Kravis said, "and see how we can make it even more effective."
The chairman of the partnership, Robert Catell, pointed out that the investment fund has extensive experience with high-tech industries and that bringing the two organizations closer together was a way of "moving the partnership into a new era."
A native of Madison, Wis., Ms. Wylde served as president of the partnership's housing affiliate from 1982 until 1996. During that time, the New York Housing Partnership created 13,000 units of privately financed housing, reintroducing home ownership in neighborhoods that developers and banks had abandoned years before. Among its projects was Melrose Court, the first condominium development in the South Bronx.
As she assumes the leadership of the partnership, Ms. Wylde said, she expects the organization to concentrate on a few key issues. One is likely to involve the feasibility of developing a biotechnology industry in the city with the cooperation of the major medical institutions.
"We need to bring a private-sector perspective and resources to the most important issues facing the city, but not get involved in every controversy," Ms. Wylde said. "The partnership needs to be judicious about how its leadership weighs in and where."
But Ester R. Fuchs, the director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy, said she hoped that the partnership would play a more active role in researching and influencing public policy matters. "If you can mobilize the business community," she said, "you can change any policy outcome that you want."

HEADLINE: California Sets Up 3 Centers for Basic Scientific Research

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Entering an arena where the federal government has largely shaped the nation's agenda, Gov. Gray Davis of California today announced the establishment of three major research institutions dedicated to nanotechnology, biotechnology, and telecommunications and computing.
The effort, which will create the California Institutes for Science and Innovation, will be underwritten by $300 million in state funds over four years and more than twice that amount from corporate sponsors. 
 The institutions, comprising joint ventures among campuses in the University of California system, are intended to increase the competitiveness of the state's economy by focusing on technology challenges from transportation to agriculture.
They will include these components:
*The California Nanosystems Institute, at the University of California at Los Angeles in collaboration with the University of California at Santa Barbara, which will focus on the development of extremely miniaturized technologies.
*The California Institute for Bioengineering, Biotechnology and Quantitative Biomedicine, at the University of California at San Francisco in collaboration with the University of California at Berkeley and the University of California at Santa Cruz.
*The California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology, at the University of California at San Diego in collaboration with the University of California at Irvine, whose work will include development of a more powerful, wireless Internet.
The governor said he would seek funds in next year's state budget for a fourth institute at Berkeley to focus on information technology.
The creation of the centers comes in one of California's longest peacetime economic booms. And it is an uncommonly ambitious effort for a state, rather than the federal government, to undertake and finance.
"Historically, since World War II the research agenda of the country has been determined by the federal government," said Robert Conn, dean of the Jacobs School of Engineering at the San Diego campus.
The research initiatives will try to replicate the legendary Silicon Valley entrepreneurial model, Governor Davis said in a telephone interview.
In the 1930's, Frederick Terman, then an electrical engineering professor at Stanford University, encouraged his students to start business of their own rather than move East to work for traditional electronics companies.
Two of his students who chose to stay were William Hewlett and David Packard, who created the company that became the electronics and computing powerhouse.
"It's my hope to replicate Silicon Valley," Governor Davis said. "The most important thing a state government can do to improve local economies is to support research universities."
He noted that corporations had easily exceeded his goal of obtaining two-to-one matching funds from private sources.
Corporate contributors to the centers include some of the biggest names in high technology. The Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology alone has raised $140 million from companies like I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, Qualcomm and Sony. Other contributors include Genentech and Bank of America to the bioengineering center, and Hewlett-Packard and Cisco Systems to the nanosystems center.
Douglas Henton, an economist who specializes in studying the region, said the state's investment was needed to catalyze the kind of economic chain reaction touched off in Silicon Valley. But, Mr. Henton said, it was only a first step.
"The fact that the governor is paying attention to these technologies is great," said Mr. Henton, president of Collaborative Economics, an industry and government consulting firm in Palo Alto, Calif. "The test will be whether the institutes create a culture of collaboration with industry to successfully transfer technology."
California is not the first state to finance basic research. In 1990, for example, Georgia created the Georgia Research Alliance; through last year it had invested $242 million in research and development at six universities matched by $65 million in private funds.
Other state-financed basic research activities have taken place in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. But the California project dwarfs the others.
"In the past, states have put money into skills training and generally left it for the federal government to lead research activities," said Cheryl Fields, a spokeswoman for National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges in Washington.
Researchers at the California universities were enthusiastic about the open-ended nature of the research financing, saying the institutes could aim for basic-science achievements comparable to those of Bell Laboratories in its glory days.
"He's given us the resources," said Peter Rentzopis, a professor of chemistry at the Irvine campus and associate director of the Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology, said of the governor. "Now it's up to us to deliver."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Russia Ask Harsh Sanctions on Afghanistan

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The United States and Russia asked the Security Council today to toughen and broaden sanctions against the Taliban government of Afghanistan, measures that would cut the country off from most contact with the world.
The common ground taken by the Russians and Americans in demonizing the Taliban follows their taking exactly opposite sides in the catastrophic civil war that followed the Soviet invasion of 1979. 
 A coalition of holy warriors, supplied by the United States, eventually drove Russian troops out. But a decade later, in a surprising reversal, the Russians are arming these very warriors because they are fighting Moscow's new enemy, the Taliban.
The agreement by the Russians and Americans on sanctions is also rare. They both are concerned about the Taliban's influence across Central Asia and beyond, concluding that the Islamic movement supports Muslim militancy and international terrorism. Both Moscow and Washington discount fears that the new sanctions could harden the Taliban's position and ruin prospects of a negotiated settlement of the Afghan civil war.
Sergey Lavrov, the Russian ambassador, told reporters today that the new measures would leave "ample room" for peace talks to continue, a point also made by American officials.
"The problem is that the Taliban never delivered on a single promise, be this to start the dialogue, be this to stop fighting, be this to treat women and girls properly, or any other demand from the Security Council to stop the support for terrorism," Mr. Lavrov said.
Russians accuse the Taliban of involvement in the war in Chechnya. The United States is focused on the sanctuary in Afghanistan of the Saudi-born financier of militancy, Osama bin Laden, who is wanted in the United States on charges of being behind the bombings of two American embassies in Africa in 1998.
Reaction from the Taliban was swift. In Afghanistan, a minister of the Islamic movement called Mr. bin Laden "a guest and the upholder of the Afghan holy war" and said the Taliban could not be forced to hand him over.
In New York, the Taliban's representative, who may be forced to leave the United States under the new sanctions, said the proposed measures had more to do with Russian policy in Central Asia than the situation in Afghanistan. He predicted that the country would close ranks against outsiders and become more defiant.
Under the Russian-American resolution, which is almost certain to pass in the next week or two, the Council would demand the closing of all Taliban diplomatic offices around the world and those of Afghanistan's national airline, Ariana. All flights to or from landlocked Afghanistan, except for relief missions and religious pilgrimages, would be banned.
A comprehensive arms embargo would be imposed on the Taliban, but not on the opposition army of former American-backed mujahedeen struggling to keep a foothold in about 5 percent of the country. To curb the production of heroin in Afghanistan, the world's biggest opium grower, the sale of a chemical used in the making of heroin, acetic anhydride, would be banned.
Current sanctions restrict some flights of the Afghan airline and block off any Taliban financial assets abroad.
The Russian-American resolution demands not only the surrender of Mr. bin Laden, whose financial assets would be frozen worldwide, but also the closing of all training camps for Islamic militants. Sanctions would not end until all conditions were met.
Russian and American diplomats, seeking Beijing's support, have told the Chinese that these camps also send fighters to Muslim areas of China. India accuses the Taliban of involvement in the war in Kashmir.
At the insistence of France, which is wary of imposing any more open-ended sanctions, like those on Iraq, the new measures would have to be reviewed after a year.
Abdul Hakeem Mujahid, the representative in New York of the Taliban, who have been denied the United Nations seat still held by the mujahedeen opposition, said that the actions would increase sympathy for the Taliban across the Islamic world.
"The U.S. and U.N. are claiming championship of human rights all over the world, and at the same time they are killing our people with hunger," he said. "Now they want to prolong the war. They encourage the opposition to fight against the central government."
"Iran and Russia will benefit most from the sanctions," he said. "The Russian federation does want instability in Afghanistan. The Russians want to bring military forces into the region, and put the economic burden of supporting the army on the Central Asians while controlling those countries. Iran wants pipelines from Central Asia to go through Iran, not Afghanistan, the shortest way."
"This will only increase the resentment of the people of Afghanistan," he said. "We had nothing against the United States. We fought together against Russians. Ironically, today the U.S. is working alongside Russia against the people of Afghanistan."
The Taliban generally get little support from Islamic world, compared with the chorus of defense that has arisen in recent months for the Palestinians. But today neighboring Pakistan, the Taliban's main arms supplier, also condemned the proposed sanctions.
Shamshad Ahmad, Pakistan's United Nations representative and a former foreign secretary, said the sanctions would "scuttle" efforts by a representative of Secretary General Kofi Annan to start negotiations between the Taliban and their armed enemies after two decades of civil war.
"We believe that any new sanctions will further isolate and insulate the Taliban, with whom the world has been seeking to engage constructively, so that their policies can be influenced and moderated," Mr. Ahmad told reporters today. He said the measures would "only aggravate the situation, in terms of disrupting all channels of communication between the international community and the Taliban."
He added that coming on top of a severe drought in Afghanistan -- one that the United Nations estimates could put upward of a million people at risk of starvation -- the harsher sanctions could drive more people out of the country as refugees. Tens of thousands of Afghans have fled hunger and fighting in recent months.
An American official said today that the United States would be talking to Pakistan about getting it to cooperate with the new sanctions, a crucial factor in determining whether the measures will have any effect. In Islamabad, government officials say that they will support sanctions only if they are applied to both sides in the Afghan civil war.
"As a matter of principle," Mr. Ahmad said, sanctions are always unjust, unfair and counterproductive because they never, never achieve the desired objectives. They only hurt innocent people."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Republicans Gain on Spending Accord

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Congressional leaders met again today with President Clinton and said they had made modest progress toward a budget agreement that would permit the 106th Congress to finish its work and adjourn for the year.
After the hourlong session, Jake Siewert, the White House press secretary, said: "The meeting helped narrow some differences. But there are still significant differences, especially on education." 
 The basic dynamic appears unchanged. Mr. Clinton is seeking a major increase in spending on domestic programs, especially education, which includes money for school construction and financial aid to college students. Republicans will accept smaller increases, but have no desire to help Mr. Clinton enhance his reputation as the "education president." They say they can get a better deal if they wait for the next administration, which they hope will be headed by George W. Bush.
The most contentious of the spending bills provides money for education, labor and health programs in the current fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1. Mr. Clinton had been seeking $114 billion, an increase of $18 billion over last year.
After the meeting today, John P. Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said the bill would probably emerge with a total of $107 billion.
Mr. Feehery said Congress and the White House also appeared to be inching toward a compromise that would grant legal status to a limited number of illegal immigrants and allow some of their close relatives to come to the United States. Mr. Clinton had been seeking amnesty for many more illegal immigrants.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said Congress would almost certainly reach an agreement with the White House to increase Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes, home health agencies and health maintenance organizations. Those payments were cut in 1997, and health care providers say the savings far exceed what Congress intended.
"The Medicare adjustments will be easily agreed to," Mr. Armey said.
Medicare provides health care for 39 million people who are elderly or disabled.
Congress had agreed to provide $30 billion of additional Medicare money over the next five years, but the administration wanted several billion dollars more. Mr. Armey said Republicans were willing to provide $1.7 billion more, to help rural hospitals, teaching hospitals, hospices and home health agencies.
The Medicare money had been part of a bill that would cut taxes and raise the minimum wage. Senators Susan Collins of Maine and Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, both Republicans, argued that the Medicare legislation should be removed from the tax bill and passed separately. Congressional leaders said they now expected to do just that.
But the White House is insisting that Congress also do something to help provide health insurance for people who have no coverage.
"There should be some way to increase coverage for the most vulnerable citizens in the context of doing something for the health care providers," said Mr. Siewert, the White House spokesman. "We're willing to be flexible about how we do that."
In a concession to Republicans, the Clinton administration said it would scale back its demand for an increase in Pell grants, which provide money to help low-income students attend college. Mr. Clinton had been insisting that the maximum grant, now $3,300, be increased to $3,800, but administration officials said that they could accept a $3,600 maximum.
Republicans on both sides of the Capitol said the tax bill was dead. The bill would have provided $240 billion in tax relief over 10 years. It would also have increased the minimum wage by $1 an hour, to $6.15 an hour, and provided tax credits and other economic incentives for business investment in economically depressed areas -- two measures that Mr. Clinton still hopes to rescue.
Mr. Siewert said, "It's unfortunate that Congress found time to raise its own pay, but could not find time to raise the minimum wage."
The community renewal measure was worked out in months of negotiations between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert.
Mr. Armey said the weakness of the economy strengthened the Republicans' case for tax cuts.
"There's genuine concern about a recession," said Mr. Armey, a former professor of economics at the University of North Texas. "Throughout all the history of economic analysis, the best thing you can do at the onset of a recession is to cut taxes."
But, Mr. Armey said, Republicans figure they can get a better tax bill working with a Bush administration. "Governor Bush has a good tax package," he said.
The meeting today suggests that Republican leaders will keep negotiating with Mr. Clinton, at least for now, rather than pursue the confrontational strategy advocated by Tom DeLay of Texas, the House Republican whip, who said on Wednesday that he was ready for a showdown with the president.
Mr. DeLay wants to freeze spending in the current fiscal year at last year's levels for roughly one-fourth of the federal budget.
But Mr. Siewert said: "That's just not an acceptable solution. There are too many universities, too many students, too many schools all across the country that are relying on some sort of increase for education."
