HEADLINE: Make a Wish, It's Bonus Time On Wall Street

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Forget Christmas and Hanukkah, the most anticipated days of the year on Wall Street are spread over the next two weeks. That is when some of the biggest investment banks will tell their employees how big their year-end bonuses will be.
Once again, the numbers for most of them will be very big, more than most American workers can imagine receiving in a lump sum. On average, bonuses are expected to rise 5 percent to 15 percent from last year and some of the hottest deal makers will receive packages of cash and stock worth several million dollars. But for the first time in six years, investment bankers and traders are heading into bonus season with a sense of dread. 
 The stock and bond markets are in a slump and two big mergers have led to thousands of layoffs. With no rebound in sight, Wall Street executives are bracing for tough times even as they prepare to divide the spoils of what, in the end, is turning out to be their most profitable year.
"I've heard people say, 'We're going to pay a huge bonus in January but have a layoff in March,' " said Alan Johnson, president of Johnson Associates, which advises Wall Street firms on compensation. "There are a lot more serious concerns than there were a year or two ago: firms have overhired, the I.P.O. market is dead."
Mr. Johnson still says that bonuses, which account for the bulk of annual pay for most bankers and traders, will be at least 20 percent higher, on average, than they were last year. Firms set aside more money for bonuses in the first three quarters of the year than in all of 1999, so the payouts have to be considerably bigger, he said.
But Wall Street officials have been trying to douse such expectations in recent weeks, leading many of their employees to believe that they will be lucky to get a bonus even slightly larger than last year's. The consensus among recruiters and compensation consultants is that bonuses, on average, will be 5 percent to 15 percent bigger than they were for 1999.
At the Goldman Sachs Group, traditionally one of the most profitable firms in the industry, investment banking executives recently warned about the hazards of spending as though the good times would never end. People inside the firm said that total bonuses would be 15 percent to 20 percent higher than last year. A Goldman spokesman said that the firm would not discuss details of its pay practices.
Despite the sharp sell-off in technology stocks in April and a prolonged slump in the high-yield bond market, a prime source of Goldman's profits, the firm's earnings were almost 30 percent higher in the first three quarters of its current fiscal year than in the corresponding period a year earlier. The firm's expenses for employee compensation and benefits rose even more, about 33 percent.
Over all, the securities industry paid about $12 billion in bonuses at the end of 1999, according to the Securities Industry Association. It expects that number to be flat this year as overall industry pretax profits hit a record $22 billion.
"It's going to be a great year, but you have to understand that the trajectory is downward," said Frank Fernandez, the association's chief economist. "Firms are going to decide to be a little more frugal because the business outlook isn't as good as it was."
John Rogan, a managing director at Russell Reynolds Associates, a recruitment firm, said, "We have seen a readjustment of sights but bonuses being up 5 percent to 15 percent over last year is still impressive."
The variation in pay, though, is expected to be much wider than in recent years, with some bankers who specialize in the most active industry sectors, like telecommunications and technology, having their pay doubled or even tripled, while junk-bond traders and municipal finance specialists will have to settle for considerably smaller bonuses -- if they get any at all.
Employees at Goldman, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Lehman Brothers and a few other investment banks are scheduled to hear about their bonuses next week. At Lehman Brothers, managers were meeting yesterday afternoon to decide how the firm's profits would be distributed among employees.
Bonuses will come from the firm's profits but there is not necessarily a direct correlation.
"It's never been about taking this year's profits and divvying them up," one Wall Street recruiter said. In large part, this recruiter said, firms pay people as much as they think they must to keep them. In February and March, the competitive pressure was intense and the young bankers gained the upper hand, extracting new perquisites like concierge services, health club memberships and company-supplied laptop computers.
But the softening market and the acquisition of two midsize investment banks -- Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and J. P. Morgan -- removed much of that pressure. Chase Manhattan, which is buying Morgan, said it would lay off 5,000 workers; Credit Suisse First Boston said its acquisition of Donaldson would lead to 2,600 layoffs.
One reason for that sorting out is that firms have guaranteed so much pay to employees in the last few years. With the stock market bulling ahead and multibillion-dollar mergers occurring at a breakneck pace, firms waged a war for talent that sent wages spiraling. To compete, they locked in deal makers with multiyear, multimillion-dollar packages that defied the Wall Street tradition of minimizing fixed costs.
As the 1990's boomed on, two-by-fours (two years at $4 million a year) became three-by-fives.
Some firms are so flush that despite the downturn in the market, they are still spending heavily to lure people away from more established competitors. After Donaldson merged with Credit Suisse First Boston, the Swiss bank UBS hired away about 25 former Donaldson bankers who had just signed contracts to work for First Boston.
In the last two weeks, bankers have been buzzing with rumors about Deutsche Bank's costly poaching of Tony Whittemore, a telecommunications mergers banker, from the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. Recruiters and some people inside Salomon said Deutsche offered Mr. Whittemore, 32, a three-year contract that would pay him at least $18 million.
Mr. Whittemore referred a call seeking comment to a Deutsche Bank spokeswoman, who would not discuss the contract.
But pay packages like that are more the exception than the rule these days, as many bankers suddenly are clinging tightly to their jobs.
"We are hearing from people for the first time in years that they are happy just to have a job," said Cynthia Remec, president of her own recruiting firm.
She added, "They know that things are going to get rocky, and they want to position themselves in the safest place possible to ride out the storm."

HEADLINE: Shop and Home Ec Revived As New Jersey Requirements

BYLINE: By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
Confronted by educators who argued that car repair and cake decorating were as important as an appreciation of Picasso, the New Jersey Department of Education agreed to suspend new requirements that eliminated shop classes and home economics in favor of ones in visual and performing arts.
The education commissioner, David C. Hespe, sent a letter to superintendents yesterday saying that students could take courses like woodshop or metalworking to satisfy requirements in visual or performing arts, at least for the next two years. 
 Defenders of the so-called practical arts courses cried victory.
"I think we have sent a very, very clear message that you messed up," said Assemblyman Joseph R. Malone 3rd, a Republican from Burlington. "It just boggles my mind. The state board was sending a message that people who work with their hands are less valuable, less valued, than people in other areas.
"It smacks of elitism, it smacks of discrimination, it just really put into focus what people have thought for years, the impression that the state board of ed is a bunch of people sitting around with teacups and crumpets making decisions about schoolchildren in New Jersey without any regard for what the realities are."
The requirement to take five credits in the visual and performing arts in high school was part of new state graduation standards passed in 1996 after about two years of hearings and meetings around the state. Before that, the practical arts -- broadly speaking, home economics and shop classes -- had also been a requirement. The new requirements were to take effect in the academic year that began in September. The state had suggested that students could satisfy the new requirements by learning the exercise technique of Pilates or organizing and staging a chamber music recital.
Assemblyman Malone proposed a new bill reinstating the practical arts requirement after hearing complaints from teachers and principals.
"Not every student is or should be a college-bound student," said Karen Joseph, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union. "We so often hear people say, 'I tried to get an electrician and I couldn't get one,' and when they finally do, they say, 'I was astounded at the cost.' Supply and demand is a very basic element at all this. Practical arts have their place in our society, and we should not diminish their importance."
Getting rid of practical arts courses might increase the dropout rate, some educators worried.
"We have kids who come to school only because there's home economics classes," said Chuck Stein, assistant executive director of the New Jersey Principals and Supervisors Association. "The same thing can be said of woodshop or metal shop."
The Department of Education, he said, seems to think there is no artistic value in practical arts, apparently believing bad stereotypes about shop. But the range of courses, he said, includes ice sculpting, cake design and woodcarving. "These are artistic things and things kids really get into," Mr. Stein said. "We don't want them deprived of it."
Toni Kovak, who teaches culinary arts at Freehold Regional High School, wore a chef's uniform to the State House yesterday to defend her profession. "Eliminating practical arts for graduation requirements will eventually hurl our educational system back into the 1950's," she said. "We'll be segregating our elite students to pure academia with no life skills and our 'imperfect' children to a quasi-vocational setting with limited academic options."
The state, however, says that its graduation requirements in all courses add up to 100 credits. Most high schools require 120 credits for graduation, so students have room for courses that the state does not require, and schools can individually decide to require practical arts.
Some educators, though, said that if the courses were not required, students would not take them, and local boards of education might eliminate the offerings. That insecurity would make it hard to attract teachers.
Commissioner Hespe suspended the requirements until at least the 2002-3 school year. In the meantime, he said he would review the requirements next year, as part of a five-year process required when the state originally passed the new graduation requirements. He appointed Assemblyman Malone to head a committee to explore whether practical arts should be required.
"We have acted very quickly to the issues that have arisen," Mr. Hespe, somewhat beleaguered, said yesterday. "Do we know there are passions out there? Certainly we do."
But there were passions on the other side, too. "We've been ridiculed in the press, been accused of being frilly, artsy people, of being elitist," said Marete Wester, executive director of the Alliance for Arts Education. "We, too, reach marginalized, at-risk students. We need creative skills. We need people who can think differently."

HEADLINE: Take My Money. Please.;
Good Service Is Relative at Holidays

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In terms of good service, Wednesday morning began with promise. The guy from the laundry actually brought my bag up to my apartment instead of making me go down to the lobby in my bathrobe to pick it up -- something I normally tolerate, because at least this laundry does not lose socks.
Service, be it from laundries, supermarkets, bank tellers or store clerks, is a highly subjective concept. What one person regards at doting, another views as gnatlike hovering. One friend is terribly galled when cashiers toss her shopping bag on the counter like so much cabbage, something many people would not even notice. Some want delivery, others covet selection. Most desire civility. 
 It is no secret that good service in Manhattan retail stores is often as rare as discounted Prada, especially during the holidays. Lines are long, gift wrapping is often done begrudgingly and sales clerks are often young and inexperienced, and prefer sharing tidbits about their love lives with one another to ringing up sales.
But the holidays are not about Macy's and Toys "R" Us alone. There is gift wrap to be purchased, dinner to pick up on the way home. Sometimes, the attempt to make the most mundane of purchases -- a box of tissues -- is the one that sends a crazed shopper over the edge. So my mission was thus defined: spend the entire day shopping, both for holiday and basic needs, and see how service is shaping up this season.
For fortification, I started with breakfast at the French Roast Cafe on the Upper West Side with my friend Deb. Eggs, coffee and check came in a timely fashion. So there was a piece of parsley on Deb's water glass, what can you expect from a 24-hour restaurant?
Rushing through the cold air, I tried to stop at Starbucks on Broadway and 87th Street for a coffee to go. The line, as usual, was out the door, the baristas -- those charged with making the hot drinks -- moved in a sluggish manner paradoxical to their product. Regular coffee is self-serve, but still one must wait in line with those getting exotic concoctions to pay. Note to Seattle: Expect strong competition from the deli in a recession.
I fled, without a coffee, to Zany Brainy, a toy store near 89th Street.
There I happened upon a large sale rack of toys made by Noodle Kidoodle, the name of this store before it was acquired by Zany Brainy last spring. I loaded up.
I waited in a short line. A clerk chatted on the phone. I waited some more. The conversation finally wound down, and she agreed to let me pay. I then headed to the back to gift wrap, where I was informed that the Noodle Kidoodle toys were ineligible for wrapping. I could have the paper, but would not be permitted to enjoy the actual service of having these items encased in it. "I don't see the logic in it," admitted the clerk, "it is just what the manager said." She decided to thwart the store's attempt to give bad service by wrapping everything anyway.
Next stop, Radio Shack, where I was to procure a microphone for my teenage cousin, Myles. (Something about rapping along with his music, but that's his mother's problem.) It was there that I experienced a common Radio Shack problem: the sale item was "sold out."
The gentleman behind the counter retreated to the back and came back with a large pile of microphones, all roughly the same price, for my inspection. So what was the difference between them? "Um, well," he began, adding some furious blinking. He turned one box over and began to read aloud from its side.
It dawned on him that I found this insufficient, and he called for a fellow clerk, who explained that one was more powerful. Anticipating an exchange, I bought it and moved on.
The General Store is a small toy store on Broadway, and I decided to pick up a few special things. One of the young women offered to wrap my gifts in pretty purple tissue, while the other obsessively played "Oh! Susanna" on a set of chimes. This might annoy some, but I find it refreshing when people are enthusiastic about what they are selling.
I entered Duane Reade with a simple mission, to buy Kleenex and face soap without getting hurt. This is often a difficult task, and this day was no exception, as I tried to dodge stock clerks pushing huge dollies of merchandise, expecting me to get out of their way. Loaded down with shopping bags, my tissue boxes and soap teetering between my chin and forearms, I got in line.
A clerk appeared behind the counter and, never looking up, waved her fingers furiously at me, which I translated as some prelingual gesture of summoning one to pay. Without making eye contact, she rang me up, slapped my change and shopping bag on the counter and walked away while yelling over her shoulder at the man behind me, "She's open."
A harried woman rushed in, and asked for a common brand of diaper pail liners. She was greeted with a blank stare, and was finally told that the store did not carry them. I suggested she try a store near 80th Street. The clerks, apparently perceiving her request as akin to one for bread in Communist Moscow, did not appear to care. "It just seems like a lot to walk six blocks when you are already up here," the customer said, defeated.
I headed down to SoHo, where I intended to buy pants and have lunch. I became dangerously enticed by the Stork Club, a tiny store on Sullivan Street that sells very expensive children's clothing. Just looking. Really. But the sales clerk, Ti, began to point out the merits of $50 knit hats. ("The kids love them!")
My hand was literally on the door to leave, but Ti would not be defeated. "These jeans are really cute," she said in a gentle, coaxing voice usually reserved for massage therapists. "You can always bring them back and we will make them with whatever color trim you like in the right size." How I walked out of there with a pair of $70 pants for a 4-year-old is pure testament to Ti.
Off to the Cub Room Cafe for lunch, and then to Dean & Deluca. In each place, I was treated with blase but speedy service. That is fine with me. This is not Ames, Iowa. I do not need to know my waiter's name, or witty banter. I want my food in a timely manner and to be allowed to move on.
Moving on, in this case, meant walking down Prince Street to Agnes B., a specialty store, where I grabbed several pairs of pants. Tags were hard to find, and I needed help understanding the sizes. This proved difficult, because either the pasta I ate for lunch had rendered me invisible, or the saleswomen believed it was a mere coincidence that they were simultaneously in the store with me, a customer eager to unload money.
I suddenly felt vaguely fat and in need of a haircut, and I went to brave the pants. When I poked my head out of the dressing room to request another size, the saleswoman, a tad annoyed, hauled herself up from the floor, where she was squatting and eating udon noodles, to procure more clothes.
I implore: Is there a woman out there who, when actually confronted with pants that fit, would not immediately purchase five pairs? I made the point that I was more than happy to do just that, and the saleswoman made a perfunctory look around the store for more pants. She did not have much. I wandered over to the cosmetics counter, and she walked away. Um, could I have this lipstick? Somewhat annoyed, she informed me that I was getting the last one, perhaps reserved for a younger/thinner/hipper self-service customer.
Ti, Agnes B. needs you!
Moving uptown to Bloomingdale's. First stop, the coat department. It has been years since I bought a winter coat, and today was to be the day. The fact that I was lying on my back to get a better peek at the tags might have been a signal of my seriousness. Two clerks were chatting about their evening out. "I should come to your house and help you dress!" "Yeah you should!" "Yeah!"
I called out from a rack: "Where is this coat?" and gestured to a short navy wool jacket. One of the women waved her hand toward the center of the room. "Over there, sweetheart." Like her, I could not be bothered.
Over to the cashmere sweaters, where I plowed through the piles in search of my mother-in-law's size. I grabbed a pedicure kit for no one in particular, and two pairs of jeans, seized by this feeling that the store was closing in around me and I had to get all I could. I proceeded to the counter, where a woman named Denise informed me that she would give me 20 percent off if I agreed to pick my things up on Thursday, when the markdowns officially would begin. Three cheers for Denise!
Off to Saks Fifth Avenue, where I once again tried to buy a coat. I found one, and a room full of saleswomen clucked with approval. One of them, Daisy, tried to ring me up, but she could not see. Turned out she had picked up a co-worker's glasses. She put on the proper pair and beamed.
I ran downstairs to buy my mother-in-law a tree ornament. I quickly found it, but then was stuck waiting in line for 20 excruciating minutes, flanked by the mobs, as I waited to pay. One clerk rang up, the other wrapped. God help them both, working this crowd, but they could not have been slower if they were paid by the minute.
The last stop was back on the Upper West Side, at Fairway Market, where I picked up dinner. Great prices and fine produce aside, I find that Fairway often expresses contempt for its customers by refusing to put signs in the aisles so that they can find things.
"Where is the nutmeg?" I inquired of one man, who punted the question to a co-worker, who had no idea and asked yet another man, who was stocking seltzer. He looked at me gravely. "Oh, we don't have any of that." I ambled over and found a giant rack of it. Pity the fool who wanted to make a sweet potato pie that night.
Spotty service, decent chicken, short walk. It isn't perfect, but hey, this is New York. I'll take it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.M. to Cut Production By 14.5% in First Quarter
General Motors announced a big slowdown in factory production while Chrysler asked its suppliers to cut their prices by 5 percent on Jan. 1, further signs that Detroit is struggling with an abrupt weakening of auto sales and ballooning inventories of unsold cars.
G.M. said that it would produce 14.5 percent fewer vehicles in the next three months than it did in the first quarter of this year. Its shares fell 69 cents, to $51.38. Ford had already announced that its output would be down 10 percent. And while Chrysler has not disclosed its first-quarter production plans, it is also expected to make fewer cars by eliminating overtime and by not operating some factories at all for a week or two at a time. Page C2.
 
Senate Approves Bankruptcy Bill
The Senate approved a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws, passing legislation by an overwhelming margin that makes it harder for people to seek legal protection from payment of their debts. But the bill's prospects for becoming law are uncertain at best because Congress may not get the opportunity to override President Clinton's threatened veto before lawmakers adjourn for the year. A1.
 
The Nexus of Privacy and Security
At SafeNet 2000, a Microsoft-sponsored conference on computer security and privacy, high-technology businesses and advocacy groups touched on all the major policy issues facing technology companies. It showed, as Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, said in a keynote address, that privacy and security "are tied together in a very deep way." C4.
 
Stocks Slide on Technology Worries
Stocks fell only modestly even as investors found more reasons to worry about technology earnings. The Nasdaq composite index lost 43.84 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,752.66. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.91 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,343.55. And the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 47.02 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,617.36. C7.
 
Motorola to Fall Shy of Estimates
Motorola said that it would fall short of Wall Street's sales and profit projections for the current quarter because of sharply reduced demand for its chips and continuing profit margin erosion in its cell phone business. C3.
 
High-Profile TV Shows Canceled
Three broadcast networks moved to shake up their prime-time schedules, canceling several of the most publicized new programs of the season, including NBC's "The Michael Richards Show" and Fox's "The Street." Taken with other cancellations announced recently, and sliding ratings for some other heavily anticipated series, the new television season, which began with promise, is now listing badly as it heads for its midseason changes. C6.
 
3 Research Centers for California
Gov. Gray Davis of California announced the creation of three research institutions dedicated to nanotechnology, biotechnology, and telecommunications and computing. A30.
 
Brazil Optimistic on Phone Auction
Despite waning interest in cellular phone licenses, the government of Brazil hopes to raise at least $3.4 billion over the next three months by selling nine licenses to offer mobile phone services. World Business, Section W.
 
Abbey National Rejects Lloyds Offer
Abbey National in Britain rebuffed a takeover offer from Lloyds, setting the stage for Lloyds to appeal directly to Abbey's shareholders. The approach came as Abbey National was working out details of a merger with the Bank of Scotland. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Jets Circulate Plan for Football Stadium Linked to the Javits Center

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
The New York Jets have quietly begun circulating detailed architectural plans as they seek support for a 75,000-seat football stadium on the West Side of Manhattan that would convert into an annex of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and transform into an even larger sports bowl should the city lure the Olympics in 2012.
The plans, which include a retractable roof and a "turf farm" for sunning removable sections of natural stadium grass, seek to forge a political compromise between two forces whose rivalry has helped thwart development in the area: Gov. George E. Pataki, who wants an expansion of the Javits Center, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who wants a stadium. Since the state owns the land and the city controls the zoning, neither man can do what he wants without the other. 
 Jets officials, who have not said who will pay for what is widely considered to be a $1 billion project, are hoping their plans can finally bring the two sides together. They are also promoting the project to the city's business and opinion leaders as "not a stadium," even while saying it would be a good place for the Super Bowl. Instead, they are casting it as a more politically palatable convention center expansion that may not enrage community groups on the Upper West Side.
They also say that their stadium is "complementary" with the larger plans of their friends at NYC 2012, the local Olympic committee that desperately needs a stadium to bring the summer games to New York. "What we've accomplished so far is Step 1 of a 2,500-step process," said Jay Cross, the president of Jets Development, the new subsidiary that is spending hundreds of thousands of dollars searching for a home for the football team that now plays unhappily in the New Jersey Meadowlands. The Jets played at Shea Stadium in Queens for 21 years before moving to the Meadowlands in 1985.
What the Jets have not accomplished so far is the conclusive approval of Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Pataki and Robert E. Boyle, the chairman of the Javits Center. Yesterday, Mr. Boyle reacted with exasperation to the Jets' plans. If Mr. Cross, a Canadian, "thinks that's an expansion of the Javits Center," Mr. Boyle said, "he needs to spend more time in New York." He added that "if they're trying to make a stadium into a convention center, or a convention center into a stadium, that's dead on arrival."
Nonetheless, the governor continues to say that he is open to any plan that expands the Javits Center, which is widely derided as an out-of-date, second-class building unworthy of its city. The mayor, who saw an early version of the Jets' plan in September and would like to leave behind a major sports stadium as a legacy of his era, has, to no one's surprise, embraced the plan.
"We thought it was an impressive design," Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles said this week.
Under the Jets' plan, conceived by the New York City architectural firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, the stadium would sit across the street from the Javits Center and stretch over the West Side rail yards, from 30th Street to 34th Street along the Hudson River. For big trade shows, Mr. Cross said, the stadium could be converted within 24 hours to exhibition space and connected to the Javits Center by a footbridge over 34th Street.
Such a plan, Mr. Cross said, would enlarge the Javits Center from its present 800,000 square feet of meeting and exhibit space to 1.1 million square feet, including a new 45,000-square foot ballroom.
Although Mr. Boyle welcomed those plans, it was more important to him, he said, that the convention center expand at least two blocks north, from 39th Street to 41st Street.
Like Mr. Boyle, some economists have questioned the viability of stadium-cum-convention centers. Among them is Robert A. Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College in Illinois who has written extensively about such projects. "A stadium is not an optimal space for either trade shows or conventions," Professor Baade said in October.
Mr. Cross acknowledged the skepticism. "All of those people are quite correct in what they're saying," he said. "But what we're proposing has never been done before. It would be a no-compromise building," which he said means installing a "lighting grid" in the stadium that would optically lower the ceiling and transform it from a "cavernous space" to a more human-scaled area better suited for conventions.
The exterior of the stadium, Mr. Cross added, would be "airy" and "glassy" and surrounded by a large public plaza on the banks of the river.
"We see this as a building," Mr. Cross said. "We don't see this as a concrete bucket where people are going to sit and watch sports."
Although Mr. Cross said it would be ideal to extend public transportation to the area -- the Olympics plan calls for the extension of subway and railroad service -- it was not critical, he said, to the development of the stadium.
Studies commissioned by the Jets have found, he said, that traffic for Sunday afternoon or Monday evening football games would not be worse than it is during normal business hours.
Community groups have countered that such traffic would make the neighborhood unlivable.
Mr. Cross, who developed the $240 million, 20,000-seat American Airlines Arena in Miami for the Miami Heat, was hired by the Jets last summer. He met with city and state officials in September, when he showed them early drawings by Alex Cooper, the co-architect for the master plan for Battery Park City. Since then, Mr. Cross has hired additional architects who have expertise in sports stadiums and convention centers.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Intel Joins Industry Dirge as It Lowers Its Financial Projections

BYLINE: By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation, the world's largest semiconductor maker, cautioned investors today that its revenues this quarter would fall short of projections. The company became the latest addition to the growing list of companies that face troubles in the lethargic market for personal computers.
Blaming order cancellations by large customers and general slowdowns in the world economy, Intel said it expected revenue for the fourth quarter to be flat from the previous quarter, when revenue totaled $8.7 billion. The company had projected growth of 4 to 8 percent. 
 Holiday sales have historically propelled computer companies and chip makers to a strong fourth quarter, but this year Intel joined Gateway, Apple Computer and Hewlett-Packard in acknowledging sharp slowdowns in PC sales.
"The back part of the dog is acknowledging what the front part of the dog has been seeing for a long time," said Andrew J. Neff, a senior managing director with Bear, Stearns.
Intel fell $1.81, to $30.50, in extended trading before rising to $32.63. During regular trading, the shares had gained 56 cents. Intel shares have fallen 57 percent since August.
Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., had warned of weakening demand in Europe as early as September. But in a conference call with analysts today, Intel executives said they saw slowed growth in all market sectors, across the world.
"Economies worldwide appear to be slowing more quickly than we had anticipated," said Sean M. Maloney, senior vice president and director of sales and marketing for Intel.
Analysts had been expecting earnings of 42 cents a share for the current quarter, which ends Dec. 31, up from 35 cents a share in the period a year earlier, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
As computer sales slow, the companies that make computers place fewer orders for the semiconductors that power them.
"The PC industry has moved from being a growth business to being a cyclical growth business, partially as a result of its size," Mr. Neff said. "It's much more responsive to economic forces than it was earlier in its life cycle."
Ashok Kumar, an analyst who covers the semiconductor industry for U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said Intel's revenue would grow only 2 percent from the period in 1999 if this quarter's revenue was flat compared with the third quarter.
"I was hoping for some silver linings, that they could pull off something in Europe," Mr. Kumar said. "Clearly that didn't happen."
Intel stuck with its projections of 63 percent for gross margins, largely because the company spent less than expected.
The company said expenses, excluding special charges, would remain flat at $2.3 billion, compared with a 6 to 8 percent increase previously projected.
The woes also hit Microsoft, which lost $19 billion in market share today after Rick G. Sherlund, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, lowered quarterly sales and earnings estimates, "given the preponderance of evidence of sluggish retail PC demand."
Microsoft stock fell $3.56, or 6 percent, to $53.13.
Acknowledging that consumer computer sales account for only 10 percent of Microsoft's revenues, Mr. Sherlund cut his revenue expectations by $125 million, to a range of $6.775 billion to $6.8 billion, an 11 percent increase over the period last year. Mr. Sherlund reduced earnings estimates 3 cents, to $1.88, which is slightly below what Microsoft forecast in its most recent guidance on Oct. 18.
Roger McNamee, a co-founder of Integral Capital Partners and Silver Lake Partners, private investment firms based in Menlo Park, Calif., wondered why the decline in PC growth had taken investors by such surprise.
"In some ways, the greater surprise is that it took so long for this deceleration to happen," he said.
Adding to the gloom today was a report by the International Data Corporation, a leading market research firm, which forecast domestic annual PC sales growth for 2000 of 12.2 percent, half of the 1999 total. International Data, of Framingham, Mass., also lowered its sales estimates for the current quarter, projecting 15.8 percent growth compared with estimates of 17.1 percent made three months ago.
Loren Loverde, director of the firm's sales tracking program, attributed the soft market to reduced desire by consumers to spend money because of a dropping stock market and rising oil prices. I.D.C. did see some hope overseas, he said, but the United States drives global sales, with 37.5 percent of the world market.
While it agreed on slowed growth in the domestic market and Europe, International Data saw bright spots where Intel did not. Intel said Asian markets had slowed below expected levels, despite brisk sales in Japan and China, but International Data forecast Asian growth of 33.4 percent in the fourth quarter. And though Intel cited slowdowns in notebook computer production in Taiwan, International Data said notebook sales in the United States, Western Europe and Asia all exceeded expectations. The firm expects growth in notebook sales of 32 percent in the quarter.
"We are concerned about the dip in the fourth quarter, but we think we have other areas of strength," Mr. Loverde said.
But Daniel Kunstler, an analyst with J. P. Morgan, said he would not be surprised to hear more computer makers express caution in the coming weeks.
"I think we're going to get a lot of bad news out of these stocks before Christmas," Mr. Kunstler said.

HEADLINE: Senators Back Major Overhaul Of Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Senate approved a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws today, passing legislation by an overwhelming margin that makes it harder for people to seek legal protection from payment of their debts. The vote was 70 to 28.
But the bill's prospects for becoming law are uncertain at best because Congress may not get the opportunity to override President Clinton's threatened veto before lawmakers adjourn for the year. Even so, it is unclear whether an override, which would require a two-thirds vote, would succeed. 
 The legislation, a compromise hammered out by House and Senate negotiators, was adopted by voice vote by the House on Oct. 12, and enjoys broad bipartisan support in that chamber, as well as from credit-card companies, banks and retailers.
An earlier version of the bill passed the House last year by a veto-proof margin of 313 to 108.
The bill imposes new income requirements on those in bankruptcy who wish to get a fresh start by making use of the debt-forgiveness provisions of the law.
The White House, civil rights groups and consumer advocates criticized the measure because it would allow anti-abortion protesters to avoid court judgments over illegal protests by seeking bankruptcy protection, and because it failed to end exemptions available in Florida and Texas that allow people with large homes to avoid forfeiting them when filing for bankruptcy.
Today's vote added a twist to the contentious year-end budget negotiations between President Clinton and the Republican-controlled House and Senate in this unusual lame-duck session.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican who sponsored the bill, called on the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, to keep the Senate in session long enough to allow the bill's supporters to mount an override vote. Mr. Lott's aides said it was too early to tell when the session would wrap up.
In a sign of the White House's resolve to avoid an override threat, Mr. Clinton and his chief economic adviser, Gene Sperling, called about 10 Senate Democrats today to lobby them to reverse their votes in favor of an earlier version of the bill, approved in February, 83 to 14.
Mr. Sperling, in a telephone interview after the vote, said the administration was "disappointed that the president's repeated efforts to find a more balanced bill were rejected."
But he expressed confidence that the administration could persuade enough Democrats who voted for the bill today to switch their positions in a veto override situation, and back Mr. Clinton.
Since 1990, the rate of personal bankruptcy filings has increased by almost 100 percent, Mr. Grassley said. After dropping last year, the number of filings is back up again this year. The nation's largest banks, credit-card companies and retailers support the legislation as a way to crack down on those who are taking advantage of bankruptcy laws to skip out on mountains of debt.
"This becomes a financial management tool for some," said Mr. Grassley, who added that the legislation amounted to the biggest change in bankruptcy laws since 1978.
The bill generally provides that anyone able to make $6,000 to $10,000 in payments over five years would not be able to file for protection under Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code, which enables them to have many kinds of debt forgiven.
"Businesses will no longer have to swallow nearly $40 billion in bankruptcy losses, losses that can wipe out revenues, economic growth and job creation," Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a statement.
But the measure offers an exception to people who earn less than the median income in their region. For instance, supporters of the bill say an American family of four with an annual income of less than $51,000 would be able to have some debts forgiven.
Women's groups and consumer advocates opposed the measure, saying it is too harsh and inflexible.
"This does not meet the standard of fairness," Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, said.
The measure, for example, would restrict, but not eliminate, exemptions that allow a person entering bankruptcy to shield an unlimited amount of money from creditors by investing it in an expensive house.
Under the bill passed today, the "homestead" exemption would be capped at $100,000 if the home was bought by the debtor in the two years before filing for bankruptcy. But home purchases before that would continue to be exempt from bankruptcy proceedings.
The lame-duck session revived the bankruptcy bill from the legislative graveyard, at least for now. But here is why the bill's prospects are so murky. Mr. Clinton has 10 days, not counting Sundays, to sign the bill once it reaches his desk. Republican aides said they would try to deliver the legislation to the White House either late tonight or Friday.
The president can kill the bill if it goes unsigned and Congress adjourns within that 10-day period. This is called a "pocket veto," and is politically preferable for Mr. Clinton and Senate Democrats who might switch their votes in an override.
But if Congress is still in session after 10 days, Mr. Clinton would have to veto the bill or else it would become law with or without his signature. Just getting to this veto threshold would be "a long shot," said Edward L. Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association. "Those who voted for the bill today are pretty well committed."
Mr. Yingling said supporters would mount a furious lobbying campaign to pressure Democratic backers to override Mr. Clinton's veto.
In today's vote, 53 Republicans and 17 Democrats voted in favor; 28 Democrats voted against. Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, voted present.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
How Senate Voted on Bankruptcies
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 7, (AP) -- Following is the 70-to-28 roll call by which the Senate voted today to approve legislation making it harder for people to erase credit card and other debts in court. On this vote, a "yes" vote was a vote to approve the bill and a "no" vote was a vote to reject it. Voting "yes" were 17 Democrats and 53 Republicans. Voting "no" were 28 Democrats and no Republicans. One Democrat and one Republican did not vote.

Bayh, Ind.; Biden, Del.; Bingaman, N.M.; Breaux, La.; Bryan, Nev.; Byrd, W.Va.; Cleland, Ga.; Conrad, N.D.; Dorgan, N.D.; Graham, Fla.; Hollings, S.C.; Johnson, S.D.; Kerrey, Neb.; Lincoln, Ark.; Miller, Ga.; Robb, Va.; Torricelli, N.J.
 
DEMOCRATS NO
Akaka, Hawaii; Baucus, Mont.; Boxer, Calif.; Daschle, S.D.; Dodd, Conn.; Durbin, Ill.; Edwards, N.C.; Feingold, Wis.; Feinstein, Calif.; Harkin, Iowa; Inouye, Hawaii; Kennedy, Mass.; Kerry, Mass.; Kohl, Wis.; Lautenberg, N.J.; Leahy, Vt.; Levin, Mich.; Lieberman, Conn.; Mikulski, Md.; Moynihan, N.Y.; Murray, Wash.; Reed, R.I.; Reid, Nev.; Rockefeller, W.Va.; Sarbanes, Md.; Schumer, N.Y.; Wellstone, Minn.; Wyden, Ore.
 
DEMOCRATS NOT VOTING

HEADLINE: Two Primary Figures Emerge in Bombing of the Cole

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER with JOHN F. BURNS 

 BODY:
Yemeni officials have told the Clinton administration that they have identified two key figures in the October bombing of the destroyer Cole, and intelligence officials say they believe that at least one of them is associated with the organization controlled by Osama bin Laden.
A senior Yemeni official said yesterday that the man who ran the Cole bombing was Muhammad Omar al-Harazi, a Yemeni-born Saudi. 
 American officials said yesterday that they believe that Mr. Harazi -- who is known to Washington as Abdul Ali-Nashiri or Abdul al-Nassir -- was connected with the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa, in which more than 200 people died.
One intelligence official identified Mr. Harazi as an explosives expert who works for al Qaeda, Mr. bin Laden's group accused of international terrorism.
From the onset of the Cole investigation, Yemeni and American investigators have said that a prime suspect as the mastermind of the bombing is Mr. bin Laden, a Saudi exile who is living in Afghanistan. But one Yemeni official cautioned that the links to Mr. bin Laden fell far short of establishing that he had played any direct role in the attack.
The official noted that thousands of militant young Arabs had trained and fought in Afghanistan, many under the direction of Mr. bin Laden.
"Just about everybody who went to Afghanistan is linked in some way to bin Laden," the official said. "But if you're asking, can we prove that bin Laden was responsible for the attack on the Cole, the answer is, no, we can't, at least not yet."
American and Yemeni officials identified another key figure in the plot as Jamal al-Badawi. Officials said he was in custody and was providing much of the information about the Cole bombing, in which 17 sailors died.
American officials said Yemeni officials have also reported telephone records showing contacts before the Cole bombing between suspects in the attack and members of al Qaeda.
American officials said that another suspect in custody told Yemeni officials that he was paid about $5,000 by an associate of Mr. bin Laden to help pay for the bombing of the Cole and to videotape the attack. American officials said that a further link to Mr. bin Laden had been established when Mr. Badawi told Yemeni investigators that he was trained in Afghan camps run by Mr. bin Laden and that he had fought with Mr. bin Laden's forces in Bosnia.
Mr. Badawi had previously been identified by Yemeni officials as having helped to procure the fiberglass skiff that was used to carry at least a third of a ton of high explosives in the attack on the Cole, which blew a 40-by-60-foot hole at the ship's waterline, causing what the Navy has estimated at $240 million in damage.
Much of the information about the links between Mr. bin Laden's organization and the Cole bombing was first reported last night by ABC News.
On Wednesday, Prime Minister Abdul Karim al-Iryani told The Associated Press that the ship bombing had reached far beyond Yemen, involving what he called "international terrorist elements."
Mr. Iryani identified these elements as so-called "Arab Afghans," Arabs who fought in the guerrilla war against Soviet forces in Afghanistan in the 1980's and subsequently spread out across much of the world in a loosely linked terrorist network.
The latest disclosures come as the Clinton administration is mounting a campaign to broaden and toughen economic and political sanctions against the Taliban government of Afghanistan, where Mr. bin Laden has been living since 1996.
The United States and Russia asked the United Nations Security Council yesterday to approve new measures that would cut the country off from most contact with the rest of the world, except for relief workers.
The Taliban spokesman in New York reiterated the ruling group's position that Mr. bin Laden was a "guest and the upholder of the Afghan holy war." Afghanistan, he said, would not be pressured into expelling him.
The Clinton administration has been careful not to assign blame for the bombing of the Cole to Mr. bin Laden or his organization, saying that the investigators have not found a smoking gun that directly links the bombing to either the Saudi millionaire or his militant Islamic network.
For their part, Yemeni officials were even more cautious about whether Mr. Harazi had present or past links with Mr. bin Laden.
Mr. Harazi, the man named as the main organizer of the attack from within Yemen, was born in the Harazi mountains, about 60 miles west of Sana, the Yemeni capital. Like many thousands of people in this poverty-stricken country, including Mr. bin Laden, the Harazi family migrated to Saudi Arabia, where Mr. Harazi gained his citizenship.
Officials in the Federal Bureau of Investigation say that Mr. Harazi has been identified as having inspired or directed several terrorist attacks on American targets over the past decade.
Mr. bin Laden has been indicted in one attack against Americans, the 1998 bombings of the embassies in East Africa. A federal trial of alleged conspirators in the embassy bombings is scheduled to begin in Manhattan in early January.
The telephone records and other links emerging between the suspects in the attack on the Cole and those associated with the East Africa bombings are likely to increase the administration's determination to take tougher action to close down the sanctuary that Afghanistan has provided to Mr. bin Laden and his group, and to other Muslim militants.
A former counterterrorism official in the Clinton administration said it was important not to assume the White House would endorse military action against Mr. bin Laden or the Taliban if direct evidence of firm links continues to mount.

HEADLINE: Budget Is Victory for Argentine President

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
President Fernando de la Rua won a badly needed victory today when the opposition-controlled Senate approved his budget and paved the way for a large rescue package backed by the International Monetary Fund.
The vote followed weeks of wrangling in Congress in which the government made several concessions, including dropping $600 million of $700 million in spending cuts it originally requested. 
 The 2001 budget does not offer a new direction for a government that has been largely unsuccessful in jump-starting an economy stuck in a two-year-old recession. It will continue to have a $6.5 billion deficit next year, assuming the economy grows 2.5 percent as officials project, precisely the same deficit as this year.
But the fact that the government persuaded the opposition in record time to go along with its budget calmed investors and economists who feared that President de la Rua might have been crippled by a bribery scandal that led to the resignation of his vice president and the revamping of his cabinet two months ago. A poll released today showed that the president has an approval rating of just 7 percent after a year on the job.
"It is a mediocre budget in economic terms because it does not cut in areas where you have mismanagement," said Martin Redrado, chief economist at Fundacion Capital, "but the I.M.F. will be happy because it shows the government has the capacity to deliver."
Opposition senators, many of whom are under siege because of allegations they took bribes to pass a new labor code earlier this year, apparently decided they could not risk killing the budget and taking the blame if a bailout by the I.M.F. fell through.
The government and the I.M.F. have been negotiating for weeks to put together a lending package designed to remove the specter of a possible default next year that has dried up international capital markets and pushed up interest rates.
News reports in the Argentine press have suggested that an I.M.F.-led loan package of $25 billion to $30 billion could be announced as early as this weekend. But American officials say that total includes previously committed loans, and the amount of new lending is likely to be a good deal less and spread out over many months. I.M.F. officials have told Argentine officials they want to see a credible budget and a phasing out of the state pension fund system.
The new budget obliges the government to reduce its deficits to zero by 2005, and limits future outlays to provincial governments known for corruption and inefficiency.
President de la Rua recently sent to Congress a pension reform bill that would increase the retirement age of female workers to 65 from 60, reduce minimum payments and oblige new state workers to enter the private pension system beginning next year. The plan faces tough sledding in Congress, although it may still be instituted by a presidential decree.
The Senate passed the budget by a vote of 39 to 4 in the predawn hours, and then added a few amendments this afternoon to save subsidies for tobacco farmers and energy subsidies for the frigid provinces in southern Patagonia. Those additions are likely to be approved by the lower house in coming days.
In recent days, as it became apparent that the budget would pass, the Argentine stock market recovered some of its recent losses and government officials have spoken with increasing optimism about the future.
"The Argentine economy is going to grow a lot faster than people expect," the economy minister, Jose Luis Machinea, told a bankers association as the Senate debated the budget. "An era of prosperity is coming for Argentines."
After economic performance fell by 3.2 percent in 1999, the economy this year is expected to grow by a mere one-half of 1 percent. Unemployment has crept up to nearly 16 percent.
The Argentine economy has suffered from several factors out of the country's control. International prices for its main agricultural products have been depressed for more than a year, while its manufacturing exports have lost markets since the Brazilian real was devalued in January 1999 and as the European euro has declined in value.
Critics have argued that Argentina needs to drop its policy of pegging the value of the peso to the dollar to boost exports. But government officials insist that they will continue the policy, rather than risk the kind of capital flight and bankruptcies that accompanied devaluations in the past.

HEADLINE: The Business of Baseball Is . . . Business

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Baseball's Unfair Economics" (editorial, Dec. 5): 
 You mention the opposition that the proposed increased revenue-sharing from high- to low-earning teams may bring from the players and the owners, but you omit the opposition that it may bring from fans.
Yankee fans are willing to pay high ticket prices and high concession-stand costs because they believe that they will have a quality product on the field every year. Fans in Minnesota may pay half the price for tickets and lower concession-stand costs, so they receive a lesser product on the field.
Is it fair to a Yankee fan to take his high hot-dog cost and build a better team in Minnesota for its fans? If baseball is to thrive as it has for the last few years, something must be done about this imbalance, but it is equally important to consider the fans.
 
GARY C. WILLIAMS
Hamilton, N.J., Dec. 5, 2000

HEADLINE: 2 Automakers Act on Weakening Sales

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 7

 BODY:
General Motors announced a big slowdown in factory production today while Chrysler asked its suppliers to cut their prices by 5 percent on Jan. 1, further signs that Detroit is struggling with an abrupt weakening of auto sales and ballooning inventories of unsold cars.
G.M. said that it would produce 14.5 percent fewer vehicles in the next three months than it did in the first quarter of this year. Ford announced last Friday that its output would be down 10 percent in the next three months. And while Chrysler has not yet disclosed its first-quarter production plans, it is also expected to make many fewer cars in January, February and March by eliminating overtime and by not operating some factories at all for a week or two at a time. 
 G.M. had a 104-day supply of unsold vehicles at dealerships and in transit at the end of November, the company's largest supply since the last recession, when G.M.'s inventory peaked at 106 days in January 1991, said Haig Stoddard, the manager of industry analysis at Ward's Automotive, an auto industry data service. Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G., had a 78-day inventory on Nov. 30 and Ford had an 80-day inventory, he said.
Automakers try to keep a 60-day supply in the field so that each dealership has an adequate selection of models in a variety of colors and with various options. Ward's, the industry's main source of inventory data, is still gathering data on how much inventory foreign automakers had on Nov. 30, Mr. Stoddard said.
Sharp declines in auto production are beginning to produce ripples across the Midwest and on Wall Street. G.M. and Ford are the world's two largest manufacturing companies by a wide margin, each accounting for slightly more than 1 percent of the nation's economic output, while Chrysler accounts for nearly another percentage point. The Chicago branch of the Federal Reserve estimated a few years ago that the auto industry directly or indirectly accounted for a quarter of the combined economic output of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana.
Delphi Automotive Systems, the world's largest maker of auto parts, announced last Friday that it was laying off 1,700 workers indefinitely because of reduced demand from assembly plants. The Visteon Corporation, an auto parts giant spun off last summer by Ford, warned on Tuesday that it would earn only 35 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Excluding one-time gains, the company's prediction was 70 percent lower than analysts were expecting, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of G.M., told Reuters at the end of a luncheon at Boston College today that the entire auto industry needed to produce fewer vehicles.
"What we're all going to have to do is ratchet back production capacity, and that's painful," Mr. Wagoner said. "Once you swallow that, then you hopefully reach a steady state and lower level of production across the board."
G.M. said it would build 1,301,000 vehicles in the first quarter, down from 1,521,000 in the quarter a year earlier. G.M. also reduced its forecast today for production in the current quarter by 5,000 vehicles, to 1,373,000.
This has been the best year ever for auto sales, and even November was a fairly strong month by historical standards. But automakers have achieved those sales with larger rebates and other incentives, and these discounts are now cutting so deeply into profits that manufacturers are deciding to reduce output instead.
Diane C. Swonk, the senior vice president and chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago, said that she still saw little cause for concern. "We're in an economy that's downshifting from 110 miles per hour to 60 miles per hour," she said. "As you downshift, manufacturing takes it on the chin."
Automakers seeking quick financial improvement have relied for decades on asking suppliers to cut their prices. Before being acquired two years ago by Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, the Chrysler Corporation had experimented with a partnership in which it tried to reduce costs in its assembly plants and at suppliers at the same time by sharing information, instead of demanding lower prices for auto parts. But that partnership appeared tattered today as Chrysler informed suppliers that if they wanted to win future contracts, they should cut prices by 5 percent on Jan. 1 and seek an additional reduction of 10 percent over the next two years.
"We are in a difficult business situation, and we know the only way to initiate change effectively is by working together," said Dieter Zetsche, a longtime Mercedes executive who became Chrysler's president last month. "The true test of a strong relationship is measured during times such as these."

HEADLINE: A Sense of Disbelief and Obligation to One's Family

BYLINE: By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
The number is almost unfathomable to Bukuru Benoit, a Food Emporium deliveryman who arrived in New York from Burundi nearly penniless six years ago. He is reluctant to broach the subject, to muse about how he would spend it, to even say, "$30,000."
It's not that he feels undeserving; he believes he is owed that much or more. It is, rather, a matter of disbelief, almost skepticism, about someday soon having a check for more money than he thought he would ever see all at once, for an amount it would take three years to earn by shuttling groceries around the Upper West Side. 
 Mr. Benoit, 34, is one of about 100 deliverymen to whom the Food Emporium supermarket chain has agreed to pay $3 million in back pay under a settlement announced yesterday. The deliverymen, most of them immigrants from West Africa, accused Food Emporium of wage violations because they worked long hours, six or seven days a week, for half the federally mandated minimum wage.
So they lived five, six or more to an apartment, eating home-cooked rice and beans and doing without all the amenities they thought they could earn in the "country of opportunity," as Mr. Benoit called the United States.
Despite word of the settlement, Mr. Benoit and his co-workers at the Food Emporium on Broadway and 68th Street were not gloating yesterday and had no plans to quit their jobs or quickly spend the money. Rather, there was just a muted sense of relief.
"My family does not have something to eat," Mr. Benoit explained. "For me to have things here means they would not have anything. This money would make me happy, but it will be sent first to my family."
Mr. Benoit left Burundi on a mission, he said, not only to make a better life for himself, but to earn enough money to ease the hardships endured by his mother and other family members. Tribal factions had ripped apart his homeland's economy, he said, leaving factories closed and many of his countrymen dead. Mr. Benoit said he felt obligated to help them before he helps himself.
Batchili Charles, 30, a native of Congo who lives in the Bronx, agreed that his share of the money would not go toward consumption for consumption's sake. "I don't think the money is going to reflect on my actual life," he said. "It will just give some relief."
So no shopping sprees? What about a more spacious apartment?
"The first priority for most of us is family," Mr. Charles said. "Many of us also want to go to school. The problem has been not having money to get training to get better jobs. To study computer science, that is my dream."
Marcel Mweze, 31, agreed. "I want to do any training that can help me to have any skill, any nice job in America," he said.
Mr. Benoit said that he and many of the others had accepted the working conditions because they did not have a choice.
"It was not enough money to live on, but I only had one friend in New York and I had to do something for myself," Mr. Benoit said, his words a soft-spoken mix of French and English. "We lived in one house, five or six people."
"The situation was very bad," he said. "But I believe I will be happy soon."

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 881 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Firebrand Considers the Post-Whitman Era

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
BUSTER SOARIES knows very well that the things he's been saying in his sermons and speeches sound raw. Going on about black street gangs and drug dealers and wife beaters is a risky thing for someone who is both a Baptist minister and, as New Jersey's secretary of state, the highest-ranking black person in the administration of Gov. Christie Whitman.
But the Rev. DeForest B. Soaries Jr., or Buster to everyone in the State House, is convinced that the time is overdue for an attack on the faults in the black community while simultaneously holding the white majority's feet to the fires of justice. So there he was at Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton recently, jolting about 600 black middle school boys with a dose of reality as he sees it: 
 "If being black means taking drugs and beating on your girlfriend, I don't want to be black," he roared as the boys watched, transfixed. "And if being white means paying your bills and using proper language and having a nice house, call me white!"
Back in his corner office in the State House, Mr. Soaries, 49, says he has been misunderstood and called a traitor for working for a white, Republican administration. But his habit of blunt speaking has not abated when it comes to minority concerns aboutthe racial-profiling scandal that is rocking the state. As state officials reluctantly disclosed recently that they had been aware of the practice in some form for years, Mr. Soaries stepped forward as the only member of the administration to condemn the state police and to demand change. Being a lightning rod is not a new experience to him, however.
When Mr. Soaries was 19, he was kidnapped and threatened with death by a gang of black drug dealers on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, where he was a sophomore. The level of drug use among African-Americans dismayed him, and he and his growing network of friends and contacts had been putting pressure on the police and the university to crack down. The experience left him with one big thought.
"I think it cured me of ever falling into the trap that all blacks are good and all whites are bad," he said. "It was an inoculation, and it cured me from seeing the world in all racial terms."
Mr. Soaries ended his speech at Shiloh on another point, that racism is as real as the police officer who stops minority drivers -- he himself has been pulled over -- because of race.
For all the economic progress New Jersey has enjoyed in the seven years Mrs. Whitman has been governor, he said, members of minorities "live in a state where if you look in your rear-view mirror and it's the police, you're nervous if you're black." That problem will be solved, he said, only when New Jersey elects its first minority governor. Someone who would protect the progress minorities have made, who is not afraid to criticize ills within the minority community. Someone like him.
I WANT a minority governor," Mr. Soaries said as he ended his speech at Shiloh Baptist. "I want a governor who looks like me!"
The quest for justice has carried Mr. Soaries from a childhood in segregated Montclair to the Urban League, to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Operation PUSH and then to a doctorate in divinity and his own pulpit at the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens, in Somerset. Along the way, he collected the names and contacts that help move public policy, and the policy he wants to move now is for a different kind of governor.
"My position is that I want a minority governor," he said at a news conference at the State House on Wednesday. "This state has a festering cancer of racism and sexism in a state agency that cannot be allowed to exist." Since none of the candidates he favored had offered to run, he would consider it himself.
Isn't making race the test for the next governor a kind of profiling in itself? Mr. Soaries, who recently switched from independent to Republican, was not biting. "Let's talk math, not race," he said. "If you sell hot dogs and you ignore one-third of your market, you're destined to fail."
What the state needs now, Mr. Soaries said, is a governor with better instincts on racial issues.
"My position is that it's going to take someone who has a high racial I.Q.," he said. "It's going to take someone whose background includes reaching people across racial lines, and it's going to take someone who lives in close proximity to people in the gap."
"The gap" is one of Mr. Soaries's favorite terms. He uses it to describe the space between the rich and the poor, the protected and the persecuted, the hopeful and the hopeless. The gap runs from Newark past his window in Trenton, on through Camden and into Vineland. Mr. Soaries patrols it every weekday from his State House office, every Sunday from his pulpit, and the rest of the time at home, where his wife, Donna, cares for their 11-year-old twins, Martin and Malcolm.
"The one show they like that creates a challenge to me is the W.W.F.," Mr. Soaries said, touching on the fake agony of Vince McMahon's World Wrestling Federation. "I've got to personally work on finding some redemptive value in the W.W.F., and I believe we may be able to develop a literacy program, based on W.W.F. images and personalities." A pause. "I'll have to call Vince McMahon about that."
